SUMMARY:
I grew up saying ‚ÄúAllahu Akbar‚Äù numerous times every day.
Allahu AkbarThe saying literally means God is the greatest.
It is required of all Muslims to say several times during prayer, which is demanded five times a day.
So when and why is the phrase Allahu Akbar used as a battle cry, when a terrorist is about to kill someone?
Here‚Äôs where the double standard hurts: When that man killed 58 people in Las Vegas, the word terrorist was not uttered by anyone.
TEXT:
I grew up saying ‚ÄúAllahu Akbar‚Äù numerous times every day.

And no, I wasn‚Äôt, and am not, a terrorist.

I wasn‚Äôt someone who blew buildings up, killed people or shot a missile from my rocket launcher. As far as the West is concerned, those are the events associated with the saying when something bad is about to happen. People of the West are terrified of the phrase.

I was a Muslim boy trying to pray as many times as he could amidst a life of love and peace, in a home that did not condone any terrorism. My father was a poet who read me love poetry instead of nursery rhymes. He uttered the phrase when he prayed. If love existed in the form of a man, it was my father.

‚ÄúLove everyone,‚Äù was the phrase he uttered almost daily. To him, there was not a problem he couldn‚Äôt solve with love.

Allahu Akbar

The saying literally means God is the greatest. It is required of all Muslims to say several times during prayer, which is demanded five times a day. On the average a Muslim ends up saying it hundreds of times. The words are also used as a celebration of life: When a baby is born, when a couple marry or when a veteran returns home safe.

The word Islam means surrender. You‚Äôre supposed to surrender to God and worship him. Love, mercy and compassion are uttered several hundred times a day by any Muslim when they say Besm Allah Alrahman Alraheem, In The Name Of God The Merciful The Compassionate. That saying is uttered before you do anything.

So when and why is the phrase Allahu Akbar used as a battle cry, when a terrorist is about to kill someone? The latest incident was the horrific act in New York when the terrorist shouted the phrase before the police shot him, and after he killed eight people and injured many more.

For the majority of Muslims, to shout God‚Äôs name as you killed the innocent is an abomination. Muslims no more want innocent people killed than anyone else. So why is the phrase used by terrorists?

For the same reason ISIS and Al-Qaida exist: The misinterpretation of Islam. When you use religion as the motive for you actions, you have the power to appeal to the masses. It‚Äôs a brain washing if you will. The terrorists who flew the planes into the World Trade Center on September 11th are no different than any suicide bomber in Israel/Palestine, are no different that the one who mowed down bicyclists in New York. They are people who misunderstood and misused the religion. They are sick and twisted and evil.

The phrase is to remind Muslims that God is supreme. That‚Äôs it. It was never to be used as a battle cry during horrendous actions furthering political agendas with evil motives.

My heart sank when I heard the terrorist shouted the saying after the attack. I will never understand the link between Islam and Terrorism. The Islam I grew up amidst condemns such actions. It preaches love and peace and tranquility and feeding the hungry and clothing the poor and sheltering the homeless. One of the five main requirements of Islam in addition to prayer and fasting is to give a percentage of your money to the poor.

Is There A Difference?

To me, there is no difference between the terrorists who shout Allahu Akbar when committing a crime and those white nationalists and racists who shouted ‚ÄúJews will not replace us‚Äù in Charlottesville ‚Äï Virginia recently.

Here‚Äôs where the double standard hurts: When that man killed 58 people in Las Vegas, the word terrorist was not uttered by anyone. Why is it only attached to people who claim Islamic affiliation?

The Quran was brought down to Muhammad in the seventh century. The verses which preach war and fighting were contextual and apply to the time when he and his followers had no choice but to fight back, or die. It is no different than the Old Testament which contains many verses preaching war and killing.

In Deuteronomy Chapter 2, Verses 32-37, Moses is told to kill men, women, and children:

‚ÄúAnd the LORD said unto me, Behold, I have begun to give Siphon and his land before thee: begin to possess, that thou mayest inherit his land. Then Sihon came out against us, he and all his people, to fight at Jahaz. And the LORD our God delivered him before us; and we smote him, and his sons, and all his people. And we took all his cities at that time, and utterly destroyed the men, and the women, and the little ones , of every city, we left none to remain. From Aroer, which is by the brink of the river of Arnon, and from the city that is by the river, even unto Gilead, there was not one city too strong for us: the LORD our God delivered all unto us.‚Äù

How is this any different than what‚Äôs in the Quran? And why are Muslims judged by a different prism? Most of the Quran preaches love and harmony and helping those who have not. Take this for example:

‚ÄúAnd feed with food the needy wretch, the orphan and the prisoner, for love of Him (saying): We feed you, for the sake of Allah only. We wish for no reward nor thanks from you.‚Äù [76:8-9]

Any ancient religious book can be misunderstood and misrepresented. The Ku Klux Klan said the Jesus was the first Klansman. They burned crosses to spread their ill will. How is that any different?

My Sister

Karim Shamsi-Basha My sisters Mimi, right, and Rowaida.

My sister Rowaida lives in New York. We chatted last night when I wanted to make sure her head covering was not causing any problems. In the past when terrorists committed atrocities in the name of Islam, women with head coverings were profiled. She said everything was fine, and prayed for those people affected by the terror.

My sister prayed for them.

She is a teacher and her husband is an architect. All they want is food, water, and a roof over their heads, and for their children to thrive. They have four: a computer scientist, a doctor, a physical therapist, and a pharmacist. They love like anyone else, and they have compassion and mercy and empathy like anyone else.

The covering on her head says two things: Modesty and humility.

A Wish Or Two

I have one wish, well maybe two.

The first is for my children to thrive and go through life without any judgment based on their last name.

The second is for this world to know that Muslims mean no one any harm. The people who mean harm are as far from Islam as the KKK is far from Christianity.

My religion is love.
TITLE: I Say Allahu Akbar. I Am Not A Terrorist.

SUMMARY:
Rekindling (GB) ridden by Corey Brown wins the Emirates Melbourne Cup at Flemington Racecourse on November 07, 2017 in Flemington, Australia.
(Mike Keating/Racing Photos via Getty Images)Rekindling has won the 2017 Melbourne Cup at Flemington.
The winner was purchased as a yearling by prominent Melbourne businessman Lloyd Williams, who has now won his sixth Cup as an owner.
Brown rode 2009 Melbourne Cup winner Shocking, and has ridden around the world since then, before moving back home earlier this year.
This was a stirring Melbourne Cup.
TEXT:
Rekindling (GB) ridden by Corey Brown wins the Emirates Melbourne Cup at Flemington Racecourse on November 07, 2017 in Flemington, Australia. (Mike Keating/Racing Photos via Getty Images)

Rekindling has won the 2017 Melbourne Cup at Flemington.

Johannes Vermeer ran second and Max Dynamite ran third -- an incredible performance from the nine-year-old which ran second in 2015. Big Duke ran fourth, the first Australian horse to finish.

The winner was purchased as a yearling by prominent Melbourne businessman Lloyd Williams, who has now won his sixth Cup as an owner.

Rekindling, which started at 15-1, was ridden by Corey Brown, the Sydney-based rider originally from the tiny town of Wingham, on the NSW north coast. Brown rode 2009 Melbourne Cup winner Shocking, and has ridden around the world since then, before moving back home earlier this year.

Just got there. That's Rekindling in the pink cap.

"I've been back from overseas for about nine months, I can't believe it," Brown told Channel 7, flanked by his wife Kylie and brood of three teenage daughters.

"It's a dream even riding in the race but to come out and win it again... I'm lost for words."

....Aaaand that makes two Cups for Corey.

This was a stirring Melbourne Cup. As with 2016 when Heartbreak City and Almandin cleared out from the pack, two horses battled it out down that long, long Flemington straight.

Johannes Vermeer had been ridden beautifully -- so well in fact that jockey Ben Melham perhaps hit the lead a little earlier than planned. He kicked well clear. But could he hold on? Almost. Half a length was the difference and all credit to the winner.

Incredibly, the Irish-trained winner was the youngest horse in the race -- classed as a four year old in Australia because the horses' birthday falls on August 1, but technically still three.

His trainer Joseph O'Brien is also young, at just 24. His father Aidan O'Brien is one of the foremost trainers in the world, but young Joe has now done something his dad is yet to achieve.

"I really didn't expect to have to say a few words. All I can really do is thank Lloyd and Nick [Williams] who sent me the horse at the start of the year. I can't quite believe it yet."
TITLE: Melbourne Cup 2017: The Winner Is Rekindling

SUMMARY:
One of the two puppies allegedly killed by Vishesh Iyengar.
Worse, he boasted about killing the first puppy, posting it on a WhatsApp group, reported The Times of India.
"1 down, 1 more to go, DoggyTales," Vishesh Iyengar reportedly posted in a WhatsApp group of some of his classmates at an engineering college in Vellore.
The second puppy had been recently rescued by another resident in the area and was their pet.
The resident who had rescued the second puppy reportedly claimed that Iyengar did not show any remorse, saying, "It's just a dog, I didn't kill a human."
TEXT:
One of the two puppies allegedly killed by Vishesh Iyengar.

ADVERTISEMENT

A man in Tamil Nadu was so overcome with anger that some puppies apparently peed in his clothes, that he flung them off a terrace, killing them on the spot. Worse, he boasted about killing the first puppy, posting it on a WhatsApp group, reported The Times of India.

"1 down, 1 more to go, DoggyTales," Vishesh Iyengar reportedly posted in a WhatsApp group of some of his classmates at an engineering college in Vellore. "Black dog down," he replied after a group member asked him if the dog was dead.

According to reports, Iyengar killed one black puppy and another light brown puppy soon afterwards. The second puppy had been recently rescued by another resident in the area and was their pet. It had apparently wandered into the apartment complex where Iyengar lives.

A police complaint has been registered at the Katpadi K1 station by animal rights activists. The resident who had rescued the second puppy reportedly claimed that Iyengar did not show any remorse, saying, "It's just a dog, I didn't kill a human."

Also On HuffPost:
TITLE: Engineering Student Kills 2 Puppies In Tamil Nadu, Posts News Proudly On WhatsApp Group

SUMMARY:
Die Studenten einer Universit√§t in Los Angeles waren wahrscheinlich erstmal erschrocken, als sie in den H√∂rsaal gingenVor ihnen lag ihr Dozent - in einem SargDie ganze Geschichte und die Aufnahmen dazu seht ihr auch im Video obenDozenten haben es oft nicht leicht.
Sie stecken M√ºhe und Arbeit in den Unterricht ihrer Studenten und letztlich wird ihnen oft nur mit schlechten Testergebnissen gedankt.
‚ÄúEure Testergebnisse waren zum Sterben schlecht‚ÄùNachdem eine Klausur schlecht ausgefallen ist, lie√ü er sich n√§mlich etwas ziemlich Erschreckendes f√ºr seine Studenten einfallen.
"Mein Ziel im Leben ist es, so dramatisch wie er zu sein"Hunderttausende Twitter-User waren begeistert von der Aktion des Dozenten und teilten und kommentierten den Post.
So wunderten sich einige, woher er den Sarg hatte und wie er ihn in den H√∂rsaal der Universit√§t gebracht hat.
TEXT:
Die Studenten einer Universit√§t in Los Angeles waren wahrscheinlich erstmal erschrocken, als sie in den H√∂rsaal gingen

Vor ihnen lag ihr Dozent - in einem Sarg

Die ganze Geschichte und die Aufnahmen dazu seht ihr auch im Video oben

Dozenten haben es oft nicht leicht. Sie stecken M√ºhe und Arbeit in den Unterricht ihrer Studenten und letztlich wird ihnen oft nur mit schlechten Testergebnissen gedankt. Es ist daher wohl nachvollziehbar, dass der ein oder andere Professor frustriert ist.

In Los Angeles brachte die Frustration einen Professor jetzt sogar wortw√∂rtlich dazu, sich in einen Sarg zu legen.

‚ÄúEure Testergebnisse waren zum Sterben schlecht‚Äù

Nachdem eine Klausur schlecht ausgefallen ist, lie√ü er sich n√§mlich etwas ziemlich Erschreckendes f√ºr seine Studenten einfallen. Er legte sich in einen Sarg, der im H√∂rsaal aufgestellt wurde. Seine Erkl√§rung: ‚ÄúEure Testergebnisse waren zum Sterben schlecht.‚Äù

Einer seiner Studenten, Mario, hielt den Streich des Lehrers auf einem Foto fest und teilte dieses auf Twitter.

"Mein Ziel im Leben ist es, so dramatisch wie er zu sein"

Hunderttausende Twitter-User waren begeistert von der Aktion des Dozenten und teilten und kommentierten den Post. Das Foto sorgte allerdings auch f√ºr viel Verwirrung. So wunderten sich einige, woher er den Sarg hatte und wie er ihn in den H√∂rsaal der Universit√§t gebracht hat.

‚ÄúSind S√§rge nicht ziemlich teuer? Oder kann man die heutzutage auch mieten? Ich habe so viele Fragen‚Äù, schrieb zum Beispiel ein Twitter-Nutzer. Andere applaudieren dem Professor und merken anerkennend an: ‚ÄúMein Ziel im Leben ist es, so dramatisch wie er zu sein.‚Äù

Auf die Anfrage der HuffPost, um welchen Kurs es sich handelte und wie schlecht die Ergebnisse genau waren, √§u√üerte sich der Student, der mit seinem Foto einen Viralhit landete, bisher noch nicht.

(lm)
TITLE: Als die Studenten morgens in den H√∂rsaal kommen, liegt dort ihr Dozent in einem Sarg

Doch Investigativ-Journalist Georg Mascolo, der das Rechercheteam von NDR, WDR und "S√ºddeutscher Zeitung" leitet, lehnt jegliche Zusammenarbeit mit staatlichen Beh√∂rden ab.
Die Dinge, die nicht in Ordnung seien, k√∂nne jeder relativ einfach erkennen.
‚ñ∫ "Wenn auf einer Kleinstinsel 1000 Flugzeuge registriert sind, dann wei√ü ich, dass das nicht in Ordnung ist."
Ein Teil des Problems innerhalb der EU sei, dass es nicht nur um Kleinststaaten in der Karibik oder im √Ñrmelkanal geht.
Damit spielt er auf Malta und die Niederlande an, die als Steueroasen in den Paradise Papers auftauchen.
TEXT:
Die Enth√ºllungen von vertraulichen Dokumenten aus Steueroasen schlagen erneut hohe Wellen

CDU-Politiker Meister forderte bei "Hart aber fair" Einblicke in das Material, um Steuerbetrug besser aufkl√§ren zu k√∂nnen

Doch Investigativ-Journalist Mascolo glaubt nicht, dass das helfen w√ºrde

Die Fronten bei "Hart aber fair" waren klar: Michael Meister, CDU-Politiker und Parlamentarischer Staatssekret√§r beim Bundesfinanzminister, fordert eine Ver√∂ffentlichung der Paradise Papers.

Doch Investigativ-Journalist Georg Mascolo, der das Rechercheteam von NDR, WDR und "S√ºddeutscher Zeitung" leitet, lehnt jegliche Zusammenarbeit mit staatlichen Beh√∂rden ab. Sein Team hat die Dokumente f√ºr deutsche Leser ausgewertet.

Besonders absurd findet Mascolo dabei ein Argument, das CDU-Politiker Meister mantraartig im ARD-Talk von Frank Plasberg wiederholt: Eine Offenlegung der Papiere w√ºrde den Finanzbeh√∂rden helfen, m√∂gliche neue Konstruktionen zur Steuerumgehung zu finden.

Die Probleme sind v√∂llig offensichtlich

"Man muss gar kein Steuerrechtsseminar hier abhalten", warf Mascolo in die Runde. Die Dinge, die nicht in Ordnung seien, k√∂nne jeder relativ einfach erkennen. Dann zerlegte der renommierte Journalist in drei S√§tzen die Argumentation Meisters und anderer Finanzpolitiker:

‚ñ∫ "Wenn ich vor einem Haus stehe, in dem es drei Stockwerke gibt und 700 Firmen registriert sind, dann wei√ü ich, dass dort irgendetwas nicht in Ordnung ist."

‚ñ∫ "Wenn auf einer Kleinstinsel 1000 Flugzeuge registriert sind, dann wei√ü ich, dass das nicht in Ordnung ist."

‚ñ∫ "Und wenn ein international gut verdienendes Unternehmen seine Steuerlast auf 13 bis 15 Prozent dr√ºckt, dann wei√ü ich, dass etwas nicht in Ordnung ist."

Mascolo erbost: "Wir diskutieren √ºber diese Dinge schon viel zu lange."

Ein Teil des Problems innerhalb der EU sei, dass es nicht nur um Kleinststaaten in der Karibik oder im √Ñrmelkanal geht. "Wir reden √ºber Mitgliedsstaaten in der Europ√§ischen Union." Damit spielt er auf Malta und die Niederlande an, die als Steueroasen in den Paradise Papers auftauchen.

Viele Pl√§ne - "Aber nichts geschieht"

Mascolo beklagte, dass es kurz nach √∂ffentlichkeitswirksamen Steuerleaks immer wieder Pl√§ne zum Stopfen der Schlupfl√∂cher gegeben habe - doch die seien meistens nach ein oder zwei Jahren versandet.

An CDU-Politiker Meister gerichtet erkl√§rte Mascolo: "Ich wette, die Finanzbeamten kennen l√§ngst alle Konstruktionen. (...) Denn da stecken nicht viele Geheimnisse drin."

Doch Mascolo sagt: "Aber nichts geschieht."

(ben)
TITLE: In 3 S√§tzen offenbart Investigativ-Journalist Mascolo das ganze Versagen der Politik beim Steuerbetrug

TEXT:
Teenagers who perform poorly at school are five times more likely to attempt suicide and to self harm as adults, a comprehensive new study of over 26,000 young people has found.

The Swedish researchers followed the teenagers for up to three decades, from the age of 16 through to 46 years.

Sixteen-year-olds who scored in the bottom quarter of their year at school were five times more likely to end up in hospital due to suicide attempts or self harm than top performing students.

It found that students who scored in the bottom quarter of their year at the age of 16 were five times more likely to end up in hospital due to suicide attempts or self harm than those who were in the top quarter.

Both men and women who struggled at school were equally affected.

Moreover, it was not only the transition from high school into adult life which saw a spike in suicide attempts -- poor performers were at an elevated risk right up to middle age.

"This is a highly elevated risk, and it is remarkable that it reaches far into adulthood," the study's lead author Dr Alma Sorberg Wallin of the Karolinska Institutet said.

But Dr Wallin also noted that the study didn't prove that it was the difficulties at school directly causing poor mental health, as students who struggle academically are also more likely to come from low socio-economic families and have other risk factors for poor mental health.

This is a highly elevated risk, and it is remarkable that it reaches far into adulthood."

"We would however need to know more to identify helpful interventions -- for example, is school failure in itself a risk factor, or is poor performance rather an indicator of vulnerability?"

Interestingly, the researchers found that how well the students did at school was a much better indicator of their risk of suicide than their IQ, suggesting it was not the students' intelligence per say which put them at risk.

Delaying entry to school (i.e. starting school at age 6 rather than age 5) also made no difference to the participants' mental health as adults.

Starting school later to school had no affect -- positive or negative -- on the participants' mental health as adults.

The University of Sydney's Associate Professor Alexandra Martiniuk said the findings agreed with previous, smaller studies done in the U.S, China and New Zealand.

A child health epidemiologist for vulnerable children, Martiniuk said it was possible that the flow-on effects from poor grades in high school -- inhibiting a person's ability to go on to further study and potentially resulting in a worse job and thus socio-economic position -- were what was behind the poor mental health.

"Alternatively, it could be that characteristics in childhood -- like impulsivity or behaviour challenges -- are associated with suicidality, and these characteristics are likely to lead to poor school grades," she theorised.

"Doing poorly in school typically pummels one's self-esteem and this could also increase risk of suicidality."

She said the findings were a reminder of the need for more school program to improve social and emotional abilities in children, which not only lower students' emotional distress but also improve their academic performance.

If you need help in a crisis, call Lifeline on 13 11 14. For further information about depression contact beyondblue on 1300224636 or talk to your GP, local health professional or someone you trust.
TITLE: Kids Who Struggle At School Are More Likely To Attempt Suicide As Adults

El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump , ha llegado este mi√©rcoles a China, la etapa m√°s delicada de su gira asi√°tica dedicada principalmente a forjar un frente com√∫n contra las ambiciones nucleares de la "cruel dictadura" de Corea del Norte.
Sin embargo, recientemente Trump ha elogiado al presidente chino Xi Jinping, cuya ayuda es esencial en su cruzada contra Corea del Norte.

La visita de Trump a Corea del Sur ha estado marcada por el clima de tensi√≥n que impera en la pen√≠nsula coreana, debido a la intensificaci√≥n del programa nuclear norcoreano.

TEXT:
El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump , ha llegado este mi√©rcoles a China, la etapa m√°s delicada de su gira asi√°tica dedicada principalmente a forjar un frente com√∫n contra las ambiciones nucleares de la "cruel dictadura" de Corea del Norte.

El avi√≥n de Trump ha aterrizado en el aeropuerto de Pek√≠n proveniente de Se√∫l para una visita de menos de 48 horas en China, pa√≠s al cual hab√≠a criticado violentamente antes de su elecci√≥n, hace justo un a√±o, acus√°ndolo de haber "robado" millones de empleos a Estados Unidos.

Sin embargo, recientemente Trump ha elogiado al presidente chino Xi Jinping, cuya ayuda es esencial en su cruzada contra Corea del Norte. "Espero con mucha impaciencia entrevistarme con el presidente Xi, que acaba de obtener una gran victoria pol√≠tica", ha dicho Trump en un tuit pocas horas antes de llegar a Pek√≠n.

Leaving South Korea now heading to China. Looking very much forward to meeting and being with President Xi! ‚Äî Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) 8 de noviembre de 2017

Trump se refer√≠a al nuevo mandato de cinco a√±os obtenido por Xi en el reciente congreso del Partido Comunista de China (PCCh) y por lo tanto al frente del pa√≠s m√°s poblado del mundo.

Trump, que ha descendido del avi√≥n en compa√±√≠a de su esposa Melania, visitar√° el mi√©rcoles, acompa√±ado por Xi la Ciudad Prohibida de Pek√≠n, el antiguo palacio de los emperadores chinos. Luego ambos mandatarios cenar√°n junto a sus esposas.

La parte pol√≠tica de la cumbre est√° prevista para el jueves.

Lo elogia para preparar el terreno y ponerle de buen humor porque tiene cosas desagradables para decirle

"Lo elogia para preparar el terreno y ponerle de buen humor porque tiene cosas desagradables para decirle", ha opinado el sin√≥logo Jean-Pierre Cabestan, de la Universidad Bautista de Hong Kong.

LAS TENSAS RELACIONES CON CHINA

China, que asegura 90% del comercio con Corea del Norte, est√° en una posici√≥n crucial para presionar al r√©gimen de Kim Jong-Un, que en septiembre pasado llev√≥ a cabo un nuevo ensayo nuclear.

El gobierno chino se comprometi√≥ a aplicar estrictamente las √∫ltimas sanciones de la ONU contra Corea del Norte, pero rechaza las amenazas de Donald Trump y aboga por un di√°logo con su vecino.

Antes de viajar a China, Trump lanz√≥ en Se√∫l una nueva advertencia al presidente norcoreano, a quien inst√≥ a abandonar su programa nuclear y a salir de su aislamiento a trav√©s de la diplomacia.

"No nos subestimen, no nos pongan a prueba", dijo Trump en un discurso pronunciado ante el parlamento de Se√∫l. "Todas las naciones responsables deben unir sus fuerzas para aislar al brutal r√©gimen de Corea del Norte", pidi√≥ Trump. "No se puede apoyar, no se puede suministrar, no se puede aceptar", dijo en referencia a China y a Rusia.

Aplaudido por los parlamentarios, Trump advirti√≥ que no dejar√° que "las ciudades estadounidenses sean amenazadas con la destrucci√≥n". "Lleg√≥ la hora de la fuerza", dijo el presidente estadounidense.

La visita de Trump a Corea del Sur ha estado marcada por el clima de tensi√≥n que impera en la pen√≠nsula coreana, debido a la intensificaci√≥n del programa nuclear norcoreano.

Pyongyang realiz√≥ en septiembre su sexto ensayo nuclear, el m√°s poderoso hasta la fecha, y prob√≥ varios misiles capaces de alcanzar el territorio estadounidense

En su discurso, Trump calific√≥ al r√©gimen de Pyongyang como una "cruel dictadura", pero ofreci√≥ al l√≠der norcoreano "un camino hacia un futuro mejor". "Las armas con las que ustedes se est√°n haciendo no les dar√°n m√°s seguridad", dijo Trump. "Est√°n poniendo a su r√©gimen ante un grave peligro", advirti√≥.

"Sin embargo, pese a todos los cr√≠menes cometidos contra Dios y el hombre", agreg√≥, "nosotros les vamos a ofrecer un camino hacia un futuro mejor".

En sus palabras, el presidente estadounidense tambi√©n destac√≥ su v√≠nculo con Corea del Sur.

Por la ma√±ana, Trump fue obligado a suspender un intento de visita sorpresa a la Zona Desmilitarizada que divide la pen√≠nsula de Corea debido al mal tiempo, lo que le dej√≥ "bastante frustrado", seg√∫n dijo la Casa Blanca.

La Casa Blanca hab√≠a informado antes del viaje que el mandatario no visitar√≠a la zona pero Trump dej√≥ su hotel en Se√∫l temprano por la ma√±ana y abord√≥ un helic√≥ptero en la base militar de Yongsan, pero fue obligado a dar marcha atr√°s.

Es habitual que los presidentes estadounidenses que visitan Corea del Sur se desplacen a esta zona. Los soldados de Se√∫l y los de Pyongyang se sit√∫an frente a frente a lo largo de la franja de seguridad marcada por bloques de hormig√≥n y casetas azules.

El presidente surcoreano, Moon Jae-In, hab√≠a volado con anterioridad, antes de que el tiempo empeorara, por lo que se qued√≥ esperando ante la frontera, una zona llena de alambradas, sembrada de minas y barreras antitanques, seg√∫n los medios.

El helic√≥ptero de Trump despeg√≥ de Yongsan pero tuvo que volver debido al mal tiempo. Esper√≥ durante casi una hora a que las condiciones mejoraran, pero el tiempo empeor√≥ y el viaje fue cancelado.

"La verdad es que est√° bastante frustrado", dijo Sanders.

Sanders dijo que estaba previsto que el presidente surcoreano, Moon Jae-In, se encontrara con Trump en la franja de seguridad, lo que seg√∫n Sanders, hubiera sido "un momento hist√≥rico", ya que nunca un presidente estadounidense ha visitado junto al jefe de Estado surcoreano la zona.
TITLE: Trump llega a China, la etapa m√°s delicada de su gira asi√°tica centrada en Corea del Norte

SUMMARY:
Your body processes calories from certain foods differently, depending on whether or not the food (and its ingredients) are nutrient-rich or nutrient-poor.
Kelly Hogan, a clinical nutrition and wellness manager at Mount Sinai‚Äôs Dubin Breast Cancer center, helped explain why certain foods, such as kale, are processed differently in our bodies than a food like sugary cereal.
She said it‚Äôs important to focus on the nutrient density of foods.
‚ÄúA [100-calorie bowl of] cereal that is high in sugar is not going to give you the same quality nutrients.
‚ÄúIn a diet with plenty of these whole foods, there is absolutely room for less nutrient dense but also delicious foods, like cake, for example.‚Äù
TEXT:
Not all calories are created equal.

Your body processes calories from certain foods differently, depending on whether or not the food (and its ingredients) are nutrient-rich or nutrient-poor. Kelly Hogan, a clinical nutrition and wellness manager at Mount Sinai‚Äôs Dubin Breast Cancer center, helped explain why certain foods, such as kale, are processed differently in our bodies than a food like sugary cereal. She said it‚Äôs important to focus on the nutrient density of foods.

‚ÄúA [100-calorie] bowl of kale with an egg is going to give you high quality protein, fiber and a big variety of vitamins and minerals like vitamins, A, C, K, folate, etc,‚Äù Hogan said. ‚ÄúA [100-calorie bowl of] cereal that is high in sugar is not going to give you the same quality nutrients. And what‚Äôs more, the fact that it is low in protein and fiber but high in sugar can set you up for a blood sugar spike and crash, bringing on more cravings for sweets or refined starches throughout the day.

She added, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs easy to overeat when eating these types of food because of these blood sugar fluctuations and the fact that they aren‚Äôt typically super filling.‚Äù

Getty

You can tell you‚Äôre having a blood sugar crash if you start to experience irritability, dizziness, weakness or an intense feeling of hunger, Hogan said.

‚ÄúThis is where the term ‚Äòhangry‚Äô comes from as well ‚Äï when our blood sugar is low and we need to eat something, we often have difficulty concentrating, focusing and are more likely to snap at others,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúThe body will physiologically crave something sweet or starchy when blood sugar is low because these are the foods that can raise blood sugar quickly.‚Äù

To prevent these type of crashes, try eating foods that are nutrient rich, like fruits, veggies, lean proteins, legumes, nuts, seeds, beans and dairy (the Center for Disease Control has a helpful graphic that offers nutrient-dense information for certain ingredients). Hogan likes to call these ‚Äúwhole foods‚Äù and you might know some of them by another term ‚Äï ‚Äúcomplex carbohydrates.‚Äù

‚ÄúComplex carbohydrates are carbohydrates that take the body longer to break down into sugar because they have longer, more complex chemical structures compared to sugar,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey are a more sustainable energy source because of this and won‚Äôt raise blood sugar quite as quickly as more simple sugars.‚Äù

And no matter what, don‚Äôt assign foods labels like ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúbad.‚Äù

‚ÄúGiving food labels like that fuels a diet culture and harmful relationship with food,‚Äù Hogan said. ‚ÄúIn a diet with plenty of these whole foods, there is absolutely room for less nutrient dense but also delicious foods, like cake, for example.‚Äù
TITLE: How Your Body Knows The Difference Between 100 Calories Of Kale vs. Junk Food

SUMMARY:
The Duchess of Cambridge has revealed she is still getting used to not having Prince George at home now he has started primary school.
‚ÄúAs a mother just getting used to leaving my own child at the school gates, it is clear to me that It takes a whole community to help raise a child,‚Äù she said.
The Duchess was speaking at the Place2Be school leaders forum on Wednesday 8 November, as she kicked off a discussion on how schools can provide practical support to children, young people and their families.
‚ÄúWhether we are school leaders, teachers, support staff or parents ‚Äì we‚Äôre all in this together,‚Äù she continued.
‚ÄúWe are all working to give children the emotional strength they need to face their futures and thrive.‚Äù
TEXT:
The Duchess of Cambridge has revealed she is still getting used to not having Prince George at home now he has started primary school.

‚ÄúAs a mother just getting used to leaving my own child at the school gates, it is clear to me that It takes a whole community to help raise a child,‚Äù she said.

The Duchess was speaking at the Place2Be school leaders forum on Wednesday 8 November, as she kicked off a discussion on how schools can provide practical support to children, young people and their families.

‚ÄúWhether we are school leaders, teachers, support staff or parents ‚Äì we‚Äôre all in this together,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúWe are all working to give children the emotional strength they need to face their futures and thrive.‚Äù
TITLE: Duchess Of Cambridge Says She Is Still Getting Used To Leaving Prince George At The School Gates

SUMMARY:
El l√≠der de Podemos, Pablo Iglesias, ha compartido este martes en su perfil de Facebook el v√≠deo de un "currela canario" en el que √©ste reflexiona sobre los poderosos y las banderas.
A continuaci√≥n, se muestra harto de lo que llama "corriente patriota", por la que las banderas de Espa√±a cuelgan de las ventanas.
Cada vez me representan menos las banderas porque veo que las banderas desunen.
Las banderas marcan territorios, crean fronteras, causan guerras y son las culpables de un mont√≥n de cosas", advierte.
Se debe sentir como que tiene una gran maqueta de juguete en la que todos estamos peleando.
TEXT:
El l√≠der de Podemos, Pablo Iglesias, ha compartido este martes en su perfil de Facebook el v√≠deo de un "currela canario" en el que √©ste reflexiona sobre los poderosos y las banderas.

"Un currela canario nos recuerda una verdad como un templo. Antes se dec√≠a ni guerra entre pueblos ni paz entre clases. √âl hoy lo explica mejor", asegura Pablo Iglesias.

El hombre comienza diciendo que tiene "cara de culo" porque no ha dormido haciendo c√°lculos y enumerando sus gastos. "Imag√≠nense lo que me queda para vivir el resto del mes. Y aun as√≠ dicen que tengo que estar agradecido", lamenta.

A continuaci√≥n, se muestra harto de lo que llama "corriente patriota", por la que las banderas de Espa√±a cuelgan de las ventanas. "En un pa√≠s donde le silban a Piqu√© pero no le silban a Rajoy. Si le hubiesen silbado a Rajoy la mitad de lo que a Piqu√©, igual tu hijo no estaba trabajando en un McDonald's en Londres con dos carreras y un m√°ster", subraya.

Luego asegura que se siente canario, espa√±ol, canario y ciudadano del mundo. "No me representan las banderas. Cada vez me representan menos las banderas porque veo que las banderas desunen. Las banderas marcan territorios, crean fronteras, causan guerras y son las culpables de un mont√≥n de cosas", advierte.

Por √∫ltimo, explica que "lo peor que le puede pasar al rico, al hombre de la clase alta" es que "todos nos llev√°semos mejor". "A √©l le interesa que todos nosotros estemos pele√°ndonos. Se debe sentir como que tiene una gran maqueta de juguete en la que todos estamos peleando. Y mientras todos estemos peleando a √©l le sigue yendo bien", advierte.

"Vamos a luchar m√°s juntos, vamos a olvidarnos de tanta bandera, de tanta mariconada y vamos a unirnos un poquito m√°s y a lucharnos por lo que es nuestro. Y si salimos a la calle, que sea para estar unidos", concluye.
TITLE: Un "currela canario" triunfa con su reflexi√≥n sobre las banderas en las ventanas

SUMMARY:
Democrats targeted the 17 GOP-held districts where Democratic presidential rival Hillary Clinton defeated Trump.
Carter, a former Marine, failed to provide the state Democratic Party with daily updates about his campaign, prompting the party to deny him aid and go silent on his bid.
Virginia Democratic Del.
This is a tsunami,‚Äù said David Toscano, the Democratic leader in the Virginia House of Delegates.
But what Democrats hope is that the GOP loss in Virginia ‚Äï where Gillespie played up the nativist message popularized by Trump ‚Äï will make Republicans rethink their strategy.
TEXT:
FAIRFAX, Va. ‚Äï The Democratic Party romped to victories across the country Tuesday, gaining key state legislative seats, two governorships and full control of the state governments of New Jersey and Washington, where they‚Äôll have wide power to enact their agenda.

In one sense, the wins should have been expected: President Donald Trump is extremely unpopular, and the party that holds the White House usually does worse in congressional, state and local elections in years when the president isn‚Äôt on the ballot.

And the victories were expected in some cases. In New Jersey, Democrat Phil Murphy, a former Goldman Sachs banker, consistently led in the polls and will now be the next governor. But elsewhere, outcomes were more uncertain.

Many Democratic activists were worried that the party was going to let the Virginia governor‚Äôs mansion slip from its grasp. Concern that Lt. Gov. Ralph Northam was failing to excite the base, along with a fear-mongering anti-immigrant campaign run by Republican Ed Gillespie, led to concerns it would be a repeat of the 2016 presidential race.

Win McNamee via Getty Images Democrat Ralph Northam celebrates his victory over Ed Gillespie to be governor of Virginia.

Northam, however, sailed to victory Tuesday, guaranteeing Democrats a seat at the table when state legislative and congressional districts get redrawn in 2020. The party won the races for lieutenant governor and attorney general, too.

The night was validation for the many activists around the country who joined the resistance after Trump‚Äôs win and have been feverishly working at the grassroots to mobilize the party‚Äôs base. There‚Äôs no doubt that the victories will provide a jolt of energy for what‚Äôs coming in the 2018 midterm elections.

‚ÄúToday‚Äôs progressive victories in Virginia make one thing clear: A newly awakened grassroots movement is rising up to reject Trump‚Äôs politics of hate and reclaim political power,‚Äù said Maria Urbina, the political director of the progressive Indivisible movement, which has more than 180 active groups in Virginia.

Democrats also saw the wins as a rejection of the type of nationalism championed by Trump and his former aide, Breitbart News Executive Chairman Steve Bannon, who maintained that a win by Gillespie in Virginia would prove that ‚ÄúTrumpism without Trump can show the way forward.‚Äù

‚ÄúTonight, the message for Democrats and the country is that fear and division and hatred do not work,‚Äù Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe (D) said. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt work here in Virginia, and they‚Äôre not going to work in Virginia.‚Äù

Trump attempted to distance himself from the crushing GOP losses Tuesday night, tweeting from South Korea that Gillespie ‚Äúworked hard but did not embrace me or what I stand for.‚Äù

Almost no one expected Democrats to do as well as they did in the Virginia House of Delegates. Democrats targeted the 17 GOP-held districts where Democratic presidential rival Hillary Clinton defeated Trump. Winning all of the seats would swing control of the chamber, but few thought it was possible. Republicans have controlled the state‚Äôs house of delegates for nearly two decades and held a 66-34 majority.

The last time Democrats picked up more than one seat in the body was 2007, when they gained four. Last week, Virginia Democratic National Committeewoman Yasmine Taeb estimated that a pickup of six to eight seats would constitute a ‚Äúsuccess.‚Äù

But by 9:30 p.m., Democrats had already picked up 14 Republican-held seats in the House of Delegates, with eight more in play.

Northern Virginia, a Democratic stronghold, turned only bluer. Voters outside a polling location in Fairfax, which supported Clinton by a two-to-one margin in 2016, cited health care, education and Trump as top issues that drove them to the polls Tuesday.

‚ÄúIt seems like the other guy, Gillespie, he‚Äôs being supported by Trump, and [the president] tweeted about him,‚Äù Soleyman Ahmed, who voted for Northam, told HuffPost. ‚ÄúNortham seems like he‚Äôs a doctor, he‚Äôs served in the government, he‚Äôs got experience that could help.‚Äù

The electoral wave lifted the fortunes of even very left-wing candidates, including Democrat Lee Carter, a member of the Democratic Socialists of America and supporter of single-payer health care. He unseated GOP House Majority Whip Jackson Miller in Northern Virginia‚Äôs 50th District. Carter, a former Marine, failed to provide the state Democratic Party with daily updates about his campaign, prompting the party to deny him aid and go silent on his bid. The Washington, D.C., chapter of DSA stepped in to help with canvassing, and on Tuesday Carter won.

In Virginia‚Äôs 13th District, outside Fredericksburg, voters ousted Republican Del. Bob Marshall, the author of the state‚Äôs bill to ban transgender people from using the bathrooms of their choice, and replaced him with Danica Roem, a transgender woman who ran on a platform of fixing the area‚Äôs transit problems.

Virginia Democratic Del. Charniele Herring said Roem‚Äôs victory ‚Äúsends a message to politicians that the politics of bigotry is over. It‚Äôs not acceptable to voters.‚Äù

CHRIS KEANE / Reuters Chris Hurst, a former TV anchor, beat a Republican incumbent for the 12th District seat in Virginia's House of Delegates.

Chris Hurst, a former Roanoke news anchor whose girlfriend was fatally shot by a colleague on-air in 2015, beat an incumbent Republican in the state‚Äôs 12th District, which stretches from Blacksburg, the home of Virginia Tech, to the West Virginia border.

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt a wave. This is a tsunami,‚Äù said David Toscano, the Democratic leader in the Virginia House of Delegates.

This isn‚Äôt a wave. This is a tsunami. David Toscano, Democratic leader of the Virginia House of Delegates

The wins in New Jersey, Virginia and Washington, where Democrats won a key Washington state Senate seat ‚Äî and, with it, control of the only part of the state government they didn‚Äôt already run ‚Äî will have real policy consequences in the short term. Northam will be able to veto Republican legislation in Virginia, and Democratic pickups in the Virginia House of Delegates will give him much more leverage in the legislature. New Jersey, where Murphy ran on promises to legalize marijuana and introduce public banking will be under full Democratic control for the first time in nearly a decade. In Washington, Democratic Gov. Jay Inslee and the Democratic-controlled legislature will have much more freedom to enact their agenda.

The election results will affect lives in other states, too. In Maine, voters approved a ballot measure expanding Medicaid to tens of thousands of people over the objections of Paul LePage, the state‚Äôs Republican governor. In New York City, Bill de Blasio ‚Äî who achieved a longstanding liberal goal of creating a universal pre-kindergarten program ‚Äî became the first Democratic mayor to win reelection since Ed Koch in 1985.

The big question for Democrats now will be whether they can translate wins in this year‚Äôs elections to victories in next year‚Äôs congressional midterm elections. The Virginia electorate in 2017 is not the same territory as the battlegrounds Democrats will face next year ‚Äî for one thing, Trump is more unpopular in the state than he is in the nation as a whole. And, as FiveThirtyEight recently noted, Virginia‚Äôs off-year results ‚Äúhaven‚Äôt been so predictive‚Äù as a barometer of each party‚Äôs strength in the following midterm House races.

But what Democrats hope is that the GOP loss in Virginia ‚Äï where Gillespie played up the nativist message popularized by Trump ‚Äï will make Republicans rethink their strategy.

‚ÄúI think the appeal to the bad side of human instinct ‚Äï which Donald Trump did when he ran, and now Republicans are adopting ‚Äï does not serve America well, but won‚Äôt serve them well either,‚Äù Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) told HuffPost on Tuesday, before the results came in.

Next up: A Dec. 12 special election for a U.S. Senate race in deep-red Alabama, where Roy Moore, a controversial-but-Republican judge, is narrowly leading former U.S. attorney Doug Jones, a Democrat, in the polls.

But on Tuesday night, most Democrats were still focused on celebrating their victories, not preparing for the long slog ahead.

The Democrats are like ‚Äúthe field goal kicker who‚Äôs missed three kicks in a row,‚Äù said Jared Leopold, communications director for the Democratic Governors Association. ‚ÄúNow we‚Äôve made a few, and we‚Äôve got our groove back.‚Äù

‚ÄúWelcome to the bounce-back,‚Äù said Paul Kent, an elated union member who attended Northam‚Äôs victory party on Tuesday. ‚ÄúPeople have been waiting for a day like today since Nov. 9. This was the real bellwether. The narrative is we‚Äôre coming. There is no apathy.‚Äù

Ariel Edwards-Levy and Daniel Marans contributed reporting.
TITLE: Watch Out, Donald Trump. Here Come The Democrats.

SUMMARY:
Actor Tom Hanks has been in enough romantic comedies to know how to help during a real-life wedding proposal.
The Oscar-winning actor played A-list cupid in the engagement of Ryan McFarling and Nikki Young at the Texas Book Festival in Austin, Texas, on Saturday.
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs Ryan‚Äôs question, and it is for Nikki Young,‚Äù Hanks said in the clip below.
Then Hanks ushered them onto the stage where McFarling presented the ring ‚Äï and received a ‚Äúyes‚Äù from Young.
Young went on to call it the ‚Äúmost epic proposal ever‚Äù and said she was a ‚Äúsuper fangirl‚Äù of Hanks.
TEXT:
Actor Tom Hanks has been in enough romantic comedies to know how to help during a real-life wedding proposal.

The Oscar-winning actor played A-list cupid in the engagement of Ryan McFarling and Nikki Young at the Texas Book Festival in Austin, Texas, on Saturday.

Hanks was promoting his new book Uncommon Type: Some Stories during a Q&A event when he declared he was bored with the questions and wanted to ask one himself, KVUE of Austin reported.

‚ÄúHere‚Äôs Ryan‚Äôs question, and it is for Nikki Young,‚Äù Hanks said in the clip below. ‚ÄúNikki, will you marry me?‚Äù

McFarling took a knee in front of a pleasantly shocked Young, who was sitting in the front row. Then Hanks ushered them onto the stage where McFarling presented the ring ‚Äï and received a ‚Äúyes‚Äù from Young.

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt breathe, I almost fainted,‚Äù the bride-to-be said in a Facebook video posted by KVUE‚Äôs Molly Oak.

Young went on to call it the ‚Äúmost epic proposal ever‚Äù and said she was a ‚Äúsuper fangirl‚Äù of Hanks.
TITLE: Tom Hanks Is An A-List Cupid Helping A Guy Propose At Book Fest

TEXT:
Bei "Die H√∂hle der L√∂wen" haben sich alle f√ºnf Investoren zu einem Mega-Deal zusammengeschlossen

Dabei hatten sie zun√§chst abgelehnt, in das d√§nische Startup einzusteigen

Der junge Gr√ºnder Thomas stimmte die L√∂wen um

"Too Good to Go" hei√üt ihre App. Was sie bietet: Kosteng√ºnstiges Essen aus Restaurants, Superm√§rkten und Hotels ‚Äì und die M√∂glichkeit, Lebensmittelverschwendung zu bek√§mpfen. Es war der gr√∂√üte Deal, den die TV-Show "Die H√∂hle der L√∂wen‚Äú bislang gesehen hat.

Eine Millionen Euro bekamen die f√ºnf Gr√ºnder der App von den L√∂wen geboten. Dabei hatte es am Anfang schlecht ausgesehen f√ºr die"Too Good to Go"-Jungs.

‚ñ∫ Doch noch einmal von vorne: Die D√§nen Peter Wiedeking, Julian St√ºtzer, Thomas Bj√∂rn Momsen, Klaus Pedersen und Stian Olesen pr√§sentierten in der Vox-Show "Die H√∂hle der L√∂wen" ihre Smartphone-App, √ºber die Gastronomen Essen, das droht, in die Tonne zu wandern, g√ºnstiger an Kunden verkaufen k√∂nnen.

Die App zeigt den Usern an, wo sie die Gerichte zu einem reduzierten Preis bekommen und zu welchem Zeitpunkt sie diese abholen k√∂nnen. Dann k√∂nnen sie per Klick zuschlagen. "60- bis 70-Prozent reduziert", wie die Gr√ºnder erkl√§ren.

F√ºr f√ºnf Prozent ihres Unternehmens wollten die D√§nen 1 Million Euro. Auf rund 19 Millionen Euro bezifferten sie ihren Firmen-Wert. Den L√∂wen war das zu viel ‚Äì auch wenn alle von der Idee der App begeistert waren. "Eins Plus mit Sternchen‚Äú, schw√§rmte L√∂we Carsten Maschmeyer gar.

Das Unternehmen w√§chst, doch es braucht √úberzeugung

Trotz guten Wachstumsaussichten, die die Gr√ºnder vorrechneten, stiegen alle f√ºnf Investoren nacheinander aus.

Dann ergriff Gr√ºnder Thomas noch einmal das Wort ‚Äì und pl√∂tzlich kam alles anders. Der 24-J√§hrige appellierte an die Investoren, mit ihnen "etwas Cooles" auf die Beine zu stellen. Es gehe nicht nur um Geld. "Man kann Teil von etwas Gr√∂√üerem sein." Im Verbund: Alle f√ºnf L√∂wen sollten zusammen die Millionen locker machen.

Nach einer kurzen Beratung, f√ºr die sich alle zur√ºckzogen, kam der Deal dann tats√§chlich zustande. 200.000 Euro pro Kopf gegen 1,8 Prozent des Unternehmens f√ºr jeden, also etwas unter 10 Prozent der Anteile.

So einen Mega-Deal hatte es in der Vox-Show noch nie gegeben. Maschmeyer erkl√§rte zurecht feierlich: "Wir haben heute L√∂wen-Geschichte geschrieben."

Update: Nachdem die Kameras aus waren, soll der Deal doch wieder geplatzt sein. Der Grund: Die d√§nischen Unternehmer √ºberlegten es sich offenbar anders. Nicht nur traten mehrere der f√ºnf Gr√ºnder, die in der Fernsehshow zu sehen waren, pl√∂tzlich aus dem operativen Gesch√§ft zur√ºck, auch die Zusammenarbeit mit den Investoren wurde eingestellt.

(mf)
TITLE: "DHDL": Alle L√∂wen lehnen ihre App ab ‚Äì bis pl√∂tzlich Gr√ºnder Thomas das Wort ergreift

SUMMARY:
The joys of this breathtaking and passionate affair is best summed up at the annual Dharamsala International Film Festival, now in its 6th edition.
Free from the tempting vanities that the Mumbai Film Festival seductively pulls off, Dharamsala Film Festival, like the actor Adil Hussain said, is a great festival because 'there is no red carpet.'
In that context, Hotel Salvation is also a very political choice as opening film, even if it's incidental and not deliberate.
Adil Hussain at the 6th Dharamsala International Film Festival.
About the film, Barry said, "A film like Mukti Bhavan is so moving and one is at a loss for words.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

There's nothing quite like the winter romance of mountains and the movies.

The joys of this breathtaking and passionate affair is best summed up at the annual Dharamsala International Film Festival, now in its 6th edition.

Monks, both young and old, dressed in soothing red robes, people the vibrant town, strolling across its long-winding streets. Clad stylishly in what appear Ray Bans, red sneakers, and black backpacks, they make for quite a sight.

Tourists, both local and foreign, walk the streets with the restless enthusiasm only wanderlust can inspire. At the central square is where the cinephiles gather, exchanging notes about what to watch and what to skip, and where to find the most delicious Momos (it's at the Tibet Kitchen btw, a lovely restaurant just around the corner of the square).

Assembled under trying circumstances and functioning with modest resources, DIFF opened Thursday evening at the Tibetan Children's Village (TCV) near the Dal lake, about 10 minutes away from Dharamsala's main town, McLeod Ganj.

Free from the tempting vanities that the Mumbai Film Festival seductively pulls off, Dharamsala Film Festival, like the actor Adil Hussain said, is a great festival because 'there is no red carpet.'

Hussain, a naturally gifted actor, who sprung up on the scene with his layered performance in Gauri Shinde's much-celebrated English Vinglish, was present at the opening ceremony as his film, Mukti Bhavan (Hotel Salvation is its international title), opened the festival.

Hotel Salvation, which translates to 'deliverance from harm', is an uniquely inspiring choice of film for a festival set in Dharamsala, a place that's largely populated by Tibetans who escaped home due to a brutal Chinese oppression in search of a safe place. The festival founders, Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, are vocal critics of the Chinese occupation of Tibet and its systematic cleansing of Tibetan culture.

In that context, Hotel Salvation is also a very political choice as opening film, even if it's incidental and not deliberate.

The film has been often cited as the best film of the year. At least that was the case until Amit Masurkar's Newton came along.

Directed by debutant Shubhashish Bhutiani, who was only 23 when he pitched the idea to Hussain, Mukti Bhavan is a hauntingly beautiful portrait of life and death and of troubled parent-offspring relationships.

As Hussain's character, Rajiv, takes his father to the titular hotel, where the elderly come to peacefully transition into the realm of the unknown, the film very subtly nudges one into examining our own attitudes towards mortality, parents as well as how their upbringing influences the way we end up treating our children. Incidentally, this was also one of the underlying themes in Titli.

Adil Hussain at the 6th Dharamsala International Film Festival.

Hussain and Behl have a fractured father-son relationship and it's this very complexity that Bhutiani explores with nuance and subtlety.

On the deathbed, can you get yourself to despise your father, or even love him fully, for the decisions that dramatically altered the course of your life? Hate, bitterness, distance are all components of the larger sentiment of love which overpowers most feelings in Hotel Salvation's morbid yet deeply funny universe.

The film has a terrific ensemble, led by Hussain and supported ably by Lalit Behl (who played the quietly sinister patriarch in Kanu Behl's Titli), Palomi Ghosh, Geetanjali Kulkarni, and Navnidra Behl.

Hussain spoke about how he drew out this part from his personal experience of having had a troubled relationship with his father, who wanted him to become a professor of English and not an actor. It was only in the last two years of his late father's life did he come around to approving his career choice, after watching an interview of his on the BBC.

About his performance, Hussain said, "I have learnt to be responsive and not reactive. I tend to internalise and hold back my emotions. Whatever seeps out is the performance you see on-screen."

Incidentally, Hussain's acting mentor, the legendary Barry John, was in the audience. About the film, Barry said, "A film like Mukti Bhavan is so moving and one is at a loss for words. There are so many emotions one experiences that one doesn't know how to cope with it."

It couldn't have been summed up in a better way.

The festival will continue until the weekend, where Rima Das' MAMI-favorite, Village Rockstars, plays as the closing film.

Among other films to be screened at the 4-day long festival include India's Oscar-entry Newton, Konkona Sen Sharma's A Death in the Gunj, and Rahul Jain's, Machines.

Also see on HuffPost:
TITLE: Dharamsala Film Festival 2017: Finding Salvation In The Mountains

SUMMARY:
A soldier's moving tribute to his baby girl during the First World War has been turned into a powerful exhibit at the Canadian War Museum in Ottawa.
Flowers became a symbol of hope to Lt.-Col. George Stephen Cantlie, who served with the Royal Highlanders of Canada during the First World War.
While in France, the Canadian soldier picked flowers from the trenches and battlefields to send to his one-year-old daughter, Celia, and his family in Montreal.
Cantlie's daughter and granddaughter, Elspeth Angus, preserved the dried blossoms he sent, and now, a century later, 10 of the artifacts are on display in the Canadian War Museum's War Flowers exhibit.
In addition to being visually appealing, War Flowers also includes an olfactory component where certain smells are released at the push of a button to trigger memories.
TEXT:
A soldier's moving tribute to his baby girl during the First World War has been turned into a powerful exhibit at the Canadian War Museum in Ottawa.

Flowers became a symbol of hope to Lt.-Col. George Stephen Cantlie, who served with the Royal Highlanders of Canada during the First World War. While in France, the Canadian soldier picked flowers from the trenches and battlefields to send to his one-year-old daughter, Celia, and his family in Montreal.

A post shared by Canadian War Museum (@canwarmuseum) on Nov 3, 2017 at 6:03am PDT

In his handwritten letters home, Cantlie referred to his daughter as "wee Celia" and added, "Much love and lots of kisses from Daddy," CTV News reports.

Cantlie's daughter and granddaughter, Elspeth Angus, preserved the dried blossoms he sent, and now, a century later, 10 of the artifacts are on display in the Canadian War Museum's War Flowers exhibit.

Filmmaker Viveka Melki curated the moving multi-sensory display to highlight 10 personal wartime stories that give insight into human nature. Each of Cantlie's flowers represent one story, such as daisies, which are used to symbolize the lost innocence of Quebec armed force officer Jean Brillant, who died in battle, but was awarded the Victoria Cross for his contributions to the 1918 Battle of Amiens.

A post shared by Canadian War Museum (@canwarmuseum) on Nov 6, 2017 at 5:09pm PST

"The exhibit is not about battles and munitions, death or destruction, it's more about the people and the effect the war had on them and their personality," explained historian Alexander Reford, who helped Melki with the display.

According to Melki, "the goal of the exhibit was to make history intimate." As a result, she curated the display with all senses in mind to create an emotional experience for the viewer.

In addition to being visually appealing, War Flowers also includes an olfactory component where certain smells are released at the push of a button to trigger memories.

Poppies on the National War Memorial following Remembrance Day ceremonies in Ottawa on Nov. 11, 2016.

"War Flowers is an extraordinary example of art's power to enrich our understanding and experience of history in unexpected ways, while providing diverse perspectives on Canada's contribution to the war effort," said Canadian War Museum director, Stephen Quick, to Artsfile.

With Remembrance Day right around the corner, this exhibit is a powerful reminder of the contributions and sacrifices Canadians made in order to help bring the First World War to an end.

War Flowers is on display in Ottawa until Jan. 7, 2018, but is slated to move to Toronto, followed by France next spring and Montreal in July, CBC reports.

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: WWI Soldier‚Äôs Moving Tribute To Daughter Turns Into Powerful Canadian Exhibit

Los que siempre despreciaron, odiaron y ningunearon a los viejos comunistas, hoy les usan sin pudor para decir que no hay presos pol√≠ticos. Mi abuelo y mi padre estuvieron en las c√°rceles de Franco y aunque esto no sea el franquismo, en Espa√±a hoy hay presos pol√≠ticos

Las palabras de Iglesias, que en pocas horas tienen 3.200 retuits y cerca de 7.000 'me gusta', han generado miles de comentarios en un encendido debate:

No. No y no. En Espa√±a hay leyes. Y si no nos gustan, mecanismos para cambiarlas. Y hay carceles para quien no las cumple.

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTThe Collins Dictionary has said the "word of the year" is "fake news" though of course that's two words.
While Trump may have helped Fake News win the word-of-the-year mantle, India has been quite a fake news factory.
BJP leader Priti Gandhi posted Julian Assange's fake endorsement of Narendra Modi for Prime Minister which Wikileaks had to deny.
"Now they want us to bleed more by telling the state government to stop state advertisements as well," he said.
The government's idea to crack down on fake news sounds like good news.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The Collins Dictionary has said the "word of the year" is "fake news" though of course that's two words. It had seen an unprecedented usage increase of 365% since 2016. "Fake news today is legitimate news," it said.

Helen Newstead, the head of language content, said, "Fake news, either as a statement of fact or as an accusation, has been inescapable, contributing to the undermining of society's trust in news reporting."

While Trump may have helped Fake News win the word-of-the-year mantle, India has been quite a fake news factory.

Now, according to Asian Age, the government is contemplating cracking down on fake news.

And about time. Fake news in India is like air pollution in Delhi ‚Äì toxic, stubborn and growing stronger.

The government has said official advertisements should be denied to outlets that indulge in "unethical reporting", news published out of "bad intent" and "fake news".

The Directorate of Advertising & Visual Publicity will stop release of advertisements to such publications. Until now the print media policy already stated a newspaper could be suspended from empanelment if it was found to have deliberately submitted false information regarding circulation.

This is not symbolic. Government ads are a major source of revenue for media.

The devil, as always, lies in the details. What is fake news? And who defines it? Who defines bad intent? Clearly one person's fake news is another person's truth or at least their agenda.

Fake news in India is like air pollution in Delhi ‚Äì toxic, stubborn and growing stronger.

Take a few recent examples:

During the riots in Basirhat, an image of a burning vehicle was sent out as part of a call to #SaveBengal. It was shared by Nupur Sharma, BJP spokesperson from Delhi and used on a flyer for protests. The image, it turned out, was from the 2002 Gujarat riots under Narendra Modi's watch.

BJP IT cell head Amit Malviya has been caught more than once peddling fake news, tweets he has refused to take down even after they have been proved to be false. Once he circulated a mischievously edited video clip of NDTV anchor Ravish Kumar. Another time during the Ram Rahim trial he posted a picture of Rahul Gandhi meeting Sant Niranjan Dass of Dera Sach Khand Ballan but captioned it as "Rahul Gandhi visited Dera Sach Sauda as recently as Jan 2017 to seek support."

BJP leader Priti Gandhi posted Julian Assange's fake endorsement of Narendra Modi for Prime Minister which Wikileaks had to deny.

These could be honest mistakes. Who among us has not fallen for fake news, especially when it fits our ideological bias? But sometimes it's far more deliberate and it comes from within the government itself, not some mischief monger on social media.

The state-run Press Information Bureau infamously photoshopped a picture of Narendra Modi looking at flood-ravaged Chennai with divyadrishti clarity through his chopper window. And of course, that iconic "rare" picture of Modi sweeping the floor at a 1988 RSS rally turned out to be a well-morphed fake photo.

So when it comes to curing the epidemic of fake news, physician heal thyself.

Does this mean the BJP is the sole offender? Of course, not. But as Rohan Venkataramakrishnan points out in Scroll, the BJP was an "early pioneer when it came to using the internet for organizing and building political awareness" and it also "has been at the forefront of the fake news phenomenon, with top party leaders and ministers occasionally revealing the kinds of dishonest messages that are much more rampant among the base."

Even more worryingly, in a country where the phrase "anti-national"can be used casually as a bludgeon to silence any dissent that is too bothersome, these new DAVP guidelines could just be another weapon to bring media to heel. The Centre has already told the Jammu and Kashmir government to stop advertising in local newspapers that allegedly publish "anti-national"articles "glamorizing terrorists and anti-national elements". Shujaat Bukhari, editor of Rising Kashmir told HT that three major newspapers there, including his own, are banned from getting central government ads for eight years because they cover "anti-national" issues, for example, the funerals of militants. "Now they want us to bleed more by telling the state government to stop state advertisements as well," he said.

So when it comes to curing the epidemic of fake news, physician heal thyself.

Government ads have long been part of a strategy to make sure that media does not get too uppity. As other ad revenues shrink government ads gain even more clout.

In 2012, Dhirendra K. Jha dubbed Nitish Kumar Bihar's editor-in-chief because he used the government's ad budget to control and bend the media to his will. The editor of Bihartimes.com said though it has been "No. 1" since inception in 1999, its application for empanelment with the Public Relations Department was kept pending without any "concrete reason" while a site based in Bhopal with tenuous connections to Bihar got government ads. He said he believes it's because his site carries reports related to corruption in the state. An Urdu paper Pindar ran afoul of the government because of a piece by its chief editor that apparently upset the government. The editor, Raihan Ghani, said he was demoted to managing editor and eventually resigned. Curiously the year after Ghani was gagged, the paper's government ad revenues ballooned from 1 lakh to 24 and the year after to 40 lakh.

When the ABP group in Bengal was perceived at loggerheads with the Trinamool government, Mamata Banerjee had banned their newspapers from state libraries. Global campaign group Avaaz said that five West Bengal outdoor advertising agencies and one newspaper group refused to run ads urging Mamata Banerjee to "stop attacking protesters and start attacking the problem" after the gangrape of a young woman in Kamduni. Jayalalithaa's Tamil Nadu was boomtown for lawsuits against media perceived as being overly critical of the government. In five years it filed 213 defamation cases against political opponents, 55 of them against media houses for "derogatory " statements whether it was reporting on the CM's vacations or water scarcity in Tamil Nadu. Its predecessor DMK was a poor second with 40 cases between 2006 and 2011.

The government's idea to crack down on fake news sounds like good news. Who could argue with punishing the purveyors of fake news? But the fear is it will have little to do with promoting free and fair journalism and far more to do with the carrot-and-stick policy that makes media toe the line.

SUMMARY:
A former Welsh government minister, who was suspended by Labour over his ‚Äòpersonal conduct‚Äô, has been found dead, his family have announced.
Carl Sargeant quit his post as Cabinet Secretary for Communities and Children in Cardiff last week after what he called ‚Äúshocking and distressing‚Äù allegations were made against him.
His body was found at his home in Connah‚Äôs Quay, north Wales, at 11.30am on Tuesday.
His family said in a statement on Tuesday: ‚ÄúCarl was a much loved husband, father and friend.
We are devastated beyond words, and we know our grief will be shared by all those who knew and loved him.‚Äù
TEXT:
A former Welsh government minister, who was suspended by Labour over his ‚Äòpersonal conduct‚Äô, has been found dead, his family have announced.

Carl Sargeant quit his post as Cabinet Secretary for Communities and Children in Cardiff last week after what he called ‚Äúshocking and distressing‚Äù allegations were made against him.

His body was found at his home in Connah‚Äôs Quay, north Wales, at 11.30am on Tuesday. North Wales Police said they were ‚Äúnot treating his death as suspicious‚Äù. It is understood that Sargeant took his own life.

All Welsh Assembly business was suspended as a mark of respect.

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said his death was ‚Äúterrible and deeply shocking news‚Äù and Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones said his passing would be ‚Äúa great loss‚Äù to the party and the country.

Sargeant was suspended from the party last week and had the whip withdrawn in the National Assembly for Wales while an investigation took place into the allegations against him.

Labour‚Äôs national party HQ suspended him on Friday following unspecified allegations against him.

His family said in a statement on Tuesday: ‚ÄúCarl was a much loved husband, father and friend. He wasn‚Äôt simply a part of our family. He was the glue that bound us together. He was the heart of our family. We loved him so very much.

‚ÄúHe was the most kind and caring husband, father, son and friend. We are devastated beyond words, and we know our grief will be shared by all those who knew and loved him.‚Äù
TITLE: Former Welsh Government Minister Carl Sargeant, Who Faced Claims About 'Personal Conduct', Found Dead

TEXT:
No es hora de comer, de hecho a√∫n faltan m√°s de tres horas, pero lo √∫nico en lo que puedes pensar es en la pr√≥xima vez que te llevar√°s algo a la boca y lo que ser√°. ¬øPor qu√© te sucede eso?

La raz√≥n es sencilla. Resulta que nuestro cerebro y cuerpo est√°n conspirando constantemente para hacernos creer que es la hora de comer, cuando en realidad no lo es. Estas son las nueve razones por las que sufres el enga√±o del hambre atroz:

Anoche no dormiste lo suficiente

¬øTe ruge el est√≥mago los d√≠as en que la alarma suena muy temprano? Eso es porque tu cuerpo no ha descansado lo suficiente y le faltan horas de sue√±o. La falta de sue√±o se ha relacionado con mayores niveles de la conocida como hormona Ghrelin, que es la encargada de desencadenar la sensaci√≥n de tener hambre.

Para empeorar las cosas debes saber que cuando no se ha descansado lo suficiente al cuerpo se le antojan carbohidratos, alimentos cargados de calor√≠as que sirven de combustible mientras tu mente busca fuentes alternativas para recargar energ√≠a. Los investigadores creen que esto podr√≠a ser una pista de por qu√© la gente con falta de sue√±o corre un mayor riesgo de obesidad.

Ayer comiste demasiado

La ciencia no tiene una base s√≥lida para explicar este fen√≥meno, pero muchas veces cuando te acuestas con la sensaci√≥n de tener el est√≥mago lleno, te levantas con m√°s hambre que nunca. A diferencia de lo que cree la mayor√≠a, no es que el tama√±o de tu est√≥mago est√© aumentando, sino la comida que tomaste. Si ingeriste alimentos con alto contenido en almid√≥n podr√≠an haber modificado los niveles de az√∫car en la sangre, y por eso sientes que todav√≠a no est√°s lleno, seg√∫n explica la autora de Healthy Living's, Meredith Melnick.

Est√°s en el periodo premenstrual

No hay pruebas objetivas que den credibilidad a esta teor√≠a, pero muchas mujeres saben que est√°n en el periodo premenstrual porque tienen m√°s apetito que de costumbre. Durante la fase premenstrual, aumenta la segregaci√≥n de progesterona. Este incremento genera un mayor apetito y una sensaci√≥n de incomodidad con el cuerpo. Seg√∫n la publicaci√≥n Psychology Today, el resto de mam√≠feros siguen un patr√≥n similar de sobrealimentaci√≥n durante la premenstruaci√≥n.

Podr√≠as haber desayunado mejor

El desayuno es la comida m√°s importante del d√≠a y tambi√©n la m√°s f√°cil de saltarse, pero un mal desayuno puede arruinarte un d√≠a entero. Un estudio publicado este a√±o se√±ala que uno de los componentes m√°s importantes para un desayuno completo y equilibrado es la prote√≠na. Las personas que toman desayunos altos en prote√≠nas tienen menos antojos de ingerir a lo largo del d√≠a comidas grasas y alimentos azucarados. Una pieza de fruta es la opci√≥n m√°s f√°cil y r√°pida para ingerir algo sano tras cerrar la puerta de casa y salir con las prisas habituales hacia el trabajo. Pero una pieza de fruta no es suficiente, ya que necesitas al menos 300 o 400 calor√≠as para mantenerte satisfecho hasta el almuerzo, seg√∫n la dietista Keri Gans.

Tomas medicamentos

Hay muchos tipos de medicamentos que estimulan el apetito, desde los antihistam√≠nicos para las alergias hasta las pastillas para la artritis. En los √∫ltimos 20 a√±os, los medicamentos que provocan este efecto se han multiplicado por tres, seg√∫n el doctor George Blackburn, director asociado del departamento de nutrici√≥n de Harvard Medical School. En muchos casos, una vez culminada la toma de medicinas, el apetito vuelve a su estado habitual. Pero para aquellas personas que deben someterse a tratamientos de larga duraci√≥n o incluso cr√≥nicos, los expertos recomiendan consultar con los m√©dicos para encontrar el medicamento m√°s apropiado, ya que se puede prescribir uno similar que genere menos efectos de este tipo.

Tomas bebidas bajas en az√∫car

Al tomar una bebida dulce baja en calor√≠as, el cerebro recibe el mensaje de que las calor√≠as est√°n en camino. Sin embargo, las calor√≠as no llegan. El gusto dulce por s√≠ solo puede provocar que el cerebro mande se√±ales que conducen a sentir apetito para compensar esa p√©rdida. Todav√≠a se requieren m√°s investigaciones para entender este fen√≥meno. Mientras tanto, podr√≠a ser buena idea cortar o al menos reducir el consumo de bebidas edulcoradas artificialmente.

Est√°s sediento

Un poco de deshidrataci√≥n puede provocar sensaci√≥n de fatiga y, al igual que sucede con la falta de sue√±o, el cuerpo te pide que ingieras calor√≠as a modo de combustible. En ese proceso, crees que tienes hambre cuando en realidad lo que tienes es sed. Algunos expertos recomiendan a las personas que quieren perder peso tomar un vaso de agua antes de las comidas y esperar unos minutos hasta la ingesta de alimentos. Para distinguir entre el hambre real y la sed, la revista Men's Health sugiere pensar en un men√∫ abundante: si te apetece es que tienes hambre, si no es hora de que tomes un poco de H2O en su lugar.

Est√°s aburrido

Muchas de nuestras actividades diarias est√°n impulsadas por la dopamina, la hormona de la motivaci√≥n, la recompensa y el est√≠mulo. A nivel biol√≥gico, segregamos dopamina al comer, lo que es maravilloso. Por esa misma raz√≥n, cuando estamos aburridos el cerebro busca la manera f√°cil de generar dopamina y comer algo es su soluci√≥n. Hay otras alternativas: hazte con un buen libro, escucha una buena canci√≥n, medita o haz ejercicio.

Est√°s estresado

Hay una base biol√≥gica en el hecho de comer de manera impulsiva. Desde la perspectiva evolutiva, nuestra respuesta natural ante una situaci√≥n de estr√©s es evitar convertirnos 'en la cena' del adversario. Unos m√∫sculos fuertes proporcionan la habilidad de correr para huir de un le√≥n, un tigre o un oso. Pero despu√©s de la persecuci√≥n el cuerpo est√° agotado y necesita energ√≠a. Por eso el propio estr√©s activa partes del cerebro que aumentan el apetito, especialmente de alimentos grasos o azucarados. Puesto que hoy en d√≠a el estr√©s es algo muy habitual y las bestias salvajes ya no forman parte de nuestra vida, comerse un donuts para aliviar el estr√©s no es la mejor opci√≥n.
TITLE: 9 razones por las que tu mente te hace creer que tienes hambre

SUMMARY:
A Change.org petition posted four days ago is asking that ‚ÄúKevin Can Wait‚Äù star Kevin James take over the Underwood role originated by Spacey.
As of Monday afternoon, nearly 18,000 people signed the petition, making it more likely to reach its goal of 25,000.
Kevin Spacey is a rapist.
Both are named Kevin.
Seems like a smart business decision to me.‚Äù‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve ever seen Paul Blart mall cop, then you know that actors of Kevin James‚Äô caliber only come around once in a life time.‚Äù
TEXT:
Now that Netflix has officially cut ties with Kevin Spacey in the wake of the growing number of sexual abuse allegations against him, the streaming giant is reportedly considering other options for the upcoming season of ‚ÄúHouse Of Cards.‚Äù

Although it‚Äôs likely Spacey‚Äôs Frank Underwood character will be killed off early in the show‚Äôs final season ‚Äï something that happened in the British version ‚Äï some fans of the show are suggesting producers simply replace Spacey with another actor also named Kevin.

A Change.org petition posted four days ago is asking that ‚ÄúKevin Can Wait‚Äù star Kevin James take over the Underwood role originated by Spacey.

The petition, started by a man in the Netherlands named Robbie Pyma, makes the case for why the former ‚ÄúKing of Queens‚Äù star is a natural choice to play a ruthless character who works his way to the office of president of the United States.

Pyma states his reasoning in a short, but eloquent statement to Netflix founder Reed Hastings:

‚ÄúLosing a great show is hard, no matter the circumstances. However with hardship come[s] the opportunity for a great show to become one of the greatest television shows of all time. I think Kevin James can elevate ‚ÄòHouse of Cards‚Äô to a globally adored franchise like ‚ÄòGame of Thrones‚Äô and make the entire world focus on one of the most important Netf[l]ix Original series there is.‚Äù

Though James tends to stick to comedic roles, he has played politicians before, most notably the POTUS in the 2015 Adam Sandler comedy ‚ÄúPixels.‚Äù

So far, Pyma‚Äôs offbeat casting suggestion is winning lots of support. As of Monday afternoon, nearly 18,000 people signed the petition, making it more likely to reach its goal of 25,000.

Some of the sample comments include the following:

‚ÄúKevin James is a national treasure. Kevin Spacey is a rapist. Both are named Kevin. Seems like a smart business decision to me.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve ever seen Paul Blart mall cop, then you know that actors of Kevin James‚Äô caliber only come around once in a life time.‚Äù
TITLE: 'House Of Cards' Fans Petition For Kevin James To Replace Kevin Spacey
