TEXT:
AGRESSIONS SEXUELLES - L'actrice Jessica Chastain veut rompre la culture de l'omerta dans une industrie d'Hollywood "malsaine" et offrir une caisse de r√©sonance aux victimes d'agressions sexuelles, apr√®s l'avalanche des accusations visant notamment les producteurs Harvey Weinstein et Brett Ratner.

"Je ne suis pas √† l'aise avec le silence", affirme √† l'AFP celle qui tient le r√¥le-titre du premier film r√©alis√© par Aaron Sorkin, "Le grand jeu". "Si on est dans une industrie malsaine, on fait partie du probl√®me et notre inaction vaut complicit√©", ajoute-t-elle.

For years, many in power tried to divide & conquer women in order to dominate, control, & victimize them. The inexcusable behavior stops now https://t.co/AbMsdPU22E ‚Äî Jessica Chastain (@jes_chastain) 26 octobre 2017

"Pendant plusieurs ann√©es, beaucoup d'hommes au pouvoir ont tent√© de diviser et de conqu√©rir les femmes dans le but de les dominer, les contr√¥ler et les victimiser. Ce comportement inexcusable s'arr√™te maintenant."

"C'est important pour moi d'utiliser toute plateforme dont je b√©n√©ficie pour amplifier la voix de celles et ceux qui risquent tout pour sauver d'autres personnes", assure l'actrice √¢g√©e de 40 ans, √† propos des plus de 100 femmes qui ont d√©cid√© de d√©noncer le harc√®lement, les agressions sexuelles voire les viols commis par Harvey Weinstein ou d'autres titans du septi√®me art.

"J'ai beaucoup d'amies qui ont √©t√© utilis√©es √† mauvais escient, maltrait√©es", fait-elle valoir, lors d'un entretien en vue de la sortie du "Grand Jeu". L'un de ses derniers tweets sur les affaires qui secouent Hollywood a fait d'autant plus de bruit qu'il vise l'un des co-producteurs d'un de ses prochains films, "X-Men: Dark Phoenix", Bryan Singer.

"N'oublions pas", a-t-elle ainsi √©crit en retweetant un article sur des accusations d'agressions sexuelles sur mineur contre Bryan Singer, qui ont refait surface dans la foul√©e des autres affaires. Le r√©alisateur am√©ricain a √©t√© vis√© par plusieurs plaintes relatives √† ces accusations ces derni√®res ann√©es, toutes abandonn√©es ou d√©bout√©es.

Let us not forget https://t.co/0TNDxl8h1Q ‚Äî Jessica Chastain (@jes_chastain) 4 novembre 2017

Jessica Chastain a justifi√© le fait d'avoir jou√© dans "X-Men" en affirmant que Bryan Singer n'√©tait pas pr√©sent sur le tournage et qu'elle ne savait pas qu'il en √©tait co-producteur jusqu'√† r√©cemment.

"Comment on va changer les choses?"

"Je pense que les gens devraient pr√™ter attention (au fait de savoir) avec qui ils travaillent", ajoute-t-elle. La californienne r√©v√©l√©e dans "The Tree of Life" de Terrence Malick, raconte √™tre devenue f√©ministe en grandissant aupr√®s d'une m√®re c√©libataire.

"Je l'ai vue se battre pour que nous ayons toujours de quoi manger et j'ai vu les injustices autour d'elle", se souvient-elle. Elle a √©galement pris t√¥t conscience des discriminations envers les femmes, d√®s ses √©tudes √† la prestigieuse √©cole de spectacle new-yorkaise Julliard.

"Il y avait deux tiers d'hommes et un tiers de femmes dans les classes. J'ai demand√© √† un professeur: 'Pourquoi ce n'est pas 50/50?' et il m'a dit 'il y a plus de r√¥les pour hommes que pour femmes'. Et j'ai r√©pondu 'comment on va changer les choses si on ne change pas cette mentalit√©?'", raconte-t-elle.

Pour celle qui vient de tourner avec le Qu√©b√©cois Xavier Dolan ("The Death & Life of John F. Donovan"), ce n'est toutefois pas l'industrie du film qui est en cause, mais le syst√®me patriarcal dans son ensemble.

"Dans tout secteur o√π il y a un groupe d√©mographique en charge du gagne-pain d'autres, on voit des abus de pouvoir. En politique, √† Wall Street, dans les m√©dias, et √† Hollywood. On doit s'efforcer d'avoir plus de diversit√© aux postes de pouvoir", argumente-t-elle.

√Ä voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Face aux agressions sexuelles, Jessica Chastain d√©nonce l'"industrie malsaine" d'Hollywood

SUMMARY:
The magnitude of this latest Rohingya refugee crisis may be comparable to two other acute refugee crises this subcontinent saw in the past.
During the first refugee crisis, India was a newborn state, during the second one it was a young 'third world' developing democracy.
Fifty years elapsed since the second refugee crisis, when the major Rohingya refugee crisis developed.
In this changed scenario, it's essential to assess and evaluate India's performance in the Rohingya refugee crisis.
But, in taking the wrong side of the genocidal anti-democratic forces in Myanmar, India betrayed its own creed and fundamental constitutional philosophy.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The forced displacement of ethnic Rohingya people from the Rakhine state of Myanmar resulted in a massive refugee crisis in South Asia. The magnitude of this latest Rohingya refugee crisis may be comparable to two other acute refugee crises this subcontinent saw in the past.

First was the massive human relocation following the creation of India and Pakistan in 1947, and the next was the refugee exodus to India during the 1971 Bangladesh war. The exodus of Afghans into Pakistan is another massive but a more steady, long-standing process.

Among these, India was both a victim and the host during the first one and a gracious host during the second one. During the first refugee crisis, India was a newborn state, during the second one it was a young 'third world' developing democracy. Fifty years elapsed since the second refugee crisis, when the major Rohingya refugee crisis developed. And last 50 years have changed India.

India is the aspiring regional superpower now.

India is the aspiring regional superpower now. To the Western developed states, India is the face and gateway to South Asia. It seems the world elites and the Western democracies have outsourced the job stabilising the region to India. In this changed scenario, it's essential to assess and evaluate India's performance in the Rohingya refugee crisis.

While India's expected role was to play a neutral arbitrator and a stabilising force to contain the crisis, it clearly failed to do so. Although under pressure from the friendly government of Bangladesh, India has later tried to take a less one-sided stand, its continued position has been to take the Myanmar side in this conflict and undermine the ethnic cleansing and the massive humanitarian crisis that was fermenting in the Rakhine state of Myanmar.

It seems that India is competing with China to become Myanmar's favourite strategic partner.

By failing to take the anticipated role of a neutral mediator in this crisis, India failed itself, its people as well as many others who want to see India play the role of a 'grown-up' in this part of the world. India, in sharp contrast to its arch-rival Pakistan, rightfully projects itself as an exceedingly diverse society and tolerant democracy with basic human rights, religious freedom and freedom of speech protected by the Constitution. But, in taking the wrong side of the genocidal anti-democratic forces in Myanmar, India betrayed its own creed and fundamental constitutional philosophy.

India failed its values

India definitely sees Myanmar as a neighbour of high economic and strategic potential. It seems that India is competing with China to become Myanmar's favourite strategic partner. And this narrow economic interest may have forced India to shun its broader 'regional superpower' aspiration, at least in the case of Bangladesh and Myanmar. India has made a conscious decision to abandon its closer neighbour Bangladesh with a friendly government to court a distant neighbour Myanmar, which is more likely to pick China as its economic and strategic partner.

If Myanmar can get its way removing all Muslim Rohingya from Myanmar, people of Indian subcontinental origin belonging to other religion will be the next targets.

The present government of Bangladesh took an immense political risk and spent almost all its remaining political capital in giving in to every single demand India had. Bangladesh paid heed to India's security concerns and did all it could to ensure India's security. Now when Bangladesh is under a serious security threat caused by this influx of refugees, it naturally expected India to stand beside her. But now, to pursue its own narrow interests, the government led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi threw the government of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina under the bus.

Another problem with India's pro-Myanmar stand is that the populations those are being persecuted in Myanmar are people of subcontinental ethnic heritage. Basically, the Rohingyas are people of mostly Bangladeshi origin who have lived in the Arakan region of Myanmar for centuries. The main reason they are being persecuted, ethnically cleansed and killed is the fact that they don't look like their neighbours of 'Bamar' ethnicity, the main ethnic group that makes up Myanmar's population. They look like they are from the Indian subcontinent, and they have very distinct east Indian culture. The common slur the non-Rohingya Rakhines use to denote the Rohingya is the term 'Kala (black)', alluding to the darker skin colour of the Rohingyas.

Among the refugee camps in Bangladesh, there are Rohingya of Hindu denomination along with overwhelming majority Muslims. And there is a reason that reports of Hindu-Rohingya persecution are being staged and widely publicised by Myanmar authorities, for now, Myanmar Junta wants to project the issue as a Buddhist-Muslim communal issue. But if Myanmar can get its way, removing all Muslim Rohingya from Myanmar, people of Indian subcontinental origin belonging to other religions will be the next targets.

There is a colossal failure in understanding the fact that Rohingya crisis is a tragedy of unfathomable proportion.

Most of the Rohingyas are from the Muslim minority in the Rakhine state of Myanmar. One reason the Rohingyas are so helpless is the fact that they are Muslims.

A group of Muslims, mainly under the banner of terrorist organisations like Al-Qaeda and ISIS, have done despicable things over the last two decades. Their brutality on innocent people all over the world and the gruesome way they publicised these acts made it clear that they wanted to earn global hatred and fear. Beheading innocent captives on camera, photos of them burning people alive, photos of suicide/truck bombs got them what they wanted. The world hates them. The problem is they pulled the whole religion down too. Over 1 billion Muslims are now seen by the rest of the world, reasonably so, with suspicion, unease, and sometimes fear.

Hate always follows fear

India's PM and current policymakers are probably blinded by the fact that the Rohingya victims are Muslims, i.e. 'terrorists'. The Indian foreign policy establishment and PM Modi probably did not see the humanitarian side of the brutal ethnic cleansing, and the genocide-proportion persecution ‚Äî all they are seeing is an influx of 'potential terrorists'. There is a colossal failure in understanding the fact that the Rohingya crisis is a tragedy of unfathomable proportion. Failing to contain the events leading to this tragedy that has fallen on a marginal Muslim population, India risks creating a goldmine for future terrorist recruits in its backyard.

If political advisors of PM Modi hope that a successful expulsion of Bengali-speaking Rohingyas from Myanmar will be a prelude to do similar thing from the Indian states neighbouring Bangladesh, their political acumen must be short-sighted. Neither India nor Myanmar would benefit from a chaotic festering refugee crisis in a country located between them.

For PM Modi, it is a missed opportunity to claim his stature as the first 21st-century statesman of India. And for India, the continued plight of the Rohingyas is a testament against the claim that India is the regional superpower and stabilising factor in South Asia. While India approvingly watches over the unabated ethnic cleansing in Myanmar, it fails people of its own ethnic heritage too.

The opinions expressed in this post are the personal views of the author. They do not necessarily reflect the views of HuffPost India. Any omissions or errors are the author's and HuffPost India does not assume any liability or responsibility for them.
TITLE: In Failing To Protect The Rohingyas, India Has Failed Itself

SUMMARY:
House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) is defending his call for prayers after a gunman killed 26 people in a Texas church on Sunday.
Ryan and other politicians have been criticized for offering thoughts and prayers instead of legislative action to reduce gun violence.
People who do not have faith don't understand faith, I guess I'd have to say.
Frank Pomeroy, pastor of First Baptist Church of Sutherland Springs, lost his 14-year-old daughter and at least 25 other church members in Sunday's mass shooting.
Frank Pomeroy and Bishops United Against Gun Violence.
TEXT:
House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) is defending his call for prayers after a gunman killed 26 people in a Texas church on Sunday.

Ryan and other politicians have been criticized for offering thoughts and prayers instead of legislative action to reduce gun violence. But on Monday night, Ryan told Fox News host Laura Ingraham:

"It's disappointing, it's sad, and this is what you'll get from the far secular left. People who do not have faith don't understand faith, I guess I'd have to say. And it is the right thing to do is to pray in moments like this, because you know what? Prayer works. And I know you believe that, and I believe that and when you hear the secular left doing this thing, it's no wonder you have so much polarization and disunity in this country when people think like that."

Sending "thoughts and prayers" on social media has become a way for both religious and secular people to grieve after national tragedies.

For religious people in particular, prayer is an important form of worship and a way to ask God for guidance and intervention.

Especially after great personal sorrow, faith helps people to cling to hope. The Rev. Frank Pomeroy, pastor of First Baptist Church of Sutherland Springs, lost his 14-year-old daughter and at least 25 other church members in Sunday's mass shooting. He told reporters on Monday that he has decided to "lean into the Lord."

"I don't understand, but I know my God does," Pomeroy said.

But it is one thing for Pomeroy to lean into his faith after the shooting at his church, and something completely different for Ryan to offer prayers without action ‚Äï especially after reportedly receiving more than $170,000 in contributions from gun rights groups in 2016.

In a statement, Bishops United Against Gun Violence, a group representing more than 70 Episcopal bishops, said that Christians are called to pray after the tragic shooting in Texas, but that prayer should also be accompanied by deep introspection about "whether we are complicit in the evils we deplore."

"In the wake of the heartbreaking shooting at First Baptist Church in Sutherland Springs, Texas, we find ourselves both calling people to prayer, and wishing that the word did not come so readily to the lips of elected leaders who are quick to speak, but take no action on behalf of public safety," the bishops said. "Each of us has a role to play in our repentance. Elected representatives bear the responsibility of passing legislation that protects our citizenry. If our representatives are not up to this responsibility, we must replace them. In the meantime, however, we ask that in honor of our many murdered dead, elected leaders who behave as though successive episode of mass slaughter are simply the price our nation pays for freedom stop the reflexive and corrosive repetition of the phrase 'thoughts and prayers.'"

"One does not offer prayers in lieu of demonstrating political courage, but rather in preparation."

See Ryan and Ingraham's full discussion in the clip above.

This article has been updated with comments from Rev. Frank Pomeroy and Bishops United Against Gun Violence.
TITLE: Paul Ryan Defends His Call For Prayers After Texas Mass Shooting: 'Prayer Works'

Der Fall aus Darmstadt zeigt: Spricht ein Mann von einer Schlange in der Hose, muss das keine jugendfreie Umschreibung sein.
Als es um die Aufnahme des Sachverhalts ging, verlor wohl einer der Streith√§hne die Geduld.
19-J√§hriger: "Ich habe ein Schlange in der Hose"Bevor die Polizisten ihn mit auf das Revier nehmen konnten, durchsuchten sie den Mann.
Dabei fiel ihnen eine deutliche Ausbeulung der Hose des Betroffenen auf.
Der 19-J√§hrige zog tats√§chlich eine rund 35 Zentimeter lange (Baby-)K√∂nigspython aus der Hose.
TEXT:
Die Polizei nahm einen Betrunkenen in Gewahrsam | MattoMatteo via Getty Images

Die Polizei in Darmstadt hat einen Betrunkenen in Gewahrsam genommen

Bei der Durchsuchung des 19-J√§hrigen stie√üen die Beamten auf eine Ausbeulung der Hose

Darin befand sich eine Schlange

Wer etwas von einer Beule in der Hose eines Mannes h√∂rt, glaubt schnell zu wissen, um was es da geht. Der Fall aus Darmstadt zeigt: Spricht ein Mann von einer Schlange in der Hose, muss das keine jugendfreie Umschreibung sein.

Tats√§chlich war die Polizei aus einem anderen Grund am Dienstagabend in die Heidelberger Stra√üe in Darmstadt gekommen. Anrainer hatten sie alarmiert: Zwei M√§nnern stritten sich lautstark auf der Stra√üe.

Die Beamten konnten den Zoff dann aber schlichten. Als es um die Aufnahme des Sachverhalts ging, verlor wohl einer der Streith√§hne die Geduld. Laut der Polizist wurde er zusehends aggressiver, so dass der angetrunkene Mann in Gewahrsam genommen werden musste.

19-J√§hriger: "Ich habe ein Schlange in der Hose"

Bevor die Polizisten ihn mit auf das Revier nehmen konnten, durchsuchten sie den Mann. Dabei fiel ihnen eine deutliche Ausbeulung der Hose des Betroffenen auf.

Woher die k√§me? Der Mann antwortete: Er trage eine Schlage in seiner Hose mit sich. Und das war die Wahrheit. Der 19-J√§hrige zog tats√§chlich eine rund 35 Zentimeter lange (Baby-)K√∂nigspython aus der Hose.

War das ein Versto√ü gegen das Tierschutzgesetz?

Das Tier musste die Reise des Mannes in die Ausn√ºchterungszelle nicht mitmachen. Stattdessen legten die Beamten das Tier in eine Transportbox.

Nach dem Eigent√ºmer der Schlange wird aktuell gesucht, eventuell geh√∂rt das Tier einem Familienmitglied des 19-J√§hrigen. Weiterhin wird √ºberpr√ºft, ob durch den nicht artgerechten Transport des Tieres durch den betrunkenen Mann gegen das Tierschutzgesetz versto√üen wurde.

(jg)
TITLE: Darmstadt: Polizisten wollen 19-J√§hrigen mitnehmen, als sie die Beule in der Hose sehen

On Instagram, the instructor recently revealed she likes to take food out of her fridge using her feet.

In a short video, the handstand extraordinaire can be seen taking veggies off the shelves one by one, then taking them across the kitchen while upside down.

Her dogs are clearly fascinated and they‚Äôre not the only ones. The video has received more than 143,000 views, and it‚Äôs seriously dividing opinion.

TEXT:
POLITIQUE - Chose promise, chose due. L'Assembl√©e nationale a adopt√© dans la soir√©e du mardi 7 novembre en premi√®re lecture le projet de budget de la D√©fense pour 2018, en augmentation de 1,8 milliard par rapport √† l'ann√©e pr√©c√©dente, conform√©ment aux engagements du gouvernement.

Ce premier budget du quinquennat du pr√©sident Emmanuel Macron, dot√© de 32,4 milliards d'euros, "pr√©voit une hausse historique de 1,8 milliard d'euros", a d√©clar√© devant les d√©put√©s la ministre des Arm√©es Florence Parly. "C'est un effort in√©dit, le point de d√©part d'une remont√©e en puissance exceptionnelle, puisque chaque ann√©e ensuite, et ceci jusqu'en 2022, le budget du minist√®re des Arm√©es augmentera de 1,7 milliard par an".

Ce projet de budget, en hausse de 5,6% par rapport au budget 2017, accorde 1,2 milliard d'euros suppl√©mentaire aux cr√©dits d'√©quipements, a ajout√© la ministre. "C'est un budget de remont√©e en puissance qui r√©pond aux besoins des arm√©es et pr√©pare leur avenir, que je veux ambitieux, innovant, autonome et europ√©en aussi".

A la tribune de l'Assembl√©e, Florence Parly a r√©affirm√© le but de parvenir √† ce que la France, en 2025, consacre 2% de son Produit int√©rieur brut (PIB) √† la D√©fense. Ce chiffre sera de 1,82% en 2018, contre 1,7% un an plus t√¥t.

Pour les R√©publicains, le d√©put√© Charles de La Verpilli√®re, tout en reconnaissant que l'augmentation de 1,8 milliard √©tait "bienvenue", a d√©clar√© que "les d√©put√©s Les R√©publicains √©prouvent des doutes et des inqui√©tudes concernant en premier lieu l'ex√©cution du budget 2017, apr√®s l'annulation de 850 millions de cr√©dits inscrits √† ce budget. Etes-vous certaine, Madame la ministre, que cela ne va pas affecter les capacit√©s op√©rationnelles" des forces arm√©es ? "Cela r√©duit √† peu de choses, reconnaissez-le, l'augmentation r√©elle de ce budget 2018", a-t-il ajout√©.

Le d√©put√© LREM Jean-Charles Larsonneur, membre de la Commission de la D√©fense, a pr√©cis√© que "l'effort de r√©armement" repr√©sent√© par le projet de budget 2018 pr√©sentait "une forte hausse des cr√©dits d'√©quipements" qui permettrait notamment l'acquisition d'un satellite Musis, de deux avions de transport A 400M, huit h√©licopt√®res Ca√Øman, cinq h√©licopt√®res Tigre, trois Rafale et les trois premiers v√©hicules Griffon du programme de blind√©s Scorpion.

SUMMARY:
Comedian John Candy, who passed away in 1994, is one of the five most profitable Canadian actors since 1980, according to an analysis from Vervesearch.
All five of the most profitable Canadian actors are or were known for their comedies.
Fox movie, there was $2.62 in revenue at the domestic (U.S. and Canadians) box office.
That's enough to make Fox the number-five most profitable Canadian actor since 1980.
Here are the most profitable Canadians actors of the last three-and-a-half decades, and what their movies earned (in U.S. dollars).
TEXT:
Comedian John Candy, who passed away in 1994, is one of the five most profitable Canadian actors since 1980, according to an analysis from Vervesearch.

Canadians have long been proud of their contribution to Hollywood. The list of famous Canadian faces in Tinseltown is as long as it is familiar to those of us living north of the border.

U.K. research firm Verve Search decided to find out exactly which of these Canadians stars are actually the biggest, and they used box-office hauls to do the measuring.

What they found was a white male club, but a funny one. All five of the most profitable Canadian actors are or were known for their comedies.

Watch: "IT" becomes highest-grossing September movie of all time.

‚Äã

‚ÄãVervesearch used data from Box Office Mojo to calculate how much revenue each movie star's films made, on average, for every dollar invested into its budget.

For example, it determined that for every dollar invested in a Michael J. Fox movie, there was $2.62 in revenue at the domestic (U.S. and Canadians) box office.

Fox's biggest movie, not surprisingly, was "Back to the Future," which earned $10.08 for every dollar invested.

That's enough to make Fox the number-five most profitable Canadian actor since 1980.

Here are the most profitable Canadians actors of the last three-and-a-half decades, and what their movies earned (in U.S. dollars).

5. Michael J. Fox

Michael J. Fox at the Silicon Valley Comic Con in San Jose, Calif., March 19, 2016.

Earnings for every $1 of investment: $2.62

Top grossing movie: "Back to The Future" ($10.08)

Born in Edmonton and raised in Burnaby, Fox gained fame as Alex P. Keaton in the hit 1980s TV series "Family Ties." His status a teenage heart-throb was solidified with his leading role in "Back to the Future," which remains his highest-grossing movie. Fox is active in the search for a cure for for Parkinson's disease, from which he has been suffering since age 28.

4. John Candy

Earnings for every $1 of investment: $2.89

Top grossing movie: "Uncle Buck" ($4.45)

Born in Newmarket, Ont., Candy gained fame as a member of the Toronto branch of the Second City comedy troupe, eventually landing roles in such movies as "Splash," "Cool Runnings," "Planes, Trains and Automobiles" and "Uncle Buck." Candy died of a heart attack at age 43, in 1994.

3. Mike Myers

Mike Myers accepts his award for favorite movie for his film "Austin Powers 3" at the Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards in Santa Monica April 12, 2003.

Earnings for every $1 of investment: $2.95

Top grossing movie: "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me" ($5.24)

A native of Scarborough, Ont., Myers gained fame as Wayne in the "Wayne's World" skits on "Saturday Night Live" in the early 1990s. He then went on to headline a number of major movie franchises, including "Wayne's World," the "Austin Powers" movies and the "Shrek" movies, in which he voiced the title character.

2. Seth Rogen

Actor Seth Rogen from Hulu's 'Future Man' poses for a portrait during Comic-Con 2017 at Hard Rock Hotel San Diego, San Diego, Calif., July 22, 2017.

Earnings for every $1 of investment: $3.79

Top grossing movie: "Neighbors" ($7.34)

This Vancouver native first broke into the Hollywood scene with his role in the short-lived but critically acclaimed 2000 TV series "Freaks and Geeks." Since then, he has been a creative force behind such movies as "Superbad," "Pineapple Express" and "This is The End."

1. Leslie Nielsen

A picture of actor Leslie Nielsen is displayed during an homage during the 83rd Annual Academy Awards, Feb. 27, 2011 ,in Hollywood, Calif.

Earnings for every $1 of investment: $4.44

Top grossing movie: "Prom Night" ($11.23)

The native of Regina (and brother of prominent parliamentarian Erik Nielsen) was a dramatic Hollywood movie actor for decades before landing a role in 1980's "Airplane!" in which he famously told Robert Hays, "stop calling me Shirley." The movie launched Nielsen into a new comedic career that included the high-grossing "Naked Gun" franchise. Nielsen passed away in 2011.

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: Here Are Canada‚Äôs Most Profitable Actors Since 1980

SUMMARY:
Tons of breaking news and important things going on, so we're glad you're here to talk about Jennifer Garner's pet chicken she walks on a leash.
Garner posted the caption alongside the photo of her walking her pet chook, but that's not where the story ends.
A post shared by Jennifer Garner (@jennifer.garner) on Nov 6, 2017 at 4:34pm PST"Meet one of our ladies, Regina George," Garner continued.
Back in October Garner posed with THREE chickens and a tote bag that says "Chickens Y'all".
#TBT @hamiltonmusical A post shared by Jennifer Garner (@jennifer.garner) on Sep 14, 2017 at 10:45am PDTA true, magical gift to us all.
TEXT:
There sure is a lot of important news out there these days. Tons of breaking news and important things going on, so we're glad you're here to talk about Jennifer Garner's pet chicken she walks on a leash.

"That doesn't sound like important news to me," you might be saying, but you would be wrong.

"If there isn't a Chicken Lady Day," Garner wrote on her Instagram, "there really should be. Man, my life gets more exciting all the time".

Garner posted the caption alongside the photo of her walking her pet chook, but that's not where the story ends.

A post shared by Jennifer Garner (@jennifer.garner) on Nov 6, 2017 at 4:34pm PST

"Meet one of our ladies, Regina George," Garner continued. "Regina loves long walks, dehydrated bugs, and kale. Regina hates... carbs."

Garner finished up the EXCEPTIONAL caption with the following hashtags: #shesanicechickenbutaMeanGirl, #MeanGirlsthemovie, #ithinkshehasaburnbook, #cluckcluck.

This isn't even the first time Garner has posted on her Instagram about chickens in recent weeks. Back in October Garner posed with THREE chickens and a tote bag that says "Chickens Y'all".

A post shared by Jennifer Garner (@jennifer.garner) on Sep 30, 2017 at 11:24am PDT

We did some investigating and despite tagging Reese Witherspoon and her design brand Draper James and despite the store selling a variety of tote bags with messages like "Peace Y'all" and "Go Nuts Y'all" there is no sign of a "Chickens Y'all" tote.

Garner only joined Instagram in September, but since then she has been a force to be reckoned with, posting incredible content like the time she was recovering from dental surgery and was still high on anesthetic.

Throwback Thursday-- that time I had dental anesthesia...laughing gas + novocaine + Hamilton = you're welcome. #TBT @hamiltonmusical A post shared by Jennifer Garner (@jennifer.garner) on Sep 14, 2017 at 10:45am PDT

A true, magical gift to us all.
TITLE: Jennifer Garner Has A Pet Chicken Named After A 'Mean Girls' Character She Walks On A Leash

SUMMARY:
Labor Senator Sam Dastyari has been targeted by members of a far-right group and racially abused in a Melbourne pub.
Prior to an event promoting his book in Footscray, Dastyari was racially heckled by three or four men who filmed the four-minute confrontation.
"I don't get along [with] Sam Dastyari.
I don't get along w Sam Dastyari.
Thugs confront Labor senator @samdastyari in a pub and call him a 'monkey' and 'terrorist'.
TEXT:
Labor Senator Sam Dastyari has been targeted by members of a far-right group and racially abused in a Melbourne pub.

Prior to an event promoting his book in Footscray, Dastyari was racially heckled by three or four men who filmed the four-minute confrontation.

The camera-footage shows the men, who call themselves 'Patriot Blue' approaching Dastyari at the bar ordering drinks as one of them shouts "I've got some money from China, mate. Want some money?", before the abuse rapidly becomes more aggressive.

"You terrorist, you little monkey" is screamed at him as the men move in close around Dastyari, telling him to "go back to Iran".

Dastyari responds to the men's aggressive taunts with apparent calmness, smiling and telling them to "say hello to the United Patriots Front for me".

After collecting his drinks, Dastyari turns from the bar to walk back to the table he had been seated at, but is followed by the aggressive men, one of them appearing to poke the senator in the back while demanding why he won't answer their "questions".

Once seated, the white nationalists continue to film and jostle around behind Dastyari, before he again tells them, "mate, you're a bunch of racists, go away".

"What race is Islam?" the men respond, before Tim Watts moves into the camera-frame, looks directly into it and asks "what race is dickhead?"

After airing the video on his show, Paul Murray tweeted out an edited version of the video, condemning the behaviour of the abusive men.

"I don't get along [with] Sam Dastyari. But there is NO EXCUSE for the harassment he copped at a pub today," Murray said.

I don't get along w Sam Dastyari.



But there is NO EXCUSE for the harassment he copped at a pub today. pic.twitter.com/PozuZGFAeV ‚Äî Paul Murray LIVE (@pm_live) November 8, 2017

Others used social media to voice their disgust over the ugly behaviour.

What a disgrace. Thugs confront Labor senator @samdastyari in a pub and call him a 'monkey' and 'terrorist'. He handled an ugly scene very well https://t.co/P7mwLkkF8k #auspol ‚Äî Bevan Shields (@BevanShields) November 8, 2017

Kudos to @samdastyari and @TimWattsMP for staying cool and patient in the face of absolute dim-witted knuckle-dragging racism and bigotry in that "patriots" video. Sad that this still happens today in Australia ‚Äî Josh Butler (@JoshButler) November 8, 2017

Look at these tryhard numpties. @SamDastyari cool, but favourite bit is @TimWattsMP asking 'What race is dickhead?' https://t.co/v1ZuikeWRT ‚Äî ToryShepherd (@ToryShepherd) November 8, 2017

Dastyari posted his own video of the controntation to his Facebook page late on Wednesday night, showing his hecklers from a different angle.

"I don't normally like to post about these people - it gives them oxygen - but tonight I'm making an exception," he said in an accompanying comment.

Earlier in the evening, the backbencher addressed the incident on Twitter with a degree of humour, acknowledging Watts for the way he intervened.

Tonight will always be the night that we got harassed by cowardly white nationalists & @TimWattsMP yelled "what race is dickead" #strayamate ‚Äî Sam Dastyari (@samdastyari) November 8, 2017

Others were also keen to applaud Senator Watts for his well-timed one-liner.

What race is dickhead? is my new favourite thing @TimWattsMP ‚Äî Karen Barlow (@KJBar) November 8, 2017
TITLE: Right-Wing Hate Group Targets Sam Dastyari In Melbourne

Je pensais que Clinton allait gagner, que j'allais partir √† la retraite et que tout irait pour le mieux.
Et √ßa m'a confort√© dans l'id√©e qu'il s'agissait d'une administration qui se tournerait vers des conseillers politiques et des id√©ologues.
Son travail est apparu dans Time, Outside et Wired et figure dans la collection permanente de la biblioth√®que du Congr√®s.
TEXT:
J'ai d√©j√† rencontr√© des d√©tracteurs de Donald Trump, de nombreux d√©tracteurs, de ceux qui sautent sur chaque th√©orie du complot et qui refusent de lui accorder le moindre b√©n√©fice du doute. Un an apr√®s l'√©lection du nouveau pr√©sident, les quatre personnes avec qui j'ai r√©cemment pass√© la matin√©e √† la Solly's Tavern de Washington (sans alcool, ne vous inqui√©tez pas) n'√©taient pas des d√©tracteurs de Trump. Il s'agissait, en revanche, de d√©serteurs.

Chacun d'entre eux, √† un moment ou √† un autre au cours des neuf derniers mois, a quitt√© son poste au sein de l'administration actuelle, apr√®s avoir d√©cid√© qu'il pourrait mieux servir son pays √† l'ext√©rieur du gouvernement plut√¥t que de l'int√©rieur. Ils n'√©taient pas non plus ravis de partir. Ils √©taient fonctionnaires et souhaitaient le rester et, √† l'exception de l'un d'entre eux, avaient travaill√© sous des pr√©sidents des deux partis. Pendant leurs ann√©es pass√©es au service du public, il leur √©tait arriv√© d'√™tre en d√©saccord avec leurs sup√©rieurs, de craindre l'arriv√©e de nouvelles r√©glementations et de se m√©fier des nominations politiques, mais ils √©taient rest√©s parce que c'est la nature d'une carri√®re dans le gouvernement. C'√©tait diff√©rent.

Lorsqu'ils se sont retrouv√©s pour cette conversation il y a deux semaines, l'entente fut instantan√©e. L'ambiance √©tait conviviale et famili√®re comme celle d'une r√©union d'anciens √©l√®ves, outre le fait qu'ils √©taient encore de parfaits inconnus cinq minutes plus t√¥t. Ils √©taient originaires de diff√©rents secteurs de la bureaucratie, leurs √¢ges et leurs formations variaient consid√©rablement, mais ils s'√©taient pos√© les m√™mes questions depuis l'√©lection de Trump. Leurs coll√®gues de travail se sentiraient-ils trahis apr√®s leur d√©part ? Leurs rempla√ßants auraient-ils des opinions antith√©tiques aux leurs? Apr√®s avoir pass√© la majeure partie de leur vie dans les services administratifs, se sentaient-ils vraiment pr√™ts √† prendre publiquement position ? Une fois arriv√©s au c≈ìur de l'entretien, qui a √©t√© √©dit√© et r√©sum√© par souci de clart√©, ils se sont montr√©s sinc√®res, dr√¥les et enrag√©s. Ils ne travaillent peut-√™tre plus pour le gouvernement, mais ils se consid√®rent toujours comme des fonctionnaires.

Tr√®s bien. Sharon, vous √™tes partie la premi√®re. Commen√ßons avec le soir des √©lections. √Ä quoi pensiez-vous? Que ressentiez-vous?

Sharon McGowan (ancienne directrice adjointe de la branche des droits civiques du d√©partement de la Justice des √âtats-Unis): J'ai ressenti cette angoisse qui commen√ßait √† s'emparer de moi, de fa√ßon tr√®s physique. Alors le lendemain de l'√©lection, ma femme et moi avons d√©cid√© de rester √† la maison pour se regrouper en famille. En tant que couple homosexuel dans ce pays, nous connaissions exactement les enjeux. Et pendant les premiers jours, j'ai essay√© de garder un √©tat d'esprit positif: ¬´Peut-√™tre que Trump ne pensait pas vraiment ce qu'il a dit, peut-√™tre que c'√©tait seulement pour l'audimat.¬ª Et √ßa a plut√¥t bien fonctionn√©! Au moins jusqu'√† ce que Jeff Sessions ne soit annonc√© comme candidat pour le poste de procureur g√©n√©ral. C'est l√† que j'ai r√©alis√© que mes jours dans le gouvernement √©taient compt√©s.

Vous √©tiez certaine de devoir partir?

McGowan: Non, j'ai vraiment eu des moments de doute. Le jour de ma d√©mission par exemple, Sally Yates (procureure g√©n√©rale √† titre int√©rimaire, ndlr) s'est √©lev√©e et a d√©clar√© qu'elle ne d√©fendrait pas le ¬´Muslim ban¬ª et je me suis dit: ¬´Oh non, peut-√™tre que je me suis tromp√©e. Peut-√™tre que je devrais rester aÃÄ l'int√©rieur.¬ª Et puis bien s√ªr, on est tous revenus apr√®s la pause publicitaire pour d√©couvrir que Yates avait √©t√© vir√©e. Alors j'ai eu l'impression que c'√©tait un signe de l'univers pour me faire comprendre que je n'avais pas abandonn√© le navire trop t√¥t.

Sharon McGowan. Au sein du d√©partement de la Justice, elle a contribu√© √† faire avancer des politiques progressistes, telles que l'√©galit√© en mati√®re de mariage. Elle est d√©sormais directrice de la strat√©gie chez Lambda Legal.

Walt, vous √™tes rest√© jusqu'au mois de juillet. Parlez-moi du moment o√π vous avez r√©alis√© que votre monde avait radicalement chang√©.

Walter Shaub (ancien directeur de l'Office of Government Ethics, le bureau d'√©thique gouvernementale): Mon histoire est diff√©rente dans la mesure o√π je me suis r√©veill√© le lendemain matin de l'√©lection en √©tant assez optimiste quant au travail qui m'attendait avec l'√©quipe de transition. On avait pass√© environ cinq mois √† travailler avec eux avant l'√©lection, et c'√©tait des gens tr√®s s√©rieux qui s'y connaissaient vraiment.

Alors j'ai envoy√© un e-mail de f√©licitations enthousiaste d'un c√¥t√© et un e-mail de condol√©ances de l'autre, et j'ai re√ßu des r√©ponses de chaque √©quipe nous remerciant pour le travail de l'OGE. Les gens de l'√©quipe de Trump ont dit qu'ils √©taient impatients de continuer √† travailler avec nous et qu'ils t√©l√©phoneraient dans l'apr√®s-midi pour convenir d'un rendez-vous. La transition prend environ 73 jours, et vous disposez de cette p√©riode pour mettre en place tout un gouvernement. Vous devez savoir ce que vous faites, et vous devez utiliser chaque seconde judicieusement. C'est une t√¢che monumentale. Mais cet apr√®s-midi-l√†, tous ceux avec qui nous avions travaill√© avaient disparus et puis ce fut le silence radio.

Plus tard, on a lu des bulletins d'informations qui sugg√©raient que Don McGahn (un habitu√© de Washington qui exerce d√©sormais le r√¥le de conseiller juridique de la Maison-Blanche, ndlr) √©tait susceptible d'endosser le r√¥le de conseiller pour la transition, mais nous n'avons pas pu obtenir de rendez-vous avec lui avant longtemps. Alors si je peux √™tre l'Homme, n'importe qui peut l'√™tre.

Mais d√©sormais, c'est bien plus difficile pour moi de convaincre les gens que le service f√©d√©ral est l'endroit o√π ils pourront ressentir le m√™me sentiment d'√©panouissement que j'ai √©prouv√© lorsque j'y √©tais. Savoir que le pouvoir du gouvernement f√©d√©ral est utilis√© pour causer tellement de tort ‚Äì pour d√©chirer des familles, pour cautionner la discrimination ‚Äì √ßa me semble maladroit d'essayer de vendre le service f√©d√©ral √† un membre de l'une des communaut√©s qui sont victimes des abus. J'attends avec impatience le jour o√π tout cela appartiendra √† l'histoire ancienne.

Shaub: Et bien, j'ai toujours peur de cet effet dissuasif. Je veux saisir cette opportunit√© pour encourager les jeunes √† rejoindre la fonction publique. Et la fonction publique se pr√©sente sous de nombreuses formes. Il y a l'administration des √©tats et les autorit√©s locales, les associations √† but non lucratif et bien s√ªr, le gouvernement f√©d√©ral, que je recommande toujours fortement. Les jeunes qui arrivent vont se retrouver aux niveaux inf√©rieurs et seront isol√©s de la majorit√© des bouleversements. En m√™me temps, ils se retrouvent avec des responsabilit√©s importantes √† un tr√®s jeune √¢ge. Et ils peuvent faire une diff√©rence en essayant d'apporter des services de base √† la nation.

La fonction publique est vraiment gratifiante. J'ai encore des pr√™ts √©tudiants √† rembourser alors heureusement que c'est gratifiant.

CR√âDITS

ENTRETIEN - LYDIA POLGREEN

Lydia est la r√©dactrice en chef du HuffPost.

PHOTOGRAPHIE - STEPHEN VOSS

Stephen est un photographe bas√© √† Washington, D.C. Son travail est apparu dans Time, Outside et Wired et figure dans la collection permanente de la biblioth√®que du Congr√®s.

A voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Quatre d√©serteurs de l'administration Trump entrent dans un bar‚Ä¶

SUMMARY:
Yizo Yizo is probably one of the most controversial, and most loved drama series in South African TV history ‚Äì‚Äì and it's back on our screens.
Here are some of the actors who just got more famous since Yizo Yizo...1.
The character of Javas, played by Meshack Mavuso, was memorable for his use of the phrase "ugrand jo?"
Mokoena was one of the most successful actors to graduate from Yizo Yizo.
He later played another gangster, Ding-Dong, on the e.tv soapie Rhythm City, and starred in South African hit movie Jerusalema.
TEXT:
Yizo Yizo is probably one of the most controversial, and most loved drama series in South African TV history ‚Äì‚Äì and it's back on our screens. On Tuesday night, viewers got a nostalgia trip, and those who missed the episode had a severe case of FOMO...

If you were born in 2000 or your parents never allowed you to watch #YizoYizo now is your chance on Sabc Encore at 20:30 it's a lot Fam ..‚ô†Ô∏è ‚Äî King Of Lituation (@ExquisiteVince_) November 7, 2017

The show had an iconic cast at the time, and most of the actors are still thriving in local shows. Here are some of the actors who just got more famous since Yizo Yizo...

1. The character of Javas, played by Meshack Mavuso, was memorable for his use of the phrase "ugrand jo?" (are you okay?), which later became the signature adlib for The Bomb Productions. He went on to work in Isidingo, and now stars in Mzanzi Magic's Isithembiso.

So this is where the ugrand jo originated from #YizoYizo pic.twitter.com/NphH9Fntun ‚Äî Rudolph (@Rudolph_Bashin) November 7, 2017

2. Charmaine Mtinta won the Avanti Award for Best Actress in a Drama Series for playing Nomsa. She was Mavuso's love interest, and their first kissing scene was one of the epic moments of the series.

She later took on the role of Pearl, a gold-digging widow, in the SABC1 sitcom Gauteng Maboneng; later she starred in Mzansi Magic telenovela Inkaba. Mtinta has also been in the SABC soapies Generations and The Missing Link.

3. Thulas was played by Fana Mokoena, who has now stepped into the political arena ‚Äì‚Äì who would have guessed it? He's now a parlaimentarian for the Economic Freedom Fighters, and does not shy away from serious commentary.

Mokoena was one of the most successful actors to graduate from Yizo Yizo. We saw him in various soapies, including Generations and The Lab. He also starred in movies like World War Z and delivered a chilling portrayal of genocidal General Augustin Bizimungu in Hotel Rwanda.

It's so weird seeing some of these actors and actresses play school kids üòÇ o Fana Mokoena. #YizoYizo #SABCEncore ‚Äî thando 2/5/16 (@Mello_Muffin) November 7, 2017

4. Ronnie Nyakale's role as Papa Action was his first claim to fame. He later played another gangster, Ding-Dong, on the e.tv soapie Rhythm City, and starred in South African hit movie Jerusalema.

He is now part of the Generations: The Legacy cast, playing gangster-turned-businessman Cosmo.

5. Sophie Ndaba played Louisa Tlali ‚Äì‚Äì one of the laziest on-screen teachers of all time. In reality, Ndaba's hard work has led to her success as an actress and businesswoman. She made a big impact in her long-running role as Queen Moroka in Generations, and recently played the supporting role of nosy-yet-sophisticated Nkadimeng on Isidingo.

She also has a booming events business, which she has been running for close on 17 years.
TITLE: These Are Yizo Yizo's 5 Most Memorable Actors

SUMMARY:
Global demand for the horns fuels both crude poaching networks in southern African countries (the heartland of the black rhino) and larger organised crime networks.
Photojournalist Brent Stirton is documenting the cruelty and tragedy of the trade in rhino horn.
The outlook for black rhinos Black rhinos once ranged across sub-Saharan Africa, but now they only survive in five countries: South Africa, Namibia, Kenya, Zimbabwe and Tanzania.
Richard says, 'Although I do not qualify to criticise the traditional cultural use of animal parts, it is largely greed, irresponsibility and ignorance fueling the rhino horn trade.
International trade in rhino horn has been banned since 1977, and South Africa banned it domestically in 2009.
TEXT:
The outlook is bleak for black rhinos. They have been critically endangered since 1996, and the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) reports that the population has declined by an estimated 97.6% since 1960. The mammals are slaughtered in huge numbers for their horns, which are used in traditional medicine and for decoration, and can be worth more than their weight in gold in illegal international markets. Global demand for the horns fuels both crude poaching networks in southern African countries (the heartland of the black rhino) and larger organised crime networks. Photojournalist Brent Stirton is documenting the cruelty and tragedy of the trade in rhino horn. His image, Memorial to a species (pictured below), emerged as the grand title winner of this year's Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition, out of almost 50,000 competition entries from 92 countries.

The jury awarded Brent's shot the competition's most coveted title because it was the most memorable and striking image of all 16 categories. The judges also felt it had 'sculptural power' and strong use of light, encapsulating the breakdown of a vulnerable species in one single frame. Provoking debate The photograph also highlights the battle to survive facing many species all over the world.

Richard Sabin, the Museum's Principal Curator of Mammals, believes the image is crucial for encouraging dialogue and debate about international conservation issues. He says, 'The Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition isn't just about beautiful images and technical ability - it is also about provoking and stimulating debate. 'This image is difficult to look at, but what it shows is an inescapable part of the human exploitation of the natural world. 'Wildlife Photographer of the Year showcases the world's best nature photography, so it is a perfect platform to use to discuss uncomfortable realities.'

The outlook for black rhinos Black rhinos once ranged across sub-Saharan Africa, but now they only survive in five countries: South Africa, Namibia, Kenya, Zimbabwe and Tanzania. Numbers hit rock bottom in 1995, with just 2,410 black rhinos alive in the wild. The population doubled to 4,880 by the end of 2010, but current levels are still 90% lower than three generations ago, mainly due to international trade in rhino horn. The horns are used in traditional medicine in countries including China and Vietnam, although there is no scientific evidence to suggest rhino horn material has any medicinal qualities. It is made of keratin, the same protein that makes up fingernails and hair. It grows from the skin and is not part of the animal's skeleton. Horns are also used in several countries to make prized ornaments such as jewellery, drinking vessels and the handles of ceremonial weapons. Recent years have seen a substantial rise in the price of horns, driving a further increase in poaching in some areas. Richard says, 'Although I do not qualify to criticise the traditional cultural use of animal parts, it is largely greed, irresponsibility and ignorance fueling the rhino horn trade. Better education systems need to be put in place. 'I despair when I see images of animals that are an important part of a major ecosystem being senselessly destroyed. Losing these animals forever would be a tragedy for humankind.'

What‚Äôs being done? Efforts are being made to save the few black rhinos there are left in the wild. Campaigning organisations work to improve knowledge about trafficking routes and reduce the demand for illegal rhino horn, and all five species of rhino are protected under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). International trade in rhino horn has been banned since 1977, and South Africa banned it domestically in 2009. Museum collections can help conservation efforts by providing historic data about the range, population structure, diet and distribution of different rhino species. The Natural History Museum has what is considered to be the most comprehensive rhino research collection in the world, consisting primarily of skeletal material.

Such specimens, which have temporal and spatial data, can provide vital scientific information that helps protect some of the most vulnerable species on our planet. In 2017, rhino material held in the Museum's collections informed a landmark study on the genetic structure of historic and modern rhino populations. It is hoped that studies like this will inform future conservation efforts. Richard says, 'The research paper was published as a result of our outstanding collections. Skeletal material has genetic data locked away within it, which new technologies are helping us to unlock and use to address a range of important conservation issues. 'As a world-leading scientific research centre, we recognise the impact that human activity is having on the natural world, and our responsibility to lead the debate about how we can ensure a sustainable future for our planet.'
TITLE: Wildlife Photographer of the Year: The brutal reality of rhino poaching

SUMMARY:
Trump, speaking in Seoul as part of his 12-day tour of Asia, delivered a direct and at times heavy-handed message to Kim Jong Un, telling the North Korean leader: ‚ÄúDo not underestimate us.
pic.twitter.com/9tsZRCC83j ‚Äî Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) November 8, 2017‚ÄúI also come here to deliver a message directly to the leader: The weapons you are acquiring are not making you safer.
North Korea is not the paradise your grandfather envisioned.
The speech stands in contrast to Trump‚Äôs past remarks, in which the president has threatened or demeaned Kim on Twitter.
White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said the planned visit, even though it did not take place, was of a ‚Äúhistoric nature‚Äù and showed ‚Äúthe strength of the alliance‚Äù between the U.S. and South Korea.
TEXT:
President Donald Trump took a far more measured tone during his address to South Korea‚Äôs National Assembly on Wednesday, touting the option of diplomacy with North Korea while delivering a strong message to the country‚Äôs leader that it must end its nuclear weapons program.

Trump, speaking in Seoul as part of his 12-day tour of Asia, delivered a direct and at times heavy-handed message to Kim Jong Un, telling the North Korean leader: ‚ÄúDo not underestimate us. Do not try us.‚Äù

However the president echoed calls from a day earlier when, speaking at a news conference with South Korean President Moon Jae-in, he urged Pyongyang to ‚Äúcome to the table and make a deal.‚Äù

Together, we dream of a Korea that is free, a peninsula that is safe, and families that are reunited once again! pic.twitter.com/9tsZRCC83j ‚Äî Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) November 8, 2017

‚ÄúI also come here to deliver a message directly to the leader: The weapons you are acquiring are not making you safer. They are putting your regime in grave danger,‚Äù Trump told the National Assembly. ‚ÄúEvery step you take down this dark path increases the peril you face. North Korea is not the paradise your grandfather envisioned. It is a hell that no person deserves.

‚ÄúWe will offer a path to a much better future. It begins with an end to the aggression of your regime, a stop to your development of ballistic missiles and complete verifiable and total denuclearization.‚Äù

North Korea has so far refused offers of diplomacy and said it would not put its nuclear weapons ‚Äï or its ballistic missiles capable of reaching the United States ‚Äï on the bargaining table.

The speech stands in contrast to Trump‚Äôs past remarks, in which the president has threatened or demeaned Kim on Twitter. In September, he vowed to ‚Äútotally destroy North Korea‚Äù during his first address to the United Nations and called Kim a ‚Äúrocket man ... on a suicide mission for himself and for his regime.‚Äù

Other Trump administration officials, including Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis, have said diplomacy would remain on the table ‚Äúuntil the first bomb drops.‚Äù

Trump‚Äôs speech Wednesday, which included a sweeping history of the conflict on the Korean peninsula, included some overt hits at the North, including his assertion that the region ‚Äúis a country ruled by a cult.‚Äù He pointed to human rights abuses by Pyongyang against its own people and acts of aggression including the recent death of American student Otto Warmbier, who Trump said was ‚Äútortured‚Äù to death.

‚ÄúWe will not allow American cities to be threatened with destruction, we will not be intimidated and we will not let the worst atrocities in history be repeated here, on this ground we fought and died so hard to secure,‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúTo those nations that choose to ignore this threat ‚Äï or, worse still, to enable it ‚Äï the weight of this crisis is on your conscience.‚Äù

A surprise visit by Trump and Moon to the Korean Demilitarized Zone, the heavily-armed buffer region between North and South Korea, was canceled at the last minute on Wednesday due to poor weather. White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said the planned visit, even though it did not take place, was of a ‚Äúhistoric nature‚Äù and showed ‚Äúthe strength of the alliance‚Äù between the U.S. and South Korea.
TITLE: Trump Bucks Usual Aggression, Opens The Door To Negotiations With North Korea

SUMMARY:
"Por tanto, son proclives a la frustraci√≥n, la impaciencia y la falta de satisfacci√≥n cuando no alcanzan sus objetivos.
En el caso del aburrimiento, por ejemplo, el sujeto simplemente se quedaba solo en una sala durante seis minutos.
"Lo que desencadena el h√°bito principalmente es la frustraci√≥n y la impaciencia, de modo que ese gesto sustituye a una acci√≥n m√°s constructiva".
No obstante, cuando es dif√≠cil parar esos h√°bitos e interfieren en la vida diaria, se pueden convertir en trastornos del comportamiento.
"No tratamos el h√°bito directamente para que la persona no tenga que aprender una respuesta contraria que lo reemplace".
TEXT:
¬øTe est√°s toqueteando el pelo o mordiendo las u√±as sin darte cuenta mientras lees este art√≠culo? Una investigaci√≥n de la Universidad de Montreal, en Canad√°, sugiere que los comportamientos compulsivos de este tipo dicen mucho m√°s sobre tu personalidad de lo que crees.

Las personas que suelen ser impacientes o que se aburren y se frustran con facilidad tienen m√°s probabilidades de llevar a cabo comportamientos repetitivos en relaci√≥n con el cuerpo, tales como rascarse, morderse las u√±as o arrancarse las pesta√±as, explicaron los especialistas.

El estudio, publicado en una edici√≥n del Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry, apunta al perfeccionismo (un rasgo que puede ser m√°s nocivo de lo aparente) como una causa subyacente.

"Creemos que los individuos con estos comportamientos repetitivos pueden ser perfeccionistas, lo que significa que son incapaces de relajarse y de llevar a cabo una tarea a un ritmo normal", afirmaba en un comunicado de prensa el doctor Kieron O'Connor, profesor de psiquiatr√≠a en la universidad y uno de los principales autores del estudio. "Por tanto, son proclives a la frustraci√≥n, la impaciencia y la falta de satisfacci√≥n cuando no alcanzan sus objetivos. Tambi√©n experimentan un mayor nivel de aburrimiento".

En el estudio, los investigadores trabajaron con 48 participantes, de los cuales la mitad presentaba habitualmente estos comportamientos. Los otros participantes, que no ten√≠an estos h√°bitos, actuaban como grupo de control. Se pregunt√≥ a los participantes hasta qu√© punto experimentaban emociones como aburrimiento, enfado, culpa, irritabilidad y ansiedad. Entonces, cada participante era expuesto a situaciones destinadas a provocar alguna sensaci√≥n en particular, entre otras relajaci√≥n, estr√©s, frustraci√≥n y aburrimiento. En el caso del aburrimiento, por ejemplo, el sujeto simplemente se quedaba solo en una sala durante seis minutos.

Los participantes con un historial de conductas nerviosas centradas en el cuerpo expresaron una mayor necesidad de llevar a cabo esos comportamientos cuando se sent√≠an estresados o frustrados. Pero no sent√≠an esta necesidad cuando estaban relajados.

Si te muerdes las u√±as de vez en cuando, no hay por qu√© preocuparse; probablemente no est√©s causando mucho da√±o. De hecho, los investigadores afirman que estos comportamientos cumplen un prop√≥sito temporal cuando no somos capaces de canalizar nuestra energ√≠a de forma m√°s productiva.

"Los efectos positivos de estos h√°bitos son la estimulaci√≥n y una forma (inadaptada) de regular la emoci√≥n", explicaba O'Connor v√≠a correo electr√≥nico a la edici√≥n estadounidense de The HuffPost. "Lo que desencadena el h√°bito principalmente es la frustraci√≥n y la impaciencia, de modo que ese gesto sustituye a una acci√≥n m√°s constructiva".

No obstante, cuando es dif√≠cil parar esos h√°bitos e interfieren en la vida diaria, se pueden convertir en trastornos del comportamiento. La actriz Olivia Munn, por ejemplo, ha hablado alguna vez sobre su lucha contra la tricotiloman√≠a, un trastorno de ansiedad que consiste en quitarse las pesta√±as de forma compulsiva.

"No me muerdo las u√±as, pero me arranco las pesta√±as", confes√≥ Munn en New York Daily News en 2012. "No duele, pero es muy molesto".

Entonces, ¬øc√≥mo pueden tratarse estos h√°bitos? De acuerdo con O'Connor, en la actualidad existen dos posibles v√≠as: un tratamiento de conducta que implique sustituir la man√≠a por una acci√≥n contraria, y la otra ser√≠a mediante un enfoque diferente que se centre en los factores subyacentes que crean tensi√≥n, como el perfeccionismo y los pensamientos negativos.

"Observamos todos los pensamientos y comportamientos presentes en situaciones de alto riesgo para esa conducta y los modificamos a trav√©s de una terapia cognitiva para que se asemejen a los pensamientos en situaciones de bajo riesgo", cont√≥ O'Connor. "No tratamos el h√°bito directamente para que la persona no tenga que aprender una respuesta contraria que lo reemplace".
TITLE: El perfeccionismo detr√°s del h√°bito de morderte las u√±as

SUMMARY:
In the ‚ÄúHarry Potter‚Äù universe, it‚Äôs a little befuddling why the Dursleys hate Harry so much.
According to the theory, the Dursleys were such turd buckets because Harry was a Horcrux and they had to live with him for years.
Just like Slytherin‚Äôs Locket adversely affected Ron‚Äôs mood during ‚ÄúHarry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,‚Äù Harry may have had a similar effect on the Dursleys.
In an interview with Daniel Radcliffe about his new movie ‚ÄúJungle,‚Äù we brought up the theory and asked if it could explain why the Dursleys were so mean.
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs interesting, yeah.‚ÄùRadcliffe continued, ‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôs definitely the first time I‚Äôve heard that one.
TEXT:
Dumbledore once said happiness can be found, even in the darkest of times, if one only remembers to turn on the light.

Yeah, that‚Äôs easy to say when you don‚Äôt live with the Dursleys.

In the ‚ÄúHarry Potter‚Äù universe, it‚Äôs a little befuddling why the Dursleys hate Harry so much. He seems like a generally genial guy. Sure, he can be a bit moody, but he‚Äôs got a piece of the Dark Lord living inside of him. Give the man a break.

Actually, the fact that Harry is somewhat of a Horcrux became the center of a popular theory a couple of years ago, and it seemed to finally explain why the Dursleys were so horrible to the wizard all this time.

According to the theory, the Dursleys were such turd buckets because Harry was a Horcrux and they had to live with him for years. Just like Slytherin‚Äôs Locket adversely affected Ron‚Äôs mood during ‚ÄúHarry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,‚Äù Harry may have had a similar effect on the Dursleys. Though Ron and Hermione spent a lot of time with Harry at Hogwarts, the Dursleys were with him constantly over a much longer period of time.

In an interview with Daniel Radcliffe about his new movie ‚ÄúJungle,‚Äù we brought up the theory and asked if it could explain why the Dursleys were so mean.

‚ÄúOh OK, so it affects the behavior of people around it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs interesting, yeah.‚Äù

Radcliffe continued, ‚ÄúYeah, that‚Äôs definitely the first time I‚Äôve heard that one. It‚Äôs definitely interesting because it sort of posits a world where these people only known to be a certain way. Actually if you remove him from the situation, [they] would have been quite a nice, friendly family.‚Äù

OK, maybe ‚Äúfriendly family‚Äù is a stretch.

‚ÄúHaving been there for Richard Griffiths‚Äô (Vernon) and Fiona Shaw‚Äôs (Petunia) performances,‚Äù Radcliffe said, ‚ÄúI feel like it was more they just hated having this kid around.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut I think that‚Äôs definitely a cool theory,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúHas anyone asked Jo Rowling what she thinks of that one yet? I feel like that one ‚Äï that‚Äôs definitely a good one.‚Äù

Though it‚Äôs not in the books, J.K. Rowling has written about the Dursleys‚Äô dislike for Harry on Pottermore, calling them ‚Äúreactionary, prejudiced, narrow-minded, ignorant and bigoted.‚Äù Rowling explained that Petunia‚Äôs loathing stemmed from jealousy of her sister Lily‚Äôs magical abilities, and that Vernon hated anything out of the ordinary. The couple also had a falling out with Harry‚Äôs parents and never made up.

Rowling doesn‚Äôt mention whether or not Harry being a Horcrux contributed to the Dursleys‚Äô hatred; however, the theory does make a lot of sense and offers a unique way of looking at the family.

Even Radcliffe thinks it‚Äôs cool. If this were Quidditch, we‚Äôd call it a keeper.
TITLE: Even Daniel Radcliffe Is Into This 'Harry Potter' Theory About The Dursleys

SUMMARY:
Apr√®s l'annonce par Renault d'un syst√®me d'√©vitement automatique d'obstacles dans la matin√©e, c'est la start-up Navya qui fait parler d'elle, ce mardi 7 novembre.
La soci√©t√© lyonnaise, sp√©cialis√©e dans les v√©hicules sans conducteur, vient en effet de d√©voiler Cab, un taxi autonome.
Dont le but affich√© est tout simplement d'aller concurrencer Waymo, la filiale de Google, leader sur les voitures autonomes.
Ils roulent souvent dans des zones sans trafic (a√©roports, zones industrielles, etc), mais dans certaines exp√©rimentations, dans des environnements urbains.
La soci√©t√©, pionni√®re en la mati√®re, a d√©j√† accumul√© pr√®s de 5 millions de kilom√®tres depuis le d√©but du projet Google Car.
TEXT:
TRANSPORTS - C'est d√©cid√©ment la journ√©e de la voiture autonome fran√ßaise. Apr√®s l'annonce par Renault d'un syst√®me d'√©vitement automatique d'obstacles dans la matin√©e, c'est la start-up Navya qui fait parler d'elle, ce mardi 7 novembre.

La soci√©t√© lyonnaise, sp√©cialis√©e dans les v√©hicules sans conducteur, vient en effet de d√©voiler Cab, un taxi autonome. A peine plus grand qu'un C4 Picasso, le v√©hicule aux allures futuristes dispose de 6 places assises, mais n'a ni volant ni p√©dales, comme vous pouvez le voir dans la vid√©o ci-dessus.

Et on ne parle pas ici d'un prototype: le v√©hicule est finalis√© et sera commercialis√© d√®s la rentr√©e 2018. Pour un prix "entre 230.000 et 260.000 euros", affirme au HuffPost le PDG Cristophe Sapet. Dont le but affich√© est tout simplement d'aller concurrencer Waymo, la filiale de Google, leader sur les voitures autonomes.

Un premier minibus deux ans plus t√¥t

Un objectif bien ambitieux, mais il faut dire que Navya ne part pas de rien. Deux ans plus t√¥t, elle lan√ßait son premier v√©hicule sans volant ni p√©dale. Depuis, 50 unit√©s de ce minibus, appel√© Arma, ont √©t√© vendues. Ils roulent souvent dans des zones sans trafic (a√©roports, zones industrielles, etc), mais dans certaines exp√©rimentations, dans des environnements urbains.

Ce mardi, l'engin, capable de transporter 15 passagers, est √©galement rebaptis√© Shuttle. "Tout ce qu'on a appris avec ce v√©hicule nous a servi pour le Cab", pr√©cise Christophe Sapet, qui envisage d'ailleurs de commercialiser un troisi√®me mod√®le plus petit, pour compl√©ter la flotte d'ici quelques temps.

Le taxi autonome est √©videmment bard√© de capteurs en tout genre, essentiels pour ce genre de v√©hicules. 10 lidars, 6 cam√©ras et 4 radars notamment, pour les connaisseurs. Ce qui repr√©sente la moiti√© du prix du Cab.

Niveau utilisation, on demande une course comme sur une application de VTC dy type Uber. Sauf qu'il n'y a pas de chauffeur. L'app permet √©galement de g√©rer l'ouverture et la fermeture des portes.

En France en avril ?

Le Cab est vu comme un compl√©ment du Shuttle. Le taxi vise avant tout √† s'installer dans les centres des grandes m√©tropoles. Sauf que pour l'instant, ce genre de v√©hicule est interdit sur les routes, en France comme dans la majorit√© des pays.

Pour autant, il est possible de n√©gocier des exp√©rimentations avec les pouvoirs publics. Si Navya a d√©j√† deux partenaires pour son Cab, d'autres devraient √™tre annonc√©s d'ici le CES, le plus grand salon de l'√©lectronique, √† Las Vegas en janvier 2018.

"On esp√®re avoir les autorisations pour des exp√©rimentations dans une des trois grandes villes fran√ßaises d'ici le mois d'avril", affirme Christophe Sapet. C'est en multipliant ces tests que Navya esp√®re concurrencer les g√©ants du secteur.

Rouler autant que Google

Si tout se passe bien, Navya devrait "√™tre au m√™me niveau que Waymo en termes de kilom√®tres parcourus par jour" l'ann√©e prochaine, esp√®re le PDG. Un objectif louable, mais cela ne sera pas suffisant pour atteindre le niveau de Google. La soci√©t√©, pionni√®re en la mati√®re, a d√©j√† accumul√© pr√®s de 5 millions de kilom√®tres depuis le d√©but du projet Google Car.

Christophe Sapet estime tout de m√™me avoir des avantages pour se hisser dans la cour des grands. Notamment un savoir faire dans tous les domaines li√©s aux voitures autonomes: la construction du v√©hicule, mais aussi l'intelligence artificielle qui le dirige, les capteurs qui nourrissent cette derni√®re, etc.

Mais m√™me si l'on dit souvent que la technologie est de plus en plus m√ªre, le pari d'une voiture sans aucun moyen de reprendre le contr√¥le est tout de m√™me un saut dans l'inconnu. Sans m√™me parler du changement de l√©gislation n√©cessaire pour qu'une telle r√©volution soit autoris√©e sur toutes les routes.

Apr√®s tout, m√™me le leader Google, qui envisagerait de lancer une premi√®re exp√©rimentation de taxis enti√®rement autonomes en 2018 √† Phoenix, aurait encore parfois des soucis, notamment dans les parkings de centres commerciaux.

Christophe Sapet est conscient des d√©fis et estime que ce genre de taxi ne pourra fonctionner, dans un premier temps, que dans des quartiers bien d√©limit√©s. Il est par contre confiant sur les capacit√©s de Navya. "Nos v√©hicules roulent tous les jours dans des conditions climatiques difficiles. C'est notre savoir faire", lance-t-il. Et pour prouver que cette technologie est s√ªre, il n'h√©sitera pas √† traverser Paris dans un Navya Cab. A condition d'en avoir l'autorisation.

√Ä voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Navya Cab, le taxi autonome fran√ßais qui veut concurrencer Google

TEXT:
Algunas caras familiares van a regresar a Grey's Anatomy en el cap√≠tulo 300, que se emite en Estados Unidos este jueves 9 de octubre.

Este drama m√©dico tan longevo va a traer de vuelta a los fantasmas de temporadas anteriores para el gran cap√≠tulo Who Lives, Who Dies, Who Tells Your Story (Quien vive, quien muere, quien cuenta tu historia), que gira en torno a un accidente en una monta√±a rusa (Lo cierto es que esperamos que no se refieran a fantasmas de verdad, porque todos sabemos c√≥mo acab√≥ eso la √∫ltima vez).

Aunque int√©rpretes como Katherine Heigl, Sandra Oh y T.R. Knight no van a volver (miembros del reparto original que ya han abandonado la serie), habr√° pacientes con un gran parecido a esos personajes que har√°n su aparici√≥n en este episodio repleto de nostalgia.

"El episodio 300 va a ser como un viaje al pasado", ha contado el actor James Pickens Jr. en E! News. "Veremos a algunos actores que llegan al hospital despu√©s de un horrible accidente y que nos recordar√°n a Izzie, George y Cristina Yang", se√±ala.

"Encontraron a tres int√©rpretes incre√≠bles... Cuando llegu√© y los vi me sorprend√≠ mucho, porque fueron una parte imprescindible del √©xito que tuvo la serie y ten√≠an mucho talento, as√≠ que los echamos mucho de menos. Por tanto, a los espectadores les gustar√≠a mucho decir 'Vaya, ah√≠ est√°n de nuevo", ha se√±alado el actor.

La actriz Sara Drew ha explicado a Entertainment Weekly que "ese parecido hace que el reparto original recuerde a esas personas y luche para que estas vivan".

Heigl dej√≥ Grey's Anatomy en la sexta temporada tras un supuesto enfrentamiento con la creadora de la serie, Shonda Rhimes. Esta supuesta enemistad surgi√≥ cuando la actriz tom√≥ la pol√©mica decisi√≥n de retirarse de la carrera por un Emmy en 2008 porque pensaba que su papel "no merec√≠a una nominaci√≥n".

Knight abandon√≥ la serie antes que Heigl, cuando su personaje fallece tras un accidente de autob√∫s. Por su parte, Oh fue la que m√°s tiempo permaneci√≥ en la serie de los tres, y se despidi√≥ tras la d√©cima temporada.

Rhimes ha dejado la puerta abierta para el regreso de esta actriz, pero no as√≠ con Heigl. Ella no volver√° a los pasillos del Grey Sloan Memorial Hospital, pese al hecho de que la actriz ha manifestado su deseo de volver a interpretar a su personaje.

"Ya basta con esa historia. Le he dado mil vueltas a esa idea y he reflexionado si podr√≠a funcionar. Y creo que la respuesta es no", apunta Rhimes respecto a la posible vuelta de Heigl en 2015.

A continuaci√≥n puedes ver el v√≠deo promocional del episodio n√∫mero 300.

Este art√≠culo fue publicado originalmente en el HuffPost Estados Unidos y ha sido traducido del ingl√©s por Mar√≠a Gin√©s Grao por El HuffPost.
