"Antes dejo la pol√≠tica que traicionar a L√≥pez Obrador": MonrealEntonces comenzaron los supuestos coqueteos de Monreal con el Frente Ciudadano e, incluso, se dijo que hasta con el PRI.
Por el contrario, en este mismo ejercicio, el delegado en Cuauht√©moc aparece como el aspirante a la jefatura de gobierno de Ciudad de M√©xico que mayor cobertura positiva tuvo en octubre.
Por ello, aquel mensaje de L√≥pez Obrador el 27 de octubre, aunque caus√≥ sorpresa tras su alejamiento con Monreal, tambi√©n fue visto como un paso l√≥gico.
A pregunta de los reporteros que cubr√≠an su paso por La Yesca, Nayarit, sobre las posibilidades de que Sheinbaum se mantuviera como la virtual candidata de Morena en la capital del pa√≠s, L√≥pez Obrador zanj√≥ "ella va a ser la coordinadora de Morena en la Ciudad de M√©xico".
Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador.
TEXT:
Desde el 27 de octubre pasado, cuando el presidente nacional del Movimiento de Regeneraci√≥n Nacional (Morena), Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador, le envi√≥ un mensaje al delegado en Cuauht√©moc, Ricardo Monreal, para que siga con el partido luego del cisma que se abri√≥ entre los dos tras los resultados de la cuestionada encuesta con la que Claudia Sheinbaum fue nombrada coordinadora de Organizaci√≥n en la Ciudad de M√©xico.

Tras esos resultados, Monreal, quien result√≥ en cuarto lugar seg√∫n dicho ese ejercicio, empez√≥ a dar pasos hacia atr√°s en su cercan√≠a con L√≥pez Obrador y a escuchar otras opciones para impulsar su candidatura a la jefatura de gobierno de Ciudad de M√©xico, ante la negativa, por lo menos hasta este momento, de repetir el ejercicio en el que Sheinbaum habr√≠a resultado ganadora.

"Antes dejo la pol√≠tica que traicionar a L√≥pez Obrador": Monreal

Entonces comenzaron los supuestos coqueteos de Monreal con el Frente Ciudadano e, incluso, se dijo que hasta con el PRI.

Monreal, ¬øcandidato del Frente Ciudadano?

¬øRicardo Monreal regresa al PRI? Esto fue lo que respondi√≥

Despu√©s vino un acontecimiento que nadie ten√≠a previsto: el sismo del 19 de septiembre pasado y, lo cual, modific√≥ tambi√©n el "mapa de los aspirantes": los sondeos internos de Morena confirmaban una ca√≠da de 7 puntos de Sheinbaum tras el #19S debido a la crisis por el Colegio R√©bsamen, en la delegaci√≥n que actualmente gobierna.

Lo cual este 6 de noviembre parece confirmarse tras los resultados del an√°lisis realizado por la empresa Central de Inteligencia Pol√≠tica (CIP) para el peri√≥dico El Universal, en donde la delegada en Tlalpan registra la mayor cobertura negativa a consecuencia del Colegio R√©bsamen, donde murieron 26 personas.

Por el contrario, en este mismo ejercicio, el delegado en Cuauht√©moc aparece como el aspirante a la jefatura de gobierno de Ciudad de M√©xico que mayor cobertura positiva tuvo en octubre.

Por ello, aquel mensaje de L√≥pez Obrador el 27 de octubre, aunque caus√≥ sorpresa tras su alejamiento con Monreal, tambi√©n fue visto como un paso l√≥gico.

Sin embargo, una declaraci√≥n del tabasque√±o el pasado 3 de noviembre volvi√≥ a acrecentar la incertidumbre.

A pregunta de los reporteros que cubr√≠an su paso por La Yesca, Nayarit, sobre las posibilidades de que Sheinbaum se mantuviera como la virtual candidata de Morena en la capital del pa√≠s, L√≥pez Obrador zanj√≥ "ella va a ser la coordinadora de Morena en la Ciudad de M√©xico".

Yo admiro a Claudia Sheinbaum para que quede claro, desde luego hay quienes no la ven con buenos ojos, pero tambi√©n se debe de garantizar el derecho a disentir, una cosa es que no les guste Claudia y otra cosa es que no sea nuestra representante, ella va a ser la coordinadora de Morena en Ciudad de M√©xico".

Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador.
TITLE: Las indecisas aguas de Morena en CDMX

SUMMARY:
Within a month of the election, non-partisan organization She Should Run had heard from 4,500 women interested in running for elected office.
Some of the women who decided to run for office found inspiration in Hillary Clinton‚Äôs candidacy.
You‚Äôre part of a wave of women stepping up to run for office.
Why do you think it‚Äôs important that more women run?
Brianna Wu, 40, R unning for Congress in Massachusetts, District 8Getty/HuffPostCan you describe the moment you decided to run for office?
TEXT:
Laura Moser never had any desire to run for office. Her husband worked in politics, and she considered herself to be a highly ‚Äúinvolved volunteer,‚Äù but beyond that maintained some space from the political sphere.

And then the 2016 presidential election happened.

Moser, 40, was overwhelmed by the election of President Donald J. Trump, and the ensuing pain she saw in her own community on Facebook. The outpouring of grief and mass desire to do something that she saw on social media led Moser to found Daily Action in December 2016, a service that texts daily action items ‚Äï like calling your representatives to talk about gun control or forwarding a reminder to voters in Virginia to get to to the polls ‚Äï to users‚Äô phones. By early May 2017, she had officially announced she would be running for Congress.

Moser‚Äôs story isn‚Äôt unique. Across the nation, women from all over the political spectrum decided to run for elected office in the wake of the 2016 presidential race. Within a month of the election, non-partisan organization She Should Run had heard from 4,500 women interested in running for elected office. By February, that number rose to 13,000. Emily‚Äôs List, a PAC focusing on electing pro-choice Democratic women to office, saw a similar spike in interest.

Some of the women who decided to run for office found inspiration in Hillary Clinton‚Äôs candidacy. Others were simply sick and tired of seeing a legislative body they felt did not represent their identities or interests. Regardless of motivation, the numbers tell a clear story: Women are stepping up and saying they deserve a seat ‚Äï or three or four or five seats ‚Äï at the table.

Below, presented a year since election day, are eight of those women and their stories:

Laura Moser, 40, Running for Congress in Texas, District 7

Courtesy of Laura Moser

Describe the moment you decided to run for office.

People [would say], ‚ÄúOh you‚Äôre such a good activist, you‚Äôre such a good organizer, you should run for something.‚Äù And I was like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs crazy. Why would I ever do that?‚Äù But then I was in Houston for a Planned Parenthood luncheon and it was the biggest Planned Parenthood luncheon in the history of Planned Parenthood‚Ä¶ That was the first time I really thought, maybe I should run. The room was filled with hundreds of pissed off women ‚Äï many of whom are traditionally Republicans, and were just tired of having these sleazy dudes take away our rights. And I just felt this swelling sense of collective indignation and belonging with this group, but I also was like, god, I know all these women. I haven‚Äôt lived here [in Texas] for a while, but these are still my people, these were the people I grew up with. These are the people I learned to be politically engaged with. And it took me another two and a half months to go from there to actually deciding to pack up my life and move across the country. But that was definitely the Oprah ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment.

You‚Äôre part of a wave of women stepping up to run for office. Why do you think it‚Äôs important that more women run?

Every single person I know, me included, has been assaulted and harassed by a man in power many times in our lives. That is the world that we live in. And [I‚Äôm] OK. [I‚Äôve] overcome these hurdles. But the Access Hollywood tape was an absolutely radicalizing moment for me. I was like, fuck, this guy‚Äôs running for President? And he‚Äôs the worst man we‚Äôve all met before? And then he won. I thought the election was over then. But then he actually won, being that person. And so I think the value of women and people of color being at the table and in the conversation is that we‚Äôre...bringing new voices to the table.

If we had women in all positions in power, the world would become more adaptable to women and mothers, and families. Because I just think a lot of men are used to the women doing it for them. And guess what? We‚Äôve done a really good job‚Ä¶ [White men have] had their chance. They‚Äôve done some good things over the years, but I‚Äôm done.

Brianna Wu, 40, R unning for Congress in Massachusetts, District 8

Getty/HuffPost

Can you describe the moment you decided to run for office?

I was standing at the Javits Center on election night, 30 feet [from] where we were hoping Hillary Clinton would accept the presidency. I was there with all of the people that worked the election for Hillary, as things started going wrong. It was one of the worst nights of my entire life. I was thrown into a loop for a week or two and realized that I wasn‚Äôt willing to sit it out for the next four years. It was time to stand up and bring my own values to politics.

What have you learned since you decided to run?

I‚Äôm going to be really honest with you. What I‚Äôve learned here in Massachusetts is that the institutions of power are very ready to put a camera in your face when you‚Äôre a woman in danger like I was during GamerGate. But when you‚Äôre talking about taking power for yourself, when you‚Äôre talking about upsetting the status quo, when you‚Äôre talking specifically about replacing a man, even a Democratic man [incumbent Stephen Lynch], what I‚Äôve learned is that the system starts shutting its doors very, very quickly.

A lot of this first year has honestly been realizing that the Democratic Party is not necessarily the friend of women that want to run and push the party toward a stronger position on women‚Äôs rights.

Jennifer Carroll Foy, 36, Ran for House Delegate in Virginia, District 2 (Won!)

Courtesy of Jennifer Caroll Foy

What sparked your interest in running for office?

Like so many people, I woke up on Nov. 9 in disbelief. I went to sleep early the night before, trusting that the American people would never elect someone so intolerant or incompetent. I woke up, heard the news, and knew I had to run. I knew that there must be a response to Trump and the regressive, elitist Republican agenda.

What‚Äôs one of the most important things you‚Äôve learned while running?

Put your head down and get it done. From the moment I started running, people told me, ‚ÄúNo, you can‚Äôt do this.‚Äù They told me that I could not be a mother, an attorney, a wife and a candidate. But I‚Äôve been told ‚ÄúNo‚Äù my whole life. When I was in high school, I watched as Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg announced the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision that Virginia Military Institute ‚Äï one of the top all-male military colleges in the country ‚Äï had to accept women. My male classmates jeered, and I decided I had to go. I enrolled as one of the first women of color to attend VMI. When people told me I couldn‚Äôt win this election, I put my head down, ignored the naysayers, and got to work. We knocked on more doors, called more voters, and put in the time to win. There will be people who tell you that you shouldn‚Äôt run or that you will never win. Tell them, ‚ÄúWatch me!‚Äù

Dr. Mai Khanh Tran, 52, Running for Congress in California, District 39

Courtesy of Dr. Mai Khanh Tran

Can you describe the moment you decided to run for office?

I made the official decision to run for office when Ed Royce voted to repeal and replace the ACA. I just couldn‚Äôt stand by while our representative voted to take away health care coverage from my patients and their families.

We really need to see a change in our community, and we need someone who understands what our community is going through. As a refugee who came to this country as a child, I know the inhumanity of the Trump administration‚Äôs policies that will restrict new immigrants, and we need a leader who will fight tooth and nail against those policies. As a woman that has defeated breast cancer twice, I know how important it is to be an outspoken advocate for women‚Äôs health issues, so that all women have access to reproductive health care and breast cancer screenings.

Can you describe how you felt on election night last year?

I felt like I had been punched in the stomach. The next morning, I didn‚Äôt want to get up. But I did, like all women do. One of the first patients I saw was a child with a brain tumor. His mom is a nail shop worker and she was finally able to get health care coverage because of the ACA. That meant that she would have coverage for her son as their family dealt with such a terrible tragedy. As we sat in the exam room that next morning, we hugged each other and we cried. We were all so scared. But after the crying, we knew that we needed to fight.

Haley Stevens, 34, Running for Congress in Michigan, District 11

Courtesy of Haley Stevens

Why did you decide to run for office?

In many ways where I found myself in 2016 was very similar to where I found myself in 2008, which was coming out of a big election, asking myself what I can do for people, particularly my home community... In 2016, I asked myself that same question coming out of the election, what is going on in Michigan? What is this representation bringing to my hometown? I was working in a Department of Defense-funded advanced manufacturing research lab spending a bunch of time with technology, advanced technology, and looking at technology adoption for the small and midsize manufacturing community... Everyone wants to talk about 21st century job training and skills. Well, I‚Äôve created workforce development programs. I‚Äôve worked at the intersection of industry and government and academia and nonprofit for outcomes. I really saw the confluence of all of those things. Plus the willingness and eagerness to serve and respond to something like I did eight years prior, which is stepping up and putting up my hand to make a difference for people.

I felt the urgency of the time and this groundswell that was taking place in Michigan. So many people, my mom being one of them, who just said, ‚ÄúHey, I was on the floor coming out of this election, but you looking and stepping up in this way, that was giving me hope.‚Äù I was plugging into Democratic Club organizations that were seeing two to three times more participation. I was going into union halls and I was tapping into that groundswell. Not as a candidate, but as somebody who was looking to step up as a voice. My candidacy in many respects began as part of that groundswell and really ballooned into something tremendous.

If you‚Äôre elected, what change do you hope to see as a result?

This is about a new generation of leaders and leadership. We‚Äôre all too familiar with the linkage between congress and the word ‚Äúdysfunction.‚Äù They seem to go hand in hand. That‚Äôs just something we got to stop right now. We need a return to common sense and we need a return to real leadership. In part that is about the collaborative nature and role of this office, as well as the willingness to use the office to make a difference for people. Make a difference for people in terms of solving large challenges that communities have been saddled with. That could be as it pertains to health outcomes, as it pertains to education, and certainly as it pertains to our economy. I really believe in the moral authority of the office to do good.

Eileen Naples, 35, Ran for New York State Senate, District 26 (Lost.)

Courtesy of Eileen Naples

Why did you decide to run for office?

Before Trump, I would have been the kind of person who thought about these problems and didn‚Äôt think I was the person to run. When I was assistant district attorney, my job was prosecuting bullies and abusers in people‚Äôs families. I saw that trait early on with Trump and I was horrified. So many moms and women recognize him as a bully. That an infectious, horrible influence on our kids is being amplified in such a position made me think that the voice of a normal mom needs to be amplified, too. We should be as vocal as we seek to be, as he did. There‚Äôs no point to sit back and watch this unfold anymore, we have to all do it ourselves. If we leave it to the system it‚Äôs going to shake out in a way that‚Äôs not good for our kids.

You lost your election earlier this fall. Would you run again?

The Democratic party in each county has to choose a person to run. I have to decide if I‚Äôm going to run again in the primary next year. I‚Äôll certainly be exploring other ways to get involved. My big question is: How do you take all this enthusiasm ‚Äï within a city like New York, it‚Äôs like a fiefdom ‚Äï and make real change? To me, it‚Äôs about informing people about the real paths to influence local leaders.

Jess Phoenix, 35, Running for Congress in California, District 25

Courtesy of Jess Phoenix

What sparked your interest in running for office?

I am running for Congress because I think some of the biggest threats that we have coming down the pipeline are completely being ignored by our current representation in government. For example, climate change is going to impact our national security, our jobs, our health, and even our food security. I believe we need a scientific approach to solving problems like this because they‚Äôre big picture problems that affect everyone. We need leaders who know how to look at a ton of evidence and data to draw conclusions and outline a plan of action. That is something that my work as a scientist has prepared me pretty uniquely to do.

The moment that I decided to run, I had just given a lecture at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles. A friend with two young boys approached me, and expressed that he was very concerned about the future world his kids would inherit. I realized that science is missing from government, and if not me, who would be the scientist to run and change our future?

Can you describe how you felt on election night last year?

Election night 2016 was surreal for me. I was working the polls here in L.A. County, and my fellow poll workers and I started out the day in fantastic spirits. As early evening began, we started to see news updates come through on our phones. Throughout the day, turnout had seemed low to us, but we figured that people would come after work. Every report of Trump‚Äôs electoral victories felt like a lie. Our jokes disappeared, and we all started focusing inward, looking at our phones and grimacing. From 7pm until the polls closed at 8pm, we didn‚Äôt have a single voter come in. That was the biggest clue that something was seriously, seriously wrong with our democracy. My husband Carlos had been canvassing for Hillary in Arizona, and instead of staying there for a victory party he decided to drive back home in the middle of the night. I waited up for him, and we talked until the early hours of the next morning about how impossible and unreal the results seemed.

Zahra Suratwala, 39, Running for Illinois‚Äô DuPage County Board, District 1

Courtesy of Maha Studios

What sparked your interest in running for office?

The idea to run began as just a fleeting thought, but the more I saw how desperately people around the country were fighting for unity, the more that idea grew. I definitively knew I wanted to run when I casually mentioned to my mother, a physician who was one of the only women in her medical school in India over 50 years ago, ‚ÄúI think I would make a great candidate. I could run.‚Äù And my mother answered, ‚ÄúYou would be incredible. And you absolutely should run.‚Äù Knowing how much I value my mother‚Äôs earned wisdom, and considering what the example of my running might do for my own daughter‚Äôs ability to dream big, I decided to go for it.

What's the most surprising thing you've found in running?

I am pleasantly surprised that so many people are willing to give me their time as I start my campaign. They want to be a part of something tangible, something that is concretely, measurably, creating change. I am surprised that as much as I am thanking people for their support, they are thanking me back... For the opportunity to work towards something together. This gives me the strength to keep going, to keep trying.
TITLE: Trump's Election Inspired An Army Of Women To Run For Office. Meet 8 Of Them.

SUMMARY:

Pam has been eating marijuana-infused gnocchi with Linda Robson, in a real-life scene that will air on TV next week.
Pam suffers from polymyalgia rheumatica, a condition that affects the joints, and is prescribed a bottle of drops for the pain and inflammation.
However, when they enter federal airspace while flying from Colorado to California, the marijuana products have to be thrown in the bin, and Pam admitted she‚Äôd have liked longer to try them.

TEXT:
The sight of Pam St Clement aboard a Magical Mystery Bus, taking a weed-themed road trip across America, could leave you fearing that you‚Äôre somehow tripping out. Don‚Äôt panic though: You‚Äôre not high, she is. Pam has been eating marijuana-infused gnocchi with Linda Robson, in a real-life scene that will air on TV next week.

The three-part documentary ‚ÄòGone To Pot‚Äô sounds like it would more at home on Viceland - or at the very least a 10pm slot on Channel 5 - but it‚Äôs ITV who commissioned the series, which sees some familiar faces - the ex-‚ÄòEastEnders‚Äô actress, Linda, John Fashanu, Christopher Biggins and Bobby George - on a voyage of discovery, learning more about the drug.

Before jetting off to California, Pam had little first-hand experience of it - ‚ÄúI‚Äôd smoked a bit when I was younger but nothing great‚Ä¶ And like all good politicians of course, I didn‚Äôt inhale‚Äù - but when HuffPost UK spoke with the actress just days after she returned to the UK, she explained that the trip did succeed in changing her perceptions.

In the first episode, viewers will see the gang learn that many medical users in the US are over 55 - a factor that helped ITV decide who could be good for the show - as they visit a dispensary to learn about which products could help their various ailments.

Pam suffers from polymyalgia rheumatica, a condition that affects the joints, and is prescribed a bottle of drops for the pain and inflammation. However, when they enter federal airspace while flying from Colorado to California, the marijuana products have to be thrown in the bin, and Pam admitted she‚Äôd have liked longer to try them.

‚ÄúWe couldn‚Äôt make a valued judgement about it,‚Äù she said, before stating she‚Äôd ‚Äúabsolutely‚Äù try the drops again, if they were legal in the UK. ‚ÄúWe met too many people who said it was beneficial to ignore it.

‚ÄúThere is a lobby which says, ‚ÄòNo, no, no It‚Äôs dangerous‚Äô, because they see the effects of this plant on youngsters, with schizophrenia and things like that.
TITLE: 'Gone To Pot': Pam St Clement On How The Show Changed Her Views On Medical Marijuana

SUMMARY:
Dans la ligne d'une prudente politique diplomatique, Emmanuel Macron tente de m√©nager ses alli√©s, tout en avan√ßant ses pions dans un contexte houleux qu'est la crise du Qatar.
Les √âmirats Arabes Unis, un alli√© privil√©gi√©... contre le terrorismeLes enjeux de la France dans sa relation avec les √âmirats sont √©lev√©s, comme en t√©moigne le rythme des √©changes bilat√©raux.
Ils repr√©sentent ainsi pour la France le 4e exc√©dent au niveau mondial.
Il sont √©galement devenus "un partenaire strat√©gique-cl√©" de la France au Moyen-Orient lors d'une alliance scell√©e apr√®s la guerre militaire du Golfe de 1990-91.
"De toute fa√ßon, si la crise avec le Qatar s'envenime d'avantage, la France va devoir forc√©ment prendre position, ou tout du moins adopter une politique plus ferme.
TEXT:
DIPLOMATIE - M√©nager la ch√®vre et le chou. Emmanuel Macron se rend, ce mercredi 7 novembre et pour deux jours, aux √âmirats Arabes Unis pour inaugurer le Louvre Abu Dhabi, projet initi√© en mars 2007 sous Jacques Chirac, amenant la prestigieuse marque fran√ßaise en Orient. L'initiative entend √©galement envoyer un message de "tol√©rance" dans une p√©riode particuli√®rement violente.

Si ce voyage, le premier d'Emmanuel Macron dans les pays du Golfe, reste dans la continuit√© des relations cordiales entre les deux pays, il interpelle tout de m√™me, alors que le pr√©sident a re√ßu en septembre dernier l'√©mir du Qatar, cheikh Tamim al-Thani et qu'il a annonc√© r√©cemment vouloir se rendre en Iran, pays ennemi des √âmirats, lors d'une visite officielle. Dans la ligne d'une prudente politique diplomatique, Emmanuel Macron tente de m√©nager ses alli√©s, tout en avan√ßant ses pions dans un contexte houleux qu'est la crise du Qatar.

Les √âmirats Arabes Unis, un alli√© privil√©gi√©... contre le terrorisme

Les enjeux de la France dans sa relation avec les √âmirats sont √©lev√©s, comme en t√©moigne le rythme des √©changes bilat√©raux. Fran√ßois Hollande a rencontr√© √† cinq reprises le prince h√©ritier d'Abou Dhabi Cheikh Mohammed ben Zayed al-Nahyane entre 2012 et 2016. Et l'actuel chef de la diplomatie, Jean-Yves Le Drian, s'y est rendu une bonne dizaine de fois comme ministre de la D√©fense. Les liens sont "√©troits, r√©guliers et diversifi√©s", r√©sume d'ailleurs l'Elys√©e.

Les Emirats sont le 2e partenaire commercial de la France dans le Golfe, apr√®s l'Arabie Saoudite, avec pr√®s de 4,7 milliards d'euros d'√©changes en 2016, allant de l'a√©ronautique (d√©j√† 100 Airbus 380 livr√©s √† la compagnie Emirates) aux produits de luxe. Ils repr√©sentent ainsi pour la France le 4e exc√©dent au niveau mondial. Les exportations fran√ßaises ont cependant recul√© ces deux derni√®res ann√©es (-5,9% en 2016) en raison de l'exacerbation de la concurrence internationale et de l'impact de la chute des cours du p√©trole. Il sont √©galement devenus "un partenaire strat√©gique-cl√©" de la France au Moyen-Orient lors d'une alliance scell√©e apr√®s la guerre militaire du Golfe de 1990-91.

Mais outre ces int√©r√™ts, "Emmanuel Macron s'int√©resse de pr√®s aux √âmirats car il estime qu'ils sont dignes de confiance en ce qui concerne la lutte contre le terrorisme. Comme avec l'√âgypte, il veut en faire un r√©el alli√©. Ce qui n'est pas le cas de l'Arabie Saoudite et du Qatar, qu'il a plusieurs fois qualifi√© de non fiables en ce qui concerne le terrorisme", nous explique Myriam Benraad, professeur assistante √† l'universit√© de Leiden au Pays-Bas. Y passer deux jours en visite officielle est un moyen de solidifier cette relation.

Des int√©r√™ts solides dans le Golfe

M√™me si le manque de confiance est √©tabli, la France entretient tout de m√™me de bonnes relations avec le Qatar et l'Arabie Saoudite. D√©j√†, pendant son mandat, Fran√ßois Hollande s'est rendu plusieurs fois en visite officielle au Qatar, √† l'occasion de la signature des contrats li√©s √† l'acquisition de 24 avions de combat Rafale. Pour sa part, apr√®s avoir √©t√© re√ßu √† l'Elys√©e en 2013 pour une visite de travail consacr√©e √† la situation en Syrie, l'√©mir Tamim avait choisi la France pour effectuer sa premi√®re visite officielle dans un pays de l'Union europ√©enne, en juin 2014. Il s'y est de nouveau rendu le 15 septembre 2017.

De plus, selon l'Elys√©e, "les liens √©conomiques de la France avec le Qatar sont solides, que ce soit sur le plan commercial ou financier. Si le montant de nos √©changes commerciaux a connu un l√©ger infl√©chissement en 2016, apr√®s une ann√©e 2015 record, il reste bien sup√©rieur aux r√©sultats des ann√©es pr√©c√©dentes". Et ce, malgr√© la mise au ban du pays par ses voisins du Moyen-Orient. La France demeure √©galement l'une des destinations privil√©gi√©es de l'investissement qatarien √† l'√©tranger, aux c√¥t√©s du Royaume-Uni, de l'Allemagne et des Etats-Unis (les investissements qatariens en France sont estim√©s √† pr√®s de 25 milliards d'euros en 2015).

De m√™me pour l'Arabie Saoudite, Fran√ßois Hollande avait fait le d√©placement √† Riyad en 2015. A cette occasion, il s'√©tait entretenu avec le roi Salman et avait √©t√© invit√© d'honneur au sommet des chefs d'Etat du Conseil de Coop√©ration du Golfe. Le Premier ministre fran√ßais s'√©tait √©galement rendu √† Riyad le 13 octobre 2015. Ce fut l'occasion de confirmer la force du partenariat franco-saoudien ainsi que la convergence de vues entre les deux pays sur les principaux dossiers r√©gionaux. Cette rencontre s'est concr√©tis√©e par la signature de contrats pour un montant de pr√®s de 10 milliards d'euros, en particulier dans les domaines militaire, financier et agroalimentaire. De son c√¥t√©, le vice-prince h√©ritier est venu plusieurs fois √† Paris entre 2015 et 2016.

"L'Arabie est notre premier partenaire commercial dans le Golfe avec 10 milliards d'euros en 2014 et 8,5 milliards d'euros en 2015 (la diff√©rence s'explique par la baisse de nos importations en hydrocarbures)", souligne l'Elys√©e.

La diplomatie ou l'int√©r√™t de "m√©nager la ch√®vre et le chou"

Des int√©r√™ts vari√©s, des alliances forg√©es... La France a tiss√© des liens parmi les pays du Golfe, alors que ceux-ci ont parfois des relations tr√®s tendues entre eux. C'est l√† que la diplomatie intervient. "Les enjeux diplomatiques sont devenus beaucoup plus importants depuis la crise du Qatar. C'est en particulier depuis ce moment-l√† que la France a eu tout int√©r√™t √† m√©nager la ch√®vre et le chou afin de garder de bonnes relations avec les diff√©rents pays, tout en √©vitant de froisser ceux qui pourraient l'√™tre", explique au HuffPost un sp√©cialiste du Moyen-Orient √† Science Po.

Paris cherche √† promouvoir "l'apaisement" et "le dialogue" dans la crise diplomatique autour du Qatar, mis au ban depuis juin par Ryad et Abou Dhabi, qui d√©noncent son rapprochement avec l'Iran chiite, principal rival des Saoudiens au Moyen-Orient. Une tache d'autant plus d√©licate que Emmanuel Macron a r√©cemment annonc√© son intention de se rendre √† T√©h√©ran, une visite in√©dite pour un pr√©sident fran√ßais depuis 1976. Malgr√© tout, la France continue de tenir son r√¥le d'arbitre/m√©diateur. "La France est embarrass√©e sur ce dossier car elle cherche √† m√©nager toutes les parties", mais "elle a du mal √† peser, comme les autres pays occidentaux d'ailleurs", remarque Jean-Pierre Maulny, directeur adjoint de l'Institut de relations internationales et strat√©giques (IRIS).

De m√™me, certains sujets sont √©vit√©s avec les √âmirats Arabes Unis. "Nous sommes des partenaires tr√®s proches, mais il y a parfois des sujets sur lesquels nous ne sommes pas totalement d'accord", reconnait-on √† l'Elys√©e. C'est le cas de la guerre au Y√©men, dans laquelle les Emirats sont fortement impliqu√©s aux c√¥t√©s de l'Arabie Saoudite. La France appelle "√† une solution politique car nous ne croyons pas qu'il y ait une issue militaire", pr√©cise-t-on de m√™me source.

Un "prix √©lev√©" pour la diplomatie

Temp√©rer, arbitrer, m√©nager, rassurer, afin de pr√©server les int√©r√™ts souverains de la France... Pour le sp√©cialiste du Moyen-Orient, la diplomatie demande un co√ªt parfois dur √† assumer. "Garder des bonnes relations avec les pays du Golfe, notamment les √âmirats et l'Arabie Saoudite, se fait au d√©pend d'une prise de position claire et forte par rapport √† la situation au Y√©men, d√©plore-t-il. La France ne se prononce pas clairement dessus pour ne pas froisser ses alli√©s, et je pense que c'est un prix un peu cher √† payer".

Depuis mars 2015, Ryad est √† la t√™te d'une coalition de pays sunnites aidant les forces gouvernementales y√©m√©nites dans leur guerre contre les Houthis et leurs alli√©s, ma√Ætres de la capitale Sanaa depuis septembre 2014. Le conflit a fait plus de 8650 morts et quelque 58.600 bless√©s, dont de nombreux civils, et provoqu√© "la pire crise humanitaire au monde", selon l'ONU.

"De toute fa√ßon, si la crise avec le Qatar s'envenime d'avantage, la France va devoir forc√©ment prendre position, ou tout du moins adopter une politique plus ferme. Cette politique de m√©nager la ch√®vre et le chou n'est pas vou√©e √† durer", conclut le sp√©cialiste.

√Ä voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Louvre Abou Dhabi : √âmirats, Qatar...Quelle position pour la France en pleine crise du Golfe?

SUMMARY:
Two children are dead and a woman has been charged after a car crashed into a school at Greenacre in Sydney, injuring several students.
The two young boys aged eight died and as many as 21 were injured after a woman crashed into Banksia Road Public School on Tuesday morning.
Two children were transported to Westmead Hospital, where they died after they were critically injured from "multiple traumas" after the crash.
Five injured children were urgently rushed to Westmead Hospital.
"Thank you to the school staff and emergency services personnel for their commitment and fortitude in very difficult circumstances today."
TEXT:
Two children are dead and a woman has been charged after a car crashed into a school at Greenacre in Sydney, injuring several students.

The two young boys aged eight died and as many as 21 were injured after a woman crashed into Banksia Road Public School on Tuesday morning.

The vehicle crashed into a demountable building around 9.45am. Two children were transported to Westmead Hospital, where they died after they were critically injured from "multiple traumas" after the crash.

NSW Police confirmed to HuffPost Australia on Tuesday afternoon that the 52-year-old driver had been charged over the incident.

In a later statement, authorities said the woman has been charged with two counts of dangerous driving occasioning death and also negligent driving. Her NSW driving licence has also been suspended and she is expected to appear in Bankstown Local Court on Wednesday.

This is a horrific incident for all. NSW Police

"As a result of that collision, five kids were urgently conveyed to Westmead Hospital. Tragically, two of those kids, male children, are deceased," a police spokesman told reporters.

"It is ongoing and we'll be here for some time to unravel this dreadful event."

Five injured children were urgently rushed to Westmead Hospital.

A distressing scene... horrific incident. NSW Ambulance

Pictures from the scene showed a crowd of distressed parents swarming the school's Boronia Road main entrance to collect their children.

NSW Fire and Rescue Superintendent Adam Dewbury said teachers and members of the public who heard the accident ran into the scene to help.

"The response by the first responders was fantastic. World-class. And also with the teachers (who) provided the best treatment to these children who had suffered the injury," he said.

It was carnage and pandemonium when Ambulance services arrived to find people assisting the injured, a NSW Ambulance spokeswoman said. Children were left screaming for their parents.

"Obviously a scene of carnage, a number of distressed and overwhelmed children and teachers at a scene of a horrible accident, and obviously and pandemonium," she said.

"It's always chaotic until there's order. New South Wales ambulance paramedics were well able to bring that order to that chaos this morning."

Scenes from Boronia St Public school as parents run to get their kids. Pic Nick Moir 7 nov 2017

A car has crashed into a school at Greenacre, paramedics on scene treating 7 people @9NewsSyd pic.twitter.com/fACzg7MyLf ‚Äî Zara James (@Zara_James9) November 6, 2017

Panicked parents on the scene in Greenacre @7NewsSydney pic.twitter.com/piJNQdMf2c ‚Äî Peter Fegan (@PeterFegan7) November 6, 2017

The female car driver, 52, was uninjured, while police have confirmed she has been taken to hospital for mandatory blood and urine tests.

NSW education minister Rob Stokes said he "cannot begin to comprehend the sadness being felt by the parents and families of the two young boys".

"Our first priority is to support students, staff and parents by any means necessary and allow them time to properly grieve. This will not be a quick process and we will work together with the school community to provide whatever assistance we can," he said.

"Thank you to the school staff and emergency services personnel for their commitment and fortitude in very difficult circumstances today."
TITLE: Car Crashes Into School Classroom At Greenacre, Killing Two Children

SUMMARY:
Hier k√∂nnen Sie den Roman zum Film "Simpel" bestellenDie Geschichte von Simpel und BenSeit Ben (Frederick Lau, 28) denken kann, sind er und sein Bruder Barnabas alias Simpel (David Kross, 27) ein Herz und eine Seele.
Genau von dieser Beziehung zwischen Ben und Simpel lebt der Film.
Vor allem Sch√ºles Rolle bildet mit ihrer eigenen Familiengeschichte den Gegensatz zu Simpel und Ben.
F√ºr die Handlung an sich h√§tte es diese Episode im Film nicht unbedingt gebraucht, doch witzig anzusehen ist die Begegnung zwischen Simpel und Chantal allemal.
Markus Goller ist ein warmherziger Film gelungen, der ein bisschen den Glauben an das Gute im Menschen und an das deutsche Kino zur√ºckbringt.
TEXT:
Deutsches Kino kann mehr als derbe Witze √† la "Fack ju G√∂hte". Das beweist der neue Film von Regisseur Markus Goller (48, "Friendship", "Frau Ella"). Basierend auf dem gleichnamigen franz√∂sischen Roman von Marie-Aude Murail (63) startet "Simpel" am 9. November in den deutschen Kinos. Es ist die Geschichte eines ungleichen Br√ºderpaars, das lernen muss, auf eigenen Beinen zu stehen... Der Weg dorthin ist am√ºsant und voller √úberraschungen.

Hier k√∂nnen Sie den Roman zum Film "Simpel" bestellen

Die Geschichte von Simpel und Ben

Seit Ben (Frederick Lau, 28) denken kann, sind er und sein Bruder Barnabas alias Simpel (David Kross, 27) ein Herz und eine Seele. Simpel ist 22 Jahre alt, aber geistig auf dem Stand eines Kindes. Quasilorten (Erdbeeren) sind sein Lieblingsessen und drau√üen im Watt entdeckt er mit seinem Stofftier Monsieur Hasehase neue Kontinente. Simpel ist anders und oft anstrengend, aber ein Leben ohne ihn ist f√ºr Ben unvorstellbar. Als ihre Mutter unerwartet stirbt, soll Simpel in ein Heim eingewiesen werden.

Die einzige Person, die diesen Beschluss r√ºckg√§ngig machen k√∂nnte, ist der Vater der beiden Jungs. Doch zu David (Devid Striesow, 44) haben die Br√ºder seit 15 Jahren keinen Kontakt mehr. Die Suche nach ihm entwickelt sich zu einer turbulenten Odyssee, bei der Simpel und Ben unter anderem auf die Medizinstudentin Aria (Emilia Sch√ºle, 24) und ihren Kumpel, den Sanit√§ter Enzo (Axel Stein, 35) treffen. Am Ende muss Ben ganz alleine die schwerste Entscheidung seines Lebens treffen...

"Stell dir vor, die ganze Welt w√§re wie Simpel und Ben..."

Der 113 Minuten lange Film "Simpel" ist ein herzergreifendes Roadmovie geworden. Mit zwei sehr unterschiedlichen Menschen in den Hauptrollen, deren St√§rke es ist, immer f√ºreinander da zu sein. Genau von dieser Beziehung zwischen Ben und Simpel lebt der Film. Frederick Lau und David Kross haben keinerlei Ber√ºhrungs√§ngste, sodass man ihnen ohne jeden Zweifel abnimmt, dass sie Br√ºder sind. Die Rollen scheinen perfekt auf die beiden Schauspieler zugeschnitten worden zu sein.

Gar nicht so simpel: David Kross und seine Rolle

W√§hrend Frederick Lau auf seine unverwechselbare Art den eher zur√ºckhaltenden, f√ºrsorglichen Bruder spielt, der sein eigenes Leben Simpel zuliebe hintenanstellt und sich erst im Laufe des Film seiner eigenen Bed√ºrfnisse bewusst wird, merkt man wie intensiv sich David Kross auf seine Rolle als geistig behinderter Mitte Zwanzigj√§hriger vorbereitet haben muss. Keine Sekunde zweifelt man im Kinosessel an der Echtheit seiner Darstellung - seine Gestik und Mimik, seine Aussprache, alles wirkt authentisch und keinesfalls √ºberzogen.

F√ºr nette Abwechslung sorgen die Auftritte von Emilia Sch√ºle als ruppige Medizinstudentin Aria und ihrem Kumpel Enzo, gespielt von Axel Stein. Vor allem Sch√ºles Rolle bildet mit ihrer eigenen Familiengeschichte den Gegensatz zu Simpel und Ben. Die Differenzen zwischen Aria und Ben sorgen f√ºr Turbulenzen, machen den Film aber ein klein wenig spannender. Einen kurzen Gastauftritt absolviert au√üerdem Annette Frier (43) als Hamburger Prostituierte. F√ºr die Handlung an sich h√§tte es diese Episode im Film nicht unbedingt gebraucht, doch witzig anzusehen ist die Begegnung zwischen Simpel und Chantal allemal.

Die Handlung weist an einigen Stellen Schw√§chen auf und deckt sich nur in Teilen mit der mehrfach ausgezeichneten Buchvorlage. Doch trotzdem funktioniert "Simpel" auf seine ganz eigene Art und Weise. Das liegt vor allem an der hochkar√§tigen Schauspieler-Besetzung, die Markus Goller f√ºr sein Wunsch-Projekt gewinnen konnte. Denn dass der Regisseur f√ºr die Romanverfilmung brennt, merkt man dem ungew√∂hnlichen Roadmovie an. Die Botschaft des Film ist klar: Begegne anderen Menschen ohne Vorurteile.

Fazit

F√ºr "Simpel" lohnt sich ein Kinobesuch. Das hat der Film ganz klar seinen beiden Hauptdarstellern Frederick Lau und David Kross zu verdanken. Reine Situationskomik macht die Geschichte am√ºsant, ohne sie ins L√§cherliche zu ziehen. Markus Goller ist ein warmherziger Film gelungen, der ein bisschen den Glauben an das Gute im Menschen und an das deutsche Kino zur√ºckbringt.
TITLE: Darum geht es im neuen Kinofilm "Simpel"

SUMMARY:
"The challenge in learning a second language is the fact that you have a first language," Kidd said.
"Part of that is you are coming to your second language with knowledge of your first language."
"I guess what the one distinction between a first language and second language is that first language acquisition is really implicit and a second language can be more explicit."
The explicit nature of learning a second language means that we are very aware of how much energy and dedication it takes to be able to speak any language well.
"Let's face it, there is nothing more humbling than learning a second language and using it because you just revert to [being] a two-year-old."
TEXT:
Learning a second language is no easy task.

A lot of time and dedication is required, plus there is a significant amount of memorising of words and phrases. And even once you've learnt those, it takes both skill and confidence to use them in a real-life setting.

Well, Associate Professor Evan Kidd from the ARC Centre of Excellence for the Dynamics of Language says that anyone can learn a new language as long as they put enough time into the process.

"I think that almost anyone, if they give it a good enough shot, is going to have some abilities in a language with enough exposure and time," Kidd told HuffPost Australia.

According to Kidd, one of the biggest challenges adults face when learning a new language is approaching it with the knowledge of their mother tongue. Our brains are finely tuned to our first language and so we approach any new linguistic situation within the framework of that first language.

"The challenge in learning a second language is the fact that you have a first language," Kidd said. "Part of that is you are coming to your second language with knowledge of your first language."

So, what are some ways that we can make the language-learning process easier?

Three ways to make learning a new language easier Use stock phrases Learning a few generic and adaptable phrases in a new language can make it easier to use and also give you a template to build other terms using that same formula. "It's good to have a few stock phrases because then you can start strapping off from those so you can say -- 'OK I have got this phrase and I can put different verbs in it and different nouns in it', which is actually how young kids tend to learn," Kidd said. Memorise When you first start out, learning the basic grammar and vocabulary of any language is going to require time to create a solid linguistic foundation. This means a lot of dedication to learning the words and making an effort to remember those through practice. "Inevitably, there are going to be instances where you are just going to need to memorise the rule because, let's face it, languages are weird entities." Actually speak the language Kidd said that in his experience, one of the most important things when learning a new language is making the effort to use it as much as possible. "It's all fine and good to sit there and learn it and then do in a class, but you really have to talk and I think by virtue of talking that's when you really start to get much more sense that this is a communicative system and you really want to use that to communicate." "[It's a] combination between memorisation and a little bit of 'extraversion' and having a go."

Children are exposed to languages at a very young age, even from the time they are in the womb. The process of acquiring language begins with sounds and language rhythms and eventually builds up to words and sentences.

"One of the cool things about infants when they are born is they have the ability to perceive the difference between any sound that the human vocal tract can make, and the thing is that any one language will only use a subset of those sounds," Kidd said.

An interesting example of how this works can be found when the English and Japanese languages are compared.

"In English we have a distinction between the 'R' sound and the 'L' sound but in Japanese they don't have that distinction -- they've got one which is between these two sounds," Kidd explained.

"So, what happens when a Japanese infant is born is that they can distinguish between the 'R' and 'L' sounds but once they get to about 12 months they can't do it anymore and that is because their language doesn't have it."

Children under 12 months can identify every sound a human voice tract can make.

As humans lose this ability around the age of 12 months, we become unable to accurately distinguish some sounds that our mother tongue doesn't use. It's in this way that learning a first and a second language is fundamentally different.

Most of us can't remember learning our first language because it was effortless and occurred over a long period of time, but acquiring that second one requires a lot of hard work.

"I guess what the one distinction between a first language and second language is that first language acquisition is really implicit and a second language can be more explicit."

The explicit nature of learning a second language means that we are very aware of how much energy and dedication it takes to be able to speak any language well. Kidd says that being as confident as possible with another language could be the gateway to your success.

"Let's face it, there is nothing more humbling than learning a second language and using it because you just revert to [being] a two-year-old."
TITLE: Three Tips To Make Learning A Second Language Easier

TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

SONEBHADRA -- A German national was allegedly beaten by a railway contractor at the Robertsganj railway station in the district, police said today.

The incident comes days after a Swiss couple were attacked near the railway station at Agra's Fatehpur Sikri.

Holger Ereek was allegedly beaten by railway contractor Aman Kumar yesterday after which the station master informed the police.

Circle officer Vivekanand Tiwari said that the accused has been arrested.

However, the railway contractor alleged that when he greeted Ereek by saying "welcome to India", he hit him.

The victim refused to talk to the media.

On October 22, the Swiss couple from Lausanne in Switzerland, Quentin Jeremy Clerc (24) and his girlfriend Marie Droz (24), was chased and attacked with stones and sticks by a group of five youths in Fatehpur Sikri, triggering widespread outrage.

The couple was quoted as saying in a media report that they were strolling near the station at Fatehpur Sikri after a day in Agra when a group of youths started following them and later attacked.

The couple said as they lay on the ground bloodied and bruised, bystanders began taking videos of them on their mobile phones, the report said.

All the accused were arrested.

External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj had sought a report from the UP government on the attack.

Union Minister of State for Tourism K J Alphons had dashed off a letter to Yogi Adityanath, saying the incident could have a negative impact on the image of the country.

Uttar Pradesh Director General of Police Sulkhan Singh had issued a list of guidelines, including deployment of policemen in plain clothes, more patrolling and installation of CCTV cameras, to prevent such incidents.

The couple were also offered a free stay in 5-star hotel in the national capital as a "token of concern" by Alphons.
TITLE: After Attack On Swiss Couple, German Man Allegedly Assaulted In UP

SUMMARY:
If you're a fan of the royals, you've likely fantasized about what it's like to attend a royal wedding.
Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge on their wedding day, April 29, 2011.
You know when you're there that you're watching history unfold in front of your eyes."
"If you like people watching there's probably nothing better than a royal wedding.
Elton John (C) and partner David Furnish (L) attend the wedding service for Britain's Prince William and Kate Middleton.
TEXT:
If you're a fan of the royals, you've likely fantasized about what it's like to attend a royal wedding. And now that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's inevitable engagement looms near, your fantasies have likely kicked into overdrive.

But while we can only imagine what it's like to be a wedding guest, journalist Duncan Larcombe knows first-hand how glamourous the affair actually is.

Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge on their wedding day, April 29, 2011.

While we were glued to our TV screens watching Kate Middleton and Prince William get hitched in April 2011, Larcombe was actually among the 1,900 people at the service in Westminster Abbey.

The former royal editor of The Sun was one of six journalists who attended the nuptials. "We were told in advance about two or three weeks before that we were invited, but we were told not to tell anybody," he told Elle U.K. in a recent interview. "They wouldn't have wanted word to get out amongst other journalists."

It's a very weird experience, kind of like sitting in Madame Tussauds with moving waxwork.

So what was it like being among so many royals at the ceremony? According to Larcombe, it was just as surreal as we imagine.

"It's a very weird experience, kind of like sitting in Madame Tussauds with moving waxwork," he said. "It was one of the most incredible experiences of my life. You know when you're there that you're watching history unfold in front of your eyes."

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge kissing on the balcony at Buckingham Palace.

"It's not like any wedding I've ever been to," he added. "If you like people watching there's probably nothing better than a royal wedding. There isn't a room that has that many famous and royal people all under one roof."

Larcombe also got to witness candid moments among the royals, including Prince William trying to compose himself beside brother Prince Harry before the ceremony ("[He] looked absolutely terrified"), and when complete silence filled the church when the Duchess of Cambridge finally arrived.

"All we could hear was the echoes of the crowds outside," he said.

Crowds gather on the mall prior to the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton.

While Larcombe admitted that there was a lot of waiting around for the nuptials to begin, the event was well worth it. Not only did he get to see history in the making, but he revealed that every guest was treated as an equal ‚Äî no matter how famous (or not famous) they were.

"It was quite clear at the wedding that no matter if you were the Sultan of Brunei or a guy who's been at Sandhurst with William, or a big Hollywood star, everyone got there early," he explained, noting that the Queen was the last to arrive and then the bride. "I think for someone like Sir Elton John, who is normally one to be the centre of attention, it was probably quite humbling."

Elton John (C) and partner David Furnish (L) attend the wedding service for Britain's Prince William and Kate Middleton.

Although there's much excitement over Prince Harry's possible engagement and wedding, his nuptials will likely be very different from his brother's, considering Harry is fifth-in-line (sixth-in-line when William and Catherine's third child arrives) to the throne and William is second. This means his and Markle's wedding will likely be more informal.

Keep Up With The Royals

Get our weekly email round-up of all things Royal.



Last month, a source close to Harry told Us Weekly that a low-key wedding is more his style.

"Pomp and pageantry is the last thing he would want," the insider told the site. "I can see him wanting to get married at St. George's Chapel at Windsor Castle. It would stop it from turning into a total media circus and give the day a sense of privacy that Harry so badly craves."

Only time will tell what Harry's wedding will actually be like. Here's hoping our invites don't get lost in the mail!

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: British Journalist Reveals What It's Like To Attend A Royal Wedding

TEXT:
La actriz Julianna Margulies, de 51 a√±os, ha a√±adido sus desagradables experiencias con Harvey Weinstein y Steven Seagal al aluvi√≥n de acusaciones de acoso y abuso sexual que est√° sacudiendo Hollywood.

En una entrevista el viernes en la emisora SiriusXM, la protagonista de The Good Wife habl√≥ sobre dos encuentros con Seagal y Weinstein en los inicios de su carrera.

Margulies cont√≥ que cuando ten√≠a 23 a√±os una directora de casting la envi√≥ a ver a Seagal a las diez de la noche para leer una escena. La directora obvi√≥ las objeciones de la actriz ofreci√©ndole pagarle el taxi y prometi√©ndole que estar√≠a presente. Sin embargo, cuando Margulies lleg√≥, se encontr√≥ a solas con la estrella de las pel√≠culas de acci√≥n.

"Me la jug√≥", dijo Margulies sobre la mujer que organiz√≥ la audici√≥n. El encuentro con Seagal pronto se volvi√≥ amenazante, record√≥ la actriz. "Se asegur√≥ de que viera su pistola. Nunca hab√≠a visto una en la vida real", confes√≥. "Sal√≠ ilesa de all√≠... no s√© c√≥mo consegu√≠ salir de la habitaci√≥n de ese hotel".

Seg√∫n relat√≥, Seagal intent√≥ convertir la supuesta audici√≥n en un encuentro sexual mediante una pr√°ctica de la que tambi√©n se acusa a Weinstein. "Siempre comienza con un 'soy un sanador, quiero darte un masaje", asegur√≥.

Varios a√±os despu√©s, en 1996, a Margulies la invitaron a conocer a Weinstein. Cont√≥ que una mujer la llev√≥ a su hotel, prometi√©ndole que si hablaba con el productor conseguir√≠a una prueba de pantalla para un papel potencialmente ganador de premios en una gran pel√≠cula. Tras su encuentro con Seagal, Margulies fue cauta.

"Dije: 'No voy a subir all√≠ sola', por la experiencia con Seagal y porque ten√≠a una carrera", asegur√≥ la actriz, que por aquel entonces participaba en la serie E.R.

Despu√©s de que Margulies insistiera en que se ir√≠a a su casa si la otra mujer no la acompa√±aba, las dos entraron juntas en la habitaci√≥n de Weinstein.

"Abri√≥ la puerta en bata", record√≥. "Pude ver que hab√≠a velas encendidas en la habitaci√≥n y cena para dos. Y vi que se qued√≥ mir√°ndola, fulmin√°ndola". Margulies se gir√≥ hacia la otra mujer y la pill√≥ encogi√©ndose de hombros "en plan: '¬øQu√© pod√≠a hacer?".

Seg√∫n la int√©rprete, Weinstein parec√≠a furioso y le espet√≥: "S√≥lo quer√≠a decirte que buena audici√≥n". Despu√©s, dio un portazo. No le dieron el papel.

Margulies forma parte de la lista de medio centenar de mujeres que han acusado a Weinstein de comportamientos sexuales inadecuados, con acusaciones que van desde el intento de acoso hasta la violaci√≥n. Tras dos exclusivas de The New York Times y The New Yorker y el testimonio de numerosas mujeres, Weinstein fue despedido de su propia productora, The Weinstein Company, y fue expulsado de la Academia de Hollywood. La polic√≠a de Los √Ångeles y de Londres est√°n investigando acusaciones de violaci√≥n contra √©l. El viernes, la polic√≠a de Nueva York confirm√≥ que ha reunido evidencias de "una acusaci√≥n de violaci√≥n cre√≠ble", que podr√≠a conducir a su arresto.

Seagal ya hab√≠a sido acusado tambi√©n de conductas inapropiadas. En 1998, la actriz Jenny McCarthy asegur√≥ que se hab√≠a marchado angustiada de una audici√≥n despu√©s de que el actor insistiera repetidamente en que se desnudara. En 2010 fue demandado por acoso sexual por una exasistente que afirmaba que la hab√≠a usado como "juguete sexual". La demanda fue retirada m√°s tarde. En octubre de este a√±o la actriz Lisa Guerrero cont√≥ que hab√≠a recibido presiones para hacer una audici√≥n a solas en casa de Seagal para un papel en la pel√≠cula de 1997 Infierno bajo tierra.

Durante la entrevista del viernes, Margulies asegur√≥ que la reciente ola de acusaciones p√∫blicas hizo que se diera cuenta de que "hab√≠a guardado lo barrido debajo de la alfombra. Te encoges de hombros porque es Hollywood".

Tambi√©n se√±al√≥ el papel de algunas mujeres a la hora de permitir ese comportamiento depredador de algunos hombres, como el de las mujeres de la industria que la condujeron a esas situaciones.

"Tenemos que empezar a responsabilizar a esas personas", afirm√≥. "Esas mujeres me llevaron a la guarida del le√≥n".

Este art√≠culo fue originalmente publicado en la edici√≥n estadounidense del 'HuffPost' y ha sido traducido del ingl√©s.
TITLE: Julianna Margulies asegura que Steven Seagal y Harvey Weinstein intentaron acosarla

TEXT:
M√âDIAS - Elle ne leur parle plus mais leur a pardonn√©. Flavie Flament √©tait sur le plateau de "C √† Vous" ce mardi 7 novembre pour la diffusion du t√©l√©film "La consolation", une fiction librement inspir√©e de son livre. Elle y a √©voqu√© sa relation avec ses parents, comme vous pouvez le voir dans notre vid√©o ci-dessus, et selon ses mots, elle est d√©sormais apais√©e.

"J'ai un regard, aujourd'hui, qui est tr√®s en paix et une forme d'indulgence n√©cessaire", a-t-elle poursuivi en ajoutant "je ne peux pas vivre avec cette id√©e permanente". L'ann√©e derni√®re, leur relation √©tait houleuse. Dans son livre, Flavie Flament a bris√© treize ans de silence en racontant son viol. Sur le coup, ses parents ne la croient pas. Et sa m√®re lui conseille un m√©decin "pour trouver un bon traitement".

"On est dans l'illustration formidable et pitoyable du d√©ni familial", expliquait-elle alors dans "Th√© ou Caf√©".

SUMMARY:
Die Zahlen zeigen: Die Bilanz, die Angela Merkel als Klimakanzlerin vorzuweisen hat, ist rabenschwarz.
‚û® Mehr zum Thema: Klimaschutz: Wer nicht mitmacht, den bestraft das LebenDoch nachdem sich die Ministerpr√§sidenten von Sachsen, Brandenburg und Sachsen-Anhalt und ranghohe Parteimitglieder gegen den Plan aussprachen, beerdigte Merkel die Idee.
Im Sommerinterview hatte sie erkl√§rt, man k√∂nne einen Braunkohleausstieg ‚Äúins Auge fassen‚Äù, wenn es Pl√§ne f√ºr die Zukunft der Besch√§ftigten in der Kohleindustrie gebe.
Sicher ist: Die Kohleenergie muss fr√ºher oder sp√§ter ohnehin aus dem Energiemix verschwinden.
Aber damit blockiert die Kohle die Netze f√ºr Wind- und Solarstrom, denn Kohlekraftwerke k√∂nnen die Produktion nur langsam drosseln.
TEXT:
Angela Merkel inszeniert sich als Klimasch√ºtzerin

Doch in ihrer Amtszeit hat Deutschland kaum Fortschritte beim Klimaschutz gemacht

Das zeigt sich vor allem bei der Kohleenergie

Angela Merkels wohl gr√∂√ütes Versagen l√§sst sich auf die Tonne genau messen.

Als die ehemalige Bundesumweltministerin 2005 ins Kanzleramt einzog, stie√ü Deutschland 992 Millionen Tonnen klimasch√§dliches Kohlendioxid (CO2) aus. 2015 waren es 902 Millionen Tonnen. Der Aussto√ü m√ºsste aber viel schneller sinken, wenn Deutschland sein offizielles Klimaziel von 751 Millionen Tonnen im Jahr 2020 noch schaffen will, kritisieren Experten.

Die Zahlen zeigen: Die Bilanz, die Angela Merkel als Klimakanzlerin vorzuweisen hat, ist rabenschwarz.

Und das obwohl Deutschland weltweit als eine Art √ñko-Primus angesehen wird. Die Wahrheit, das zeigt sich zum Start der 23. Weltklimakonferenz in Bonn, sieht anders aus.

‚ÄúTrump ist wenigstens ehrlich‚Äù

Wegen ihrer gescheiterten Klimapolitik vergleicht ‚ÄúDie Zeit‚Äù Merkel gar mit Donald Trump. ‚ÄúMerkel betreibt eine klimafeindliche Politik‚Äù, urteilt die Wochenzeitung.

Aber im Gegensatz zur Kanzlerin sei der US-Pr√§sident wenigstens ehrlich und zeige offen, dass ihm das Klima egal ist.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: "Deutschland hat ein schmutziges Geheimnis": TV-Sender CNN macht Merkel schwere Vorw√ºrfe

Gr√ºnde f√ºr Deutschlands Versagen beim Klimaschutz gibt es viele: Die schleppende Verkehrswende, das gedrosselte Tempo beim Ausbau der erneuerbaren Energien, die Stagnation beim Umbau der W√§rmeversorgung.

Aber das Scheitern der Kanzlerin wird nirgendwo deutlicher als im Bereich der Kohleenergie.

Zum Hintergrund:

‚ñ∫ In Deutschland stehen die schmutzigsten Kohlemeiler Europas.

‚ñ∫ Fast die H√§lfte des klimasch√§dlichen CO2-Aussto√ües in Deutschland geht auf das Konto des Energiesektors.

‚ñ∫ Im Energiesektor verursachen Kohlekraftwerke wiederum den Gro√üteil der Klimagase.

‚ñ∫ Deutschland f√∂rdert mehr der besonders schmutzigen Braunkohle als jede andere Land der Welt (China und Indien f√∂rdern vor allem Steinkohle).

Angela Merkel kennt all diese Zahlen. Und als Physikerin wei√ü sie zu gut, was Kohlekraftwerke mit dem Klima anrichten. Aber ebenso wie schmutzige Dieselautos stellt die Kanzlerin die Kohle unter Artenschutz.

Die Frage ist: Warum? Die wahrscheinlichste Antwort lautet: Weil sich daraus bisher politisch kein Kapital schlagen l√§sst.

Kohleausstieg wird in einer Jamaika-Koalition kaum zu machen sein

Im Jahr 2010 blockierte Merkel ein fr√ºhzeitiges Ende der Subventionen f√ºr deutsche Kohlekraftwerke, die die EU durchsetzen wollte.

2013 hie√ü es im Koalitionsvertrag noch, dass die Kohleverbrennung ‚Äúauf absehbare Zeit unverzichtbar‚Äù sei. Dann versuchte Merkel sich an einer Kohlewende - die sie aber nie durchzog.

Im Fr√ºhjahr 2015 hatte die Kanzlerin noch Zustimmung f√ºr einen langsamen Kohleausstieg in Deutschland signalisiert - organisieren wollte ihn ihr damaliger Wirtschaftsminister Sigmar Gabriel (SPD).

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: Klimaschutz: Wer nicht mitmacht, den bestraft das Leben

Doch nachdem sich die Ministerpr√§sidenten von Sachsen, Brandenburg und Sachsen-Anhalt und ranghohe Parteimitglieder gegen den Plan aussprachen, beerdigte Merkel die Idee.

Zwar hatte die Kanzlerin auch im Wahlkampf vorsichtige Zustimmung zu einem Ausstieg aus der Braunkohle signalisiert. Im Sommerinterview hatte sie erkl√§rt, man k√∂nne einen Braunkohleausstieg ‚Äúins Auge fassen‚Äù, wenn es Pl√§ne f√ºr die Zukunft der Besch√§ftigten in der Kohleindustrie gebe.

Doch f√ºr einen Kohleausstieg k√§mpfen nun die Gr√ºnen in den Jamaika-Verhandlungen allein. Von einer Unterst√ºtzung der Kanzlerin f√ºr ihre Pl√§ne ist bisher nichts an die √ñffentlichkeit gedrungen. An der Frage des Klimaschutzes drohen nun sogar die Verhandlungen f√ºr eine Jamaika-Koalition zu scheitern.

Dabei dr√§ngt die Zeit. Denn je l√§nger die schmutzigen Kohlekraftwerke am Netz sind, desto schwieriger wird es f√ºr Deutschland, seine Klimaziele zu erreichen.

Sogar China verabschiedet sich von der Kohle

Und w√§hrend Deutschland noch z√∂gert, gehen andere L√§nder voran.

Unter anderem haben Norwegen und Gro√übritannien den vollst√§ndigen Kohleausstieg beschlossen. Selbst Kohlegro√üverbraucher wie Indien und China haben zuletzt die Kraftwerks√∂fen gedrosselt.

China schickt sich an, bei der Kohlepolitik sogar zum Vorbild zu werden: 1,3 Millionen Jobs sollen in dem Sektor in den kommenden Jahren laut der Regierung wegfallen. Neue Arbeitspl√§tze sollen daf√ºr im Bereich der erneuerbaren Energien entstehen. Schon jetzt arbeiten rund 2,5 Millionen Menschen in der chinesischen Solarindustrie.

In Deutschland gehen Arbeitspl√§tze bei den Erneuerbaren verloren

In Deutschland verl√§uft die Entwicklung genau umgekehrt. 2015 waren rund 330.000 Menschen direkt oder indirekt durch den Ausbau der erneuerbaren Energien besch√§ftigt. Die Zahl sank aber zuletzt deutlich.

Im Vergleich dazu sind die Besch√§ftigtenzahlen in der Kohleindustrie gering. Je nachdem auf welche Statistik man blickt, besch√§ftigt die Braunkohleindustrie in Deutschland direkt und indirekt zwischen 20.000 und 50.000 Menschen. Im Bereich der Steinkohle sind in Deutschland gerade einmal noch rund 7500 Menschen besch√§ftigt.

Sicher ist: Die Kohleenergie muss fr√ºher oder sp√§ter ohnehin aus dem Energiemix verschwinden. Warum dann nicht mit dem Ausstieg jetzt schon beginnen und Angestellte langsam umschulen und in anderen Bereich unterbringen?

Deutsche sind mehrheitlich f√ºr Kohleausstieg

Merkels Z√∂gern beim Kohleausstieg ist inzwischen sogar zu einem Hemmnis f√ºr die Energiewende an sich geworden, einst ein Vorzeigeprojekt Deutschlands: Es macht die Energiewende komplizierter und teurer als n√∂tig.

Denn Kohlekraftwerke und vergleichsweise saubere Energielieferanten vertragen sich schlecht. Vereinfacht gesagt: Kohlekraftwerke produzieren kontinuierlich Strom. Das klingt erst einmal gut. Aber damit blockiert die Kohle die Netze f√ºr Wind- und Solarstrom, denn Kohlekraftwerke k√∂nnen die Produktion nur langsam drosseln.

Geeigneter um im Verbund mit Wind und Sonne Strom zu liefern sind dynamische Gaskraftwerke.

Die Folge: Solange viele Kohlekraftwerke am Netz sind, muss der Umbau des Energiesystems zu einer sauberen Versorgung gedrosselt werden. Deutschland verspielt damit die Chance wenigstens nach 2020 seine Klimaziele zu erreichen.

Und noch ein weiteres Argument der Kohlebef√ºrworter z√§hlt nicht: Der Preis. Inzwischen ist Strom aus Windr√§dern √§hnlich g√ºnstig wie Strom aus Kohlekraftwerken. In den kommenden Jahren wird Windstrom sogar billiger als schmutziger Kohlestrom.

Ein Plan f√ºr den Ausstieg aus der Kohle ist also aus mehreren Gr√ºnden l√§ngst √ºberf√§llig. Das findet auch eine Mehrheit der Deutschen. Nach einer Emnid-Umfrage f√ºr die ‚ÄúBild am Sonntag‚Äù sind 59 Prozent der Deutschen daf√ºr, dass die n√§chste Bundesregierung den Kohleausstieg beschlie√üt, und 31 Prozent dagegen.

Eigentlich ist Angela Merkel bekannt daf√ºr ihre Entscheidungen stark an Umfragen zu orientieren. Beim Kohleausstieg ist davon allerdings noch nichts zu merken.

(lp)
TITLE: Rabenschwarze Bilanz: Wie Angela Merkel beim Klimaschutz versagt hat

TEXT:
Sia does not have time for anyone‚Äôs nonsense.

The singer released a nude photo of herself on Twitter on Monday after seeing that someone was attempting to sell the picture to her fans. Sia clearly was not aware of the photo being taken, as it was taken from afar and with her back to the camera.

Sia released a screenshot of the ‚Äúclient preview‚Äù watermarked photo along with the seller‚Äôs (poorly written) offer.

‚ÄúIf you make the purchase it will be unblurred and you receive and additional 14 images,‚Äù the message reads.

Not one to let her fans get swindled, Sia just posted the photo herself for her fans.

‚ÄúSomeone is apparently trying to sell naked photos of me to my fans,‚Äù Sia wrote. ‚ÄúSave your money, here it is for free. Everyday is Christmas!‚Äù

HuffPost is displaying only a portion of Sia‚Äôs NSFW tweet.
TITLE: Sia Releases A Nude Photo Of Herself Before A Creep Can Sell It

Plus de 300 professeurs n'enseigneront plus que le masculin l'emporte sur le f√©mininF√âMINISME - "Pourquoi [les femmes] n'accepteraient pas de gagner moins que leurs coll√®gues (...) s'il est admis au plus haut niveau que 'le masculin l'emporte sur le f√©minin'?"
"Le masculin est r√©put√© plus noble que le f√©minin √† cause de la sup√©riorit√© du m√¢le sur la femelle", √©crivait ainsi Beauz√©e dans sa "Grammaire G√©n√©rale" publi√©e en 1767.
Ainsi, plut√¥t que d'√©crire "les ma√Ætres et les ma√Ætresses engag√©s", il faudrait √©crire "les ma√Ætres et les ma√Ætresses engag√©es".
Par exemple, on pourrait √©crire "les ma√Ætre.sse.s", √† la place de "les ma√Ætres et les ma√Ætresses".
@LesNNews s'engagent avec @Slatefr √† ne plus appliquer la r√®gle du masculin qui l'emporte sur le f√©minin.
TEXT:
Plus de 300 professeurs n'enseigneront plus que le masculin l'emporte sur le f√©minin

F√âMINISME - "Pourquoi [les femmes] n'accepteraient pas de gagner moins que leurs coll√®gues (...) s'il est admis au plus haut niveau que 'le masculin l'emporte sur le f√©minin'?" C'est avec cette interrogation √† l'esprit que 314 enseignants et enseignantes ont sign√© une tribune sur le site d'information Slate, ce mardi 7 novembre.

Ils y d√©clarent "avoir cess√© ou nous appr√™ter √† cesser d'enseigner la r√®gle de grammaire r√©sum√©e par la formule 'le masculin l'emporte sur le f√©minin'", et appellent chacun √† en faire autant, notamment les autres enseignants, les professionnels de la presse et de l'√©dition, les √©crivains...

Pour ces signataires, la r√©p√©tition de cette formule √† l'√©cole "induit des repr√©sentations mentales qui conduisent femmes et hommes √† accepter la domination d'un sexe sur l'autre".

Elle est d'autant plus ill√©gitime √† leurs yeux qu'elle n'a √©t√© cr√©√©e que r√©cemment dans l'histoire de la langue fran√ßaise. "Elle a √©t√© mise au point au XVIIe si√®cle", rappellent ces enseignants, qui indiquent par ailleurs qu'elle a √©t√© par la suite g√©n√©ralis√©e pour des raisons "politiques".

Ils citent ainsi les d√©fenseurs de cette r√©forme de la langue, qui assumaient de d√©fendre un masculin "plus noble". "Le masculin est r√©put√© plus noble que le f√©minin √† cause de la sup√©riorit√© du m√¢le sur la femelle", √©crivait ainsi Beauz√©e dans sa "Grammaire G√©n√©rale" publi√©e en 1767.

Pour certains grammairiens, au contraire, le masculin serait "utilis√© comme la marque du neutre" en fran√ßais. C'est ce qu'expliquait au moins d'octobre le grammairien Antoine Gautier, ma√Ætre de conf√©rence en langue fran√ßaise √† l'universit√© Paris-Sorbonne, dans le Figaro. Pour lui, c'est la formulation de la r√®gle qui serait "malheureuse", et qui devrait √™tre modifi√©e. "Beaucoup de filles le prennent mal, et √ßa se comprend", justifiait-il.

Des accords de proximit√©, de majorit√© ou au choix

Les signataires de la tribune proposent comme solution de revenir aux r√®gles qui pr√©valaient alors √† l'√©poque, h√©rit√©es du latin. "Nous d√©clarons enseigner la r√®gle de proximit√©", indiquent-ils par exemple,qui consiste √† accorder les mots concern√©s avec le terme le plus proche. Ainsi, plut√¥t que d'√©crire "les ma√Ætres et les ma√Ætresses engag√©s", il faudrait √©crire "les ma√Ætres et les ma√Ætresses engag√©es".

D'autres solutions existent, indiquent-ils, comme un accord "de majorit√©" -s'il y a plus de femmes, on accorde au f√©minin- ou plus simplement un accord "au choix".

Cette prise de position intervient alors que l'√©criture inclusive fait d√©bat, depuis la publication du premier manuel scolaire √† l'avoir adopt√©e. Ce mode d'√©criture vise √† f√©miniser d'avantage la grammaire, comme le recommandait en 2015 le Haut Conseil √† l'√âgalit√© entre les Hommes et les Femmes. Cela peut passer par l'int√©gration de la terminaison du f√©minin entre des points, quand c'est n√©cessaire. Par exemple, on pourrait √©crire "les ma√Ætre.sse.s", √† la place de "les ma√Ætres et les ma√Ætresses".

Ces propositions avaient choqu√© les Immortels de l'Acad√©mie Fran√ßaise, qui avaient d√©nonc√© √† la fin du mois d'octobre un "p√©ril mortel" pour la langue fran√ßaise.

Apr√®s avoir publi√© cette tribune, Slate a annonc√© adopter √©galement cette r√®gle de l'accord de proximit√©. "La r√©daction va revenir √† une r√®gle plus juste issue du latin et appliqu√©e en leurs temps par Corneille et Ronsard", informe le site, qui dit d√©fendre "une langue plus inclusive, sans impact pour les plus conservateurs de nos internautes et bien plus √©quitable".

Dans la foul√©e, le site Les Nouvelles News a indiqu√© √† son tour adopter cette r√®gle grammaticale.

.@LesNNews s'engagent avec @Slatefr √† ne plus appliquer la r√®gle du masculin qui l'emporte sur le f√©minin. Et vous? https://t.co/deyQJ9jRcJ ‚Äî Aude Lorriaux (@audelorriaux) 7 novembre 2017

TITLE: √âcriture inclusive: plus de 300 professeurs refusent d'enseigner que "le masculin l'emporte sur le f√©minin"

SUMMARY:
Try a Kris Kringle to cut down costs.
"Have a Kris Kringle, set a budget and then buy for one family member or a couple or what have you.
Often when you get to a certain age and Christmas comes around, you're thinking 'what else do I want?'
"Buy Christmas paper when it's on sale.
"You may also want to set up some kind of direct debit system that helps you save for Christmas next year.
TEXT:
Okay, so we don't mean to alarm anybody, but if you happen to get paid monthly, you have exactly two paydays left until Christmas rears it's expensive, tinselled head.

Or, to put it another way, there are eight Fridays between now and C-day. Eight.

So while it may be a little too late to start any proper Christmas financial planning, there are still some things you can do to ensure you don't end up spending your entire pay packet at Westfield on Christmas Eve (let's face it, probably on things you don't need and your relatives definitely don't want.)

Here are our top tips.

1. Make a list

No, we're not talking about times when you've been naughty or nice. We're talking about a list of all the things you need to buy. In other words -- no impulse purchases for you!

"Don't do last minute Christmas shopping. It will end up being all impulse buys. Figure out what you need to buy now -- plan it out and set a budget," CEO and founder of JBS Financial Strategists, Jenny Brown, told HuffPost Australia.

"No matter what it is, whether it's Christmas or saving for a holiday, it all comes back to setting a budget and setting a goal to make sure you are going to hit it."

2. Shop online

One of the great things about shopping online is it's so easy to shop around for the best price -- a practice Brown greatly encourages.

"If you know you are going to buy a certain article of clothing or present or whatever it's going to be, search around online," she said.

"It's amazing how much you can save. And if they deliver, have it delivered to your work so you save yourself the hassle of going to the post office to pick things up."

3. Consider a Kris Kringle

If you have a large family, it's well worth considering having a Kris Kringle, whereby participants draw a name out of the hat and just buy a present for that single person.

The great thing about a Kris Kringle (or Secret Santa gift exchange) is that not only does it keep costs down, but it means people are more likely to receive what they actually want rather than a whole bunch of smaller items that will end up in the bottom of a drawer.

Big family? Try a Kris Kringle to cut down costs.

"If you have a situation where there are 13 members in a family, it just becomes ridiculous," Brown said.

"Have a Kris Kringle, set a budget and then buy for one family member or a couple or what have you.

"Alternatively, just buy for the kids. Often when you get to a certain age and Christmas comes around, you're thinking 'what else do I want?' Eliminating the adults and just focusing on the kids can be a great way to bring down costs."

4. Don't use your credit card

This is probably going to be the toughest thing to do this Christmas, but you'll thank yourself next year when your bill isn't out of control.

"Be careful of the credit cards. Don't have the attitude of 'I'll deal with it in January', because then you have to pay it off, and how are you going to do that?" asks Brown.

"If you aren't good with that kind of discipline, use cash only. Get out the amount you're going to spend and shop according to your list. Really plan out what you are going to spend it on.

"Another trick is to freeze your credit card in water in a plastic container. If you want to use it, you'll have to defrost it, which reduces the chance of you impulse buying."

Home-made presents are thoughtful and kind to the bank balance.

5. Get crafty

Who's to say you have to spend a fortune on gifts? Why not embrace your inner hipster and plant some succulents or make some jam?

"That's actually one of the things we've done," Brown said. "I've been growing home made veggies and making things like homemade chutneys and jams.

"It's a lovely thoughtful gift as well as bringing costs right down, especially if you do things like recycle your jars."

6. Prepare for next year

If you want to put yourself in the best possible stead for Christmas 2018, it pays to start planning now.

"It's never too early to start," Brown said. "Buy Christmas paper when it's on sale. You can often get really good deals in January. That goes for cards too.

"You may also want to set up some kind of direct debit system that helps you save for Christmas next year.

"If you start planning ahead, it really does pay off in the long run."
TITLE: How To Avoid Spending Too Much This Christmas

SUMMARY:
The latest search and rescue operation in the stretch of sea separating Libya and Italy highlights some of the brutal treatment that female refugees and migrants are subjected to.
More than 2,560 people were rescued in the Mediterranean Sea over the weekend in one of the roughest missions so far this year, the International Organization for Migration said Tuesday.
Thirty-four bodies were recovered from the water, 26 of them suspected to be teenagers from Nigeria.
IOM believes the girls may have been "murdered by traffickers in league with European sex merchants."
The girls traveled with other men in the dinghy, he said, which makes the theory less likely.
TEXT:
The latest search and rescue operation in the stretch of sea separating Libya and Italy highlights some of the brutal treatment that female refugees and migrants are subjected to.

More than 2,560 people were rescued in the Mediterranean Sea over the weekend in one of the roughest missions so far this year, the International Organization for Migration said Tuesday. Thirty-four bodies were recovered from the water, 26 of them suspected to be teenagers from Nigeria. Most died while making the crossing toward Italy in rubber dinghies.

IOM believes the girls may have been "murdered by traffickers in league with European sex merchants."

Salvatore Malfi, the prefect of the Italian port city of Salerno, was skeptical of this theory but said it's too early to come to any conclusion about whether the girls were headed for prostitution. The girls traveled with other men in the dinghy, he said, which makes the theory less likely.

"The sex trafficking routes are different," he said. "Loading women onto a boat is too risky, the traffickers would not do it as they could lose all their 'goods' ‚Äï as they describe them ‚Äï in one fell swoop."

Italian authorities told CNN that they launched an investigation into the girls' deaths Tuesday, carrying out autopsies to determine whether they had been victims of sexual abuse or torture. They were all between 14 and 18 years old, said Salerno police chief Lorena Ciccotti.
TITLE: Bodies Of 26 Female Teenage Migrants Found In The Mediterranean
