TEXT:
George Bowden/HuffPost UK Universal Credit has led to a surge in the numbers of people needing multiple food parcels from charity, new figures show.

Average foodbank demand in Universal Credit areas climbs 30%

Foodbanks not in Universal Credit areas see 12% increase

Hammersmith and Fulham foodbank sees sharp 94% rise On a street lined with rows of multi-million pound Edwardian houses and Mercedes, Porsches and BMWs, lies the Hammersmith and Fulham Foodbank in South West London. Housed within a church and open twice a week, the foodbank helps hundreds of people a year with emergency parcels. Despite its unlikely location, the wealthy London borough‚Äôs part in the roll out of Universal Credit has seen demand across the area‚Äôs three foodbanks soar by 94%, figures seen by HuffPost UK reveal.

George Bowden/HuffPost UK The Hammersmith and Fulham Foodbank near Parsons Green, South West London, is housed within a church and open two times a week. Demand has surged by 94% since Universal Credit hit the area last year.

Sitting at a table looking at the list of tinned and fresh goods available with her daughter and grand-daughter is Maggie Millard. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been here four times since the beginning of last month,‚Äù the 57-year-old tells HuffPost. ‚ÄúI was moved from [Employment Support Allowance] and onto Universal Credit. As soon as that happened, I just couldn‚Äôt pay the rent. I didn‚Äôt have enough.‚Äù SUBSCRIBE AND FOLLOW UK Get top stories and blog posts emailed to me each day. Newsletters may offer personalized content or advertisements. Learn more Newsletter Please enter a valid email address Thank you for signing up! You should receive an email to confirm your subscription shortly. There was a problem processing your signup; please try again later Facebook

Twitter

Instagram

Podcast

Snapchat

Google+

Pinterest CLOSE Through tears, she explains how the government‚Äôs cap in housing benefit means she does not receive enough Universal Credit to cover the full rent on her council-owned home of 20 years. ‚Ä≥I went into arrears straight away,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúNow they say I‚Äôll have to pay half the rent, but what about money for everything else?‚Äù

George Bowden/HuffPost UK Maggie Millard has been forced to use food banks since moving onto Universal Credit. She's one of dozens of claimants who have been left with no option but to repeatedly seek emergency parcels to feed themselves.

Since moving onto the new benefits regime, which has been rolled out in the borough since June 2016, Maggie has been forced to seek emergency help for basics like food and heating. She‚Äôs been attending the food bank for a month, in which time she has been directed to support from Citizens Advice, who are helping her navigate the myriad of confusing rules Universal Credit imposes. ‚ÄúPeople here have been great, so, so helpful,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúOther places make you feel like you‚Äôve crawled out from a rock.‚Äù

George Bowden/HuffPost UK Food bank manager Daphine Aikens talks to Maggie Millard about her situation on a recent weekday.

‚ÄúThere are so many more Maggies,‚Äù food bank manager Daphine Aikens says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been brutal. Some people have been made to wait 12 weeks. People have nothing.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe had a mum with children, everything stopped when she moved to Universal Credit,‚Äù she adds. ‚ÄúShe had nothing and within two weeks she had no food. The family didn‚Äôt eat one weekend and her child was wandering the streets stealing food from bins.‚Äù

The entire service helped feed 2,364 people in the first half of 2016. The same figure after Universal Credit began, was 4,601

Aikens, who oversees three food banks across the area, revealed that the entire service helped feed 2,364 people in the first half of 2016. The same figure for 2017, after the roll out of Universal Credit began, was 4,601. An increase of around 94%. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been horrendous. The reality is we‚Äôre seeing people who have not eaten for days, who can‚Äôt pay their rent, who are starving, and they‚Äôre borrowing,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWhereas once we‚Äôd see someone in their hour of need once or twice, we see them now multiple times. It‚Äôs so much worse.‚Äù

George Bowden/HuffPost UK The Hammersmith and Fulham foodbank near Parsons Green sits between multi-million pound homes and besides luxury super cars. Those visiting the foodbank have to walk through this street to get there.

The Hammersmith and Fulham service is part of the Trussell Trust foodbank network, which revealed on Tuesday that the average surge in demand across all its centres in Universal Credit full service areas was 30%, when compared with a year ago. Comparative analysis of foodbanks not in full Universal Credit rollout areas showed an average increase of 12%. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre seeing soaring demand at foodbanks across the UK,‚Äù Mark Ward, Interim Chief Executive at The Trussell Trust, says. ‚ÄúThe simple truth is that even with the enormous generosity of our donors and volunteers, we‚Äôre concerned foodbanks could struggle to meet demand this winter if critical changes to benefit delivery aren‚Äôt made now. ‚ÄúPeople cannot be left for weeks without any income, and when that income does come, it must keep pace with living costs ‚Äì foodbanks cannot be relied upon to pick up the pieces.‚Äù

George Bowden/HuffPost UK A sign advertising a wine shop lies on the same street as an estate agent which listed homes for sale at more than ¬£2m. Both are just yards from the Hammersmith and Fulham Foodbank.
TITLE: Universal Credit Prompts 'Horrific' Surge In Foodbank Demand

SUMMARY:
OTTAWA ‚Äî NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh is urging Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to consider decriminalizing all illegal drugs in an effort to combat Canada's escalating opioid crisis.
In his legal practice, Singh said he witnessed first-hand how the current criminal approach is failing.

TEXT:
OTTAWA ‚Äî NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh is urging Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to consider decriminalizing all illegal drugs in an effort to combat Canada's escalating opioid crisis.

Singh, who campaigned on the promise during his party's recent leadership race, said he will push the federal New Democrats to make the position part of its own formal policy platform.

The NDP is scheduled to hold a policy convention in Ottawa in February.

"We have the evidence," Singh said in an interview this week. "Why do we continue down a path that makes no sense?"

Singh, a former criminal defence lawyer, has been vocal about the opioid issue ever since becoming the party's new leader, including during a trip last week to British Columbia, when he paid a visit to an overdose prevention site in Vancouver's Downtown Eastside.

In his legal practice, Singh said he witnessed first-hand how the current criminal approach is failing.

"We are prosecuting people and incarcerating people that don't need to be incarcerated," he said. "These are folks that need to be helped and supported."

The majority of Canadians struggling with opioid addiction are also battling problems like mental health challenges and poverty, Singh said, noting that he would exclude drug trafficking from any decriminalization efforts.

On Saturday, Singh told about 2,000 delegates at the B.C. NDP convention that Canada's drug laws need to change to recognize drug addiction is a social justice issue, not a criminal justice problem.

We have the evidence. Why do we continue down a path that makes no sense? Jagmeet SIngh

His comments come as Canadian health-care experts, including B.C.'s provincial health officer, urge the federal government to strongly consider borrowing from Portugal's approach to drug policy, including decriminalizing personal possession of illicit drugs.

Earlier this year, B.C.'s chief medical officer Perry Kendall said precious time and resources are being spent chasing people around the court system ‚Äî exertions that do nothing to curb the drug supply or prevent drug deaths.

"I think it is incumbent upon us, if we are really serious about trying to deal with this epidemic which is actually killing people, then we need to look at these alternative, regulatory frameworks to see if they might work for us," Kendall said.

It is up to Ottawa to shift its approach, because the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act is a federal law, he added. Portugal did not decriminalize all drugs in all circumstances, but rather removed the application of criminal law on personal possession for limited amounts while offering education and social supports, he said.

'There's so much stigma'

Leila Attar, a 20-year-old advocate who suffered an overdose last November after taking Percocet pills laced with fentanyl, said Tuesday she is pleased leaders like Singh are speaking about decriminalization, even if it's not a "popular opinion."

"There's so much stigma," said Attar, who is channelling her own experiences into helping others at a pop-up injection site in Ottawa.

If Trudeau fails to consider decriminalization, he is turning away from an approach that could save lives, she added.

"It is frustrating," Attar said. "We know there are so many people that are experts ... pushing for the same thing."

Singh, who visited the Ottawa pop-up site in September during his leadership bid, said while social workers and advocates are trying to step up, the government has done nothing so far to stem the tide of tragedy.

"The reason it is happening is because people are dying," Singh said. "It is across this country and what people are doing is they are absolutely filling a void."
TITLE: Jagmeet Singh Pushes Trudeau To Decriminalize All Drugs In Midst Of Opioid Crisis

TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The Haryana Urban Development Authority (HUDA) today said it sold approximately 10-acre plot to Swedish furniture maker IKEA for around Rs 842 crore in its single largest property auction till date.

HUDA sold an approximately 10 acres of commercial land for a whopping Rs 842 crore in Sector 47 of Estate-II of HUDA Gurugram, an official said. The site was put for e-auction on October 6 this year and was bidded on October 31.

"The site was successfully auctioned to IKEA, a multinational group, that designs and sells ready-to-assemble furniture..," J Ganesan, Chief Administrator HUDA, said.

"It will augment our efforts in ensuring steady revenue stream for HUDA. This is not a one-off deal as we have planned out auctions of other institutional and commercial properties across the city in the next few months. Gurugram has seen a reduced demand mainly due to rapidly changing investments scenario in real estate, especially in commercial sector. However, we are hopeful to sell more properties and gather handsome revenue for HUDA from the Estates of Gurugram," an official release quoted Ganesan as saying.

With IKEA marking its arrival in Gurugram, it very well highlights the importance of this city and its position in the global marketplace as a business and investor friendly destination, he said.

The site was put for e-auction three times earlier but had no takers until October 31 when the multinational finally participated and emerged successful.
TITLE: IKEA Buys 10-Acre HUDA Plot In Gurugram For Whopping Rs 842 Crore

SUMMARY:
South Africa and Zimbabwe behave like conjoined twins: hard to live together, painful to separate, and conscious of the fact that a separation might result in one survivor.
Does it follow that South Africa has to follow the same downward trajectory, or that there is no rescuing Zimbabwe from complete collapse?
Eerily, South Africa's ruling party fortunes are beginning to show similar symptoms of degenerate behaviour.
South Africa as the most powerful neighbour seems divided over strategy.
Unfortunately, South Africa finds itself under similar pressure -- trying to avoid falling over the socio-economic, political and fiscal cliff.
TEXT:
South Africa and Zimbabwe behave like conjoined twins: hard to live together, painful to separate, and conscious of the fact that a separation might result in one survivor. Indeed, these two have much in common: a painful colonial history, a moment of glory as the post-colonial ruling elite made the nation proud, followed by a rather disappointing and depressing end to the relevance of liberation movement politics.

Does it follow that South Africa has to follow the same downward trajectory, or that there is no rescuing Zimbabwe from complete collapse? Not necessarily. It is worth noting that a range of factors conspire against positive and peaceful outcomes. One relates to leadership weaknesses -- ruling and opposition parties alike.

Despite the dangers of predicting the "demise of Mugabe" (by now a legendary tale of how to get it wrong, a bit like predicting the end of the Cold War), it is becoming clear that even as Mr Mugabe nears the end of his reign, he manages to disrupt the succession race -- using his motley crew of supporters to remove any and all challengers to the throne.

A supporter of the ruling party Zanu PF holds a poster outside the party headquarters to show support for President Robert Mugabe following a wave of anti-governement protests over the last two weeks in Harare, Zimbabwe July 20, 2016.

One after the other, they end up joining the equally bleak opposition landscape. Could it be that Grace Mugabe has a chance to take control of the presidency? Under these conditions, conspiracy theories and speculation swirl and clog the social media.

Eerily, South Africa's ruling party fortunes are beginning to show similar symptoms of degenerate behaviour. There is no telling the outcome of the December elective conference and whether the Zuma or Ramaphosa block will take control of the party (and it is another question what to expect at the forthcoming national elections in 2019).

South Africa's President Jacob Zuma (R) jokes with his party's newly appointed Deputy President Cyril Ramaphosa (L).

Accompanying this trend -- the failure of liberation movement politics -- is the growth of complex and multilayered criminal networks that benefit from state fragility. Its dynamics have variously been described as "state capture", or the "shadow or mafia state" at work.

Viewed together with the established phenomenon of the rule of the big man -- patrimonialism -- it is hard not to conclude that both Zimbabwe and South Africa are inescapably degenerating into violent state failure.

South Africa as the most powerful neighbour seems divided over strategy. A range of civil society organisations demand action.

Several initiatives are at hand to intervene, arrest, and recover the slide. In Zimbabwe, the most recent big intervention -- SADC mediation under the leadership of Mr Mbeki resulting in a government of national unity -- brought temporary relief, but arguably allowed criminal networks to spring even deeper roots.

South Africa as the most powerful neighbour seems divided over strategy. A range of civil society organisations demand action. Political interests at home and abroad attempt to blow new life in the governing ZANU-PF or the fractured opposition.

The private sector appears disinterested, passively awaiting the inevitable. What is to be done? Unfortunately, South Africa finds itself under similar pressure -- trying to avoid falling over the socio-economic, political and fiscal cliff.

Under these conditions, it is everyone for him and herself, and the prospects for the twins look bleak indeed.

Anthoni van Nieuwkerk is a professor at the Wits School of Governance.
TITLE: Zimbabwe At A Crossroads -- And South Africa‚Äôs Inability To Intervene

Der B√ºrgermeister von T√ºbingen, in den eigenen Reihen wegen seiner gezielten Provokationen ber√ºchtigt, arbeitet sich in einem w√ºtenden Facebookpost ausgerechnet an einem Parteikollegen ab.

Das Ziel von Palmers Angriff: Partei-Urgestein J√ºrgen Trittin. Es sei ein "Trauerspiel‚Äú, dass Trittin, "ein Schatten der Vergangenheit‚Äú, √ºber die Koalition mitverhandle.

"Eine glatte L√ºge"

Trittin habe "keine Angst vor der Unwahrheit"‚Äú und sei stets darauf bedacht, "den Verhandlungspartner schlecht aussehen" zu lassen.

Dass das Verh√§ltnis zwischen Palmer und Trittin schwierig ist, zeigte sich sp√§testens im August. Als Boris Palmer sein Buch "Wir k√∂nnen nicht allen helfen" √ºber die deutsche Fl√ºchtlingspolitik vorstellte, √§tzte Trittin: "Wie, hatte Erika Steinbach keine Zeit?" SUMMARY:
Harare - Zimbabwe's sacked vice president Emmerson Mnangagwa said on Wednesday he had fled the country as he issued a direct challenge to long-ruling President Robert Mugabe and his wife Grace.
Mnangagwa was the leading contender to succeed Mugabe, 93, but his abrupt removal appeared to clear the way for the president's wife Grace to take over as president.
Mnangagwa had been one of the president's closet allies since Mugabe took power in 1980 after leading the fight against British rule.
He was sacked on Monday after a bitter clash with the president and his wife Grace, with Mugabe's spokesperson accusing him of "disloyalty, disrespect, deceitfulness and unreliability".
Mugabe, the world's oldest head of state, is due to stand in elections again next year.
TEXT:
Harare - Zimbabwe's sacked vice president Emmerson Mnangagwa said on Wednesday he had fled the country as he issued a direct challenge to long-ruling President Robert Mugabe and his wife Grace.

The ruling Zanu-PF "is not personal property of you and your wife to do as you please," Mnangagwa said in an angry five-page statement, vowing he would return to Zimbabwe to lead party members.

"This is now a party controlled by undisciplined, egotistical and self-serving minnows who derive their power not from the people and party but from only two individuals in the form of the First Family," he said.

Mnangagwa was the leading contender to succeed Mugabe, 93, but his abrupt removal appeared to clear the way for the president's wife Grace to take over as president.

Mnangagwa had been one of the president's closet allies since Mugabe took power in 1980 after leading the fight against British rule.

He was sacked on Monday after a bitter clash with the president and his wife Grace, with Mugabe's spokesperson accusing him of "disloyalty, disrespect, deceitfulness and unreliability".

Mugabe, the world's oldest head of state, is due to stand in elections again next year.

AFP
TITLE: Zimbabwean Vice-President Has Fled The Country

TEXT:
CULTURE

iPhone X √® davvero "il pi√π resistente di sempre"? Non provate a rifare questi test di caduta

Apple ha definito i nuovi iPhone 8 e iPhone X "gli smartphone con il vetro pi√π resistente di sempre". La spesa pu√≤ arrivare fino a 1359 euro e naturalmente ci si augura in effetti che il Gorilla Glass 5 che li avvolge non vada in frantumi dopo una caduta accidentale. Per questo i cosiddetti "drop test" vanno alla grande sul web: gli YouTuber pi√π coraggiosi, e con grande seguito, sacrificano uno dei nuovi esemplari riprendendo la sua caduta da almeno due altezze: 1 metro, corrispondente pi√π o meno a una fuoriuscita dalla tasca dei pantaloni, e 1,5 metri, l'altezza a cui si tiene normalmente il dispositivo quando si usa per telefonare. Quello che state vedendo √® uno dei test pi√π cliccati su YouTube dalla data di uscita dell'iPhone X, lo scorso 3 novembre. L'autore del video mette a confronto la caduta dell'iPhone pi√π costoso sul mercato con quella dell'iPhone 8. I risultati ottenuti in questo test, ovviamente, non sanciscono ufficialmente n√© definitivamente la resistenza del nuovo smartphone. Altre prove, sul web, hanno registrato esiti diversi
TITLE: iPhone X √® davvero "il pi√π resistente di sempre"? Non provate a rifare questi test di caduta

SUMMARY:
Zimbabwe's former home affairs minister, now the leader of the opposition Zapu party, Dumiso Dabengwa, has reportedly said that a military coup "cannot be ruled out" in the country following the sacking of former vice president Emmerson Mnangagwa.
Mugabe on Monday fired his deputy as tensions between Mnangagwa and the veteran leader's wife Grace to succeed him intensified.
The government-owned Chronicle newspaper published an excoriating editorial on Tuesday, accusing Mnangagwa and his supporters of being "prepared to stampede President Mugabe from power".
It accused Mnangagwa of "running parallel structures within the ruling Zanu-PF party and fomenting divisions".
Mnangagwa, 75, a veteran party loyalist who had strong ties to the military, had not yet commented on his dismissal.
TEXT:
Zimbabwe's former home affairs minister, now the leader of the opposition Zapu party, Dumiso Dabengwa, has reportedly said that a military coup "cannot be ruled out" in the country following the sacking of former vice president Emmerson Mnangagwa.

According to VOA, Dabengwa said that it was likely that most Zimbabweans could back this move "as they are tired of President Robert Mugabe's rule".

Dabengwa said this at the launch of the Dumiso Dabengwa Foundation in Bulawayo.

Mugabe on Monday fired his deputy as tensions between Mnangagwa and the veteran leader's wife Grace to succeed him intensified.

Grace declared over the weekend that Mnangagwa should be gone from both the government and Zanu-PF before the party's extraordinary congress in December.

(ZIMBABWE - Tags: ANNIVERSARY POLITICS MILITARY)

Addressing thousands of indigenous church followers during what was termed a "Super Sunday Rally" at a stadium in Harare, Grace described Mnangagwa as a "liquidator", and "ravisher" whose coup plots could be traced to 1980. According to the state-owned Herald newspaper, that was the time when he reportedly "unsuccessfully attempted to wrestle power from President Mugabe soon after the country's democratic elections".

Mnangagwa was the leading contender to succeed Mugabe, 93, but his abrupt removal appeared to clear the way for Grace to take over.

The government-owned Chronicle newspaper published an excoriating editorial on Tuesday, accusing Mnangagwa and his supporters of being "prepared to stampede President Mugabe from power".

"The President had warned his deputy time and again to desist from having grand designs to seize power unconstitutionally," the Bulawayo-based paper said.

It accused Mnangagwa of "running parallel structures within the ruling Zanu-PF party and fomenting divisions".

Mnangagwa, 75, a veteran party loyalist who had strong ties to the military, had not yet commented on his dismissal.
TITLE: 'Military Coup Can't Be Ruled Out In Zim,' Says Ex-Home Affairs Minister

SUMMARY:
The inaction of America's leadership in removing semi-automatic, assault-style weapons from proliferation throughout the suburbs of the United States has allowed the bloody parade of mass killings to roll on.
It was the 14th such speech during his time in Office and still there was no federal push to ban assault-style weapons.
Assault weapons are banned in Washington D.C. as were handguns until relatively recently.
No Administration has been prepared to take on the gun lobby and rid the nation of semi-automatic, assault-style weapons.
If the 'right to bear arms' is the constitutional reasoning that prevents a nation-wide ban on assault-style weapons, why is there a ban on fully automatic weapons?
TEXT:
"Thoughts and prayers are not enough. These guns are designed for one thing, to kill people."

"In dark times such as these, Americans do what we do best: we pull together. We join hands. We lock arms." -- Donald Trump.

The President left a few final words off the end of his statement. It should have read: "We join hands. We lock arms. And we do nothing".

Political platitudes are an insult to the dead. The inaction of America's leadership in removing semi-automatic, assault-style weapons from proliferation throughout the suburbs of the United States has allowed the bloody parade of mass killings to roll on. Sutherland Springs. Las Vegas. Orlando.

The blood of the dead has settled upon the hands of federal politicians.

This is not a recent stigma that can be laid at the feet of the current Administration alone. Republicans and Democrats alike are culpable for their lack of action in ensuring the safety of the American people from domestic terrorism at the hands of lone gunmen.

On June 16, 2016, President Obama addressed the American people following the massacre of 49 people at Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Florida. It was the 14th such speech during his time in Office and still there was no federal push to ban assault-style weapons. Indeed, Obama was still struggling to ban the sale of armour-piercing ammunition across the United States.

The AR-15 assault rifle and similar weapons are designed for one thing. To kill people. They are not an effective hunting weapon relative to the myriad of precision rifles available, designed for taking down deer and other game at extended ranges.

In fact the NRA, manufacturers and supporters of assault style weapons readily admit that the AR-15 and weapons like it are primarily marketed for home and self-defence. Self-defence against whom? Invading armies?

Some U.S. administrations do have tighter gun control than others. Assault weapons are banned in Washington D.C. as were handguns until relatively recently. The City's fight to maintain workable restrictions on access to certain firearms has been undermined by successive rulings in the U.S. Supreme Court that aspects of D.C.'s gun control laws were 'unconstitutional'.

Doing what is right is not always popular. And for those beholden to the powerful U.S. gun lobby it could be career ending. Therein lies the problem. No Administration has been prepared to take on the gun lobby and rid the nation of semi-automatic, assault-style weapons. Until decision makers are willing to put their own skin in the game, as happened in Australia in the mid '90s, nothing will change.

Australia suffered its most hateful and deadly mass murder in April 1996 when Martin Bryant murdered 35 people, including children, using legally available semi-automatic military weapons.

Australia's newly elected Prime Minister John Howard took immediate action, implementing federal firearm laws over and above state legislation. Mr Howard risked his own political future by implementing federal legislation to ban all assault weapons and restrict all other semi-automatic rifles to rural landholders deemed to have a genuine need to manage feral animals. The Government issued an amnesty and gun buyback at a significant cost to the federal budget bottom line.

At the next election, around a dozen Members of Parliament from the Howard Government lost their seats, in no small measure due to the stand the Government took on gun laws.

The price was worth it. Since 1996 there have been no repeats of the mass murder perpetrated at Port Arthur, while at the same time the rights of recreational shooters -- like myself -- to own firearms have been upheld.

Both sides of Congress have been afraid to take on 'big guns' for fear of being hounded out of office, accused of impinging upon individual rights under the second amendment.

The second amendment has been used as a cover-all, allowing military grade weapons to be proliferated throughout the suburbs of America. And yet the logic is false. If the 'right to bear arms' is the constitutional reasoning that prevents a nation-wide ban on assault-style weapons, why is there a ban on fully automatic weapons? If I have the right to own an AR-15 that discharges one bullet each time I pull the trigger, why not a weapon that can discharge the entire clip in seconds?

Perhaps because it's not in the interest of public safety to allow fully automatic military weapons to rest in the hands of civilians. And yet a semi-automatic version of the same weapon meets the public safety test? Ludicrous.

The precedence of the Australian example and what we are seeing on almost a monthly basis in the United States, places it beyond reasonable doubt that national legislation banning assault-style, semi-automatic weapons will help reduce the likelihood and severity of mass shootings.

Every month of inaction by Congress and, indeed, the President himself, to ban assault-style weapons, hastens the next breaking news story flashing across screens around the world, of another mass slaying in suburban U.S. by a gunman using an AR-15.
TITLE: Without Presidential Action On Assault Weapons, U.S. Mass Killings Will Continue

SUMMARY:
I‚Äôve come back to my hometown to be able to add to the conversation and share what wealth of knowledge I‚Äôve received living in other cities.‚Äù‚Äï Jaque Fragua, 31, artist‚ÄúI live here in Albuquerque by choice.
I‚Äôm too afraid to leave Albuquerque.‚Äù‚Äï Rose Jojole, 47, stay-at-home mom‚ÄúI was supposed to move to California, but I changed my mind.
I love Albuquerque.
It‚Äôs very peaceful and beautiful.‚Äù‚Äï Stephanie Rodgriguez (translated by Lin Marksbury), 28, educational assistant‚ÄúI moved to Albuquerque because of sign language.
... Warts and all, we love our city and our friends.‚Äù‚Äï Evelyn Dow, 56, management‚ÄúIt just seems like Albuquerque is a good city.‚Äù
TEXT:
Albuquerque was the 22nd stop on HuffPost‚Äôs Listen to America road trip. We spoke to locals about why this New Mexico city is home. Here‚Äôs what they had to say:

‚ÄúI‚Äôm returning from a stint in LA, New York, around the country really. I‚Äôve come back to my hometown to be able to add to the conversation and share what wealth of knowledge I‚Äôve received living in other cities.‚Äù

‚Äï Jaque Fragua, 31, artist

‚ÄúI live here in Albuquerque by choice. Just closer to my home, I‚Äôm originally from here in the Southwest.‚Äù

‚Äï Ty Harris, 23, artist

‚ÄúThis is where my people come from, here and in Mexico. ... I came here to be closer to my people, my roots.‚Äù

‚Äï Lisa Lucero, 53, drummer and union carpenter

‚ÄúI fell in love and I never left. It‚Äôs either love it or hate it. If you‚Äôve never been here at all, the scenery is so breathtakingly different. ... Why would you want to be anywhere else?‚Äù

‚Äï Paul Mansfield, 69, retired

‚ÄúI love New Mexico. ... When I come back to New Mexico, I literally have joy in my heart.‚Äù

‚Äï Michael Padilla, 45, business owner

‚ÄúI love it here. I‚Äôm too afraid to leave Albuquerque.‚Äù

‚Äï Rose Jojole, 47, stay-at-home mom

‚ÄúI was supposed to move to California, but I changed my mind. I wanted to stay close to my family. I‚Äôm very close to my family. ... I love Albuquerque. It‚Äôs very peaceful and beautiful.‚Äù

‚Äï Stephanie Rodgriguez (translated by Lin Marksbury), 28, educational assistant

‚ÄúI moved to Albuquerque because of sign language. ... I work here in the community now. I love it here.‚Äù

‚Äï Maila Brock, 39, sign language interpreter

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre pretty partial. This is home for us. All of our family is here. ... Warts and all, we love our city and our friends.‚Äù

‚Äï Evelyn Dow, 56, management

‚ÄúIt just seems like Albuquerque is a good city.‚Äù
TITLE: 'Why Would You Want To Be Anywhere Else?': Meet The People Of Albuquerque

SUMMARY:
Americans spend one third of their lives in bed, but as a nation, we still aren‚Äôt getting enough sleep.
As a result of chronic under-rest, our wellbeing is eroding.
To bring awareness -- and solutions -- to this public health issue, The Huffington Post has partnered with Sleep Number¬Æ to present Sleep + Wellness, an editorial section dedicated to empowering readers to live their best, healthiest lives by gaining a better understanding of sleep as a crucial pillar of our well-being.
By taking an all-encompassing, personalized approach to wellness, and educating readers on how sleep connects to fitness, work-life balance, and more, Sleep + Wellness aims to take the stress out of sleep, for good.
To contribute, please email sleeppluswellness@huffingtonpost.com.

SUMMARY:
Devant cette question essentielle, certains membres de Qu√©bec solidaire oppos√©s √† la fusion pr√©f√®rent d√©vier le d√©bat sur des √©l√©ments proc√©duriers, ayant recours √† des demi-v√©rit√©s et des exag√©rations outranci√®res, loin de la prudence et du dialogue respectueux qui caract√©risent ce parti.
Son texte est repr√©sentatif d'une aversion envers Option nationale et d'une interpr√©tation √©troite du programme et des statuts de Qu√©bec solidaire.
La forme de l'ententeUne fusion implique n√©cessairement des compromis et des efforts de part et d'autre.
En clair, le parti c√®de ses ressources financi√®res et organisationnelles pour faire conjointement la promotion du programme, des statuts, de la direction et des candidatures √©lectorales de Qu√©bec solidaire.
Faut-il rappeler que la souverainet√© √©tait un d√©j√† th√®me prioritaire de la derni√®re campagne √©lectorale?
TEXT:
La fusion entre Qu√©bec solidaire et Option nationale constitue une d√©cision politique majeure dont le principal enjeu est l'adh√©sion d'un important secteur ind√©pendantiste au parti de gauche. Devant cette question essentielle, certains membres de Qu√©bec solidaire oppos√©s √† la fusion pr√©f√®rent d√©vier le d√©bat sur des √©l√©ments proc√©duriers, ayant recours √† des demi-v√©rit√©s et des exag√©rations outranci√®res, loin de la prudence et du dialogue respectueux qui caract√©risent ce parti.

Daniel Raunet, dans un billet r√©cent, s'acharne ainsi √† d√©moniser l'entente de principe d√©voil√© par les directions des deux partis, envers lesquelles il √©prouve une mauvaise foi √©vidente. Son texte est repr√©sentatif d'une aversion envers Option nationale et d'une interpr√©tation √©troite du programme et des statuts de Qu√©bec solidaire. S'opposer √† la fusion est une position l√©gitime qui doit toutefois √™tre avanc√©e sans tordre les faits.

Processus

Il est assez √©tonnant d'accuser d'antid√©mocratique le processus menant √† la fusion, car il fait pr√©sentement l'objet d'un d√©bat dans toutes les assembl√©es locales et sera ent√©rin√© par un congr√®s de 500 d√©l√©gu√©.es en d√©cembre. Le mandat de n√©gocier une fusion, et non un pacte √©lectoral ou ponctuel - √ßa vaut la peine d'insister -, a √©t√© donn√© lors du Congr√®s de mai 2017, lui-m√™me pr√©c√©d√© de d√©bats dans les associations locales et de discussions sur les alliances politiques men√©es par le chantier du Renouveau politique depuis novembre 2016.

Ne faut-il pas reconnaitre que, au-del√† de la direction nationale, des centaines de membres solidaires ont appel√© de leurs voeux cette union?

Bien s√ªr, les membres ne pouvaient pr√©sumer de l'issue de n√©gociations et de la forme concr√®te que prendrait l'union, c'est pourquoi les membres sont appel√©s maintenant √† ratifier le projet. Ne faut-il pas reconnaitre que, au-del√† de la direction nationale, des centaines de membres solidaires ont appel√© de leurs voeux cette union?

La forme de l'entente

Une fusion implique n√©cessairement des compromis et des efforts de part et d'autre. Reconnaissons l'effort consenti par Option nationale qui accepterait de s'int√©grer √† Qu√©bec solidaire. En clair, le parti c√®de ses ressources financi√®res et organisationnelles pour faire conjointement la promotion du programme, des statuts, de la direction et des candidatures √©lectorales de Qu√©bec solidaire. C'est une fen√™tre d'opportunit√©s incroyable que des ind√©pendantistes se rallient aux causes de la gauche, du f√©minisme et de l'inclusion, plut√¥t que de retourner au Parti qu√©b√©cois de Jean-Fran√ßois Lis√©e.

En retour, ON sera reconnu comme collectif au sein de QS avec des mesures d'int√©gration avant tout transitoires. Loin d'√™tre antid√©mocratique, la pr√©sence d'un collectif au sein de notre parti devrait √™tre per√ßue comme une action exemplaire pour dynamiser le d√©bat interne et d√©fendre les minorit√©s politiques. Il s'agit d'un point d'appui pour aller plus loin en ce sens. Or, Raunet extrapole certaines clauses de l'entente √† tel point qu'il d√©forme son sens.

N'oublions pas qu'ON apporte avec lui non seulement des sommes propres, mais de nouveaux membres qui cotiseront au parti unifi√©.

Dans le but d'apporter de l'exp√©rience et de la connaissance qu'elle a b√¢ties en six ans d'existence, le collectif d'Option nationale pourra obtenir du mat√©riel de promotion de l'ind√©pendance pay√©e par le budget du parti. L'universit√© d'√©t√© sur l'ind√©pendance sera quant √† elle autofinanc√©e. N'oublions pas qu'ON apporte avec lui non seulement des sommes propres, mais de nouveaux membres qui cotiseront au parti unifi√©. Pourquoi se priverait-on d'activit√©s militantes?

Le collectif d√©l√®guera deux personnes sur le Comit√© de coordination nationale comptant 14 responsables solidaires. Cette repr√©sentation ultra minoritaire sur la plus haute instance du parti ne durera qu'une p√©riode de transition de deux ans. Stricto sensu, cela constitue la seule et unique d√©rogation aux statuts de Qu√©bec solidaire.

Il est erron√©, voire mensonger, d'affirmer que l'entente "garantit" une circonscription au chef actuel d'ON, Sol Zanetti. L'article 6 pr√©voit en fait que les porte-parole de QS appuient trois candidatures √† "l'investiture", elles devront donc √™tre valid√©es par la base. Manon Mass√© et Gabriel Nadeau-Dubois ne vont pas "parachuter" ou imposer arbitrairement ces candidatures; il est entendu que cette mesure sera appliqu√©e de "mani√®re coll√©giale" par un "comit√© de m√©diation" constitu√© entre autres d'associations locales. Dans les partis traditionnels, on voit les parachutistes lanc√©s de plus haute altitude!

Quant √† Zanetti, on appuiera sa course dans une circonscription favorable et on le mettra de l'avant lors des communications publiques. L'article 18 parle "d'activit√©s" et de "conf√©rences" sur l'ind√©pendance, et nullement d'un r√¥le de "porte-parole" tel qu'avanc√© par Raunet. C'est une pratique qui se fait d√©j√† avec d'autres figures de proue du parti. Il est vrai que Zanetti jouira d'une visibilit√© m√©diatique privil√©gi√©e, mais cela m'apparait une marque de respect rudimentaire envers les membres onistes qui l'ont √©lu chef.

Programme

Finalement, abordons les objections politiques et programmatiques, c'est l√† l'enjeu r√©el du vote du congr√®s de d√©cembre. L'ancien journaliste √† Radio-Canada se fait √©cho de plusieurs critiques pour qui l'entente serait la capitulation du "programme entier" de QS sur l'ind√©pendance. Encore une fois, l'enflure verbale passe outre le fait que le programme d'ON a √©volu√© depuis 2011 pour adopter la strat√©gie de l'Assembl√©e constituante pr√©conis√©e par QS. Se d√©chirer sur le la couleur de la Constituante passe √† c√¥t√© de son potentiel mobilisateur de cette strat√©gie. De plus, un partie importante des membres solidaires partagent la m√™me interpr√©tation que les onistes et, comme 45% des congressistes de mai 2016, souhaitent que l'Assembl√©e constituante soit dot√©e d'un mandat d√©termin√©. Ce n'est donc pas l'abandon du programme entier de QS sur l'ind√©pendance, mais l'id√©e qu'une partie des membres se font de ce programme.

Raunet fait grand cas du concept de gouvernance souverainiste qui, dans le fond, ne fait que rendre explicite le d√©fi lanc√© par le programme de QS. La mise en oeuvre ne serait-ce qu'une fraction de la plateforme √©lectorale solidaire √©branlerait la f√©d√©ration canadienne, et cela ne serait-ce que pour n√©gocier la "participation d'Ottawa" pour utiliser l'euph√©misme consacr√©. Imaginons aussi qu'un gouvernement solidaire mette au d√©fi les lois migratoires canadiennes pour assurer le refuge d√©cent aux demandeurs d'asile, est-ce qu'on s'en offusquera?

Dernier argument, et non le moindre, on invoque que la fusion mettrait en priorit√© l'ind√©pendance au d√©triment des autres principes de Qu√©bec solidaire. Pourtant, l'entente √©dicte que l'ind√©pendance sera visible "au m√™me titre que les autres principes", et le "r√©gime colonial canadien" au m√™me titre que le n√©olib√©ralisme. Faut-il rappeler que la souverainet√© √©tait un d√©j√† th√®me prioritaire de la derni√®re campagne √©lectorale? Faire un scandale sur cette question ignore cette r√©alit√©.

C'est comme si l'ind√©pendance √©tait taboue et qu'on devait lui substituer les mots d√©mocratie, f√©minisme, justice sociale ou √©cologie. Or l'ind√©pendance, comme le disait Frantz Fanon, ¬´ n'est pas un mot √† exorciser, mais une condition indispensable √† l'existence des hommes et des femmes vraiment lib√©r√©s, c'est-√†-dire ma√Ætres de tous les moyens mat√©riels qui rendent possible la transformation radicale de la soci√©t√©. ¬ª En ce sens, QS n'a jamais hi√©rarchis√© les luttes et ne le fera jamais, fusion ou non. Toutes les luttes se renforcent mutuellement sans se dissoudre dans les autres.

‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã
TITLE: La d√©rive argumentative n‚Äôest pas l‚Äôun des principes de Qu√©bec solidaire

Wenn wir die Wahl haben zwischen Glaubw√ºrdigkeitsverlust oder Neuwahlen, entscheiden wir uns f√ºr Neuwahlen.

TEXT:
In der zweiten Jamaika-Sondierungsrunde wird es ernst: Es geht um den Klimaschutz

F√ºr die FDP-Generalsekret√§rin Nicola Beer stehen die Chancen auf eine Einigung weiterhin bei 50 zu 50, sagt sie im HuffPost-Interview

Au√üerdem sieht sie trotz der Kompromissbereitschaft der Gr√ºnen gro√üe Differenzen

Nach dem Start der zweiten Sondierungsrunde geht es bei Jamaika ums Eingemachte. Nicht nur beim Klimaschutz gibt es weiter Konfliktpotenzial - auch die Fl√ºchtlingspolitik ist ein zentraler Streitpunkt.

F√ºr die FDP-Generalsekret√§rin Nicola Beer stehen die Chancen auf eine Einigung deswegen weiter bei 50 zu 50. In einem Interview mit der HuffPost sagte sie zum Beginn der Gespr√§che:

"Am Ende ist f√ºr uns klar: Wir werden uns nicht selbst verleugnen. Wenn wir die Wahl haben zwischen Glaubw√ºrdigkeitsverlust oder Neuwahlen, entscheiden wir uns f√ºr Neuwahlen. Aber das ist nicht unser Ziel."

Die Gr√ºnen gingen am Morgen einen ersten gro√üen Schritt auf die potentiellen Partner zu. Sowohl beim Verbrennungsmotor als auch beim Kohleausstieg zeigten sie Kompromissbereitschaft.

"Wir haben die heutigen Aussagen des Gr√ºnen-Chefs in diese Richtung als Signal der Einigungsbereitschaft aufgenommen", sagte Beer. Dennoch sieht die FDP-Generalsekret√§rin noch gro√üe Differenzen. "Wir wollen einen Klimaschutz, der funktioniert. Da sind wir gr√ºner als die Gr√ºnen", sagte sie.

"Wir m√ºssen uns eingestehen, dass unsere jetzige Klimaschutzpolitik nicht funktioniert hat. Sie ist die teuerste der Welt, aber wir haben keine einzige Tonne CO2 eingespart. Das ist doch v√∂llig widersinnig."

Auch bei der Fl√ºchtlingspolitik rief sie den Verhandlungspartner zur Kompromissbereitschaft auf.

"Ich setze darauf, dass auch Cem √ñzdemir irgendwann f√ºr logische Argumente zug√§nglich wird und in seinem Wahlkreis merkt, dass auch dort nicht alle Fl√ºchtlinge aufgenommen werden k√∂nnen", sagte Beer.

Das Interview lest ihr hier:

Frau Beer, nehmen wir an, Sie erhalten ein Freiticket f√ºr einen Jamaika-Urlaub und k√∂nnen einen Unterh√§ndler aus der Union oder von den Gr√ºnen mitnehmen. Wer w√§re das?



Von den Verhandlungspartnern kann ich mir auf der Insel sicher eine nette Zeit mit CSU-Generalsekret√§r Andreas Scheuer machen. Aber eigentlich m√ºsste ich nat√ºrlich meine bessere H√§lfte mitnehmen.

Heute gehen die Jamaika-Verhandlungen in die zweite Runde, doch es hakt gewaltig. Wird das noch etwas mit der Koalition?

Ich sehe die Chancen nach wie vor bei 50 zu 50, dass Jamaika gelingt. In den kommenden Tagen wird es darum gehen, die Gr√§ben aus dem Weg zu r√§umen und eine gemeinsame Vision zu entwickeln, die jeder unterschreiben kann.

Das klingt jetzt sehr freundlich. FDP-Chef Lindner redet schon √ºber Neuwahlen und eine m√∂gliche Oppositionsrolle. Wo soll das hinf√ºhren?



Am Ende haben wir keine Angst vor Neuwahlen, das wollte er deutlich machen. Uns geht es um eine neue Politik, die deutlich werden muss. Aber wir arbeiten auch nicht auf Neuwahlen hin.



K√∂nnen Sie uns das versprechen?



Ja.



Woher dann das Gerede √ºber Neuwahlen?



Am Ende ist f√ºr uns klar: Wir werden uns nicht selbst verleugnen. Wenn wir die Wahl haben zwischen Glaubw√ºrdigkeitsverlust oder Neuwahlen, entscheiden wir uns f√ºr Neuwahlen. Aber das ist nicht unser Ziel.



Haben Sie einen kleinen Westerwelle-Komplex ‚Äì nicht noch einmal aus dem Bundestag ausscheiden?



Ich neige nicht zu Komplexen, egal, mit welchem Namen Sie das verbinden. Ich neige dazu, feste Prinzipien zu haben. Am Ende muss unsere liberale Handschrift klar erkennbar sein. Wir stehen nicht als St√ºtzrad f√ºr eine Schwarz-Rote Politik, wie sie die vergangenen vier Jahre gemacht wurde.



Die Gr√ºnen sind ja auch noch mit dabei.



Ja, aber man hat ja schon den Eindruck, dass Schwarz-Gr√ºn bereits Vorgef√ºhle entwickelt hat.



Woran machen Sie das fest?



Wenn ich mir den ein oder anderen Gespr√§chsverlauf anschaue. Aber ich m√∂chte nicht zu viele Internas aus den Sondierungsgespr√§chen verraten. Generell ist uns nat√ºrlich klar, dass wir nicht alle unsere Forderung durchsetzen k√∂nnen. Doch unsere liberale Handschrift muss erkennbar sein.



Gro√üe Differenzen gibt es mit den Gr√ºnen beim Thema Klimaschutz. Wie wollen Sie hier einen Kompromiss erreichen?



Wir sind uns mit den Gr√ºnen v√∂llig einig, dass wir die Klimaschutzziele 2050 erreichen m√ºssen. Allerdings m√ºssen wir das physikalisch hinbekommen.



Gr√ºnen-Politiker Robert Habeck sagte, alle Parteien m√ºssen sich ‚Äúam Riemen rei√üen‚Äù. Das klingt nicht so, als w√§re man sich v√∂llig einig.



Wir sind uns bei den Zielen einig. Beim Weg dorthin hingegen bisher nicht. Wir m√ºssen uns eingestehen, dass unsere jetzige Klimaschutzpolitik nicht funktioniert hat. Sie ist die teuerste der Welt, aber wir haben keine einzige Tonne CO2 eingespart. Das ist doch v√∂llig widersinnig. Wir wollen einen Klimaschutz, der funktioniert. Da sind wir gr√ºner als die Gr√ºnen.



Was ist die Alternative?



Wir k√∂nnen unsere ehrgeizigen Ziele nur mit Technologien erreichen, die sich noch nicht durchgesetzt haben. Das m√ºssen wir in unserer Klimapolitik dringend miteinbeziehen.



Geben Sie uns ein Beispiel.



Etwa bei der Mobilit√§t. Wenn wir den Verbrennungsmotor abschaffen, bevor wir das Reichweitenproblem der E-Autos gel√∂st haben, machen wir realit√§tsferne Politik an den Menschen vorbei.

Wir haben die heutigen Aussagen des Gr√ºnen-Chefs in diese Richtung als Signal der Einigungsbereitschaft aufgenommen, wie Christian Lindner ja auch deutlich gemacht hat. Klare, erreichbare Ziele und Technologieoffenheit zu ihrer Erreichung statt auf Verbote zu setzen, das muss die Devise sein. Und so ist es auch mit der Kohlekraft.



Warum?



Wir haben jetzt schon Probleme mit der Versorgungssicherheit. Bei manchen Unternehmen flackert das Stromnetz und gef√§hrdet damit die Produktion, weil der Strommix aus den Erneuerbaren in Sto√üzeiten nicht ausreicht. Wenn wir die Kohle jetzt parallel zur Kernenergie aus dem Stromnetz rausnehmen, m√ºssen wir mit fl√§chendeckenden Blackouts rechnen. Das kann niemand wollen.



Was ist mit Erdgas? Das ist effizienter und nicht ganz so schmutzig wie Kohle.



Fakt ist doch: Bislang haben uns die Gr√ºnen nicht vorrechnen k√∂nnen, wie sie einen Kohleausstieg ausgleichen wollen. Da bliebe uns nur √ºbrig, Kohle- und Kernenergie aus Frankreich und Polen zuzukaufen. Ob die Gr√ºnen so wirklich das Klima retten, bezweifle ich.



Reden wir √ºber den Umgang zwischen den Jamaika-Parteien. FDP-Chef Lindner hat den Gr√ºnen etwa vorgeworfen, ein ‚ÄúKonjunkturprogramm f√ºr die AfD‚Äù zu betreiben. CSU-General Scheuer nennt die Gr√ºnen ‚Äúschizophren‚Äù. Woher kommt die schlechte Laune?



Wir schauen schlicht auf die Realit√§ten. Beispiel Fl√ºchtlingspolitik, worauf sich das Zitat von Christian Lindner ja bezog. Nat√ºrlich ist ein Familiennachzug, wie ihn die Gr√ºnen wollen, in gewissen Bereichen sinnvoll - etwa, wenn derjenige seine Familie hier in Deutschland ern√§hren kann, weil er einen Job und eine Wohnung hat.

Aber das funktioniert nur, wenn wir diejenigen abschieben, die kein Bleiberecht haben. Sonst werden uns die B√ºrger zurecht auf die Barrikaden gehen. Denn wir k√∂nnen nicht jeden aufnehmen.



Wie wollen Sie die Gr√ºnen davon √ºberzeugen?



Es gibt auch bei den Gr√ºnen Politiker wie Herrn Palmer, die davon bereits √ºberzeugt sind. Sie wissen, dass es vor Ort Schwierigkeiten gibt, einen unbegrenzten Zuzug von Fl√ºchtlingen zu schultern. Es fehlen Wohnungen, Klassenr√§ume, Lehrkr√§fte und Kita-Pl√§tze.



Herr Palmer aber spricht nicht f√ºr seine Partei. Wie wollen Sie etwa Parteichef √ñzdemir √ºberzeugen?



Ich setze darauf, dass auch Cem √ñzdemir irgendwann f√ºr logische Argumente zug√§nglich wird und in seinem Wahlkreis merkt, dass auch dort nicht alle Fl√ºchtlinge aufgenommen werden k√∂nnen.



Schauen wir auf CSU-Chef Horst Seehofer. Es wirkt so, als liefe gegen ihn ein innerparteilicher Putsch. Glauben Sie, dass er noch lange am Verhandlungstisch von Jamaika sitzen wird?



Das muss die CSU entscheiden.



Lohnt es sich, Kompromisse mit jemandem zu machen, der wom√∂glich schon bald nicht mehr f√ºr seine Partei spricht?



Am Ende des Tages machen wir Kompromisse mit der CSU, nicht mit Horst Seehofer.

Beobachter sehen die Jamaika-Verhandlungen durch die Personaldiskussion in der CSU grunds√§tzlich in Gefahr. Teilen Sie diese Sorge?



Unsere Verhandlungen k√∂nnten schneller voranschreiten, wenn die CSU so geschlossen w√§re wie die FDP. Aber Streit gibt es auch bei den Gr√ºnen, die sich untereinander nicht immer einig sind.

SUMMARY:
Auf dem Arbeitsmarkt sind Menschen mit Behinderung noch immer Menschen zweiter Klasse.
Erst als sich Shani daf√ºr entschied, ihre Behinderung aus ihren Bewerbungsschreiben zu streichen, lud man sie zu einem Vorstellungsgespr√§ch ein.
Nur kurze Zeit sp√§ter bekam sie eine Anstellung in einem Telekommunikationsunternehmen.
Sie kritisiert im Gespr√§ch mit der HuffPost, die Arbeitslosenquote betrage bei Menschen mit Behinderungen 13,9 Prozent.
‚ÄúIn Deutschland ist die Arbeitssuche f√ºr Menschen mit Behinderungen oft sehr m√ºhsam‚Äù, berichtet die Behindertenbeauftragte der Bundesregierung, Verena Bentele, der HuffPost.
TEXT:
Shani Dhanda ist eine ganz gew√∂hnliche Frau. Sie ist 30 Jahre alt, hat Eventmanagement studiert und liebt es, zu reisen. In ihrem Studiengang galt sie als eine der Jahrgangsbesten. Eine US-amerikanische Stiftung ver√∂ffentlichte sogar ihre Dissertation. F√ºr ihre Arbeit an der Universit√§t verlieh man ihr eine Auszeichnung.

Und trotzdem: √úber ein Jahrzehnt lang bewarb sich Shani Dhanda auf mehr als 100 freie Stellenausschreibungen - ohne jemals eine Antwort zu bekommen, berichtet die 30-J√§hrige in der britischen HuffPost.

Im Video oben: Shanis Geschichte ist kein Einzelfall

Schuld daran war ein Detail in ihrer Bewerbung.

Shani ist 95 Zentimeter gro√ü und hat die sogenannte Glasknochenkrankheit.

"Ich dachte, ich w√ºrde niemals einen Job bekommen - und dass, obwohl ich unbedingt einen Beitrag zur Gesellschaft leisten wollte. Die Aussicht, vielleicht niemals arbeiten zu k√∂nnen, machte mich wirklich traurig‚Äù, klagt sie.

Bereits in der Schule gab man Shani mehr als fragw√ºrdige Karrieretipps: ‚ÄúMir wurde gesagt, dass ich versuchen sollte, einen Job in der √∂rtlichen Gemeinde zu ergattern. Dort g√§be es eine j√§hrliche Quote f√ºr Menschen mit Behinderungen.‚Äù

Behandelt wie Menschen zweiter Klasse

Shani empfand das als extrem beleidigend: ‚ÄúIch wurde nicht an meinen F√§higkeiten oder Interessen gemessen. Andere sahen mich nur als eine Person mit Behinderung‚Äù. Der Fall der Britin zeigt ein Problem auf, das auch in Deutschland noch immer besteht. Auf dem Arbeitsmarkt sind Menschen mit Behinderung noch immer Menschen zweiter Klasse.

Erst als sich Shani daf√ºr entschied, ihre Behinderung aus ihren Bewerbungsschreiben zu streichen, lud man sie zu einem Vorstellungsgespr√§ch ein. Nur kurze Zeit sp√§ter bekam sie eine Anstellung in einem Telekommunikationsunternehmen.

Doch einen Job zu bekommen, ist nicht die einzige Herausforderung. "Es gibt viele verschiedene Probleme", erkl√§rt Shani. "Es gibt Probleme bei der Jobsuche und es gibt Probleme, den Job tats√§chlich zu halten."

Neben ihren br√ºchigen Knochen leidet Shani an Skoliose und Arthritis. Bei ihrer l√§ngeren Anfahrt in die Arbeit bekam sie schnell Gelenkschmerzen. Sie fragte daher ihren Arbeitgeber, ob sie √∂fter von daheim arbeiten k√∂nne.

Doch ihr Antrag wurde abgelehnt: ‚ÄúEs war ein Schlag ins Gesicht‚Äù. Shani f√ºhlte sich von ihrem Arbeitgeber im Stich gelassen. Immerhin arbeitete sie da bereits seit sechs Jahre f√ºr das Unternehmen.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: Die Sparkasse hat meine Behinderung benutzt, um mich rauszuwerfen

‚ÄúIch m√∂chte nicht um besondere Behandlung oder spezielle Anpassungen oder etwas anderes bitten, aber es ist etwas, was ich tun muss, um meine Arbeit zu machen.‚Äù

Sie beschloss darauf, ihre K√ºndigung einzureichen.

Sehr qualifiziert ‚Äì trotzdem keinen Job

√Ñhnliche Erfahrungen musste auch Lukas Hoppe in Deutschland machen. Der 23-J√§hrige ist geh√∂rlos und auf einen Schriftdolmetscher angewiesen. Nachdem er sehr erfolgreich sein Abitur abgeschlossen hatte, fand er schnell einen Ausbildungsplatz.

Auch f√ºr die Berufsschule sollte ihm ein Dolmetscher zur Verf√ºgung gestellt werden. Doch die Agentur f√ºr Arbeit lehnte es ab, diesen zu finanzieren. Der offizielle Grund: Lukas‚Äô Noten seien zu gut. Er k√∂nne erneut einen Dolmetscher beantragen, wenn seine Leistungen deutlich nachlassen w√ºrden.

F√ºr Lukas und seine Mutter eine absolut inakzeptable Situation. Sie zogen vor ein Sozialgericht und bekamen Recht. √úber den Fall berichtete die ‚ÄúNeue Osnabr√ºcker Zeitung‚Äù.

Sein Fall zeigt, mit welchen abstrusen Hindernisse Menschen mit Behinderung zu k√§mpfen haben.

Die Behinderten-Aktivistin Julia Probst setzt sich seit Jahren f√ºr Menschen wie Lukas sein. Sie kritisiert im Gespr√§ch mit der HuffPost, die Arbeitslosenquote betrage bei Menschen mit Behinderungen 13,9 Prozent. Sie ist damit deutlich h√∂her als bei Nichtbehinderten.

‚ÄúAllerdings ist es nicht so, dass Menschen mit Behinderung schlecht ausgebildet sind. Die Mehrheit ist sogar gut ausgebildet. Ihnen wird der Zugang zum Arbeitsmarkt nur deutlich erschwert‚Äù, sagt Probst.

Das h√§nge besonders oft mit Vorurteilen √ºber die Leistungsf√§higkeit der Bewerberinnen und Bewerber mit Behinderungen zusammen.

‚ÄúIn Deutschland ist die Arbeitssuche f√ºr Menschen mit Behinderungen oft sehr m√ºhsam‚Äù, berichtet die Behindertenbeauftragte der Bundesregierung, Verena Bentele, der HuffPost.

Nicht selten verhindern Vorurteile eine Einladung zum Vorstellungsgespr√§ch bei privaten Arbeitgebern - und das trotz der geforderten Qualifikation.

Endstation Behindertenwerkstatt

Probst zufolge hat das vor allem einen Grund: Der Besuch einer F√∂rderschule ende f√ºr viele Betroffene meistens in einer Behindertenwerkstatt, anstatt in einer regul√§ren Ausbildung. Von dort f√§nden immer noch zu wenige behinderte Menschen den Weg in den regul√§ren Arbeitsmarkt.

‚ÄúDer einzig richtige Weg w√§re, das teure und √ºberfl√ºssige F√∂rderschulsystem abzuschaffen und alle Regelschulen inklusiv zu machen‚Äù, erkl√§rte Probst.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: Seit sie drei Jahre alt ist, sitzt meine Tochter im Rollstuhl - jetzt rettet sie die Welt

So werde ein normales Miteinander von der Kindheit an geschaffen und private Firmen h√§tten weniger Angst vor der Einstellung eines Menschen mit Behinderung.

√Ñhnlich sieht das auch Verena Bentele. Gegen Diskriminierung von Menschen mit Behinderungen auf dem Arbeitsmarkt helfe langfristig sicher nur die inklusive Bildung.

‚ÄúWenn alle Kinder, ob mit oder ohne Behinderungen, gemeinsam lernen, dann entstehen von Anfang an weniger Vorurteile bei Arbeitgebern und Kolleginnen und Kollegen‚Äù, so Bentele.

Die UN bezeichnet die Inklusionsbem√ºhungen der Bundesregierung als mangelhaft

Schon mehrfach wurde Deutschland bei der offiziellen Staatenpr√ºfung des UN-Menschenrechtsratausschusses heftig f√ºr die mangelhafte Umsetzung von Inklusionsma√ünahmen ger√ºgt. Dies war zuletzt 2015 der Fall. Deutlich besser schneiden L√§nder wie Italien und Spanien ab.

Auch f√ºr die n√§chste Pr√ºfung 2019 sieht Julia Probst f√ºr Deutschland schwarz: ‚ÄúEs hat sich im Prinzip nichts ge√§ndert.‚Äù

Es g√§be zwar eine Schwerstbehinderten-Abgabe f√ºr Firmen, die die offizielle Quote an behinderten Mitarbeitern nicht erf√ºllen, allerdings sei diese nicht hoch genug.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: 85.000 Deutsche d√ºrfen das grundlegendste Recht in einem demokratischen Staat nicht wahrnehmen

Sind in einem Unternehmen mit mehr als 60 Mitarbeitern weniger als 5 Prozent der Arbeitspl√§tze mit Menschen mit schwerer Behinderung besetzt, muss das Unternehmen eine Geb√ºhr entrichten. Diese betr√§gt jedoch nur maximal 320 Euro im Monat. Probst fordert, diese Sanktionen deutlich zu erh√∂hen.

‚ÄúDer ehemalige Finanzminister Wolfgang Sch√§uble machte einen entsprechenden Vorschlag 2015. Der wurde allerdings nie umgesetzt‚Äù.

In zwei Jahren droht Deutschland so erneut die Note f√ºnf - und das zu Recht.

TEXT:
Die Woche kommt der K√§lteeinbruch in Deutschland

Der Wetterdienst warnt vor Blitzeis von Mittwoch auf Donnerstag

Wo am Wochenende der erste Schnee fallen soll, erfahrt ihr im Video oben

Zwei Tiefdruckgebiete sorgen am Mittwoch immer wieder f√ºr Regen in Deutschland. W√§hrend es vormittags noch im Westen regnerisch ist, ziehen die Schauer sp√§ter in den S√ºdosten. Sonst erwartet uns echtes Novemberwetter. Tags√ºber ist es meist bedeckt oder nebelig.

Ausnahmen dazu sind der S√ºden und Osten des Landes. Am Alpenrand weht der F√∂hn, der die Wolken und den Nebel in Oberbayern aufl√∂st. Auch im Osten Deutschlands kann am Nachmittag vereinzelt die Sonne scheinen. Der H√∂chstwert in Dresden liegt bei 10 Grad.

Donnerstag der beste Tag der Woche

In der Nacht zum Donnerstag bleibt es bedeckt und es regnet immer wieder leicht. Bis zum Ende der Nacht h√∂rt der Regen dann aber auf. Es wird wieder nebelig. Die Tiefstwerte liegen zwischen 2 und 6 Grad. Der Wetterdienst warnt, dass mit Stra√üengl√§tte in den Morgenstunden gerechnet werden muss. Besondere Vorsicht ist im Osten und im S√ºdosten geboten.

Der Donnerstag wird als bester Tag der verbleibenden Woche erwartet. Obwohl es mit viel Nebel losgeht, kommt noch oft die Sonne zum Vorschein.

Am Wochenende wird der erste Schneefall erwartet



Am Wochenende sollte man bestm√∂glich wenn m√∂glich f√ºr einen Kurzurlaub verreisen. Denn dann wird es nass, kalt und windig. Am Freitag zieht Regen von Norden durch das Land. Dabei wird es windig. Am Samstag kommt neuer Regen aus Westen zu uns, dabei wird es teils sogar st√ºrmisch.

In den Tieflagen ist am Sonntag sogar mit dem ersten Schnee zu rechnen. Davon sind vor allem Th√ºringen, Sachsen und Bayern betroffen.



Die besten Vorhersagen f√ºr Ihren Ort finden Sie auf weather.com

SUMMARY:
The second series of The A Word starts this evening and I'm eager to see what's changed in the world of autistic Joe and his family.
As a family with two autistic boys, I can't get enough of autism inspired TV.
I know some parents with autistic kids couldn't watch the BBC1 dramatisation.
Anthony will script like Joe, David uses sound to block out the world like Joe, but they are still all different.
It will share what it can be like for a family with autistic kids with a huge audience.
TEXT:
Will the rather iconic image of a little lad wondering down a lane in the Lake District to the sound of awesome beats be entering our world again tonight? The second series of The A Word starts this evening and I'm eager to see what's changed in the world of autistic Joe and his family. Plenty has changed in our lives in the last 18 months since the first series aired, so I'm guessing it'll be the same for them.

As a family with two autistic boys, I can't get enough of autism inspired TV. There's always plenty of opinion about these programmes - it doesn't show enough about autism, it's the nice side of autism or even it's too difficult to watch.

As a parent, my heart ached when character Joe couldn't cope with the birthday parties, I relived the nerves I had when our boys first visited the paediatrician as Joe went for his tests, and I put on my armour as Joe's parents talked to the school. It's not that we don't get on with our kids' school, it's the opposite in fact, but it's emotional armour I'm putting on.

I know some parents with autistic kids couldn't watch the BBC1 dramatisation. It felt too close to home for them. But surely, I wonder, isn't that a good thing?

I spend so much of my life trying to help others accept my children. Most of this is through sharing our experiences, portraying my children as I see them and letting people know my kids aren't to be feared. They aren't trying to be annoying kids. At least in the first series little Joe used headphones - our David has the iPad blasting out tunes at full volume disturbing the entire world.

Joe is, like many of the autistic characters on TV, a half way house between our two boys. Our son Anthony has less difficulty with communicating than Joe does, but our pre-verbal son David definitely has more. Anthony will script like Joe, David uses sound to block out the world like Joe, but they are still all different.

And they develop differently too. In the last year, we've learned that there are few things as important to David as routine and we've had some worries about Anthony's growing independence. Will these feature in the new series?

The week before series one aired we told Anthony, our eldest son, about his autism. Many parents worry about when and how to tell their kids about their diagnoses. I've read that Joe becomes aware of his autism in this series and this will be yet another heart pulling moment for many. We told Anthony because he had noticed, not only that he was different to others, but he hated himself for it. There was not doubt it was time for him to know. And he took that information and owned it - to my sheer delight. How will Joe cope I wonder?

The family on The A Word will undoubtedly have similar and different experiences to our own. Joe, their autistic child, may share traits with our boys. We may laugh at some recognisable situations and cry at others. But ultimately, I hope, the show will do what I try and do. It will share what it can be like for a family with autistic kids with a huge audience. An audience that will go through the lives of this family over the next six weeks and hopefully coming out the other side a bit more knowledgeable, a bit more aware and a bit more accepting.

To read more about our family and our autistic and neurotypical kids, follow the Rainbows are too beautiful blog, on facebook or twitter.
TITLE: What Does A New Series Of 'The A Word' Mean To Us?

SUMMARY:
A new short film imagines a world where everyone has a disability, and the rare few who don't are treated with the same condescension and prejudice as those with disabilities are treated every day.
Not only does the film, 'Jeremy the Dud', flip prejudices on their heads but also features only one main cast member without a real-life disability.
Nick Boshier, better known as one half of the Bondi Hipsters, plays Jeremy a man born "without specialty" which is more casually referred to as "a dud".
Out of the film's cast, 22 with disability are all genU participants, with only two actors appearing without a disability, Boshier and Jackson O'Doherty who plays another dud.
You can watch the full short film above or check out more about the project on the 'Jeremy the Dud' Facebook page.
TEXT:
A new short film imagines a world where everyone has a disability, and the rare few who don't are treated with the same condescension and prejudice as those with disabilities are treated every day.

Not only does the film, 'Jeremy the Dud', flip prejudices on their heads but also features only one main cast member without a real-life disability. Nick Boshier, better known as one half of the Bondi Hipsters, plays Jeremy a man born "without specialty" which is more casually referred to as "a dud".

Forced to wear a large label displaying his lacking specialty, on his birthday Jeremy is old enough to move out of assisted living and in with his Aunt and her two kids. While Jeremy just wants to get a job and maybe find a place of his own, he even tells his Aunt he doesn't want to be a burden, but everyone around him still seems to see him as just that.

'Jeremy the Dud' was created by Robot Army Productions in partnership with genU, a not-for-profit organisation that helps people with disability to set new limits on their lives, to see aging and disability as challenges, rather than disadvantages.

Out of the film's cast, 22 with disability are all genU participants, with only two actors appearing without a disability, Boshier and Jackson O'Doherty who plays another dud. According to the film's release, the production would have to start and stop to make sure only disabled people were in frame.

While 'Jeremy the Dud' takes a tongue-in-cheek approach to subverting the typical stigma and judgement that people with disability may face on a daily basis, at its core has a beautifully heartfelt message.

You can watch the full short film above or check out more about the project on the 'Jeremy the Dud' Facebook page.
TITLE: 'Jeremy The Dud': The Aussie Short Film Flipping The Script On Living With Disability

SUMMARY:
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi attends a function to mark the national Panchayati Raj or village civil council day, in New Delhi, India, Friday, April 24, 2015.
(AP Photo/Manish Swarup)ADVERTISEMENTInternet search giant Google apologised yesterday for any confusion or misunderstanding that arose over the listing of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi‚Äôs photos appearing in image search results for query on ‚ÄúTop 10 criminals in India‚Äù.
As more and more stories connect Narendra Modi to the keywords ‚Äútop 10 criminals‚Äù in news stories and on Twitter, this search result is likely to become indelible unless Google takes deliberate steps to remove Narendra Modi from the result.
This is what they did with George W. Bush, who is no longer the top search result for "miserable failure".
As long as Google remains the world's most popular search engine, SEO experts and hackers will continue their attempts to influence search results, for amusement and profit.
TEXT:
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi attends a function to mark the national Panchayati Raj or village civil council day, in New Delhi, India, Friday, April 24, 2015. Modi on Friday urged Panchayat members to work with a five-year vision with concrete development plans to bring about positive changes in their village and also emphasized on the need for education, according to local reports. (AP Photo/Manish Swarup)

ADVERTISEMENT

Internet search giant Google apologised yesterday for any confusion or misunderstanding that arose over the listing of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi‚Äôs photos appearing in image search results for query on ‚ÄúTop 10 criminals in India‚Äù.

But Modi is not the only misfit on that page. The search page also includes eminent public figures like Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, the founder of Art of Living, Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal, Lawyer and Politician Ram Jethmalani, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, and Bollywood actress Sonakshi Sinha.

So what exactly is going on? This isn‚Äôt the first time that Google‚Äôs algorithm has thrown up some completely whacked out results. A popular technique, known as ‚ÄòGoogle bombing‚Äô was used by pranksters and SEO experts to make George W. Bush the first result for the term ‚Äòmiserable failure‚Äô.

Nothing personal about it: Modi‚Äôs photo appears thrice in Google Image search, right next to extremists like Hafeez Saeed and Osama Bin Laden

If you take a closer look at the source for these results where Narendra Modi‚Äôs photo comes from, two of these are from Topyaps.com, which is creating a perfect viral storm with this post. Another one of these photos comes from a 2014 newswire where Modi promised that the Supreme Court will set up special courts to deal with politicians with criminal backgrounds. Scroll further down, and you now see reaction stories to this new development being indexed too.

As more and more stories connect Narendra Modi to the keywords ‚Äútop 10 criminals‚Äù in news stories and on Twitter, this search result is likely to become indelible unless Google takes deliberate steps to remove Narendra Modi from the result. This is what they did with George W. Bush, who is no longer the top search result for "miserable failure".

Just a few weeks ago, users found out that typing ‚ÄúNigga House‚Äù in Google Maps would direct the user to the White House. In that particular case, it turns out hackers had created a fictitious business which was verified by Google. The next step is to have this business reclaimed from another Google account, which then allows you to change the name and location of the business.

As long as Google remains the world's most popular search engine, SEO experts and hackers will continue their attempts to influence search results, for amusement and profit.

Like Us On Facebook |

Follow Us On Twitter |

Contact HuffPost India
TITLE: India's Top 10 Criminals: Modi Is Not The Only Misfit In The Gallery

Si eres fan de los royals, de seguro tienes fantas√≠as de c√≥mo ser√≠a asistir a una boda real.
"Si te gusta ver a la gente famosa, probablemente no hay nada mejor para ello que una boda real.
El mes pasado una fuente cercana a Harry dijo al US Weekly que se espera que sea una boda de mucho m√°s bajo perfil.
"Puedo adivinar que se casar√° en la Capilla de San Jorge en el castillo de Windsor.
De nuestra parte, lo que decimos es que ¬°ojal√° que nuestra invitaci√≥n no se pierda en el correo!
TEXT:
Si eres fan de los royals, de seguro tienes fantas√≠as de c√≥mo ser√≠a asistir a una boda real. Y ahora que el pr√≠ncipe Harry y Meghan Markle est√°n a punto de unirse en matrimonio, seguramente tus fantas√≠as est√°n a todo lo que dan.

Pero si bien uno s√≥lo puede imaginarse lo que es ser invitado a una boda as√≠, el periodista Duncan Larcombe conoce de primera mano qu√© tan glamoroso es un acto as√≠.

As√≠, mientras no despeg√°bamos la mirada de la tele el d√≠a en que Kate Middleton y el pr√≠ncipe William se dieron el s√≠ en abril de 2011, Larcombe de hecho figur√≥ entre las 1,900 personas que asistieron a la ceremonia nupcial en la Abad√≠a de Westminster.

El ex editor de realeza para The Sun, fue uno de los seis periodistas que asisti√≥ como invitado. "Nos dijeron unas dos o tres semanas por anticipado que ser√≠amos invitados, pero que no lo pod√≠amos decir a nadie", dijo a Elle UK en una reciente entrevista. "No quer√≠a que se esparciera esto entre otros periodistas".

As√≠ que, ¬øqu√© se sinti√≥ al estar entre tantos royals en esa ceremonia? De acuerdo con Larcombe, fue tan surreal como cualquiera lo imagina.

"Fue una experiencia muy extra√±a, algo as√≠ como sentarse en el museo de cera de Madame Tussauds, pero con estatuas parlantes", dijo. "Fue una de las experiencias m√°s incre√≠bles de toda mi vida. Es darse cuenta de que la historia se escribe frente a tus propios ojos.

"No se parece a ninguna de las otras bodas a las que he ido", a√±adi√≥. "Si te gusta ver a la gente famosa, probablemente no hay nada mejor para ello que una boda real. No hay lugar que contenta a tantos famosos y miembros de la realeza bajo un solo techo".

Larcombe tambi√©n pudo ser testigo de momentos francos por parte de los royals, incluyendo c√≥mo el pr√≠ncipe Harry trataba de componerse a s√≠ mismo al lado de su hermano Harry antes de la ceremonia. "Se ve√≠a completamente aterrado", dijo el periodista, y luego, el silencio total que llen√≥ la iglesia cuando la Duquesa de Cambridge finalmente entr√≥.

"Todo lo que pod√≠amos escuchar eran los ecos de la muchedumbre de afuera", dijo.

Si bien Larscombe se√±ala que hubo una espera interminable antes de que iniciara la ceremonia nupcial, el evento bien que vali√≥ la pena. No s√≥lo vio c√≥mo se escrib√≠a la historia ante sus ojos, sino que se demostr√≥ que cada invitado recib√≠a un trato de iguales, sin importar qu√© tan famoso (o no tan famoso) es.

"Fue muy claro en la boda que no importaba si eras el sult√°n de Brunei o un tipo que se ha cruzado en (la Real Academia de) Sandhurst con William, o una estrella de Hollywood... todos tuvimos que llegar temprano", explic√≥, a√±adiendo que la Reina fue la √∫ltima en llegar antes de la novia. "Supongo que para alguien como Sir Elton John, a quien le encanta ser el centro de la atenci√≥n, eso fue algo muy humillante".

Aunque hay mucha emoci√≥n por el eventual compromiso y boda de Harry, su ceremonia nupcial ser√° muy diferente a la de su hermano dado que William es el segundo en la l√≠nea para heredar el trono y Harry es el quinto (y ser√° el sexto cuando el tercer beb√© de William y Catherine nazca). Esto significa que la boda con Markle ser√° un tanto m√°s informal.

El mes pasado una fuente cercana a Harry dijo al US Weekly que se espera que sea una boda de mucho m√°s bajo perfil.

"La pompa y el esplendor es lo menos que Harry quiere", dijo la fuente a ese sitio. "Puedo adivinar que se casar√° en la Capilla de San Jorge en el castillo de Windsor. Con ello, no ser√≠a un circo para los medios y le dar√≠a al evento el sentido de privacidad que Harry tanto quiere".

S√≥lo el tiempo dir√° c√≥mo ser√° la real boda de Harry. De nuestra parte, lo que decimos es que ¬°ojal√° que nuestra invitaci√≥n no se pierda en el correo!
TITLE: Un periodista brit√°nico revela lo que se siente asistir a una boda real

Andy Murray and Kim Sears have welcomed their second baby .

TEXT:
It was announced that Sears had given birth just hours after the tennis champion hosted charity event Andy Murray Live at the SSE Hydro in Glasgow.

Andy Murray and Kim Sears have welcomed their second baby .

The couple, who married in April 2015, are already parents to toddler Sophia.

Murray‚Äôs grandmother gushed that the new baby was: ‚Äúanother little girl, a little sister for Sophia,

‚ÄúHopefully that will be great for her too, she said. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôll have a little playmate!‚Äù

She added that the baby is ‚Äúa good size‚Äù Kim is ‚Äúdoing well‚Äù and they have yet to decide on a baby name.

When Murray told reporters he and Sears were expecting a second child, they asked whether it would affect his performance, Murray replied: ‚ÄúNo, I wouldn‚Äôt have thought so.‚Äù

He has previously spoken out on this topic after former British number one Annabel Croft criticised him in April 2016 when he was defeated at the Miami Open 2016.

Murray responded, telling The Mirror: ‚ÄúI would rather be getting up in the middle of the night and helping Sophia than winning every tennis match and her thinking when she grows up: ‚ÄòActually, you know what, he was a s****y dad but he won a lot of tennis matches, so well done‚Äô.

‚ÄúBecoming a parent is life-changing and if it helps my tennis, great and if it doesn‚Äôt, that‚Äôs fine. That‚Äôs not a problem for me now. My priority is to be a good father first.
TITLE: Andy Murray Baby News: Kim Sears Has Given Birth To Their Second Child
