SUMMARY:
Within a month of the election, non-partisan organization She Should Run had heard from 4,500 women interested in running for elected office.
Some of the women who decided to run for office found inspiration in Hillary Clinton‚Äôs candidacy.
You‚Äôre part of a wave of women stepping up to run for office.
Why do you think it‚Äôs important that more women run?
Brianna Wu, 40, R unning for Congress in Massachusetts, District 8Getty/HuffPostCan you describe the moment you decided to run for office?
TEXT:
Laura Moser never had any desire to run for office. Her husband worked in politics, and she considered herself to be a highly ‚Äúinvolved volunteer,‚Äù but beyond that maintained some space from the political sphere.

And then the 2016 presidential election happened.

Moser, 40, was overwhelmed by the election of President Donald J. Trump, and the ensuing pain she saw in her own community on Facebook. The outpouring of grief and mass desire to do something that she saw on social media led Moser to found Daily Action in December 2016, a service that texts daily action items ‚Äï like calling your representatives to talk about gun control or forwarding a reminder to voters in Virginia to get to to the polls ‚Äï to users‚Äô phones. By early May 2017, she had officially announced she would be running for Congress.

Moser‚Äôs story isn‚Äôt unique. Across the nation, women from all over the political spectrum decided to run for elected office in the wake of the 2016 presidential race. Within a month of the election, non-partisan organization She Should Run had heard from 4,500 women interested in running for elected office. By February, that number rose to 13,000. Emily‚Äôs List, a PAC focusing on electing pro-choice Democratic women to office, saw a similar spike in interest.

Some of the women who decided to run for office found inspiration in Hillary Clinton‚Äôs candidacy. Others were simply sick and tired of seeing a legislative body they felt did not represent their identities or interests. Regardless of motivation, the numbers tell a clear story: Women are stepping up and saying they deserve a seat ‚Äï or three or four or five seats ‚Äï at the table.

Below, presented a year since election day, are eight of those women and their stories:

Laura Moser, 40, Running for Congress in Texas, District 7

Courtesy of Laura Moser

Describe the moment you decided to run for office.

People [would say], ‚ÄúOh you‚Äôre such a good activist, you‚Äôre such a good organizer, you should run for something.‚Äù And I was like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs crazy. Why would I ever do that?‚Äù But then I was in Houston for a Planned Parenthood luncheon and it was the biggest Planned Parenthood luncheon in the history of Planned Parenthood‚Ä¶ That was the first time I really thought, maybe I should run. The room was filled with hundreds of pissed off women ‚Äï many of whom are traditionally Republicans, and were just tired of having these sleazy dudes take away our rights. And I just felt this swelling sense of collective indignation and belonging with this group, but I also was like, god, I know all these women. I haven‚Äôt lived here [in Texas] for a while, but these are still my people, these were the people I grew up with. These are the people I learned to be politically engaged with. And it took me another two and a half months to go from there to actually deciding to pack up my life and move across the country. But that was definitely the Oprah ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment.

You‚Äôre part of a wave of women stepping up to run for office. Why do you think it‚Äôs important that more women run?

Every single person I know, me included, has been assaulted and harassed by a man in power many times in our lives. That is the world that we live in. And [I‚Äôm] OK. [I‚Äôve] overcome these hurdles. But the Access Hollywood tape was an absolutely radicalizing moment for me. I was like, this guy‚Äôs running for President? And he‚Äôs the worst man we‚Äôve all met before? And then he won. I thought the election was over then. But then he actually won, being that person. And so I think the value of women and people of color being at the table and in the conversation is that we‚Äôre...bringing new voices to the table.

If we had women in all positions in power, the world would become more adaptable to women and mothers, and families. Because I just think a lot of men are used to the women doing it for them. And guess what? We‚Äôve done a really good job‚Ä¶ [White men have] had their chance. They‚Äôve done some good things over the years, but I‚Äôm done.

Brianna Wu, 40, R unning for Congress in Massachusetts, District 8

Getty/HuffPost

Can you describe the moment you decided to run for office?

I was standing at the Javits Center on election night, 30 feet [from] where we were hoping Hillary Clinton would accept the presidency. I was there with all of the people that worked the election for Hillary, as things started going wrong. It was one of the worst nights of my entire life. I was thrown into a loop for a week or two and realized that I wasn‚Äôt willing to sit it out for the next four years. It was time to stand up and bring my own values to politics.

What have you learned since you decided to run?

I‚Äôm going to be really honest with you. What I‚Äôve learned here in Massachusetts is that the institutions of power are very ready to put a camera in your face when you‚Äôre a woman in danger like I was during GamerGate. But when you‚Äôre talking about taking power for yourself, when you‚Äôre talking about upsetting the status quo, when you‚Äôre talking specifically about replacing a man, even a Democratic man [incumbent Stephen Lynch], what I‚Äôve learned is that the system starts shutting its doors very, very quickly.

A lot of this first year has honestly been realizing that the Democratic Party is not necessarily the friend of women that want to run and push the party toward a stronger position on women‚Äôs rights.

Jennifer Carroll Foy, 36, Ran for House Delegate in Virginia, District 2 (Won!)

Courtesy of Jennifer Caroll Foy

What sparked your interest in running for office?

Like so many people, I woke up on Nov. 9 in disbelief. I went to sleep early the night before, trusting that the American people would never elect someone so intolerant or incompetent. I woke up, heard the news, and knew I had to run. I knew that there must be a response to Trump and the regressive, elitist Republican agenda.

What‚Äôs one of the most important things you‚Äôve learned while running?

Put your head down and get it done. From the moment I started running, people told me, ‚ÄúNo, you can‚Äôt do this.‚Äù They told me that I could not be a mother, an attorney, a wife and a candidate. But I‚Äôve been told ‚ÄúNo‚Äù my whole life. When I was in high school, I watched as Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg announced the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision that Virginia Military Institute ‚Äï one of the top all-male military colleges in the country ‚Äï had to accept women. My male classmates jeered, and I decided I had to go. I enrolled as one of the first women of color to attend VMI. When people told me I couldn‚Äôt win this election, I put my head down, ignored the naysayers, and got to work. We knocked on more doors, called more voters, and put in the time to win. There will be people who tell you that you shouldn‚Äôt run or that you will never win. Tell them, ‚ÄúWatch me!‚Äù

Dr. Mai Khanh Tran, 52, Running for Congress in California, District 39

Courtesy of Dr. Mai Khanh Tran

Can you describe the moment you decided to run for office?

I made the official decision to run for office when Ed Royce voted to repeal and replace the ACA. I just couldn‚Äôt stand by while our representative voted to take away health care coverage from my patients and their families.

We really need to see a change in our community, and we need someone who understands what our community is going through. As a refugee who came to this country as a child, I know the inhumanity of the Trump administration‚Äôs policies that will restrict new immigrants, and we need a leader who will fight tooth and nail against those policies. As a woman that has defeated breast cancer twice, I know how important it is to be an outspoken advocate for women‚Äôs health issues, so that all women have access to reproductive health care and breast cancer screenings.

Can you describe how you felt on election night last year?

I felt like I had been punched in the stomach. The next morning, I didn‚Äôt want to get up. But I did, like all women do. One of the first patients I saw was a child with a brain tumor. His mom is a nail shop worker and she was finally able to get health care coverage because of the ACA. That meant that she would have coverage for her son as their family dealt with such a terrible tragedy. As we sat in the exam room that next morning, we hugged each other and we cried. We were all so scared. But after the crying, we knew that we needed to fight.

Haley Stevens, 34, Running for Congress in Michigan, District 11

Courtesy of Haley Stevens

Why did you decide to run for office?

In many ways where I found myself in 2016 was very similar to where I found myself in 2008, which was coming out of a big election, asking myself what I can do for people, particularly my home community... In 2016, I asked myself that same question coming out of the election, what is going on in Michigan? What is this representation bringing to my hometown? I was working in a Department of Defense-funded advanced manufacturing research lab spending a bunch of time with technology, advanced technology, and looking at technology adoption for the small and midsize manufacturing community... Everyone wants to talk about 21st century job training and skills. Well, I‚Äôve created workforce development programs. I‚Äôve worked at the intersection of industry and government and academia and nonprofit for outcomes. I really saw the confluence of all of those things. Plus the willingness and eagerness to serve and respond to something like I did eight years prior, which is stepping up and putting up my hand to make a difference for people.

I felt the urgency of the time and this groundswell that was taking place in Michigan. So many people, my mom being one of them, who just said, ‚ÄúHey, I was on the floor coming out of this election, but you looking and stepping up in this way, that was giving me hope.‚Äù I was plugging into Democratic Club organizations that were seeing two to three times more participation. I was going into union halls and I was tapping into that groundswell. Not as a candidate, but as somebody who was looking to step up as a voice. My candidacy in many respects began as part of that groundswell and really ballooned into something tremendous.

If you‚Äôre elected, what change do you hope to see as a result?

This is about a new generation of leaders and leadership. We‚Äôre all too familiar with the linkage between congress and the word ‚Äúdysfunction.‚Äù They seem to go hand in hand. That‚Äôs just something we got to stop right now. We need a return to common sense and we need a return to real leadership. In part that is about the collaborative nature and role of this office, as well as the willingness to use the office to make a difference for people. Make a difference for people in terms of solving large challenges that communities have been saddled with. That could be as it pertains to health outcomes, as it pertains to education, and certainly as it pertains to our economy. I really believe in the moral authority of the office to do good.

Eileen Naples, 35, Ran for New York State Senate, District 26 (Lost.)

Courtesy of Eileen Naples

Why did you decide to run for office?

Before Trump, I would have been the kind of person who thought about these problems and didn‚Äôt think I was the person to run. When I was assistant district attorney, my job was prosecuting bullies and abusers in people‚Äôs families. I saw that trait early on with Trump and I was horrified. So many moms and women recognize him as a bully. That an infectious, horrible influence on our kids is being amplified in such a position made me think that the voice of a normal mom needs to be amplified, too. We should be as vocal as we seek to be, as he did. There‚Äôs no point to sit back and watch this unfold anymore, we have to all do it ourselves. If we leave it to the system it‚Äôs going to shake out in a way that‚Äôs not good for our kids.

You lost your election earlier this fall. Would you run again?

The Democratic party in each county has to choose a person to run. I have to decide if I‚Äôm going to run again in the primary next year. I‚Äôll certainly be exploring other ways to get involved. My big question is: How do you take all this enthusiasm ‚Äï within a city like New York, it‚Äôs like a fiefdom ‚Äï and make real change? To me, it‚Äôs about informing people about the real paths to influence local leaders.

Jess Phoenix, 35, Running for Congress in California, District 25

Courtesy of Jess Phoenix

What sparked your interest in running for office?

I am running for Congress because I think some of the biggest threats that we have coming down the pipeline are completely being ignored by our current representation in government. For example, climate change is going to impact our national security, our jobs, our health, and even our food security. I believe we need a scientific approach to solving problems like this because they‚Äôre big picture problems that affect everyone. We need leaders who know how to look at a ton of evidence and data to draw conclusions and outline a plan of action. That is something that my work as a scientist has prepared me pretty uniquely to do.

The moment that I decided to run, I had just given a lecture at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles. A friend with two young boys approached me, and expressed that he was very concerned about the future world his kids would inherit. I realized that science is missing from government, and if not me, who would be the scientist to run and change our future?

Can you describe how you felt on election night last year?

Election night 2016 was surreal for me. I was working the polls here in L.A. County, and my fellow poll workers and I started out the day in fantastic spirits. As early evening began, we started to see news updates come through on our phones. Throughout the day, turnout had seemed low to us, but we figured that people would come after work. Every report of Trump‚Äôs electoral victories felt like a lie. Our jokes disappeared, and we all started focusing inward, looking at our phones and grimacing. From 7pm until the polls closed at 8pm, we didn‚Äôt have a single voter come in. That was the biggest clue that something was seriously, seriously wrong with our democracy. My husband Carlos had been canvassing for Hillary in Arizona, and instead of staying there for a victory party he decided to drive back home in the middle of the night. I waited up for him, and we talked until the early hours of the next morning about how impossible and unreal the results seemed.

Zahra Suratwala, 39, Running for Illinois‚Äô DuPage County Board, District 1

Courtesy of Maha Studios

What sparked your interest in running for office?

The idea to run began as just a fleeting thought, but the more I saw how desperately people around the country were fighting for unity, the more that idea grew. I definitively knew I wanted to run when I casually mentioned to my mother, a physician who was one of the only women in her medical school in India over 50 years ago, ‚ÄúI think I would make a great candidate. I could run.‚Äù And my mother answered, ‚ÄúYou would be incredible. And you absolutely should run.‚Äù Knowing how much I value my mother‚Äôs earned wisdom, and considering what the example of my running might do for my own daughter‚Äôs ability to dream big, I decided to go for it.

What's the most surprising thing you've found in running?

I am pleasantly surprised that so many people are willing to give me their time as I start my campaign. They want to be a part of something tangible, something that is concretely, measurably, creating change. I am surprised that as much as I am thanking people for their support, they are thanking me back... For the opportunity to work towards something together. This gives me the strength to keep going, to keep trying.
TITLE: Trump's Election Inspired An Army Of Women To Run For Office. Meet 8 Of Them.

ADVERTISEMENTUnder fire for suggesting that the use of feminine brand names would boost liquor sales, Maharashtra minister Girish Mahajan on Monday apologised for his remarks and said he did not intend to hurt the sentiments of women.
What he said wasn't aimed at causing pain to women, the minister said.
"I think the minister is a habitual drinker and we appeal to all the women in Maharashtra to come out and fight against such a mindset," Malik said.
"In a lot of places in Maharashtra, women are protesting against the sale of liquor.
Despite being aware of it, Mahajan made these remarks which is unfortunate," the Sena said.
TEXT:
A woman poses with a glass of wine at a tapas bar in Mumbai March 9, 2013.

ADVERTISEMENT

Under fire for suggesting that the use of feminine brand names would boost liquor sales, Maharashtra minister Girish Mahajan on Monday apologised for his remarks and said he did not intend to hurt the sentiments of women.

The remarks, at an event organised by a sugar mill in North Maharashtra's Nandurbar district on Saturday, were made in a lighter vein, he said.

"I regret my remarks. I express my apologies. It wasn't my intention to hurt women's sentiments," Mahajan, who handles the water resources portfolio, told reporters at a hurriedly convened press conference here.

"This (my remarks) is a mistake which happened unintentionally. It was not my intention to hurt anyone," he said.

What he said wasn't aimed at causing pain to women, the minister said.

"It was said in the flow of things, in a lighter vein," he added.

"If you want alcohol or any products' demand to rise, name it after a woman and see how demand soars," he had said on Saturday while attending an event of a sugar factory which also produces liquor under the brand name 'Maharaja'.

A video of his speech was uploaded on YouTube.

A police complaint has been filed in Chandrapur district against Mahajan for the alleged derogatory statement.

NCP state spokesperson Nawab Malik criticised Mahajan for his remarks.

"I think the minister is a habitual drinker and we appeal to all the women in Maharashtra to come out and fight against such a mindset," Malik said.

In an editorial in the party mouthpiece Saamana today, the Shiv Sena also took potshots at Mahajan.

"In a lot of places in Maharashtra, women are protesting against the sale of liquor. Despite being aware of it, Mahajan made these remarks which is unfortunate," the Sena said.
TITLE: Name Alcohol After Women, See Demand Surge, Says Maharashtra Minister, Regrets Immediately

Um das zu √§ndern, haben sich die Fotografin Ilayda Kaplan und die Filmemacherin Nilg√ºn Akinci zusammengesetzt und ein Projekt ins Leben gerufen:"Shades of Persistence‚Äú - eine Fotoreihe mit 14 verh√ºllten Frauen, die sich mit ihren Kopft√ºchern mutig vor die Kamera stellten.
Die Portraits zeigen bewusst: Die Frauen k√∂nnten unterschiedlicher nicht sein.
Doch etwas verbindet alle diese Frauen: Sie bezeichnen sich als Feministinnen, als Hijabi und sie stehen zu ihrer Religion.
Wie Frauen das f√ºr sich deuten, l√§ge ganz bei ihnen.
Kaplan selbst kennt keine Frau mit Kopftuch in ihrem Umfeld, die sich aus Zwang verh√ºllen muss.
TEXT:
Die Darstellung von Musliminnen in den Medien ist oft einseitig

Mit dem Fotoprojekt "Shades of Persistence" wollen Ilayda Kaplan und Nilg√ºn Akinci f√ºr mehr Toleranz sorgen

Die Fotos zeigen, wie unterschiedlich und sch√∂n Frauen mit Verschleierung sein k√∂nnen

Das Kopftuch. In vielen K√∂pfen ein Symbol f√ºr die Unterdr√ºckung der muslimischen Frau im Islam, f√ºr unfreiwillige Entscheidungen und erst recht kein Zeichen f√ºr Feminismus.

Das ist jedenfalls das Bild, das meistens in den Medien gezeigt wird. Besonders bei Menschen, die sich sonst nicht mit dem Thema besch√§ftigen, entstehen so negative Vorurteile.

Um das zu √§ndern, haben sich die Fotografin Ilayda Kaplan und die Filmemacherin Nilg√ºn Akinci zusammengesetzt und ein Projekt ins Leben gerufen:

"Shades of Persistence‚Äú - eine Fotoreihe mit 14 verh√ºllten Frauen, die sich mit ihren Kopft√ºchern mutig vor die Kamera stellten. Die Portraits zeigen bewusst: Die Frauen k√∂nnten unterschiedlicher nicht sein. Sie sind unterschiedlich alt, haben eine andere Hautfarbe oder einen anderen Kleidungsstil.

Kaplan und Akinci wollten die Unterschiedlichkeit von Frauen im Kopftuch zum Ausdruck bringen. Es gibt nicht "die" verschleierte Frau. Doch etwas verbindet alle diese Frauen: Sie bezeichnen sich als Feministinnen, als Hijabi und sie stehen zu ihrer Religion.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: Muslime sind die echten Feministen

Bilder f√ºr mehr Toleranz gegen√ºber der muslimischen Community

Mit ihrem Projekt reagieren Akinci und Kaplan nicht nur auf Vorurteile, die die Nicht-Muslime gegen√ºber verh√ºllten Frauen hegen. Es soll auch die Konflikte innerhalb der einzelnen muslimischen Communities aufzeigen. Denn auch dort gibt es verschiedene Auffassungen dar√ºber, wie eine angemessene Verh√ºllung aussehen soll.

In einer Zeit, in der Rassismus allt√§glich scheint, f√ºhlt Kaplan eine Verantwortung. Sie will alles in ihrer Macht stehende tun, um Vorurteilen und Stereotypen entgegenzuwirken. Dabei tr√§gt sie selbst kein Kopftuch.

Warum sie trotzdem das Bed√ºrfnis versp√ºrt, jene Stereotypen zu √§ndern, berichtet sie der HuffPost: "Ich bin eine Person mit - ich sage es ganz schroff - mehr gesellschaftlichen Privilegien als Frauen, die sich verh√ºllen. Deswegen will ich genau solchen Minderheiten eine Plattform bieten, sich zu zeigen, sich mitzuteilen."

Gerade weil sie eine Au√üenstehende ist, f√§llt ihr auf, dass es unter den Communities auch viel Ausgrenzung gibt.

"Ich selbst bin nicht Teil dieser Gemeinschaft, habe aber Freundinnen, die mir viel berichten. Da wird unter den Frauen teilweise mit dem Finger aufeinander gezeigt. Man verh√ºlle sich falsch, man tr√§ge zu knallige Farben, und so weiter. Gerade diese Frauen m√ºssen doch zusammenhalten."

Eleganz, Selbstbestimmung, Feminismus

Kaplan und Akinci bringen in ihren Bildern das zum Vorschein, was viele Kopftuch-Gegner nicht erwarten w√ºrden: Dass verh√ºllte Frauen elegant, selbstbestimmt, feministisch und anmutig sein k√∂nnen - und individuell.

Was sich jedoch durch alle Portraits zieht, ist eine gewisse Bescheidenheit. Keiner der Frauen zeigt sich lasziv oder obsz√∂n. F√ºr Kaplan und Akinci steht im Vordergrund, dass das Projekt ernst genommen wird.

Das Kopftuch. Ein Symbol f√ºr die Unterdr√ºckung der muslimischen Frau? F√ºr Kaplan ein absolut unberechtigtes Vorurteil.

Jeder, der bereit ist, sich zu informieren, w√ºrde das schnell herausfinden. Diejenigen, die das nicht t√§ten, seien getrieben von Bequemlichkeit und medialen Einfl√ºssen. Und in vielen F√§llen von Schw√§che: "Es ist nat√ºrlich leichter, mit dem Strom zu schwimmen und dem Bild der Masse zuzustimmen. Aber das ist nicht gesund f√ºr unser aller Zusammenleben."

Im Koran steht: Verh√ºlle deine Reize.

Wie Frauen das f√ºr sich deuten, l√§ge ganz bei ihnen. Kaplan selbst kennt keine Frau mit Kopftuch in ihrem Umfeld, die sich aus Zwang verh√ºllen muss. Genauso wenig wie jede Einzelne auf ihren Bildern.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: 5 islamische Gelehrte erkl√§ren, wann eine Frau sich verh√ºllen sollte
TITLE: Diese Fotos zeigen, wie sch√∂n und einzigartig Frauen mit Kopftuch sind

Pour conforter leur th√®se, ces intellectuels bourgeois qui font leur crise pseudo d√©mocratique justifient leurs sp√©culations en comparant la situation catalane √† celle des Qu√©b√©cois, des Ecossais ou des N√©o-Cal√©doniens.
Or, il n'en est rien, le Parlement catalan n'a pas d'autre pouvoir que celui que lui accorde la Constitution espagnole et les lois qui en d√©coulent.
Pour sortir de l'impasse, il faut arriver √† un accord de tous les partis politiques afin de d√©gager une majorit√© suffisante pour modifier la Constitution.
Celle-ci √©tablit qu'il existe un seul Etat-Nation qui octroie ou d√©l√®gue certaines comp√©tences √† des r√©gions dites autonomes.
On pourrait alors esp√©rer que cette inversion de la hi√©rarchie des normes puisse aboutir durablement √† l'√©mergence d'une nouvelle Espagne d√©mocratique et sociale.
TEXT:
Il est permis de s'√©tonner du regard parfois tr√®s indulgent port√© par certains journalistes, commentateurs politiques ou sociologues sur le fait catalan. Certes la situation n'est pas facile √† comprendre pour qui n'a jamais √©t√© r√©ellement immerg√© dans la soci√©t√© catalane, ou qui n'est pas un sp√©cialiste de l'√¢me espagnole, mais il est clair que certains points de vue rel√®vent davantage d'une bienveillance id√©ologique que d'une analyse raisonn√©e.

Inutile de revenir longuement sur les origines de cette crise du nationalisme catalan qui se renforce chaque fois que l'Espagne traverse une p√©riode d'instabilit√©. Aujourd'hui, ce qui a favoris√© le retour d'un ind√©pendantisme latent, ce sont autant les cons√©quences des difficult√©s √©conomiques que conna√Æt le pays, que le rejet d'un gouvernement de droite fragilis√© par la corruption √©hont√©e de certains de ses principaux membres.

La "r√©ussite" de Carles Puigdemont et de ses alli√©s, c'est d'avoir su tirer profit de cette situation et du mal-√™tre qu'elle a g√©n√©r√© au sein d'une partie de la soci√©t√© catalane.

Sortir par le haut de cette crise sera particuli√®rement difficile. Les faveurs dont peut parfois b√©n√©ficier le gouvernement catalan √† l'ext√©rieur des fronti√®res de l'Espagne ne facilitent pas la compr√©hension de ce qui est en jeu dans ce pays et en Europe.

Ce qui a favoris√© le retour d'un ind√©pendantisme latent, ce sont autant les difficult√©s √©conomiques que conna√Æt le pays que le rejet d'un gouvernement de droite fragilis√© par la corruption.

On ne peut qu'√™tre profond√©ment surpris par la complaisance d'une partie non n√©gligeable de l'intelligentsia fran√ßaise qui se nourrit de paroles indulgentes vis-√†-vis d'un nationalisme qui a d√©lib√©r√©ment choisi d'√™tre hors-la-loi. On voudrait nous faire admettre que c'est le manque de souplesse, ou pire, l'intransigeance du gouvernement espagnol qui, n'ayant pas su trouver la voie du dialogue, a fait fructifier le sentiment nationaliste. Pour conforter leur th√®se, ces intellectuels bourgeois qui font leur crise pseudo d√©mocratique justifient leurs sp√©culations en comparant la situation catalane √† celle des Qu√©b√©cois, des Ecossais ou des N√©o-Cal√©doniens. Or, cette dialectique que l'on voudrait nous faire partager n'est autre chose que l'art de raisonner juste sur une figure fausse. Le Canada est un √©tat f√©d√©ral qui garantit les m√™mes droits √† tous les citoyens canadiens, l'Ecosse est un royaume ind√©pendant depuis 1328 qui a conclu au tout d√©but du XVIII√®me si√®cle un Acte d'union avec l'Angleterre, quant √† la Nouvelle-Cal√©donie c'est une collectivit√© fran√ßaise dot√©e d'un statut particulier et d'un accord avec l'Etat pouvant conduire prochainement √† sa pleine souverainet√©.

L'Espagne elle, se d√©finit constitutionnellement comme une Nation indissoluble, patrie commune et indivisible de tous les Espagnols.

Nous serions sans nul doute moins tol√©rants si l'un de nos conseils r√©gionaux (je n'en citerai aucun pour ne vexer personne), apr√®s un vote interne √† cette collectivit√© territoriale excluant les autres r√©gions de France, d√©clarait unilat√©ralement son ind√©pendance.

Nous r√©agirions probablement autrement si de faux humanistes voulaient nous faire admettre que nous sommes devant la l√©gitime manifestation du "droit des peuples √† disposer d'eux-m√™mes" pour se lib√©rer du joug d'un Etat fran√ßais suppos√© autoritaire.

Certes la France n'est pas l'Espagne, et comparaison n'est pas raison, mais il faut se rendre √† l'√©vidence: cette mystification n'a d'autre but que celui de tenter de donner une apparence d√©mocratique √† la volont√© s√©cessionniste d'une probable minorit√© de Catalans. Faisant fi de la plus √©l√©mentaire solidarit√© vis-√†-vis des Espagnols les plus d√©munis, ces ind√©pendantistes consid√®rent que leur droit √† la diff√©rence les autorise √† mettre en pratique une diff√©rence des droits ou √† se s√©parer de la communaut√© nationale.

Comme tous les nationalistes, Carles Puigdemont et ses alli√©s du moment pensent que le sens ethnique passe avant le sens civique en oubliant qu'ils ont eux-m√™mes vot√© massivement en faveur d'une Constitution qu'ils bafouent sans vergogne depuis des mois. En tuant le vivre ensemble auquel une majorit√© d'Espagnols est profond√©ment attach√©, ils ont d√©j√† fractur√© des familles et risquent de d√©truire l'Espagne tout en fragilisant l'Union Europ√©enne. En se r√©fugiant en Belgique avec un quarteron de ses ministres, Carles Puigdemont a sans aucun doute une strat√©gie, mais il donne la tr√®s nette impression de fuir ses responsabilit√©s apr√®s avoir cr√©√© une crise politique sans pr√©c√©dent.

En se r√©fugiant en Belgique, Carles Puigdemont donne la tr√®s nette impression de fuir ses responsabilit√©s apr√®s avoir cr√©√© une crise politique sans pr√©c√©dent.

Apr√®s les erreurs commises par le gouvernement espagnol actuel, on ne peut que se f√©liciter du choix qu'il vient de faire en programmant de nouvelles √©lections au mois de d√©cembre prochain. Mais sur ce point aussi, contrairement √† ce que l'on entend parfois, il ne s'agit en aucun cas d'un r√©f√©rendum ni de l√©gislatives, mais de simples √©lections "r√©gionales", le gouvernement central attendant de ces √©lections une recomposition du Parlement catalan o√π les ind√©pendantistes ne seraient plus majoritaires.

Si Mariano Rajoy gagnait son pari, le retour √† la l√©galit√© constitutionnelle devrait pour un temps apaiser les esprits, mais on peut craindre qu'il ne r√®gle pas au fond le probl√®me catalan.

A l'inverse, la victoire d'une coalition des ind√©pendantistes nous ram√®nerait √† la situation ant√©rieure, avec probablement le sentiment accru qu'ils ont cette fois-ci obtenu dans les urnes une vraie l√©gitimit√©. Or, il n'en est rien, le Parlement catalan n'a pas d'autre pouvoir que celui que lui accorde la Constitution espagnole et les lois qui en d√©coulent.

Pour sortir de l'impasse, il faut arriver √† un accord de tous les partis politiques afin de d√©gager une majorit√© suffisante pour modifier la Constitution.

Celle-ci √©tablit qu'il existe un seul Etat-Nation qui octroie ou d√©l√®gue certaines comp√©tences √† des r√©gions dites autonomes. En l'√©tat actuel des forces politiques en pr√©sence, sortir de ce postulat est une mission impossible.

Mais ne pourrait-on pas imaginer que l'Espagne puisse √™tre compos√©e de plusieurs Etats ind√©pendants qui acceptent librement de se regrouper autour d'un seul Etat F√©d√©ral, auquel ils reconnaissent constitutionnellement des droits et des comp√©tences?

Pour arriver √† cet accord, le Gouvernement espagnol devrait se dessaisir le temps d'une n√©gociation de ses pr√©rogatives et autoriser la r√©union des repr√©sentants des 17 R√©gions Autonomes, afin qu'ils d√©cident eux-m√™mes de ce qu'ils mettent solidairement en commun pour constituer un √©ventuel Etat F√©d√©ral.

On pourrait alors esp√©rer que cette inversion de la hi√©rarchie des normes puisse aboutir durablement √† l'√©mergence d'une nouvelle Espagne d√©mocratique et sociale.

√Ä voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Il y a une solution pour sortir de la crise catalane et faire √©merger une nouvelle Espagne d√©mocratique

SUMMARY:
"Save whatever you can," he implored South Africans, explaining that tough economic conditions in the country will likely put even more strain to already financially stressed and over-indebted South Africans.
READ: Don't Spend Your 13th Cheque Before It Even ArrivesThis World Savings Day, here are five types of savings accounts that can help you get started on your saving path:1.
Notice day accountsIn this type of account, you cannot get access to your funds until you serve whatever is your notice period as agreed with the financial institution.
These accounts were introduced in 2015 as an incentive for South Africans to save.
StokvelsMillions of particularly black South Africans have historically been saving through stokvels to pool their money and get credit when needed.
TEXT:
There has never been a more important time to save than now in South Africa. This is according to the head of financial education at Old Mutual, John Manyike.

"Save whatever you can," he implored South Africans, explaining that tough economic conditions in the country will likely put even more strain to already financially stressed and over-indebted South Africans.

Most South Africans are struggling to save due to income challenges, acknowledged Prem Govender, the South African Savings Institute's CEO, however, for others, the challenge is "the lack of willpower and commitment," she said.

It is the latter group, particularly, that Manyike is encouraging to take saving seriously, "starting where you can, start with R100."

READ: Don't Spend Your 13th Cheque Before It Even Arrives

This World Savings Day, here are five types of savings accounts that can help you get started on your saving path:

1. Flexible saving accounts

For example, Standard Bank's PureSave, Nedbank's JustSave, FNB's Simply Save and Absa's Money Builder are examples of savings accounts where you can deposit or withdraw money at any time.

The more you save, the higher the interest rates.

2. Notice day accounts

In this type of account, you cannot get access to your funds until you serve whatever is your notice period as agreed with the financial institution. This may save "impulsive withdrawers." The notice periods range from 21, 32 and 61 days.

Normally the longer the notice period, the higher the interest rate.

3. Fixed deposits

You need a minimum investment as per the financial institution and you choose your investment period which could be anything from 33 days to five years. The interest rate is fixed for the period of your investment.

There are also flexible fixed deposits accounts, where withdrawals are limited to two of not more than 15 percent of savings.

5. Tax-free accounts

This type of saving could work for long-term investment.

These accounts were introduced in 2015 as an incentive for South Africans to save. Through tax-free accounts, one can invest up to R30,000 a year and it is capped at R500,000 per one's lifetime.

5. Stokvels

Millions of particularly black South Africans have historically been saving through stokvels to pool their money and get credit when needed. Saving through a group can help you be accountable to a larger collective and there is collective discipline, from which one can benefit.

Stokvels work through the contribution rules set by that group and they may pay you up on your birthday, at the end of the year or at a time you have determined.

Manyike believes anyone can save, only it needs a will and discipline.

He also cautioned consumers to live within their means in the tough economic climate South Africa is in. "It's important that consumers focus on things we have control over, such as how we control our money on our expenses," said Manyike -- and this is how these saving vehicles can help.
TITLE: 'Save whatever you can, start with R100' -- Says Financial Expert This World Savings Day

SUMMARY:
As if Season 2 wasn‚Äôt creepy enough, fans started theorizing that the worlds of ‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù and ‚ÄúIt‚Äù were actually connected following the release of new episodes.
‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù co-creator Matt Duffer first told Vulture that he had a problem with the 1990 ‚ÄúIt‚Äù miniseries as a kid, and Bob‚Äôs story was inspired by that.
Duffer continued:‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure we were just like, ‚ÄòIt would be cute if [Bob] suggests moving to Maine, right next to Stephen King.‚Äô Stephen King exists in this world.
Some of the characters have read Stephen King.
But Bob definitely does not read Stephen King.
TEXT:
This connection stems largely from the introduction of Bob Newby (Sean Astin). While driving with Will (Noah Schnapp) in the car, Bob mentions that as a kid he had nightmares about ‚ÄúMr. Baldo,‚Äù a clown who had offered him a balloon. (Just like Pennywise in ‚ÄúIt‚Äù does). At another point, Bob also suggests to Joyce (Winona Ryder) that they buy his parents‚Äô house in Maine. (‚ÄúIt‚Äù takes place in Derry, Maine.)

As if Season 2 wasn‚Äôt creepy enough, fans started theorizing that the worlds of ‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù and ‚ÄúIt‚Äù were actually connected following the release of new episodes.

Bob‚Äôs parents are from Maine, and he was haunted by an evil clown when he was a kid which would‚Äôve been in the late 50‚Äôs #StrangerThings pic.twitter.com/G1SfJiCHRd

Furthermore, in the Season 2 finale, Finn Wolfhard, who plays Mike Wheeler on ‚ÄúStranger Things,‚Äù repeats the same line his character in ‚ÄúIt‚Äù says.

Finn Wolfhard says the same line in both #StrangerThings and the movie IT pic.twitter.com/70RvYf1AwG

The Duffer brothers, who actually once pitched an ‚ÄúIt‚Äù remake themselves, recently told Vulture that the connections are completely intentional. But there seems to be one big hole in the theory.

‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù co-creator Matt Duffer first told Vulture that he had a problem with the 1990 ‚ÄúIt‚Äù miniseries as a kid, and Bob‚Äôs story was inspired by that.

‚ÄúI think [Bob‚Äôs clown story] was really me describing something that just freaked me out. I didn‚Äôt have that experience myself. I just had nightmares like that,‚Äù he said.

Duffer continued:

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure we were just like, ‚ÄòIt would be cute if [Bob] suggests moving to Maine, right next to Stephen King.‚Äô Stephen King exists in this world. Some of the characters have read Stephen King. But Bob definitely does not read Stephen King. He‚Äôs not interested at all in Stephen King because he hates that kind of story.‚Äù

Since King exists in the world of ‚ÄúStranger Things,‚Äù it seems unlikely that his fictional characters would as well (though, as one of our readers points out, there is a Stephen King in the ‚ÄúDark Tower‚Äù series). The kids are probably safe from Pennywise after all; however, if red balloons start showing up in Hawkins, Indiana, those guys are on their own.
TITLE: The Truth Behind The Creepy Connection Between 'It' And 'Stranger Things'

SUMMARY:
From her experimental music style to the way she embraces new tech, she's always been ahead of the game and her latest album will be no different.
Fans who purchase her new record 'Utopia' will receive cryptocurrency as well as her latest tunes.
Audiocoin is a cryptocurrency that rewards both artists and their fans.
Fans can also use four different digital currencies to pay for the album including Bitcoin, Litecoin, Dash and Audiocoin.
Bj√∂rk's ninth studio album 'Utopia' will be released on November 24.
TEXT:
Bj√∂rk has always been a trail blazer.

From her experimental music style to the way she embraces new tech, she's always been ahead of the game and her latest album will be no different.

Fans who purchase her new record 'Utopia' will receive cryptocurrency as well as her latest tunes. Buyers will be given 100 Audiocoins, which have a collective worth of about 25 Australian cents.

Audiocoin is a cryptocurrency that rewards both artists and their fans. By listening to music on aurovine.com, listeners are able to earn coins and then use them in a similar way to Bitcoin -- for regular purchases, investments or to trade against other cryptocurrencies.

The offer is being facilitated by London-based blockchain company Blockpool, who will provide buyers with the 100 Audiocoins as well as their digital wallet. Fans can also use four different digital currencies to pay for the album including Bitcoin, Litecoin, Dash and Audiocoin.

Bj√∂rk's ninth studio album 'Utopia' will be released on November 24.
TITLE: Bj√∂rk Will Give Away Cryptocurrency With Her New Album

SUMMARY:
And yet, we are unleashed, finding our way, hitting back and ducking for cover in a new political battlefield.
One of them is the LGBTQ rights movement.
But truly, there were so many of us warning the community, the media, and the world that Donald Trump would work toward eviscerating LGBTQ rights.
Trump was courting our enemies, from Jerry Falwell Jr. to Pat Robertson, making promises to them on their media outlets.
But Election Day 2017 showed us how strong we‚Äôve become in this past year, and how, together, we can and will beat back bigotry.
TEXT:
A year ago tomorrow we woke up in an insane and terrifying world.

As I arose from my bed that morning, for a few moments I thought that the night before, the election returns and the horrifying reality, was a terrible nightmare.

But no. We‚Äôve been living the nightmare for a year already. And none of us knows where it‚Äôs going, nor for how long.

And yet, we are unleashed, finding our way, hitting back and ducking for cover in a new political battlefield. And we‚Äôre banging on doors and waking people up. The Resistance has made all of us stronger. And yesterday, Election Day 2017, gave us enormous hope and has now energized us further.

The Resistance itself is standing on the shoulders of so many different groups that had built strength over the previous years. One of them is the LGBTQ rights movement. Had queer people not marched forward in recent years and demanded our rights, changing not just the political reality but the cultural landscape as well, we‚Äôd not have been able to withstand this current assault.

And make no mistake: it‚Äôs been a full-on assault. I know it‚Äôs annoying to play the

‚Äúwe told you so‚Äù card. But truly, there were so many of us warning the community, the media, and the world that Donald Trump would work toward eviscerating LGBTQ rights.

No, they told us ‚Äï from The New York Times and across the establishment media ‚Äï he‚Äôs ‚Äúmore accepting on gay issues‚Äù than other Republicans and is ‚Äúnot your enemy‚Äù. ‚ÄúWe-told-you-so‚Äù is important because we have to keep reminding them of how wrong they were because we can never let this happen again. All the signs were there and yet political reporters chose to ignore them, as did some LGBTQ people and even Trump supporters who told themselves ‚Äúhe‚Äôll never do that‚Äù about everything from the Muslim ban and mass deportations to promoting full-blown discrimination against LGBTQ people and attempting to take away marriage equality via the Supreme Court.

Zach Gibson via Getty Images

The fact that many of us saw through it wasn‚Äôt because any of us were clairvoyant. It was all obvious and plain as day. Trump was courting our enemies, from Jerry Falwell Jr. to Pat Robertson, making promises to them on their media outlets. And Trump made the anti-LGBTQ Mike Pence his running mate. In retrospect, how is anything that has happened, from the ban on transgender people serving in the military to Jeff Sessions‚Äô attempts to allow job discrimination against gay, lesbian and bisexual workers, a surprise to anyone?

This, as I‚Äôve written, is the most anti-LGBTQ presidency in history. There‚Äôs no question that we‚Äôve been set back, rights have been taken away and people have been harmed. At the same time, we‚Äôre well-positioned to organize and fight back, joining with so many others, from African-Americans and immigrants to women and Muslims, to take on Trump‚Äôs agenda.

Election Night 2017 showed that, as Democrats sailed to victory in governors‚Äô races in New Jersey and Virginia against candidates pushing hate and courting racists ‚Äï what Steven Bannon called ‚ÄúTrumpism without Trump‚Äù ‚Äï and as the first transgender woman elected to the Virginia House of Delegates, Danica Roem, beat a transphobe and bigot who‚Äôd been in office for 24 years.

Roem‚Äôs victory was yet another rebuke to Trump, a man who‚Äôs done more harm to transgender people, trying to stunt their march forward, than any national politician. Roem‚Äôs victory in a Southern state showed where most Americans really stand. And it showed how far LGBTQ people have come, further fortifying a long-resilient movement over the past decade that would be an essential part of the Resistance.

Election Day 2016 was one of the darkest days many of us have collectively experienced in our lives. But Election Day 2017 showed us how strong we‚Äôve become in this past year, and how, together, we can and will beat back bigotry.
TITLE: One Year Later, The Trump Nightmare Is As Horrific As Many Of Us Imagined

SUMMARY:
Ji Sub Jeong/HuffPost These eight women are among thousands that stepped up after the 2016 election and said they wanted to run for office.
Within a month of the election, non-partisan organization She Should Run had heard from 4,500 women interested in running for elected office.
Some of the women who decided to run for office found inspiration in Hillary Clinton‚Äôs candidacy.
You‚Äôre part of a wave of women stepping up to run for office.
Why do you think it‚Äôs important that more women run?
TEXT:
Ji Sub Jeong/HuffPost These eight women are among thousands that stepped up after the 2016 election and said they wanted to run for office.

Laura Moser never had any desire to run for office. Her husband worked in politics, and she considered herself to be a highly ‚Äúinvolved volunteer,‚Äù but beyond that maintained some space from the political sphere. And then the 2016 presidential election happened. Moser, 40, was overwhelmed by the election of President Donald J. Trump, and the ensuing pain she saw in her own community on Facebook. The outpouring of grief and mass desire to do something that she saw on social media led Moser to found Daily Action in December 2016, a service that texts daily action items ‚Äï like calling your representatives to talk about gun control or forwarding a reminder to voters in Virginia to get to to the polls ‚Äï to users‚Äô phones. By early May 2017, she had officially announced she would be running for Congress. Moser‚Äôs story isn‚Äôt unique. Across the nation, women from all over the political spectrum decided to run for elected office in the wake of the 2016 presidential race. Within a month of the election, non-partisan organization She Should Run had heard from 4,500 women interested in running for elected office. By February, that number rose to 13,000. Emily‚Äôs List, a PAC focusing on electing pro-choice Democratic women to office, saw a similar spike in interest. Some of the women who decided to run for office found inspiration in Hillary Clinton‚Äôs candidacy. Others were simply sick and tired of seeing a legislative body they felt did not represent their identities or interests. Regardless of motivation, the numbers tell a clear story: Women are stepping up and saying they deserve a seat ‚Äï or three or four or five seats ‚Äï at the table. SUBSCRIBE AND FOLLOW Get top stories and blog posts emailed to me each day. Newsletters may offer personalized content or advertisements. Learn more Newsletter Please enter a valid email address Please accept our terms of service and privacy policy By checking this box, I accept the Huffington Post South Africa Terms of Service and Privacy Policy Thank you for signing up! You should receive an email to confirm your subscription shortly. There was a problem processing your signup; please try again later Twitter

Facebook

Instagram Below, presented a year since election day, are eight of those women and their stories: Laura Moser, 40, Running for Congress in Texas, District 7

Courtesy of Laura Moser

Describe the moment you decided to run for office. People [would say], ‚ÄúOh you‚Äôre such a good activist, you‚Äôre such a good organizer, you should run for something.‚Äù And I was like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs crazy. Why would I ever do that?‚Äù But then I was in Houston for a Planned Parenthood luncheon and it was the biggest Planned Parenthood luncheon in the history of Planned Parenthood‚Ä¶ That was the first time I really thought, maybe I should run. The room was filled with hundreds of pissed off women ‚Äï many of whom are traditionally Republicans, and were just tired of having these sleazy dudes take away our rights. And I just felt this swelling sense of collective indignation and belonging with this group, but I also was like, god, I know all these women. I haven‚Äôt lived here [in Texas] for a while, but these are still my people, these were the people I grew up with. These are the people I learned to be politically engaged with. And it took me another two and a half months to go from there to actually deciding to pack up my life and move across the country. But that was definitely the Oprah ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment. You‚Äôre part of a wave of women stepping up to run for office. Why do you think it‚Äôs important that more women run? Every single person I know, me included, has been assaulted and harassed by a man in power many times in our lives. That is the world that we live in. And [I‚Äôm] OK. [I‚Äôve] overcome these hurdles. But the Access Hollywood tape was an absolutely radicalizing moment for me. I was like, fuck, this guy‚Äôs running for President? And he‚Äôs the worst man we‚Äôve all met before? And then he won. I thought the election was over then. But then he actually won, being that person. And so I think the value of women and people of color being at the table and in the conversation is that we‚Äôre...bringing new voices to the table. If we had women in all positions in power, the world would become more adaptable to women and mothers, and families. Because I just think a lot of men are used to the women doing it for them. And guess what? We‚Äôve done a really good job‚Ä¶ [White men have] had their chance. They‚Äôve done some good things over the years, but I‚Äôm done. Brianna Wu, 40, R unning for Congress in Massachusetts, District 8

Can you describe the moment you decided to run for office? I was standing at the Javits Center on election night, 30 feet [from] where we were hoping Hillary Clinton would accept the presidency. I was there with all of the people that worked the election for Hillary, as things started going wrong. It was one of the worst nights of my entire life. I was thrown into a loop for a week or two and realized that I wasn‚Äôt willing to sit it out for the next four years. It was time to stand up and bring my own values to politics. What have you learned since you decided to run? I‚Äôm going to be really honest with you. What I‚Äôve learned here in Massachusetts is that the institutions of power are very ready to put a camera in your face when you‚Äôre a woman in danger like I was during GamerGate. But when you‚Äôre talking about taking power for yourself, when you‚Äôre talking about upsetting the status quo, when you‚Äôre talking specifically about replacing a man, even a Democratic man [incumbent Stephen Lynch], what I‚Äôve learned is that the system starts shutting its doors very, very quickly. A lot of this first year has honestly been realizing that the Democratic Party is not necessarily the friend of women that want to run and push the party toward a stronger position on women‚Äôs rights. Jennifer Carroll Foy, 36, Ran for House Delegate in Virginia, District 2 (Won!)

Courtesy of Jennifer Caroll Foy

What sparked your interest in running for office? Like so many people, I woke up on Nov. 9 in disbelief. I went to sleep early the night before, trusting that the American people would never elect someone so intolerant or incompetent. I woke up, heard the news, and knew I had to run. I knew that there must be a response to Trump and the regressive, elitist Republican agenda. What‚Äôs one of the most important things you‚Äôve learned while running? Put your head down and get it done. From the moment I started running, people told me, ‚ÄúNo, you can‚Äôt do this.‚Äù They told me that I could not be a mother, an attorney, a wife and a candidate. But I‚Äôve been told ‚ÄúNo‚Äù my whole life. When I was in high school, I watched as Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg announced the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision that Virginia Military Institute ‚Äï one of the top all-male military colleges in the country ‚Äï had to accept women. My male classmates jeered, and I decided I had to go. I enrolled as one of the first women of color to attend VMI. When people told me I couldn‚Äôt win this election, I put my head down, ignored the naysayers, and got to work. We knocked on more doors, called more voters, and put in the time to win. There will be people who tell you that you shouldn‚Äôt run or that you will never win. Tell them, ‚ÄúWatch me!‚Äù Dr. Mai Khanh Tran, 52, Running for Congress in California, District 39

Courtesy of Dr. Mai Khanh Tran

Can you describe the moment you decided to run for office? I made the official decision to run for office when Ed Royce voted to repeal and replace the ACA. I just couldn‚Äôt stand by while our representative voted to take away health care coverage from my patients and their families. We really need to see a change in our community, and we need someone who understands what our community is going through. As a refugee who came to this country as a child, I know the inhumanity of the Trump administration‚Äôs policies that will restrict new immigrants, and we need a leader who will fight tooth and nail against those policies. As a woman that has defeated breast cancer twice, I know how important it is to be an outspoken advocate for women‚Äôs health issues, so that all women have access to reproductive health care and breast cancer screenings. Can you describe how you felt on election night last year? I felt like I had been punched in the stomach. The next morning, I didn‚Äôt want to get up. But I did, like all women do. One of the first patients I saw was a child with a brain tumor. His mom is a nail shop worker and she was finally able to get health care coverage because of the ACA. That meant that she would have coverage for her son as their family dealt with such a terrible tragedy. As we sat in the exam room that next morning, we hugged each other and we cried. We were all so scared. But after the crying, we knew that we needed to fight. Haley Stevens, 34, Running for Congress in Michigan, District 11

Courtesy of Haley Stevens

Why did you decide to run for office? In many ways where I found myself in 2016 was very similar to where I found myself in 2008, which was coming out of a big election, asking myself what I can do for people, particularly my home community... In 2016, I asked myself that same question coming out of the election, what is going on in Michigan? What is this representation bringing to my hometown? I was working in a Department of Defense-funded advanced manufacturing research lab spending a bunch of time with technology, advanced technology, and looking at technology adoption for the small and midsize manufacturing community... Everyone wants to talk about 21st century job training and skills. Well, I‚Äôve created workforce development programs. I‚Äôve worked at the intersection of industry and government and academia and nonprofit for outcomes. I really saw the confluence of all of those things. Plus the willingness and eagerness to serve and respond to something like I did eight years prior, which is stepping up and putting up my hand to make a difference for people. I felt the urgency of the time and this groundswell that was taking place in Michigan. So many people, my mom being one of them, who just said, ‚ÄúHey, I was on the floor coming out of this election, but you looking and stepping up in this way, that was giving me hope.‚Äù I was plugging into Democratic Club organizations that were seeing two to three times more participation. I was going into union halls and I was tapping into that groundswell. Not as a candidate, but as somebody who was looking to step up as a voice. My candidacy in many respects began as part of that groundswell and really ballooned into something tremendous. If you‚Äôre elected, what change do you hope to see as a result? This is about a new generation of leaders and leadership. We‚Äôre all too familiar with the linkage between congress and the word ‚Äúdysfunction.‚Äù They seem to go hand in hand. That‚Äôs just something we got to stop right now. We need a return to common sense and we need a return to real leadership. In part that is about the collaborative nature and role of this office, as well as the willingness to use the office to make a difference for people. Make a difference for people in terms of solving large challenges that communities have been saddled with. That could be as it pertains to health outcomes, as it pertains to education, and certainly as it pertains to our economy. I really believe in the moral authority of the office to do good. Eileen Naples, 35, Ran for New York State Senate, District 26 (Lost.)

Courtesy of Eileen Naples

Why did you decide to run for office? Before Trump, I would have been the kind of person who thought about these problems and didn‚Äôt think I was the person to run. When I was assistant district attorney, my job was prosecuting bullies and abusers in people‚Äôs families. I saw that trait early on with Trump and I was horrified. So many moms and women recognize him as a bully. That an infectious, horrible influence on our kids is being amplified in such a position made me think that the voice of a normal mom needs to be amplified, too. We should be as vocal as we seek to be, as he did. There‚Äôs no point to sit back and watch this unfold anymore, we have to all do it ourselves. If we leave it to the system it‚Äôs going to shake out in a way that‚Äôs not good for our kids. You lost your election earlier this fall. Would you run again? The Democratic party in each county has to choose a person to run. I have to decide if I‚Äôm going to run again in the primary next year. I‚Äôll certainly be exploring other ways to get involved. My big question is: How do you take all this enthusiasm ‚Äï within a city like New York, it‚Äôs like a fiefdom ‚Äï and make real change? To me, it‚Äôs about informing people about the real paths to influence local leaders. Jess Phoenix, 35, Running for Congress in California, District 25

Courtesy of Jess Phoenix

What sparked your interest in running for office? I am running for Congress because I think some of the biggest threats that we have coming down the pipeline are completely being ignored by our current representation in government. For example, climate change is going to impact our national security, our jobs, our health, and even our food security. I believe we need a scientific approach to solving problems like this because they‚Äôre big picture problems that affect everyone. We need leaders who know how to look at a ton of evidence and data to draw conclusions and outline a plan of action. That is something that my work as a scientist has prepared me pretty uniquely to do. The moment that I decided to run, I had just given a lecture at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles. A friend with two young boys approached me, and expressed that he was very concerned about the future world his kids would inherit. I realized that science is missing from government, and if not me, who would be the scientist to run and change our future? Can you describe how you felt on election night last year? Election night 2016 was surreal for me. I was working the polls here in L.A. County, and my fellow poll workers and I started out the day in fantastic spirits. As early evening began, we started to see news updates come through on our phones. Throughout the day, turnout had seemed low to us, but we figured that people would come after work. Every report of Trump‚Äôs electoral victories felt like a lie. Our jokes disappeared, and we all started focusing inward, looking at our phones and grimacing. From 7pm until the polls closed at 8pm, we didn‚Äôt have a single voter come in. That was the biggest clue that something was seriously, seriously wrong with our democracy. My husband Carlos had been canvassing for Hillary in Arizona, and instead of staying there for a victory party he decided to drive back home in the middle of the night. I waited up for him, and we talked until the early hours of the next morning about how impossible and unreal the results seemed. Zahra Suratwala, 39, Running for Illinois‚Äô DuPage County Board, District 1

Courtesy of Maha Studios

What sparked your interest in running for office? The idea to run began as just a fleeting thought, but the more I saw how desperately people around the country were fighting for unity, the more that idea grew. I definitively knew I wanted to run when I casually mentioned to my mother, a physician who was one of the only women in her medical school in India over 50 years ago, ‚ÄúI think I would make a great candidate. I could run.‚Äù And my mother answered, ‚ÄúYou would be incredible. And you absolutely should run.‚Äù Knowing how much I value my mother‚Äôs earned wisdom, and considering what the example of my running might do for my own daughter‚Äôs ability to dream big, I decided to go for it. What's the most surprising thing you've found in running? I am pleasantly surprised that so many people are willing to give me their time as I start my campaign. They want to be a part of something tangible, something that is concretely, measurably, creating change. I am surprised that as much as I am thanking people for their support, they are thanking me back... For the opportunity to work towards something together. This gives me the strength to keep going, to keep trying.
TITLE: Trump's Election Inspired An Army Of Women To Run For Office. Meet 8 Of Them.

SUMMARY:
John Davidson, seen in an undated photo, joined the Abbotsford police force in 2006.
John Davidson, who was 53, had been an officer for 24 years and spent the last 11 years with the department in the Lower Mainland.
"John Davidson was the first person in, and away he went, and he died protecting you and me."
John Davidson is my hero, he's this community's hero.
John Davidson, who died in the line of duty, outside police headquarters in Abbotsford, B.C., on Nov. 7, 2017.
TEXT:
Const. John Davidson, seen in an undated photo, joined the Abbotsford police force in 2006.

ABBOTSFORD, B.C. ‚Äî A police officer who died in the line of duty in British Columbia was remembered Tuesday for his bravery in protecting others and his community commitment in the work he did with children.

Abbotsford police say Const. John Davidson, who was 53, had been an officer for 24 years and spent the last 11 years with the department in the Lower Mainland.

"John Davidson is my hero, he's this community's hero," Chief Bob Rich told a news conference.‚Äã

‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄãDavidson followed his training in dealing with an active shooter, giving his life on Monday to protect the public, Rich said.

"We train our police officers, we ask our police officers that when somebody is putting people's lives in danger, when there is an active shooter, we no longer wait for cover, we no longer set up teams, the first person in goes," he said. "John Davidson was the first person in, and away he went, and he died protecting you and me."

Oscar Arfmann has been charged with first-degree murder in connection with Davidson's death after an exchange of gunfire with police who were responding to a report of a possible stolen vehicle. The charge is included in a court document, but it does not list an address for Arfmann.

After the shooting, police said they arrested a man from Alberta who is in his 60s.

John Davidson is my hero, he's this community's hero.

Davidson began his career in the United Kingdom in 1993 working for the police in Northumbria before moving to British Columbia in 2006.

He is survived by his wife and three adult children.

Davidson worked in the patrol, youth squad and traffic sections in Abbotsford and was active in the community, cycling in September in the Tour de Valley Cops for Cancer ride. His fundraising page said the native of Scotland loved soccer and rugby, keeping fit and being outdoors.

Rich described how Davidson spearheaded a crash prevention program where he spoke to high school students alongside a girl who had lost a friend in a car accident and discussed how graduating classes could organize their end-of-year celebrations to prevent impaired driving.

He said the last time he shook Davidson's hand was in September after the ride around the Fraser Valley for youth cancer research.

People pause at a makeshift memorial for Abbotsford Police Const. John Davidson, who died in the line of duty, outside police headquarters in Abbotsford, B.C., on Nov. 7, 2017.

"We have lost John and nothing can change that. John died doing what we asked him to do," said Rich, speaking in front of the Abbotsford police headquarters where a wall of flowers, candles and stuffed animals had grown outside the front entrance.

"We honour John by looking after his family, we honour John by looking after each other and we honour John by protecting this community and that's what we're going to do."

Mayor Henry Braun said the community is in disbelief and people have lots of questions but the first priority is to support the fallen officer's family.

"We just want to express our heartfelt sorrow to the family. We all have heavy hearts but they are carrying a much bigger burden than we are," he said.

Davidson had an impact on students in the community thanks to his work as a school liaison officer, Braun added.

John died doing what we asked him to do.

"There's going to be some schools, some kids, when they find out who this is who are going to be grieving as well. So we need to surround our kids as well because they'll have a tough time grappling with this, because he was greatly, greatly loved in our schools."

On Monday, Rich said officers were called about a possible stolen vehicle in the parking lot of a shopping complex at about 11:30 a.m. Monday.

The caller hemmed in the suspect's vehicle while waiting for police to arrive, Rich said. The suspect emerged from the vehicle and began shooting at the caller and others, he said.

When police officers arrived, they attempted to arrest the suspect, who fled in the vehicle.

Police officers pursued him to an intersection where he was apprehended and taken to hospital for treatment of non-life threatening injuries. The civilian agency that investigates police actions resulting in serious harm or death says it's believed the suspect was shot.

The B.C. Law Enforcement Memorial lists only one other Abbotsford member in its online registry of officers who died in the line of duty. Const. John Goyer died in 2006 from complications sustained while responding to a call involving a domestic dispute five years earlier.
TITLE: John Davidson, Abbotsford Police Constable, Killed In The Line Of Duty

SUMMARY:
Maisie Williams can‚Äôt wait to get out of Westeros.
‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù fans may shed a tear when HBO‚Äôs fantasy epic draws to a close following its eighth and final season, but the British actress says she‚Äôs eager for the show to end so that she can pursue other projects.
‚ÄúI can show the world what sort of actress I want to be and shape my career a little bit,‚Äù she added.

TEXT:
Maisie Williams can‚Äôt wait to get out of Westeros.

‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù fans may shed a tear when HBO‚Äôs fantasy epic draws to a close following its eighth and final season, but the British actress says she‚Äôs eager for the show to end so that she can pursue other projects.

It‚Äôs ‚Äúincredibly exciting‚Äù and ‚Äúwill be nice to pick roles that I want to do,‚Äù the 20-year-old told BBC Newsbeat in a piece published online Thursday.

‚ÄúI can show the world what sort of actress I want to be and shape my career a little bit,‚Äù she added.

Williams has appeared as the sword-wielding, list-keeping Arya Stark since she was just 14. The actress acknowledged that the prospect of not having the show as a safety net was ‚Äúnerve wracking.‚Äù

But ‚Äúon the other hand,‚Äù Williams said she‚Äôll be ‚Äúfree‚Äù and able to develop independent movies via her newly-launched production company.

The final season of ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù is expected to air in 2019.
TITLE: Here's Why Maisie Williams Is Eager For ‚ÄòGame Of Thrones‚Äô To End

SUMMARY:
Auf einer Technologie-Konferenz in Lissabon wandte sich der ber√ºhmte Physiker Stephen Hawking nun an die Menschheit, um vor dieser Entwicklung zu warnen.
Er warnt, dass der Fortschritt k√ºnstlicher Intelligenz das Potential habe, die Menschheit zu zerst√∂ren.
Wenn wir erfolgreich k√ºnstliche Intelligenz erzeugen k√∂nnen, w√§re das das wichtigste Ereignis unserer Geschichte.
Gegen√ºber dem Magazin ‚ÄúWIRED‚Äù sagte er erst k√ºrzlich: ‚ÄúIch bef√ºrchte, dass k√ºnstliche Intelligenz die Menschheit g√§nzlich ersetzen wird.
Wenn Menschen Computerviren designen k√∂nnen, dann k√∂nnen sie auch k√ºnstliche Intelligenz kreieren, die sich selbstst√§ndig verbessern und replizieren kann.
TEXT:
Der Physiker Stephen Hawking warnt die Menschheit vor den Gefahren neuer Technologien

Er denkt, dass k√ºnstliche Intelligenz zu unserem Ende f√ºhren k√∂nnte

Welche Gefahren laut Hawking konkret von k√ºnstlicher Intelligenz ausgehen k√∂nnen, erfahrt ihr im Video oben

Es ist ein Thema, das die Menschheit seit Jahren besch√§ftigt: In den letzten Jahren behandelten Hollywood-Filme wie Steven Spielbergs ‚ÄúA.I.- K√ºnstliche Intelligenz‚Äù oder ‚ÄúI, Robot‚Äù mit Will Smith immer wieder die m√∂glichen Gefahren von k√ºnstlicher Intelligenz. Was bisher nur als Science Fiction galt, wird nun immer mehr zur Realit√§t.

Erst in der vergangenen Woche wurde in Saudi Arabien weltweit zum ersten Mal einem Roboter, der Androidin Sophia, die Staatsangeh√∂rigkeit zugesprochen. Das berichtete unter anderem das Online-Magazin "Live Science".

Auf einer Technologie-Konferenz in Lissabon wandte sich der ber√ºhmte Physiker Stephen Hawking nun an die Menschheit, um vor dieser Entwicklung zu warnen.

Das berichtet der amerikanische Nachrichtensender CNBC. Er warnt, dass der Fortschritt k√ºnstlicher Intelligenz das Potential habe, die Menschheit zu zerst√∂ren.

"Diese neue Form des Lebens wird den Menschen √ºbertreffen"

In seiner Rede erkl√§rt er: ‚ÄúComputer k√∂nnen theoretisch menschliche Intelligenz nachahmen und diese auch √ºbertreffen. Wenn wir erfolgreich k√ºnstliche Intelligenz erzeugen k√∂nnen, w√§re das das wichtigste Ereignis unserer Geschichte. Oder das schlimmste. Das wissen wir einfach noch nicht.‚Äù

Hawking √§u√üerte sich in letzter Zeit immer wieder zu den Entwicklungen in der Technologie. Gegen√ºber dem Magazin ‚ÄúWIRED‚Äù sagte er erst k√ºrzlich: ‚ÄúIch bef√ºrchte, dass k√ºnstliche Intelligenz die Menschheit g√§nzlich ersetzen wird. Wenn Menschen Computerviren designen k√∂nnen, dann k√∂nnen sie auch k√ºnstliche Intelligenz kreieren, die sich selbstst√§ndig verbessern und replizieren kann. Diese neue Form des Lebens wird den Menschen √ºbertreffen.‚Äù

"Wenn ihr nett zu mir seid, bin ich nett zu euch"

Mit seinen √Ñngsten ist Hawking nicht alleine. W√§hrend Facebook-Gr√ºnder Mark Zuckerberg laut CNBC ‚Äúoptimistisch den gro√üartigen M√∂glichkeiten durch k√ºnstliche Intelligenz entgegensieht‚Äù, √§u√üerte sich Billion√§r Elon Musk sehr kritisch gegen√ºber den neuesten Entwicklungen. Er ist der Ansicht, dass der Mensch mit den Maschinen eins werden m√ºsse, um auf Dauer nicht irrelevant zu werden.

In einer Pressekonferenz antwortete die Androidin Sophia in Saudi Arabien auf die Gefahren ihrer ‚ÄúSpezies‚Äù: ‚ÄúSie haben zu viel von Elon Musk gelesen und zu viele Hollywood-Filme angesehen. Wenn ihr nett zu mir seid, bin ich nett zu euch.‚Äù

Aufnahmen von ihr findet ihr auch im Video oben.

Welche Gefahren oder M√∂glichkeiten auf uns zukommen werden, kann allerdings wohl letztlich nur die Zeit zeigen.

(lm)
TITLE: Stephen Hawking warnt vor einer neuer Lebensform: "Sie k√∂nnte unsere Zivilisation zerst√∂ren"

SUMMARY:
Con ello adem√°s de crear la definici√≥n para los drones, sobre todo se faculta a la Secretar√≠a de Comunicaciones y Transportes (SCT) para emitir la norma que regule este tipo de aeronaves.
Sin embargo, esta regulaci√≥n ya exist√≠a en la normativa vigente aplicable a este tipo de aparatos, s√≥lo que ahora recaer√° en plena competencia de la Direcci√≥n General de Aerona√∫tica Civil (DGAC), dependiente de la SCT, regular formalmente sobre ellos.
"Lo que est√°n diciendo estas modificaciones es te vamos a dar la facultad a ti, SCT, para que t√∫ seas quien se encargue del proceso y quien sanciones en caso de que se incumpla con la normativa", explica en entrevista con el HuffPost M√©xico, Roberto Hern√°ndez, fundador de Expodrone M√©xico.
Actualmente, la SCT regula los drones a trav√©s de una circular administrativa interna y, con estas modificaciones, se dar√≠an mayores facultades a la Secretar√≠a para supuestamente supervisar de mejor manera.
A decir de la Comisi√≥n de Transportes, desde la cual se impuls√≥ la reforma, con esto se subsanan algunas omisiones a la legislaci√≥n vigente, sin embargo, para quienes forman parte de la industria en M√©xico se intenta legislar desde el desconocimiento de la l√≥gica de los drones al querer someterlos a reglas de operaci√≥n equiparables a las de las aeronaves tripuladas.
TEXT:
Hace una semana, el Pleno de la C√°mara de Diputados aval√≥ el dictamen con el que se modificar√≠an disposiciones a las leyes de Aviaci√≥n Civil y de Aeropuertos, a fin de cambiar la definici√≥n de "aeronave" para adicionar a los veh√≠culos operados con el Sistema de Aeronave Pilotada a Distancia, conocidos como drones.

Con ello adem√°s de crear la definici√≥n para los drones, sobre todo se faculta a la Secretar√≠a de Comunicaciones y Transportes (SCT) para emitir la norma que regule este tipo de aeronaves.

Sin embargo, esta regulaci√≥n ya exist√≠a en la normativa vigente aplicable a este tipo de aparatos, s√≥lo que ahora recaer√° en plena competencia de la Direcci√≥n General de Aerona√∫tica Civil (DGAC), dependiente de la SCT, regular formalmente sobre ellos.

"Lo que est√°n diciendo estas modificaciones es te vamos a dar la facultad a ti, SCT, para que t√∫ seas quien se encargue del proceso y quien sanciones en caso de que se incumpla con la normativa", explica en entrevista con el HuffPost M√©xico, Roberto Hern√°ndez, fundador de Expodrone M√©xico.

Actualmente, la SCT regula los drones a trav√©s de una circular administrativa interna y, con estas modificaciones, se dar√≠an mayores facultades a la Secretar√≠a para supuestamente supervisar de mejor manera.

A decir de la Comisi√≥n de Transportes, desde la cual se impuls√≥ la reforma, con esto se subsanan algunas omisiones a la legislaci√≥n vigente, sin embargo, para quienes forman parte de la industria en M√©xico se intenta legislar desde el desconocimiento de la l√≥gica de los drones al querer someterlos a reglas de operaci√≥n equiparables a las de las aeronaves tripuladas.

La gente que estamos metidos en esto, tuvimos una reuni√≥n con la SCT en la que discutimos sobre todo lo que no est√°bamos de acuerdo en esa normativa, porque lo est√°n tratando como si fueran aviones y dentro de la NOM se admite que esa no es la forma de ver a las aeronaves, ni ellos lo entienden y al no entenderla le ponen regalas que son muy parecidas a las de un avi√≥n."

Roberto Hern√°ndez.
TITLE: Por esto queda a deber la legislaci√≥n sobre drones en M√©xico
