TEXT:
Quer√≠a hacerse el gracioso, pero lo √∫nico que consigui√≥ fue desconcertar. Kiko Z√∫√±iga, exjugador del Real Oviedo y de la Real Sociedad, acudi√≥ este martes a First Dates en busca del amor y lo que se llev√≥ fue un aluvi√≥n de cr√≠ticas en Twitter.

Los seguidores del programa de Cuatro quedaron tan descolocados con su intervenci√≥n como su cita, M√≥nica. El donostiarra de 55 a√±os entr√≥ en el programa cantando el himno del Athletic de Bilbao, que interpret√≥ a d√∫o con el presentador Carlos Sobera, y lo siguiente que hizo fue imitar el habla argentina.

Kiko y el f√∫tbol son uno y M√≥nica tiene una soltura con las tarjetas rojas que da calambre #FirstDates477 https://t.co/K7ZrmLUOps pic.twitter.com/8HuYYfQVnU ‚Äî First dates (@firstdates_tv) 7 de noviembre de 2017

Ese fue el acento con el que se present√≥ a M√≥nica, una administrativa granadina de 49 a√±os, que al llegar confes√≥ tener "mucha paciencia con la humanidad" y poca con sus hijas. Y paciencia demostr√≥ cuando se top√≥ con Kiko. S√≥lo hay que ver en el v√≠deo del programa [minuto 01.45] la intensidad con la que se present√≥. "¬øPero de d√≥nde ven√≠s, vos?", le pregunt√≥, antes de entregarle una rosa. "M√≥nica, for you, one flor, one rosita", sigui√≥.

M√≥nica no daba cr√©dito y lo primero que le pregunt√≥ fue su origen. "Vengo de ac√°, vengo de all√°", sigui√≥ vacil√°ndola. "Venga, dime de d√≥nde eres y as√≠ nos conocemos, que tenemos un rat√≠n enorme. Yo vengo de Granada...", le contest√≥ ella con paciencia, casi como una maestra present√°ndose a sus alumnos de infantil.

No mostraron tanta tranquilidad los espectadores, que fueron r√°pido al ataque.

Que pereza Kiko, que le digas de donde eres co√±o... #FirstDates477 ‚Äî Antonio Mu√±oz Caro (@Anton10MuozCaro) 7 de noviembre de 2017 #FirstDates477 Kiko, no sabes que lo poco agrada y lo mucho enfada? Deja ya la bromita de hacerte el argentino. ‚Äî Ana Pitusilla (@AnaPitusilla) 7 de noviembre de 2017

"Estaba descolocada", se re√≠a en la grabaci√≥n postcita. "No s√© c√≥mo cogerlo", dec√≠a M√≥nica a c√°mara.

La cita del ahora entrenador no perdi√≥ la esperanza e insisti√≥ en llevar la cita por una vertiente m√°s c√≥mica y lo consigui√≥ durante unos minutos cuando le pregunt√≥ por su historia sentimental anterior. Fue solo un rato porque en cuanto pudo, volvi√≥ con el tono jocoso, hasta el punto que M√≥nica le pregunt√≥: "¬øPara qu√© vienes aqu√≠? ¬øPara re√≠rte un rato?".

Los seguidores del programa se solidarizaron con ella y siguieron con el ataque.

Despu√©s de tanta broma, el veredicto del p√∫blico fue claro.

M√°s paciencia (ya lo hab√≠a dicho nada m√°s empezar) demostr√≥ M√≥nica que, pese a todo, se acord√≥ de que todo el mundo merece una segunda oportunidad y lo invit√≥ a Granada. S√≥lo le sac√≥ tarjeta amarilla.

Al final era cierto que M√≥nica ten√≠a paciencia, tanta que hasta le ha dado una segunda cita a Kiko #FirstDates477 https://t.co/K7ZrmLUOps pic.twitter.com/v2PrTNxZyB ‚Äî First dates (@firstdates_tv) 7 de noviembre de 2017

Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson at the C40 mayors' summit in Mexico City, Dec. 2016.
Robertson is warning homeowners if they fail to declare their property status by Feb. 2, they will face the city's empty homes tax plus a $250 fine.
Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson is warning homeowners if they fail to declare their property status by Feb. 2, they will face the city's empty homes tax plus a $250 fine.
The tax is one per cent of a home's assessed value.
Robertson says property owners can expect to receive instructions in the mail starting this week on how to make their declarations.
TEXT:
Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson at the C40 mayors' summit in Mexico City, Dec. 2016. Robertson is warning homeowners if they fail to declare their property status by Feb. 2, they will face the city's empty homes tax plus a $250 fine.

Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson is warning homeowners if they fail to declare their property status by Feb. 2, they will face the city's empty homes tax plus a $250 fine.

The tax is one per cent of a home's assessed value.

It affects any property that is not a principal residence and is not occupied for six months a year.

Robertson says property owners can expect to receive instructions in the mail starting this week on how to make their declarations.

Watch: Vancouver house prices are unaffordable for the middle class

He says there is a $10,000 fine for false declarations and the city is in the process of setting up an enforcement system that will include hiring staff in the new year.

The tax is the first of its kind in Canada and is aimed at freeing up as many as 20,000 units for rent as the city's vacancy rate hovers near zero.

Robertson says the city must do everything it can to ease the housing crunch, and it's also proceeding with a plan to open 600 new units of temporary modular housing for the homeless.

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: Vancouver's Empty Home Tax Is On Its Way, City Warns Residents

Die als "Pizza-Connection 2.0" bekanntgewordene Gruppe von Gr√ºnen und CDU-Politikern um Omid Nouripour und Jens Spahn, die seit Jahren mit einem B√ºndnis lieb√§ugeln.

TEXT:
Bei den Jamaika-Sondierungen geht es zu Beginn der Woche zum ersten Mal nennenswert voran

Grund daf√ºr ist, dass die Gr√ºnen von ihren Forderungen abr√ºcken

Andere Parteien zeigen derlei Kompromissbereitschaft bisher nicht

"50 zu 50", sagt FDP-Generalsekret√§rin Nicola Beer.

"80 zu 20", meint Gr√ºnen-Politiker Robert Habeck.

Allein an den Antworten, f√ºr wie wahrscheinlich die sondierenden Politiker ein Zustandekommen der Jamaika-Koalition halten, l√§sst sich erkennen, wer derzeit der konstruktive Motor der Koalitions-Vorverhandlungen ist.

Die Gr√ºnen, oft als Spielverderber, als piefige Verbots-Partei gescholten, werden dieser Tage zu M√∂glichmachern. Dazu hat die Partei zu Beginn der zweiten Sondierungswoche zwei wichtige rote Linien aus dem Wahlkampf aufgegeben. Und das ausgerechnet beim Gr√ºnen-Kernthema Klimaschutz.

So besteht Parteichef Cem √ñzdemir nicht mehr auf einem Ende des Verbrennungsmotors bis 2030. Vorsitzende Simone Peter hat derweil die Koalitionsbedingung in Sachen Kohlekraft aufgeweicht. "F√ºr uns kommt es nicht darauf an, ob das letzte Kohle-Kraftwerk 2030 oder 2032 vom Netz geht. Da sind wir pragmatisch", sagte Peter der "Rheinischen Post".

Das gr√ºne Schreckgespenst, das nach Bekanntwerden des Wahlergebnisses wohl besonders in den Albtr√§umen einiger CSU-Politiker regelm√§√üige Cameo-Auftritte hatte, hat damit ausgespukt. An seine Stelle trat ein Fortschrittsgeist, der auf Dialog und Kompromiss setzt. Auf all das, was FDP und CSU bisweilen vermissen lassen.

CSU-Mann Dobrindt gr√§tscht dazwischen, wo es nur geht

Denn das Gegenst√ºck zu den gerade so konstruktiv auftretenden Gr√ºnen stellt gerade die Partei aus Bayern dar. Statt sich √ºber die in Reichweite scheinende √úbereinkunft in der Klimapolitik zu freuen, hatte CSU-Politiker Alexander Dobrindt am Dienstag nichts Besseres zu tun, als das gr√ºne Zugest√§ndnis mit einer beispiellosen Dreistigkeit ins L√§cherliche zu ziehen.

"Wenn man Schwachsinnstermine abr√§umt, dann ist das ja noch kein Kompromiss", sagte Dobrindt der "S√ºddeutschen Zeitung" und bekr√§ftigte so einmal mehr den Eindruck, dass die Jamaika-Partei mit den wenigsten Sitzen unter den (m√∂glicherweise bald) Regierenden gleichzeitig die Partei mit dem gr√∂√üten Ego ist.

Dobrindt machte so nur noch deutlicher, dass es ‚Äì wenn √ºberhaupt ‚Äì vor allem die anderen sein werden, die Jamaika m√∂glich machen. Das gilt zumal f√ºr Kanzlerin Angela Merkel, die bisweilen vor allem als Moderatorin auftritt und sich vorsichtig optimistisch gibt. Die als "Pizza-Connection 2.0" bekanntgewordene Gruppe von Gr√ºnen und CDU-Politikern um Omid Nouripour und Jens Spahn, die seit Jahren mit einem B√ºndnis lieb√§ugeln.

Und nun vielleicht sogar FDP-Chef Christian Lindner.

Der reagierte positiv auf die Gr√ºnen-Signale und k√ºndigte Abstriche bei Forderungen f√ºr eine gro√üe Steuerreform an. Ihn habe weniger die Ank√ºndigung zum Verzicht auf das strikte Ausstiegsdatum beim Verbrennungsmotor √ºberrascht, da hier bei den Gr√ºnen keine Einigkeit bestanden habe.

Mit gro√üer Aufmerksamkeit habe er aber registriert, dass sich die Gr√ºnen beim Kohleausstieg bewegt h√§tten.

Vielleicht haben sie damit sogar weitere Verschiebungen in Gang gesetzt. Nun w√§ren eigentlich auch mal die anderen dran.

SUMMARY:
Wenn wir die Wahl haben zwischen Glaubw√ºrdigkeitsverlust oder Neuwahlen, entscheiden wir uns f√ºr Neuwahlen.
Wenn wir die Wahl haben zwischen Glaubw√ºrdigkeitsverlust oder Neuwahlen, entscheiden wir uns f√ºr Neuwahlen.
Wir sind uns mit den Gr√ºnen v√∂llig einig, dass wir die Klimaschutzziele 2050 erreichen m√ºssen.
Wenn wir den Verbrennungsmotor abschaffen, bevor wir das Reichweitenproblem der E-Autos gel√∂st haben, machen wir realit√§tsferne Politik an den Menschen vorbei.
Wenn wir die Kohle jetzt parallel zur Kernenergie aus dem Stromnetz rausnehmen, m√ºssen wir mit fl√§chendeckenden Blackouts rechnen.
TEXT:
In der zweiten Jamaika-Sondierungsrunde wird es ernst: Es geht um den Klimaschutz

F√ºr die FDP-Generalsekret√§rin Nicola Beer stehen die Chancen auf eine Einigung weiterhin bei 50 zu 50, sagt sie im HuffPost-Interview

Au√üerdem sieht sie trotz der Kompromissbereitschaft der Gr√ºnen gro√üe Differenzen

Nach dem Start der zweiten Sondierungsrunde geht es bei Jamaika ums Eingemachte. Nicht nur beim Klimaschutz gibt es weiter Konfliktpotenzial - auch die Fl√ºchtlingspolitik ist ein zentraler Streitpunkt.

F√ºr die FDP-Generalsekret√§rin Nicola Beer stehen die Chancen auf eine Einigung deswegen weiter bei 50 zu 50. In einem Interview mit der HuffPost sagte sie zum Beginn der Gespr√§che:

"Am Ende ist f√ºr uns klar: Wir werden uns nicht selbst verleugnen. Wenn wir die Wahl haben zwischen Glaubw√ºrdigkeitsverlust oder Neuwahlen, entscheiden wir uns f√ºr Neuwahlen. Aber das ist nicht unser Ziel."

Die Gr√ºnen gingen am Morgen einen ersten gro√üen Schritt auf die potentiellen Partner zu. Sowohl beim Verbrennungsmotor als auch beim Kohleausstieg zeigten sie Kompromissbereitschaft.

"Wir haben die heutigen Aussagen des Gr√ºnen-Chefs in diese Richtung als Signal der Einigungsbereitschaft aufgenommen", sagte Beer. Dennoch sieht die FDP-Generalsekret√§rin noch gro√üe Differenzen. "Wir wollen einen Klimaschutz, der funktioniert. Da sind wir gr√ºner als die Gr√ºnen", sagte sie.

"Wir m√ºssen uns eingestehen, dass unsere jetzige Klimaschutzpolitik nicht funktioniert hat. Sie ist die teuerste der Welt, aber wir haben keine einzige Tonne CO2 eingespart. Das ist doch v√∂llig widersinnig."

Auch bei der Fl√ºchtlingspolitik rief sie den Verhandlungspartner zur Kompromissbereitschaft auf.

"Ich setze darauf, dass auch Cem √ñzdemir irgendwann f√ºr logische Argumente zug√§nglich wird und in seinem Wahlkreis merkt, dass auch dort nicht alle Fl√ºchtlinge aufgenommen werden k√∂nnen", sagte Beer.

Das Interview lest ihr hier:

Frau Beer, nehmen wir an, Sie erhalten ein Freiticket f√ºr einen Jamaika-Urlaub und k√∂nnen einen Unterh√§ndler aus der Union oder von den Gr√ºnen mitnehmen. Wer w√§re das?



Von den Verhandlungspartnern kann ich mir auf der Insel sicher eine nette Zeit mit CSU-Generalsekret√§r Andreas Scheuer machen. Aber eigentlich m√ºsste ich nat√ºrlich meine bessere H√§lfte mitnehmen.

Heute gehen die Jamaika-Verhandlungen in die zweite Runde, doch es hakt gewaltig. Wird das noch etwas mit der Koalition?

Ich sehe die Chancen nach wie vor bei 50 zu 50, dass Jamaika gelingt. In den kommenden Tagen wird es darum gehen, die Gr√§ben aus dem Weg zu r√§umen und eine gemeinsame Vision zu entwickeln, die jeder unterschreiben kann.

Das klingt jetzt sehr freundlich. FDP-Chef Lindner redet schon √ºber Neuwahlen und eine m√∂gliche Oppositionsrolle. Wo soll das hinf√ºhren?



Am Ende haben wir keine Angst vor Neuwahlen, das wollte er deutlich machen. Uns geht es um eine neue Politik, die deutlich werden muss. Aber wir arbeiten auch nicht auf Neuwahlen hin.



K√∂nnen Sie uns das versprechen?



Ja.



Woher dann das Gerede √ºber Neuwahlen?



Am Ende ist f√ºr uns klar: Wir werden uns nicht selbst verleugnen. Wenn wir die Wahl haben zwischen Glaubw√ºrdigkeitsverlust oder Neuwahlen, entscheiden wir uns f√ºr Neuwahlen. Aber das ist nicht unser Ziel.



Haben Sie einen kleinen Westerwelle-Komplex ‚Äì nicht noch einmal aus dem Bundestag ausscheiden?



Ich neige nicht zu Komplexen, egal, mit welchem Namen Sie das verbinden. Ich neige dazu, feste Prinzipien zu haben. Am Ende muss unsere liberale Handschrift klar erkennbar sein. Wir stehen nicht als St√ºtzrad f√ºr eine Schwarz-Rote Politik, wie sie die vergangenen vier Jahre gemacht wurde.



Die Gr√ºnen sind ja auch noch mit dabei.



Ja, aber man hat ja schon den Eindruck, dass Schwarz-Gr√ºn bereits Vorgef√ºhle entwickelt hat.



Woran machen Sie das fest?



Wenn ich mir den ein oder anderen Gespr√§chsverlauf anschaue. Aber ich m√∂chte nicht zu viele Internas aus den Sondierungsgespr√§chen verraten. Generell ist uns nat√ºrlich klar, dass wir nicht alle unsere Forderung durchsetzen k√∂nnen. Doch unsere liberale Handschrift muss erkennbar sein.



Gro√üe Differenzen gibt es mit den Gr√ºnen beim Thema Klimaschutz. Wie wollen Sie hier einen Kompromiss erreichen?



Wir sind uns mit den Gr√ºnen v√∂llig einig, dass wir die Klimaschutzziele 2050 erreichen m√ºssen. Allerdings m√ºssen wir das physikalisch hinbekommen.



Gr√ºnen-Politiker Robert Habeck sagte, alle Parteien m√ºssen sich ‚Äúam Riemen rei√üen‚Äù. Das klingt nicht so, als w√§re man sich v√∂llig einig.



Wir sind uns bei den Zielen einig. Beim Weg dorthin hingegen bisher nicht. Wir m√ºssen uns eingestehen, dass unsere jetzige Klimaschutzpolitik nicht funktioniert hat. Sie ist die teuerste der Welt, aber wir haben keine einzige Tonne CO2 eingespart. Das ist doch v√∂llig widersinnig. Wir wollen einen Klimaschutz, der funktioniert. Da sind wir gr√ºner als die Gr√ºnen.



Was ist die Alternative?



Wir k√∂nnen unsere ehrgeizigen Ziele nur mit Technologien erreichen, die sich noch nicht durchgesetzt haben. Das m√ºssen wir in unserer Klimapolitik dringend miteinbeziehen.



Geben Sie uns ein Beispiel.



Etwa bei der Mobilit√§t. Wenn wir den Verbrennungsmotor abschaffen, bevor wir das Reichweitenproblem der E-Autos gel√∂st haben, machen wir realit√§tsferne Politik an den Menschen vorbei.

Wir haben die heutigen Aussagen des Gr√ºnen-Chefs in diese Richtung als Signal der Einigungsbereitschaft aufgenommen, wie Christian Lindner ja auch deutlich gemacht hat. Klare, erreichbare Ziele und Technologieoffenheit zu ihrer Erreichung statt auf Verbote zu setzen, das muss die Devise sein. Und so ist es auch mit der Kohlekraft.



Warum?



Wir haben jetzt schon Probleme mit der Versorgungssicherheit. Bei manchen Unternehmen flackert das Stromnetz und gef√§hrdet damit die Produktion, weil der Strommix aus den Erneuerbaren in Sto√üzeiten nicht ausreicht. Wenn wir die Kohle jetzt parallel zur Kernenergie aus dem Stromnetz rausnehmen, m√ºssen wir mit fl√§chendeckenden Blackouts rechnen. Das kann niemand wollen.



Was ist mit Erdgas? Das ist effizienter und nicht ganz so schmutzig wie Kohle.



Fakt ist doch: Bislang haben uns die Gr√ºnen nicht vorrechnen k√∂nnen, wie sie einen Kohleausstieg ausgleichen wollen. Da bliebe uns nur √ºbrig, Kohle- und Kernenergie aus Frankreich und Polen zuzukaufen. Ob die Gr√ºnen so wirklich das Klima retten, bezweifle ich.



Reden wir √ºber den Umgang zwischen den Jamaika-Parteien. FDP-Chef Lindner hat den Gr√ºnen etwa vorgeworfen, ein ‚ÄúKonjunkturprogramm f√ºr die AfD‚Äù zu betreiben. CSU-General Scheuer nennt die Gr√ºnen ‚Äúschizophren‚Äù. Woher kommt die schlechte Laune?



Wir schauen schlicht auf die Realit√§ten. Beispiel Fl√ºchtlingspolitik, worauf sich das Zitat von Christian Lindner ja bezog. Nat√ºrlich ist ein Familiennachzug, wie ihn die Gr√ºnen wollen, in gewissen Bereichen sinnvoll - etwa, wenn derjenige seine Familie hier in Deutschland ern√§hren kann, weil er einen Job und eine Wohnung hat.

Aber das funktioniert nur, wenn wir diejenigen abschieben, die kein Bleiberecht haben. Sonst werden uns die B√ºrger zurecht auf die Barrikaden gehen. Denn wir k√∂nnen nicht jeden aufnehmen.



Wie wollen Sie die Gr√ºnen davon √ºberzeugen?



Es gibt auch bei den Gr√ºnen Politiker wie Herrn Palmer, die davon bereits √ºberzeugt sind. Sie wissen, dass es vor Ort Schwierigkeiten gibt, einen unbegrenzten Zuzug von Fl√ºchtlingen zu schultern. Es fehlen Wohnungen, Klassenr√§ume, Lehrkr√§fte und Kita-Pl√§tze.



Herr Palmer aber spricht nicht f√ºr seine Partei. Wie wollen Sie etwa Parteichef √ñzdemir √ºberzeugen?



Ich setze darauf, dass auch Cem √ñzdemir irgendwann f√ºr logische Argumente zug√§nglich wird und in seinem Wahlkreis merkt, dass auch dort nicht alle Fl√ºchtlinge aufgenommen werden k√∂nnen.



Schauen wir auf CSU-Chef Horst Seehofer. Es wirkt so, als liefe gegen ihn ein innerparteilicher Putsch. Glauben Sie, dass er noch lange am Verhandlungstisch von Jamaika sitzen wird?



Das muss die CSU entscheiden.



Lohnt es sich, Kompromisse mit jemandem zu machen, der wom√∂glich schon bald nicht mehr f√ºr seine Partei spricht?



Am Ende des Tages machen wir Kompromisse mit der CSU, nicht mit Horst Seehofer.

Beobachter sehen die Jamaika-Verhandlungen durch die Personaldiskussion in der CSU grunds√§tzlich in Gefahr. Teilen Sie diese Sorge?



Unsere Verhandlungen k√∂nnten schneller voranschreiten, wenn die CSU so geschlossen w√§re wie die FDP. Aber Streit gibt es auch bei den Gr√ºnen, die sich untereinander nicht immer einig sind.

(lp)
TITLE: FDP-Generalsekret√§rin Beer kritisiert Jamaika-Verhandlungen zur Klimapolitik: "Wir sind gr√ºner als die Gr√ºnen"

TEXT:
VIOL - L'islamologue et th√©ologien suisse controvers√© Tariq Ramadan, vis√© par deux plaintes pour viol en France et accus√© d'abus sexuel sur des mineures en Suisse, est mis en cong√© de l'universit√© d'Oxford, o√π il enseigne, a annonc√© mardi 7 novembre l'universit√©.

"D'un commun accord et avec effet imm√©diat, Tariq Ramadan, professeur d'√©tudes islamiques contemporaines a pris un cong√© de l'universit√© d'Oxford", indique l'universit√© dans un communiqu√©, soulignant que ce cong√© "n'implique aucune pr√©somption ou acceptation de culpabilit√© et permet au professeur Ramadan de r√©pondre aux accusations extr√™mement graves port√©es contre lui".

Tariq Ramadan, 55 ans, petit-fils du fondateur de la confr√©rie √©gyptienne islamiste des Fr√®res musulmans, et brillant orateur, b√©n√©ficie d'une forte popularit√© dans les milieux musulmans conservateurs. Il est aussi tr√®s contest√©, notamment dans les sph√®res la√Øques, qui voient en lui le tenant d'un islam politique

Deux plaintes pour viol

Il a √©t√© vis√© par deux plaintes pour viol en France, survenues au milieu de la vague de lib√©ration de la parole qui a suivi l'affaire Weinstein, du nom du puissant producteur am√©ricain accus√© de viols et d'agressions sexuelles.

Tariq Ramadan s'est d√©fendu farouchement de ces accusations de viol en d√©non√ßant sur sa page Facebook une "campagne de calomnie" qui f√©d√®re ses "ennemis de toujours". Ce p√®re de quatre enfants, mari√© depuis plus de 30 ans √† une Fran√ßaise convertie s'est dit "serein et d√©termin√©".

Samedi, la Tribune de Gen√®ve a publi√© un long article consacr√© √† quatre anciennes √©l√®ves de Tariq Ramadan lorsqu'il enseignait le fran√ßais et la philosophie √† Gen√®ve entre 1984 et 2004. Parmi ces quatre femmes, trois ont avou√© avoir c√©d√© √† "l'emprise psychologique" de leur professeur et avoir eu des relations sexuelles avec lui, l'une √† 15 ans et les deux autres √† 18 ans. La quatri√®me, qui avait 14 ans √† l'√©poque, √©voque le harc√®lement auquel elle a d√ª faire face.

Sur son compte twitter, Tariq Ramadan a d√©menti "cat√©goriquement" ces all√©gations et annonc√© le d√©p√¥t d'une plainte contre X pour diffamation.

Au Royaume-uni, un scandale de harc√®lement sexuel √©branle la classe politique depuis plusieurs semaines, visant des personnalit√©s de premier plan. L'universit√© d'Oxford dit avoir "toujours reconnu la gravit√© des all√©gations contre le professeur Ramadan, tout en soulignant l'importance de l'impartialit√© et des principes de justice et de proc√©dure r√©guli√®re".
TITLE: Tariq Ramadan mis en cong√© de l'universit√© d'Oxford apr√®s des accusations de viols

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTNEW DELHI -- The National Human Rights Commission has issued a notice to the Uttar Pradesh government over the death of 26 people in a blast at an NTPC plant in Rae Bareli.
It said there was need to ensure that such tragedies do not recur.
The notice has been sent to the chief secretary of the state.
A detailed report is expected from the government within six weeks, the rights panel said.
At least 26 persons died after a massive explosion in one the boilers at the state-run power giant's Unchahar plant yesterday.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

NEW DELHI -- The National Human Rights Commission has issued a notice to the Uttar Pradesh government over the death of 26 people in a blast at an NTPC plant in Rae Bareli.

Expressing its concern over the incident, the Commission said in a statement today that a "high-level probe into the matter is immediately required to ascertain the negligence and errors, if any, behind the incident, which involves the right to life".

It said there was need to ensure that such tragedies do not recur.

The notice has been sent to the chief secretary of the state. A detailed report is expected from the government within six weeks, the rights panel said.

At least 26 persons died after a massive explosion in one the boilers at the state-run power giant's Unchahar plant yesterday.
TITLE: NHRC Issues Notice To UP Government Over NTPC Blast

SUMMARY:

TEXT:

SUMMARY:
OTTAWA ‚Äî There was a time when the Communications Security Establishment didn't want people to know it even existed.
On an unaided basis, just three per cent of respondents correctly named "CSE" or the "Communications Security Establishment" as the government agency responsible for intercepting and analyzing foreign communications and helping protect the government's computer networks, the survey report says.
Communications Security Establishment (CSE) Chief Greta Bossenmaier takes part in a news conference in Ottawa, June 16, 2017.
About one in five people thought the Canadian Security Intelligence Service performed those duties.
In reality, CSIS's main role is investigating threats ‚Äî such as terrorism and espionage ‚Äî to Canadian security.
TEXT:
OTTAWA ‚Äî There was a time when the Communications Security Establishment didn't want people to know it even existed.

The 70-year-old cyberspy agency is now trying to emerge from the shadows, but a newly released survey suggests it is still little known to Canadians.

On an unaided basis, just three per cent of respondents correctly named "CSE" or the "Communications Security Establishment" as the government agency responsible for intercepting and analyzing foreign communications and helping protect the government's computer networks, the survey report says.

Communications Security Establishment (CSE) Chief Greta Bossenmaier takes part in a news conference in Ottawa, June 16, 2017.

About one in five people thought the Canadian Security Intelligence Service performed those duties. In reality, CSIS's main role is investigating threats ‚Äî such as terrorism and espionage ‚Äî to Canadian security.

When the Communications Security Establishment, or CSE, was mentioned by name, nearly two in five (37 per cent) said either yes (26 per cent) or maybe (11 per cent) when asked if they had heard of it before, the report says.

Ekos Research Associates conducted 10-minute telephone questionnaires about the CSE with 1,205 Canadian adults in May. The results are considered accurate to within plus or minus 2.8 percentage points, with a 95-per-cent level of confidence.

Thrust into headlines due to Edward Snowden

The $83,000 Ekos survey was commissioned to help the CSE better understand the public's awareness and attitudes towards the agency and shape communications strategies, as well as to explore views about career opportunities to guide recruitment of new employees.

The Ottawa-based CSE uses highly advanced technology to intercept, sort and analyze foreign communications for nuggets of intelligence interest to the federal government. It is a member of the Five Eyes intelligence alliance that also includes the United States, Britain, Australia and New Zealand.

The secretive CSE has been thrust into the headlines in recent years due to leaks by Edward Snowden, the former spy contractor who worked for the National Security Agency, the CSE's American counterpart.

It has also tried to be more open about its activities ‚Äî at least to a point ‚Äî through increased use of social media and participation in public events.

People just don't pay attention because we're relatively safe. Stephanie Carvin, Carleton University

But it seems none of that has made the CSE a household name.

Academia, the media, the government and spy agencies themselves could play a bigger role in informing the public about the security world, said Stephanie Carvin, an assistant professor of international relations at Carleton University's Norman Paterson School of International Affairs.

"It's clear that Canadians aren't educating themselves on these institutions," Carvin said.

"We have this reputation for being the peaceable kingdom. People just don't pay attention because we're relatively safe."

Civil liberties group suing CSE

When provided a brief description of CSE's dual interception and protection role, over four in five respondents to the Ekos survey said they considered the agency to be important, including just over half who said the CSE was very important.

The British Columbia Civil Liberties Association is suing the CSE, claiming it breaches the constitutional rights of Canadians by intercepting their private communications. The agency insists it respects privacy and abides by Canadian laws.

Nearly three in four respondents said they either completely (14 per cent) or somewhat trusted (59 per cent) the CSE to act ethically and legally in fulfilling its mandate.

At the same time, 43 per cent said they were concerned about information that government intelligence agencies may be collecting about them.

Earlier On HuffPost:
TITLE: Just 3% Of Canadians Can Name The Communications Security Establishment: Survey

TEXT:
We've all gotten used to Sia Furler hiding her face during performances and appearances, but now the 'This Is Acting' singer has acted boldly after someone tried to exploit her.

"Someone is apparently trying to sell naked photos of me to my fans," Furler tweeted on Tuesday afternoon, "Save your money, here it is for free".

Someone is apparently trying to sell naked photos of me to my fans. Save your money, here it is for free. Everyday is Christmas! pic.twitter.com/aeQlnTwLuy ‚Äî sia (@Sia) November 7, 2017

Furler's screenshot of the cheeky image also included a message from the seller attempting to exploit her for their financial gain. "If you make the purchase," the message reads, "it will be unblurred and you will receive and [sic] additional 14 images".

After Furler posted the image her fans were quick to embrace the move of undercutting the gross invasion of her privacy.

IÔ∏è thought IÔ∏è couldn't love you any more than when IÔ∏è saw you singing to a baby at a coffee shop in Echo Park but here we are November 7, 2017

Furler is currently working on a festive album 'Everyday Is Christmas' which is set to release on November 17.
TITLE: Someone Was Trying To Sell Nude Photos Of Sia So She Tweeted One Herself

SUMMARY:
Boris Johnson has been savaged by Labour‚Äôs Emily Thornberry and Yvette Cooper for a diplomatic blunder that risks extending a jail term for a British woman arrested in Iran.
Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry laid into Johnson, declaring Theresa May didn‚Äôt have the ‚Äústrength or authority‚Äù to sack him, but he should do the decent thing and resign.
How many more times does the Foreign Secretary have to insult our international partners, damage our diplomatic relations, and now imperil the interests of British nationals abroad?
The Foreign Secretary said that he also intended to take a trip to Iran personally to try to secure her release.
Boris Johnson doesn‚Äôt understand magnitude of the job & responsibility he holds https://t.co/lZkeoETlSp ‚Äî Anna Soubry MP (@Anna_Soubry) November 7, 2017
TEXT:
Boris Johnson has been savaged by Labour‚Äôs Emily Thornberry and Yvette Cooper for a diplomatic blunder that risks extending a jail term for a British woman arrested in Iran. Amid shouts of ‚Äúresign!‚Äù and ‚Äúshame!‚Äù, the Foreign Secretary also came under heavy attack from Tory MPs such as Anna Soubry after he refused to apologise properly for his remarks about Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe. Johnson admitted ‚ÄúI could have been clearer‚Äù when he claimed last week that Zaghhari-Ratcliffe had been training journalists in Iran - a line which was seized on by the Tehran authorities as proof that she was ‚Äòspreading propaganda‚Äô against the regime. But he sparked anger after he refused repeated requests to apologise for his comments. Eventually, he said he was ‚Äòsorry‚Äô- but only ‚Äòif‚Äô his words had been taken out of context. Zaghari-Ratcliffe‚Äôs employer the Thomson-Reuters foundation had insisted the Foreign Secretary should correct his remarks, amid claims that Iranian judges want to double her possible sentence for alleged spying from five years to 10 years. She was arrested last year after a family holiday to see relatives. Her three-year-old daughter has been placed with grandparents while her mother has been locked in jail, often in solitary confinement. Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry laid into Johnson, declaring Theresa May didn‚Äôt have the ‚Äústrength or authority‚Äù to sack him, but he should do the decent thing and resign.

PA Wire/PA Images Boris Johnson at the Foreign Affairs Committee last week.

Thornberry said that he should say sorry for ‚Äúthe distress and anguish that his foolish words have caused‚Äù to Zaghari-Ratcliffe and her family. ‚ÄúHow many more times does this need to happen? How many more times does the Foreign Secretary have to insult our international partners, damage our diplomatic relations, and now imperil the interests of British nationals abroad? ‚ÄúWhat will it take before the Prime Minister will say ‚ÄòEnough is Enough‚Äô? ‚ÄúBut if the truth is that she can‚Äôt, because she doesn‚Äôt have the strength or authority to sack him, how about the Foreign Secretary himself showing a bit of personal responsibility, and admitting that a job like this, where your words hold gravity and your actions have consequences, is simply not the job for him.‚Äù

Empics Entertainment Yvette Cooper.

Cooper was just as withering, declaring ‚Äúthe lives and the safety of British citizens across the globe depends on having a Foreign Secretary who does not bluster and is not too careless or too lazy to consider his words‚Äù. ‚ÄúThe Foreign Secretary cannot be trusted to do this job. And he should resign.‚Äù Johnson said that Zaghhari-Ratcliffe‚Äôs husband Richard had sent him a note welcoming his clarification. The Foreign Secretary said that he also intended to take a trip to Iran personally to try to secure her release. And he hit back at Thornberry, insisting that the Iranian foreign minister had assured him his remarks had had no bearing on the sentencing process. ‚ÄúShe deflects blame and accountability for those holding that mother in jail - and that is the Iranian regime,‚Äù Johnson said. Eventually, after his 40-minute grilling, Johnson expressed his regrets for his words, although only with a caveat that they had been misinterpreted. Lib Dem MP Layla Moran, whose Oxford constituency includes family members of the jailed mother, said: ‚ÄúThe fact is the family have been worried sick, by his irresponsible comments. ‚ÄúOn a human level is the Foreign Secretary at all sorry for the rollercoaster of emotions he has caused Nazanin and her family this week and could he at least apologise to them today?‚Äù

PA Wire/PA Images Anna Soubry

Johnson replied: ‚ÄúOf course I‚Äôm sorry if any words of mine have been so taken out of context and so misconstrued as to cause any kind of anxiety for the family of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, of course I am..‚Äù But he faced a fresh backlash for qualifying his apology with the word ‚Äòif‚Äô.

Classic non-apology ... I m sorry ‚Äòif‚Äô - might have saved himself a lot of bother if he‚Äôd just said he made a mistake + promised to fix it https://t.co/oJB0RbQjUL ‚Äî Laura Kuenssberg (@bbclaurak) November 7, 2017

The lack of contrition is as shameful as the original error. Boris Johnson doesn‚Äôt understand magnitude of the job & responsibility he holds https://t.co/lZkeoETlSp ‚Äî Anna Soubry MP (@Anna_Soubry) November 7, 2017
TITLE: Boris Johnson Savaged By Emily Thornberry And Yvette Cooper Over His Iran Blunder

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTThe Morning Wrap is HuffPost India's selection of interesting news and opinion from the day's newspapers.
Essential HuffPostNavin Singh's goof-up of Vande Mataram's lyrics exposes BJP's hypocrisy on patriotism, writes Sandip Roy, urging the ruling party to practice what it preaches.
In a first, the Supreme Court Wednesday directed the Centre to constitute special courts to exclusively try criminal cases involving politicians.
The call for it should emanate from all self respecting citizens who place a premium on the rule of law, writes HS Puri and HS Khalsa in the Hindustan Times.
The definition of harassment needs to be constantly updated, and the process for justice made more robust, argues Veena Venugopal in The Hindu.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The Morning Wrap is HuffPost India's selection of interesting news and opinion from the day's newspapers. Subscribe here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

Essential HuffPost

Navin Singh's goof-up of Vande Mataram's lyrics exposes BJP's hypocrisy on patriotism, writes Sandip Roy, urging the ruling party to practice what it preaches.

India jumped into 100th place on the World Bank's ranking of countries by Ease of Doing Business for the first time in its report for 2018, up about 30 places, driven by reforms in access to credit, power supplies and protection of minority investors.

Hollywood star Dustin Hoffman has been accused of sexually harassing a 17-year-old intern on the set of his 1985 TV adaptation Death of a Salesman.

Main News

A massive explosion ripped a boiler at the state-run power giant NTPC's Unchahar plant in Uttar Pradesh's Rae Bareli district today, killing at least 20 people and injuring nearly 100, officials said.

At least two people were killed and one injured in a shooting inside a Walmart store in suburban Denver on Wednesday, police said.

In a first, the Supreme Court Wednesday directed the Centre to constitute special courts to exclusively try criminal cases involving politicians.

Off The Front Page

In a first, an Indian canine breed is being trained for induction into the Army, which has been using foreign breeds like German Shepherds, Labradors and Great Swiss Mountain dogs till now.

A week after a man allegedly pushed off four of his daughters from a running train, resulting in the death of one of the girls in Uttar Pradesh's Sitapur district, government railway police traced the culprit's house in Bihar's Bettiah town. The accused is still absconding.

A day after naming Prem Kumar Dhumal as the BJP's chief ministerial candidate in Himachal Pradesh, party chief Amit Shah hit out at incumbent CM Virbhadra Singh and Congress vice president Rahul Gandhi saying they were deeply enmeshed in corruption.

Opinion

In The Indian Express, Pratap Bhanu Mehta writes about the strategies employed by the Chinese Communist Party to bury the revolutionary spirit of 1917.

The Sikh community has largely moved on from the massacres of 1984 but justice still eludes them. The call for it should emanate from all self respecting citizens who place a premium on the rule of law, writes HS Puri and HS Khalsa in the Hindustan Times.

The definition of harassment needs to be constantly updated, and the process for justice made more robust, argues Veena Venugopal in The Hindu.

Also on HuffPost
TITLE: The Morning Wrap: BJP's Patriotism Fail; SC Wants Special Courts To Try Politicians

TEXT:
Bei den Jamaika-Sondierungen geht es zu Beginn der Woche zum ersten Mal nennenswert voran

Grund daf√ºr ist, dass die Gr√ºnen von ihren Forderungen abr√ºcken

Andere Parteien zeigen derlei Kompromissbereitschaft bisher nicht

"50 zu 50", sagt FDP-Generalsekret√§rin Nicola Beer.

"80 zu 20", meint Gr√ºnen-Politiker Robert Habeck.

Allein an den Antworten, f√ºr wie wahrscheinlich die sondierenden Politiker ein Zustandekommen der Jamaika-Koalition halten, l√§sst sich erkennen, wer derzeit der konstruktive Motor der Koalitions-Vorverhandlungen ist.

Die Gr√ºnen, oft als Spielverderber, als piefige Verbots-Partei gescholten, werden dieser Tage zu M√∂glichmachern. Dazu hat die Partei zu Beginn der zweiten Sondierungswoche zwei wichtige rote Linien aus dem Wahlkampf aufgegeben. Und das ausgerechnet beim Gr√ºnen-Kernthema Klimaschutz.

So besteht Parteichef Cem √ñzdemir nicht mehr auf einem Ende des Verbrennungsmotors bis 2030. Vorsitzende Simone Peter hat derweil die Koalitionsbedingung in Sachen Kohlekraft aufgeweicht. "F√ºr uns kommt es nicht darauf an, ob das letzte Kohle-Kraftwerk 2030 oder 2032 vom Netz geht. Da sind wir pragmatisch", sagte Peter der "Rheinischen Post".

Das gr√ºne Schreckgespenst, das nach Bekanntwerden des Wahlergebnisses wohl besonders in den Albtr√§umen einiger CSU-Politiker regelm√§√üige Cameo-Auftritte hatte, hat damit ausgespukt. An seine Stelle trat ein Fortschrittsgeist, der auf Dialog und Kompromiss setzt. Auf all das, was FDP und CSU bisweilen vermissen lassen.

CSU-Mann Dobrindt gr√§tscht dazwischen, wo es nur geht

Denn das Gegenst√ºck zu den gerade so konstruktiv auftretenden Gr√ºnen stellt gerade die Partei aus Bayern dar. Statt sich √ºber die in Reichweite scheinende √úbereinkunft in der Klimapolitik zu freuen, hatte CSU-Politiker Alexander Dobrindt am Dienstag nichts Besseres zu tun, als das gr√ºne Zugest√§ndnis mit einer beispiellosen Dreistigkeit ins L√§cherliche zu ziehen.

"Wenn man Schwachsinnstermine abr√§umt, dann ist das ja noch kein Kompromiss", sagte Dobrindt der "S√ºddeutschen Zeitung" und bekr√§ftigte so einmal mehr den Eindruck, dass die Jamaika-Partei mit den wenigsten Sitzen unter den (m√∂glicherweise bald) Regierenden gleichzeitig die Partei mit dem gr√∂√üten Ego ist.

Dobrindt machte so nur noch deutlicher, dass es ‚Äì wenn √ºberhaupt ‚Äì vor allem die anderen sein werden, die Jamaika m√∂glich machen. Das gilt zumal f√ºr Kanzlerin Angela Merkel, die bisweilen vor allem als Moderatorin auftritt und sich vorsichtig optimistisch gibt. Die als "Pizza-Connection 2.0" bekanntgewordene Gruppe von Gr√ºnen und CDU-Politikern um Omid Nouripour und Jens Spahn, die seit Jahren mit einem B√ºndnis lieb√§ugeln.

Und nun vielleicht sogar FDP-Chef Christian Lindner.

Der reagierte positiv auf die Gr√ºnen-Signale und k√ºndigte Abstriche bei Forderungen f√ºr eine gro√üe Steuerreform an. Ihn habe weniger die Ank√ºndigung zum Verzicht auf das strikte Ausstiegsdatum beim Verbrennungsmotor √ºberrascht, da hier bei den Gr√ºnen keine Einigkeit bestanden habe.

Mit gro√üer Aufmerksamkeit habe er aber registriert, dass sich die Gr√ºnen beim Kohleausstieg bewegt h√§tten.

Vielleicht haben sie damit sogar weitere Verschiebungen in Gang gesetzt. Nun w√§ren eigentlich auch mal die anderen dran.

SUMMARY:
On October 9, just over six weeks after Rohingya refugees started surging over the border from Myanmar, I arrived in Cox's Bazar in southeast Bangladesh.
By then there were already more than half a million new arrivals, joining some 300,000 refugees already in the country.
I flew into Bangladesh straight from Jordan where I'd been working at Zaatari refugee camp for Syrians.
In the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis we are constantly playing catch up.
What has overwhelmed me in Bangladesh so far is the incredible resilience I have witnessed among the Rohingya communities.
TEXT:
On October 9, just over six weeks after Rohingya refugees started surging over the border from Myanmar, I arrived in Cox's Bazar in southeast Bangladesh. By then there were already more than half a million new arrivals, joining some 300,000 refugees already in the country. I flew into Bangladesh straight from Jordan where I'd been working at Zaatari refugee camp for Syrians.

In southern Bangladesh the people are welcoming but the environment is not. It is hot and humid, with uneven terrain and jungle. Conditions are rough. Refugees are given bamboos sticks and plastic sheets as they arrive to construct temporary shelters for their families, but it's hardly adequate shelter for the long-term and we will need to establish more durable shelter solutions quickly.

The first day I was on site I met a brave pregnant woman who had crossed the border with her three young children, having lost her husband to the conflict in Myanmar. Despite everything, she was fiercely independent and determined to set up her shelter on her own. She refused any external help and built her bamboo-framed structure with only the assistance of her seven-year-old son. She is proud of her achievement but equally concerned with the inadequacy of her new home; the plastic sheeting leaks rainwater to the interior and there is no thermal insulation whatsoever. Being heavily pregnant does not make it easier for her to cope in such uncomfortable conditions.

These people do not complain, and they do not sit on their laurels. They are active, strong and independent with amazing skills in construction.

Overcrowding is an immense challenge. UNHCR's two existing refugee camps were swamped within days of the influx. Bangladesh is one of the world's most densely populated countries already, with 163 million people living in an area smaller than Victoria, so finding land to accommodate huge numbers of refugees isn't straightforward -- especially with thousands more arriving daily. In the world's fastest-growing refugee crisis we are constantly playing catch up.

The Bangladeshi Government has allocated a 'mega' site of approximately 2,800 acres for the extension of Kutupalong refugee camp -- one of the existing UNHCR camps. However, a high percentage of this land is unusable because it is either prone to flooding, is already cultivated with rice paddies, or the slope is far too steep to build on without risk of landslides. Therefore, this site alone won't be sufficient, and we need to keep working with the government to find new land to accommodate everyone.

The throngs of young children that follow us around each day are a reminder of what we're working for. There are so many children who simply wish to be able to live a normal life, go to school every day and not fear for their safety.

I met a boy called Than who is 11 years old and wants to be a pilot when he grows up. Than is worried that he is falling behind in his studies and this may jeopardise his future. I desperately hope that with somewhere safe and secure to live, Than will be able to return to school and achieve his dreams.

Since I arrived, I've been onsite most days in a small team of technical staff, developing a transit centre for new arrivals. We need to work out where tents can go to maximise the use of space, where toilets and showers can be situated for ease of reach, as well as making sure there will still be access for delivery vehicles with supplies, or ambulances in emergencies.

The transit centre site, despite being government land, was actually being leased to a Bangladeshi family who were using it as a rubber plantation when the refugees began arriving. It took time and negotiation before we could proceed with using the land for the transit centre. We had to promise the leaser that we would only cut down two trees, which greatly restricted our ability to erect the two required portable warehouses, the 120 family tents and 25 bamboo structures. With some onsite modifications to the plan, we were able build all necessary facilities.

What has overwhelmed me in Bangladesh so far is the incredible resilience I have witnessed among the Rohingya communities. The speed at which they are rebuilding their homes is extraordinary -- vast tracks of land within the expansion zone are being developed with every passing day. These people do not complain, and they do not sit on their laurels. They are active, strong and independent with amazing skills in construction.

It is the Rohyinga refugees who are paving out the new footpaths in the expansion zones and who are building the bamboo bridges across water bodies. It is inspirational and heart-warming to witness.

__________________________

To donate, visit the UNHCR website or call 1300 722 943.
TITLE: In The Fastest-Growing Refugee Crisis The Rohingya Are Showing Their Resilience

SUMMARY:
OTTAWA ‚Äî The federal government has decided to change course on its proposed legislation to end sex-based discrimination in the Indian Act.
"Something that First Nations women have been waiting for for nearly 150 years."
Sen. Lillian Eva Dyck said a government amendment to the Indian Act will restore full legal status to First Nations women.
Once passed, the government amendment would ensure Indigenous women finally get the same ability to transmit their registered Indian status to family members, Dyck said.
The previous Senate amendment would have focused on issues beyond merely the sex-based inequities, creating ambiguities and potential legal problems, Harder said.
TEXT:
OTTAWA ‚Äî The federal government has decided to change course on its proposed legislation to end sex-based discrimination in the Indian Act.

The government's point man in the Senate, Sen. Peter Harder, told the upper chamber Tuesday that the government is offering to make a change that would restore full legal status to First Nations women and their descendants born prior to 1985 ‚Äî a measure that moved Indigenous Sen. Lillian Dyck to tears.

"Colleagues, if we pass today's motion, something wonderful will happen," Dyck told the chamber, her voice cracking. "Something that First Nations women have been waiting for for nearly 150 years."

Sen. Lillian Eva Dyck said a government amendment to the Indian Act will restore full legal status to First Nations women.

The Indian Act, which dates back to 1876, remains the primary law defining the relationship between the federal government and First Nations across the country. Its original definitions focused primarily on men, denying women many of the same privileges and powers as their male counterparts when it came to their Indian status.

Numerous amendments over the years have chipped away at those imbalances, but critics say the document as it currently stands continues to treat women unfairly, particularly when it comes to their Indian status and their ability to pass that status along to their descendants.

Once passed, the government amendment would ensure Indigenous women finally get the same ability to transmit their registered Indian status to family members, Dyck said.

"Your language, your culture, your connection to your family, your connection to your community."

Dyck recently joined forces with Sen. Sandra Lovelace-Nicholas and other advocates as part of an awareness campaign to urge the Liberal government to change the bill.

Part of the outreach, supported by the Canadian Feminist Alliance for International Action, included the distribution of a letter last week to women's organizations, academics and human rights groups to drum up support for the "full and final removal" of sex discrimination in the Indian Act.

First Nations women can breath sigh of relief: senator

The government and officials have now found an acceptable solution to a standoff between the Senate and the House of Commons, said Dyck, who urged her fellow senators to pass Harder's proposal by the end of the week.

"Let's move it and urge the members in the (House of Commons) to concur," she said.

First Nations women can breathe a sign of relief, Dyck added. "I know I will."

In June, the Senate unanimously passed a change to the bill designed to ensure Indigenous women and their descendants enjoy the same Indian status under the law as their male counterparts.

The House of Commons, however, did not originally accept the Senate's proposal, with the government saying it needed more time to examine the potential impacts.

The previous Senate amendment would have focused on issues beyond merely the sex-based inequities, creating ambiguities and potential legal problems, Harder said.

Bill was in response to Quebec court decision

The government's original bill would only have addressed discrimination in Indian Act registration since 1951, when a more modern registry was created. The amendment would, among other things, also address inequities created between 1869 and 1951, said the office of Crown-Indigenous Relations Minister Carolyn Bennett.

The Liberal government's bill was in response to a Quebec Superior Court decision that ruled certain sections of the Indian Act related to registration status violated the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

The case was brought by Stephane Descheneaux of the Abenaki community of Odanak, about 40 kilometres northwest of Drummondville, Que.

Descheneaux was unable to pass on his Indian status to his three daughters because he got it through his Indigenous grandmother, who lost her status when she married a non-Indigenous man.

Also On HuffPost:
TITLE: Liberal Government Changes Course On Update To Discrimination In Indian Act

SUMMARY:
After 10 art therapy sessions, the patients who suffered from severe or moderately severe depression had shown more improvement than the patients in the control group, the researchers concluded.
During the research, conducted by Sahlgrenska Academy at the University of Gothenburg , 43 patients with ‚Äúsevere‚Äù or ‚Äúmoderately severe‚Äù depression underwent an art therapy course.
Art therapy has a ‚Äúclear effect‚Äù on severe depression, helping some people to get back to work after time off, new research suggests.
The individual art therapy took place in psychiatry or primary care and was conducted by a specially trained therapist.
‚ÄúThe conclusion is that it was the art therapy that facilitated their improvement,‚Äù Blomdah said.
TEXT:
After 10 art therapy sessions, the patients who suffered from severe or moderately severe depression had shown more improvement than the patients in the control group, the researchers concluded.

Activities within the therapy sessions included instructions such as: ‚Äúcreate a picture of how you are feeling on this particular day.‚Äù

Meanwhile a control group of 36 people with depression and symptoms of the same level did not take part in art therapy.

During the research, conducted by Sahlgrenska Academy at the University of Gothenburg , 43 patients with ‚Äúsevere‚Äù or ‚Äúmoderately severe‚Äù depression underwent an art therapy course.

Art therapy has a ‚Äúclear effect‚Äù on severe depression, helping some people to get back to work after time off, new research suggests.

According to the researchers the majority of the participants were so affected by their depression that they were unable to work at the start of the study.

The individual art therapy took place in psychiatry or primary care and was conducted by a specially trained therapist.

Each session began with a short briefing and a relaxation exercise. After that participants created artwork with crayons and water colours.

‚ÄúThe materials were simple, allowing people to doodle and feel free to express themselves the way they wanted to, and then they would talk about the picture and its significance,‚Äù Christina Blomdahl, PhD at the institute of health and care sciences and licensed occupational therapist and art therapist, explained.

After 10 hour-long treatment sessions the patients had improved on an average of almost five steps on a rating scale used for depression.

Blomdah said this represents a large leap that entails a ‚Äúconsiderable‚Äù change to everyday life, and sometimes it may also mean that a patient is able to return to work.

Anxiety, sleep, ability to take initiative and emotional involvement are some of the factors that are assessed. In the control group that had not undergone art therapy there was no definite change.

‚ÄúThe conclusion is that it was the art therapy that facilitated their improvement,‚Äù Blomdah said.

‚ÄúPainting pictures based on themes and discussing the pictures with the therapist promotes self-reflection and brain stimulation that takes place outside of the conscious mind.‚Äù

Although Blomdahl‚Äôs study was based on adults, Mary¬≠-Rose Brady, director of operations at the British Association of Art Therapists, previously told HuffPost UK art therapy can be particulalry useful for children struggling with mental ill health.

‚ÄúWe know that children who can‚Äôt understand or name their feelings are more likely to ‚Äòact them out‚Äô, so art therapy can provide relief to a child whose only previous option was to dissolve into tears or have an angry outburst in response to overwhelming feelings,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúArt materials enable children to externalise troubling or confusing emotions, giving them form and enabling them to make links between thoughts, feelings and behaviours, perhaps for the first time.‚Äù

Debbie Thwaites, founder of art therapy charity Shine Again, explained how this works.

‚ÄúOne young boy I saw just wanted to paint poo,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt able to say ‚Äòthis person is making me feel like poo‚Äô, but he was able to get all the brown and black colours out, make a big mess and say ‚Äòthat‚Äôs what I feel like‚Äô.‚Äù

Based on the recent findings, Blomdahl hopes that art therapy will be used more extensively in healthcare.

‚ÄúBased on evidence requirements it has been more or less scrapped by psychiatry, but this is one of the largest studies that has been conducted in this area,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúIt is a step that may lead to more people being trained in it and the method being used again.‚Äù
TITLE: Art Therapy Has 'Clear Effect' On Severe Depression, Research Finds

SUMMARY:
A team of scientists have created a virtual reality tour that allows users to ‚Äòteleport‚Äô themselves into the Grand Pyramid of Giza and explore its architecture.
Using 3D technology, the Scan Pyramids Project allows visitors wearing headsets to take a guided tour inside the Grand Gallery, the Queen‚Äôs Chamber and other ancient rooms not normally accessible to the public, without leaving Paris.
‚ÄúThanks to this technique, we make it possible to teleport ourselves to Egypt, inside the pyramid, as a group and with a guide,‚Äù said Mehdi Tayoubi, co-director of Scan Pyramids, which last week announced the discovery of a mysterious void inside the depths of the Pyramid.
Scan Pyramids/ Reuters The mystery void is visible on the tour - seen here as a dotted cloudThe void itself is visible on the tour, appearing like a dotted cloud.
As they approach the pyramid from the outside, the tour even includes audio of Cairo‚Äôs deafening and ever-present traffic.
TEXT:
A team of scientists have created a virtual reality tour that allows users to ‚Äòteleport‚Äô themselves into the Grand Pyramid of Giza and explore its architecture. Using 3D technology, the Scan Pyramids Project allows visitors wearing headsets to take a guided tour inside the Grand Gallery, the Queen‚Äôs Chamber and other ancient rooms not normally accessible to the public, without leaving Paris. ‚ÄúThanks to this technique, we make it possible to teleport ourselves to Egypt, inside the pyramid, as a group and with a guide,‚Äù said Mehdi Tayoubi, co-director of Scan Pyramids, which last week announced the discovery of a mysterious void inside the depths of the Pyramid.

Scan Pyramids/ Reuters The mystery void is visible on the tour - seen here as a dotted cloud

The void itself is visible on the tour, appearing like a dotted cloud. ‚ÄúWhat is new in the world of virtual reality is that from now on you are not isolated but there are several of us, you‚Äôre in a group, you can take a tour with your family. And you can access places which you usually can‚Äôt in the real pyramid.‚Äù

While partly designed as a fun experience, the ‚Äúcollaborative immersion‚Äù project allows researchers to improve the technologies they used to detect the pyramid void and think about what purpose it may have served.

Scan Pyramids/ Reuters The VR tour allows visitors to tour parts of the pyramids not usually open to the public

The pyramid, built in around 2,500 BC and one of the seven wonders of the ancient world, was a monumental tomb soaring to a height of 479 feet. Until the Eiffel Tower was built in 1889, the Great Pyramid stood as the tallest manmade structure for more than 4,000 years. While there are passage ways into it and chambers in various parts, much of the internal structure had remained a mystery until a team from France‚Äôs HIP Institute used an imaging method based on cosmic rays to gain a view inside. So-called muon particles, which originate from interactions with rays from space and atoms in Earth‚Äôs upper atmosphere, are able to penetrate hundreds of metres through stone before being absorbed. That allows for mapping inside stone structures.

Scan Pyramids/ Reuters 'We make it possible to teleport ourselves to Egypt' - Mehdi Tayoubi, co-director of Scan Pyramids

‚ÄúMuon tomography has really improved a lot due to its use on the pyramid and we think that muography will have other applications in other fields,‚Äù said Tayoubi. ‚ÄúBut we also wanted to innovate and imagine devices to allow the wider public to understand what this pyramid is, understand it from within.‚Äù When looking through their 3D goggles, visitors can see the enormous stones of the pyramid as if they were real, and walk virtually along its corridors, chambers and hidden spaces. As they approach the pyramid from the outside, the tour even includes audio of Cairo‚Äôs deafening and ever-present traffic.
TITLE: Virtual Reality Goggles Can Now 'Teleport' You Into The Pyramid Housing A Mysterious Void

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTNEW DELHI -- India may announce measures next week to help traders and small businesses who say a new nationwide goods and services tax (GST) has increased their tax and administrative burden.
A panel of ministers last month recommended reducing tax rates for small businesses and traders and raising the minimum revenue threshold for companies that need to pay tax, local media reported.
Modi said he expected India's ranking to improve next year when the GST and other reforms were considered.
He added that there were other reforms on which India and the World Bank would need to find common ground.
Modi said along with manufacturing, India was also pushing for faster progress in developing infrastructure and was working to improve the investment climate.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

NEW DELHI -- India may announce measures next week to help traders and small businesses who say a new nationwide goods and services tax (GST) has increased their tax and administrative burden.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi said if there is consensus at the next GST council meeting due over November 9 to November 10, the government would take the necessary steps to help traders and strengthen the country's economy.

A panel of ministers last month recommended reducing tax rates for small businesses and traders and raising the minimum revenue threshold for companies that need to pay tax, local media reported.

The launch in July of the long-awaited GST, which transformed India's 29 states into a single customs union, has left thousands of small and medium-sized firms at the bottom of the supply chain short of working capital.

Modi is facing criticism for the disruption to the economy caused by the roll-out of GST and the shock removal of higher-value bills from circulation last year. As a result of these issues India's economy is expected to grow at its slowest pace in four years this fiscal year, a Reuters poll found.

Modi's comments came days after India jumped about 30 places to 100th on the World Bank's "Ease of Doing Business" rankings, reflecting reforms in accessing credit, power supply and the protection of minority investors.

Modi said he expected India's ranking to improve next year when the GST and other reforms were considered.

"There are many other reforms that have already happened but need gestation and stabilization time before they are taken into account by the World Bank," Modi said.

He added that there were other reforms on which India and the World Bank would need to find common ground.

Modi said along with manufacturing, India was also pushing for faster progress in developing infrastructure and was working to improve the investment climate.
TITLE: Centre May Announce Tax Relief For Traders Affected By GST

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTOn the eve of the first anniversary of demonetisation, Union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad today claimed that flesh trade and trafficking of women had reduced substantially in the country due to the move.
"Flesh trade has nosedived in India.
"Due to the flesh trade, a huge amount of cash used to flow to Nepal and Bangladesh...Notes of Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 (now junked) were used to make payments in the flesh trade, which has now come down," he said.
Earlier in the day, former prime minister Manmohan Singh, speaking in poll-bound Gujarat, had claimed that the note ban exercise was a failure.
"None of its (note ban) objectives was achieved," he had said during an interactive session with businessmen and traders on the current state of the economy.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

On the eve of the first anniversary of demonetisation, Union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad today claimed that flesh trade and trafficking of women had reduced substantially in the country due to the move.

He also claimed that the economic move brought down the number of stone-pelting incidents in Kashmir and put a check on Naxal activities.

"Flesh trade has nosedived in India. Trafficking of women and girls has gone down considerably," the law minister told reporters here while listing the "achievements of demonetisation", a day before the Congress-led opposition's proposed "Black Day" protest.

"Due to the flesh trade, a huge amount of cash used to flow to Nepal and Bangladesh...Notes of Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 (now junked) were used to make payments in the flesh trade, which has now come down," he said.

Prasad claimed that the note ban reduced the number of stone-pelting incidents in Kashmir, put a check on Naxal activities, increased the provident fund (PF) and insurance cover of the employees immensely and gave a huge push to digital transactions.

"I have the data," he added.

Earlier in the day, former prime minister Manmohan Singh, speaking in poll-bound Gujarat, had claimed that the note ban exercise was a failure.

"None of its (note ban) objectives was achieved," he had said during an interactive session with businessmen and traders on the current state of the economy.
TITLE: Demonetisation Has Brought Down Flesh Trade In India, Says Union Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad

SUMMARY:
Il giornalista √® stato operato questa mattina d'urgenza e "ha il setto nasale rotto e una prognosi di 30 giorni", come ha reso noto la Rai.
Dopo aver risposto a diverse domande, improvvisamente Spada ha dato una violentissima testata a Piervincenzi e l'ha rincorso, picchiandolo con un bastone.
La replica di Spada in un post su Facebook denunciando l'insistenza del cronista per un'ora e mezza, malgrado il suo rifiuto di voler rilasciare interviste, al punto di spaventare suo figlio: "Voi che avreste fatto???
Vicinanza a Piervincenzi arriva anche da Luigi Di Maio, che aggiunge "questi episodi sono intollerabili e da condannare con fermezza da parte di tutti i cittadini.
Un abbraccio in particolare a Daniele che ha ricevuto una prognosi di 30 giorni".
TEXT:
Ieri pomeriggio due inviati di "Nemo - Nessuno Escluso", il giornalista Daniele Piervincenzi e il film maker Edoardo Anselmi, sono stati violentemente aggrediti a Ostia da Roberto Spada, membro della famiglia Spada, nota alle cronache per diverse inchieste giudiziarie, e da un suo sodale. Piervincenzi, con un passato da rugbista, era a Ostia per chiedere conto a Roberto Spada del suo endorsement a Luca Marsella, candidato di CasaPound con era stato immortalato in una foto.

Il giornalista √® stato operato questa mattina d'urgenza e "ha il setto nasale rotto e una prognosi di 30 giorni", come ha reso noto la Rai. Il servizio che mostra l'aggressione andr√† in onda domani a Nemo, su Rai2 alle 21.20. Nel video pubblicato dalla pagina Facebook della trasmissione, si vede l'inviato colpito da una testata:

"Per realizzare un servizio sul voto nel municipio di Ostia - spiega in una nota la Rai, che ha diffuso anche il video dell'aggressione - Piervincenzi √® andato davanti alla palestra gestita da Roberto Spada per chiedergli un commento sul suo sostegno a Casapound, adesione dichiarata sul suo profilo Facebook qualche giorno prima delle elezioni. Dopo aver risposto a diverse domande, improvvisamente Spada ha dato una violentissima testata a Piervincenzi e l'ha rincorso, picchiandolo con un bastone. Poi, insieme a un'altra persona, si √® diretto verso il film maker, sferrando calci e pugni".

La replica di Spada in un post su Facebook denunciando l'insistenza del cronista per un'ora e mezza, malgrado il suo rifiuto di voler rilasciare interviste, al punto di spaventare suo figlio: "Voi che avreste fatto??? Negli ultimi 10 giorni sono venuti almeno 30 giornalisti a scoglionare....la pazienza ha un limite".

Virginia Raggi ha espresso tramite un post su Facebook la sua solidariet√† al giornalista e promette: "Fermeremo criminalit√† e estremismi a Roma". Vicinanza a Piervincenzi arriva anche da Luigi Di Maio, che aggiunge "questi episodi sono intollerabili e da condannare con fermezza da parte di tutti i cittadini. Un abbraccio in particolare a Daniele che ha ricevuto una prognosi di 30 giorni".
TITLE: Roberto Spada, fratello del boss Carmine aggredisce l'inviato Rai Daniele Piervincenzi e gli frattura il setto nasale
