SUMMARY:
Within a month of the election, non-partisan organization She Should Run had heard from 4,500 women interested in running for elected office.
Some of the women who decided to run for office found inspiration in Hillary Clinton‚Äôs candidacy.
You‚Äôre part of a wave of women stepping up to run for office.
Why do you think it‚Äôs important that more women run?
Brianna Wu, 40, R unning for Congress in Massachusetts, District 8Getty/HuffPostCan you describe the moment you decided to run for office?
TEXT:
Laura Moser never had any desire to run for office. Her husband worked in politics, and she considered herself to be a highly ‚Äúinvolved volunteer,‚Äù but beyond that maintained some space from the political sphere.

And then the 2016 presidential election happened.

Moser, 40, was overwhelmed by the election of President Donald J. Trump, and the ensuing pain she saw in her own community on Facebook. The outpouring of grief and mass desire to do something that she saw on social media led Moser to found Daily Action in December 2016, a service that texts daily action items ‚Äï like calling your representatives to talk about gun control or forwarding a reminder to voters in Virginia to get to to the polls ‚Äï to users‚Äô phones. By early May 2017, she had officially announced she would be running for Congress.

Moser‚Äôs story isn‚Äôt unique. Across the nation, women from all over the political spectrum decided to run for elected office in the wake of the 2016 presidential race. Within a month of the election, non-partisan organization She Should Run had heard from 4,500 women interested in running for elected office. By February, that number rose to 13,000. Emily‚Äôs List, a PAC focusing on electing pro-choice Democratic women to office, saw a similar spike in interest.

Some of the women who decided to run for office found inspiration in Hillary Clinton‚Äôs candidacy. Others were simply sick and tired of seeing a legislative body they felt did not represent their identities or interests. Regardless of motivation, the numbers tell a clear story: Women are stepping up and saying they deserve a seat ‚Äï or three or four or five seats ‚Äï at the table.

Below, presented a year since election day, are eight of those women and their stories:

Laura Moser, 40, Running for Congress in Texas, District 7

Courtesy of Laura Moser

Describe the moment you decided to run for office.

People [would say], ‚ÄúOh you‚Äôre such a good activist, you‚Äôre such a good organizer, you should run for something.‚Äù And I was like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs crazy. Why would I ever do that?‚Äù But then I was in Houston for a Planned Parenthood luncheon and it was the biggest Planned Parenthood luncheon in the history of Planned Parenthood‚Ä¶ That was the first time I really thought, maybe I should run. The room was filled with hundreds of pissed off women ‚Äï many of whom are traditionally Republicans, and were just tired of having these sleazy dudes take away our rights. And I just felt this swelling sense of collective indignation and belonging with this group, but I also was like, god, I know all these women. I haven‚Äôt lived here [in Texas] for a while, but these are still my people, these were the people I grew up with. These are the people I learned to be politically engaged with. And it took me another two and a half months to go from there to actually deciding to pack up my life and move across the country. But that was definitely the Oprah ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment.

You‚Äôre part of a wave of women stepping up to run for office. Why do you think it‚Äôs important that more women run?

Every single person I know, me included, has been assaulted and harassed by a man in power many times in our lives. That is the world that we live in. And [I‚Äôm] OK. [I‚Äôve] overcome these hurdles. But the Access Hollywood tape was an absolutely radicalizing moment for me. I was like, this guy‚Äôs running for President? And he‚Äôs the worst man we‚Äôve all met before? And then he won. I thought the election was over then. But then he actually won, being that person. And so I think the value of women and people of color being at the table and in the conversation is that we‚Äôre...bringing new voices to the table.

If we had women in all positions in power, the world would become more adaptable to women and mothers, and families. Because I just think a lot of men are used to the women doing it for them. And guess what? We‚Äôve done a really good job‚Ä¶ [White men have] had their chance. They‚Äôve done some good things over the years, but I‚Äôm done.

Brianna Wu, 40, R unning for Congress in Massachusetts, District 8

Getty/HuffPost

Can you describe the moment you decided to run for office?

I was standing at the Javits Center on election night, 30 feet [from] where we were hoping Hillary Clinton would accept the presidency. I was there with all of the people that worked the election for Hillary, as things started going wrong. It was one of the worst nights of my entire life. I was thrown into a loop for a week or two and realized that I wasn‚Äôt willing to sit it out for the next four years. It was time to stand up and bring my own values to politics.

What have you learned since you decided to run?

I‚Äôm going to be really honest with you. What I‚Äôve learned here in Massachusetts is that the institutions of power are very ready to put a camera in your face when you‚Äôre a woman in danger like I was during GamerGate. But when you‚Äôre talking about taking power for yourself, when you‚Äôre talking about upsetting the status quo, when you‚Äôre talking specifically about replacing a man, even a Democratic man [incumbent Stephen Lynch], what I‚Äôve learned is that the system starts shutting its doors very, very quickly.

A lot of this first year has honestly been realizing that the Democratic Party is not necessarily the friend of women that want to run and push the party toward a stronger position on women‚Äôs rights.

Jennifer Carroll Foy, 36, Ran for House Delegate in Virginia, District 2 (Won!)

Courtesy of Jennifer Caroll Foy

What sparked your interest in running for office?

Like so many people, I woke up on Nov. 9 in disbelief. I went to sleep early the night before, trusting that the American people would never elect someone so intolerant or incompetent. I woke up, heard the news, and knew I had to run. I knew that there must be a response to Trump and the regressive, elitist Republican agenda.

What‚Äôs one of the most important things you‚Äôve learned while running?

Put your head down and get it done. From the moment I started running, people told me, ‚ÄúNo, you can‚Äôt do this.‚Äù They told me that I could not be a mother, an attorney, a wife and a candidate. But I‚Äôve been told ‚ÄúNo‚Äù my whole life. When I was in high school, I watched as Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg announced the Supreme Court‚Äôs decision that Virginia Military Institute ‚Äï one of the top all-male military colleges in the country ‚Äï had to accept women. My male classmates jeered, and I decided I had to go. I enrolled as one of the first women of color to attend VMI. When people told me I couldn‚Äôt win this election, I put my head down, ignored the naysayers, and got to work. We knocked on more doors, called more voters, and put in the time to win. There will be people who tell you that you shouldn‚Äôt run or that you will never win. Tell them, ‚ÄúWatch me!‚Äù

Dr. Mai Khanh Tran, 52, Running for Congress in California, District 39

Courtesy of Dr. Mai Khanh Tran

Can you describe the moment you decided to run for office?

I made the official decision to run for office when Ed Royce voted to repeal and replace the ACA. I just couldn‚Äôt stand by while our representative voted to take away health care coverage from my patients and their families.

We really need to see a change in our community, and we need someone who understands what our community is going through. As a refugee who came to this country as a child, I know the inhumanity of the Trump administration‚Äôs policies that will restrict new immigrants, and we need a leader who will fight tooth and nail against those policies. As a woman that has defeated breast cancer twice, I know how important it is to be an outspoken advocate for women‚Äôs health issues, so that all women have access to reproductive health care and breast cancer screenings.

Can you describe how you felt on election night last year?

I felt like I had been punched in the stomach. The next morning, I didn‚Äôt want to get up. But I did, like all women do. One of the first patients I saw was a child with a brain tumor. His mom is a nail shop worker and she was finally able to get health care coverage because of the ACA. That meant that she would have coverage for her son as their family dealt with such a terrible tragedy. As we sat in the exam room that next morning, we hugged each other and we cried. We were all so scared. But after the crying, we knew that we needed to fight.

Haley Stevens, 34, Running for Congress in Michigan, District 11

Courtesy of Haley Stevens

Why did you decide to run for office?

In many ways where I found myself in 2016 was very similar to where I found myself in 2008, which was coming out of a big election, asking myself what I can do for people, particularly my home community... In 2016, I asked myself that same question coming out of the election, what is going on in Michigan? What is this representation bringing to my hometown? I was working in a Department of Defense-funded advanced manufacturing research lab spending a bunch of time with technology, advanced technology, and looking at technology adoption for the small and midsize manufacturing community... Everyone wants to talk about 21st century job training and skills. Well, I‚Äôve created workforce development programs. I‚Äôve worked at the intersection of industry and government and academia and nonprofit for outcomes. I really saw the confluence of all of those things. Plus the willingness and eagerness to serve and respond to something like I did eight years prior, which is stepping up and putting up my hand to make a difference for people.

I felt the urgency of the time and this groundswell that was taking place in Michigan. So many people, my mom being one of them, who just said, ‚ÄúHey, I was on the floor coming out of this election, but you looking and stepping up in this way, that was giving me hope.‚Äù I was plugging into Democratic Club organizations that were seeing two to three times more participation. I was going into union halls and I was tapping into that groundswell. Not as a candidate, but as somebody who was looking to step up as a voice. My candidacy in many respects began as part of that groundswell and really ballooned into something tremendous.

If you‚Äôre elected, what change do you hope to see as a result?

This is about a new generation of leaders and leadership. We‚Äôre all too familiar with the linkage between congress and the word ‚Äúdysfunction.‚Äù They seem to go hand in hand. That‚Äôs just something we got to stop right now. We need a return to common sense and we need a return to real leadership. In part that is about the collaborative nature and role of this office, as well as the willingness to use the office to make a difference for people. Make a difference for people in terms of solving large challenges that communities have been saddled with. That could be as it pertains to health outcomes, as it pertains to education, and certainly as it pertains to our economy. I really believe in the moral authority of the office to do good.

Eileen Naples, 35, Ran for New York State Senate, District 26 (Lost.)

Courtesy of Eileen Naples

Why did you decide to run for office?

Before Trump, I would have been the kind of person who thought about these problems and didn‚Äôt think I was the person to run. When I was assistant district attorney, my job was prosecuting bullies and abusers in people‚Äôs families. I saw that trait early on with Trump and I was horrified. So many moms and women recognize him as a bully. That an infectious, horrible influence on our kids is being amplified in such a position made me think that the voice of a normal mom needs to be amplified, too. We should be as vocal as we seek to be, as he did. There‚Äôs no point to sit back and watch this unfold anymore, we have to all do it ourselves. If we leave it to the system it‚Äôs going to shake out in a way that‚Äôs not good for our kids.

You lost your election earlier this fall. Would you run again?

The Democratic party in each county has to choose a person to run. I have to decide if I‚Äôm going to run again in the primary next year. I‚Äôll certainly be exploring other ways to get involved. My big question is: How do you take all this enthusiasm ‚Äï within a city like New York, it‚Äôs like a fiefdom ‚Äï and make real change? To me, it‚Äôs about informing people about the real paths to influence local leaders.

Jess Phoenix, 35, Running for Congress in California, District 25

Courtesy of Jess Phoenix

What sparked your interest in running for office?

I am running for Congress because I think some of the biggest threats that we have coming down the pipeline are completely being ignored by our current representation in government. For example, climate change is going to impact our national security, our jobs, our health, and even our food security. I believe we need a scientific approach to solving problems like this because they‚Äôre big picture problems that affect everyone. We need leaders who know how to look at a ton of evidence and data to draw conclusions and outline a plan of action. That is something that my work as a scientist has prepared me pretty uniquely to do.

The moment that I decided to run, I had just given a lecture at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles. A friend with two young boys approached me, and expressed that he was very concerned about the future world his kids would inherit. I realized that science is missing from government, and if not me, who would be the scientist to run and change our future?

Can you describe how you felt on election night last year?

Election night 2016 was surreal for me. I was working the polls here in L.A. County, and my fellow poll workers and I started out the day in fantastic spirits. As early evening began, we started to see news updates come through on our phones. Throughout the day, turnout had seemed low to us, but we figured that people would come after work. Every report of Trump‚Äôs electoral victories felt like a lie. Our jokes disappeared, and we all started focusing inward, looking at our phones and grimacing. From 7pm until the polls closed at 8pm, we didn‚Äôt have a single voter come in. That was the biggest clue that something was seriously, seriously wrong with our democracy. My husband Carlos had been canvassing for Hillary in Arizona, and instead of staying there for a victory party he decided to drive back home in the middle of the night. I waited up for him, and we talked until the early hours of the next morning about how impossible and unreal the results seemed.

Zahra Suratwala, 39, Running for Illinois‚Äô DuPage County Board, District 1

Courtesy of Maha Studios

What sparked your interest in running for office?

The idea to run began as just a fleeting thought, but the more I saw how desperately people around the country were fighting for unity, the more that idea grew. I definitively knew I wanted to run when I casually mentioned to my mother, a physician who was one of the only women in her medical school in India over 50 years ago, ‚ÄúI think I would make a great candidate. I could run.‚Äù And my mother answered, ‚ÄúYou would be incredible. And you absolutely should run.‚Äù Knowing how much I value my mother‚Äôs earned wisdom, and considering what the example of my running might do for my own daughter‚Äôs ability to dream big, I decided to go for it.

What's the most surprising thing you've found in running?

I am pleasantly surprised that so many people are willing to give me their time as I start my campaign. They want to be a part of something tangible, something that is concretely, measurably, creating change. I am surprised that as much as I am thanking people for their support, they are thanking me back... For the opportunity to work towards something together. This gives me the strength to keep going, to keep trying.
TITLE: Trump's Election Inspired An Army Of Women To Run For Office. Meet 8 Of Them.

SUMMARY:
Vor einem Jahr wurde Donald Trump zum US-Pr√§sidenten gew√§hltDer Religionswissenschaftler Reza Aslan hat nun eine ebenso ungew√∂hnliche wie √ºberzeugende Erkl√§rung: Trump handelte wie eine Sektenf√ºhrerUS-Pr√§sident Donald Trump.
Zudem steht der Vorwurf der L√ºge jeden Tag aufs Neue im Raum und auch die Russland-Aff√§re h√§ngt wie ein Damoklesschwert √ºber Trumps Pr√§sidentschaft.
Wohlgemerkt: Aslan verwendet das Wort mit einer negativen Konnotation, bei der eine engstirnige soziale Gruppe sich einem "charismatischen F√ºhrer" in extremster Weise hingibt.
Der US-Pr√§sident attackiert in regelm√§√üigen Abst√§nden unliebsame und kritische Medienh√§user, bezichtigt sie der Verbreitung von "Fake News".
Oktober 2017Journalisten sind f√ºr Trump "L√ºgner" und "kranke Leute", die "uns unsere Geschichte und unser Erbe wegnehmen wollen".
TEXT:
Wie konnte das nur passieren?

Vor einem Jahr wurde Donald Trump zum US-Pr√§sidenten gew√§hlt

Der Religionswissenschaftler Reza Aslan hat nun eine ebenso ungew√∂hnliche wie √ºberzeugende Erkl√§rung: Trump handelte wie eine Sektenf√ºhrer

US-Pr√§sident Donald Trump. Am 7. November 2016 hielten das die meisten Experten und US-B√ºrger f√ºr ausgeschlossen. Einen Tag sp√§ter wurden sie eines Besseren belehrt.

Trumps Beliebtheitswerte sind seitdem auf ein historisch niedriges Niveau abgest√ºrzt, seine Politik wirkt nicht selten chaotisch, er selbst scheint oft politisch umherzuirren. Zudem steht der Vorwurf der L√ºge jeden Tag aufs Neue im Raum und auch die Russland-Aff√§re h√§ngt wie ein Damoklesschwert √ºber Trumps Pr√§sidentschaft.

Doch egal was Trump sagt, tweetet oder tut. Die Anh√§nger des Republikaners scheinen in einer anderen Welt zu leben. Was andere als Makel sehen, sehen sie beim 74-J√§hrigen als St√§rke. Er ist der Deal-Maker, seine Unberechenbarkeit gilt als sein gr√∂√ütes Ass. Trump sitzt bei seinen Fans ganz fest auf seinem Thron.

Der bekannte iranisch-amerikanische Religionswissenschaftler Reza Aslan hat f√ºr diese paradoxe Sicht eine ungew√∂hnliche wie √ºberzeugende Erkl√§rung: Trump ist der Guru, seine Anh√§nger Teil einer Sekte, die ihm schon zum Wahlsieg verhalf.

Wahlkampf wie ein Massengottesdienst

In einem Artikel f√ºr die "Los Angeles Times" begr√ºndet Aslan seine Behauptung:

"W√§hrend des Wahlkampfes und danach in pers√∂nlichen Auftritten nutzte Trump die Art von emotionaler Intensit√§t zu seinen Anh√§ngern, die eher typisch f√ºr einen religi√∂sen Massengottesdienst, als f√ºr eine politische Versammlung ist."

So habe es bei Trump ebenso "ritualisierte Ges√§nge" gegeben. Dazu z√§hlt der US-Forscher die fortw√§hrenden gegen die demokratische Rivalin Hillary Clinton gerichteten Sprechch√∂re "Lock her up!" ("Sperrt sie weg!").

Ausgewachsener Trump-Kult

Angesichts der wenig schmeichelhaften Bilanz und etlicher nicht eingel√∂ster Wahlversprechen ein Jahr nach der Wahl ist f√ºr Aslan klar: "Der Eifer einiger seiner Anh√§nger scheint immer mehr einem ausgewachsenen Kult zu √§hneln."

Wohlgemerkt: Aslan verwendet das Wort mit einer negativen Konnotation, bei der eine engstirnige soziale Gruppe sich einem "charismatischen F√ºhrer" in extremster Weise hingibt.

Denn Trump-Anh√§nger weisen einige gemeinsame Merkmale mit religi√∂sen Hardlinern auf:

‚ñ∫ Die Gruppe bildet sich um eine Person, der ein prophetischer und fast g√∂ttlicher Status zugeschrieben wird. "Trump war spektakul√§r erfolgreich seine Unterst√ºtzer dazu zu bewegen, seinen Liebkosungen und nicht ihren eigenen Augen zu glauben", schreibt Aslan.

Auch einige f√ºhrende christliche Unterst√ºtzer wiesen Trump besondere F√§higkeiten zu. So soll er im direkten Kontakt mit Gott stehen.

‚ñ∫ Des Weiteren n√§hren sich die Kompetenzen eines Sektenf√ºhrers davon, dass er sich als einzig wahre Informationsquelle geriert. Aslan bemerkt mit Blick auf Trump: Konkurrierende Ideen und Fakten werden nicht nur als falsch dargestellt, "sie sind d√§monisch".

Der US-Pr√§sident attackiert in regelm√§√üigen Abst√§nden unliebsame und kritische Medienh√§user, bezichtigt sie der Verbreitung von "Fake News".

With all of the Fake News coming out of NBC and the Networks, at what point is it appropriate to challenge their License? Bad for country! ‚Äî Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) 11. Oktober 2017

Journalisten sind f√ºr Trump "L√ºgner" und "kranke Leute", die "uns unsere Geschichte und unser Erbe wegnehmen wollen".

Eine gemeinsame Umfrage der US-HuffPost und des Umfrageinstitutes YouGov-Umfrage zeigte, dass auch Trumps Anh√§nger √§hnlich denken: 60 Prozent bezeichneten die Medien als "Feind".

Nur Trump k√∂nne das Land retten

‚ñ∫ Zugleich scheint den Trump-Anh√§ngern egal, welche Beschuldigungen ihn treffen. Anders als beim Missbrauchsskandal um Hollywood-Produzent Harvey Weinstein, halten mehr als die H√§lfte der Unterst√ºtzer des US-Pr√§sidenten √§hnliche Vorw√ºrfe gegen Trump f√ºr "nicht glaubhaft".

"Einer der Wege, wie ein Sektenf√ºhrer seine unbestrittene Autorit√§t beh√§lt, ist, eine Belagerungsmentalit√§t unter seinen Anh√§ngern zu schaffen und sich als Gegenpol zu pr√§sentieren", erkl√§rt Aslan.

Denn glaubt man Trump, dann sei die USA ein dahinsichendes Land, in dem Islamisten und Migranten das Gewaltmonopol des Staates l√§ngst √ºbernommen h√§tten. Jeder Gewaltakt, wie j√ºngst in New York, scheint das Weltbild zu best√§tigen. Rassistische Ausf√§lle wie in Charlottesville werden dagegen umgedeutet.

Mantraartig wiederholte Trump deshalb schon w√§hrend des Wahlkampfes: "Ich alleine kann es reparieren."

"Ich k√∂nnte jemanden erschie√üen - und w√ºrde keine W√§hler verlieren"

Aslan zeichnet in seinem Beitrag ein d√ºsteres Bild. "Kultmitglieder neigen dazu zu glauben, dass sie an einer kosmischen Leistung teilnehmen, dass sie an einem Kampf zwischen Gut und B√∂se teilnehmen."

Egal was passiert, es scheint, dass eine fast zwei jahre alte Prophezeiung Trumps Wirklichkeit geworden ist. Der jetzige US-Pr√§sident erkl√§rte im Januar 2016:

"Ich k√∂nnte mitten auf der 5th Avenue (im Zentrum Manhattans) stehen und jemanden erschie√üen - und w√ºrde trotzdem keine W√§hler verlieren."

Das Problem: Wenn der "gute" Trump nicht gewinnt und das L√ºgen- und Phantasiegebilde des Sektenf√ºhres tats√§chlich zusammenbrechen droht, k√∂nnten die Anh√§nger gewaltt√§tig werden.

So erkl√§rte Trump-Berater Roger Stone im August: Jeder Versuch, den Pr√§sidenten aus dem Amt zu entfernen, w√ºrde in "diesem Land in einen Gewaltkrampf, einen Aufstand, enden, wie Sie ihn noch nie gesehen haben".

Das US-Magazin "Newsdesk" ist sich sicher: Bereits Aslans Theorie wird "Zorn provozieren".
TITLE: "Der Sektenf√ºhrer": US-Religionsforscher erkl√§rt, wie Trump Pr√§sident werden konnte - und warum er noch immer regiert

SUMMARY:
(Photo by Praveen Bajpai/Hindustan Times via Getty Images)ADVERTISEMENTIt might be your favourite comfort food when you're sick, but it's not going to become India's national dish.
Following multiple reports that announced the Indian government's intention to designate khichdi as the country's national dish, the union food minister Harsimrat Kaur Badal said it was all "fictitious".
Enough Khichdi cooked up on a fictitious 'National Dish'.
However, news reports soon appeared suggesting that this was part of a decision to make khichdi a national dish.
Instead, it will be reportedly promoted as a "Brand India Food" globally.
TEXT:
BHOPAL, INDIA - OCTOBER 15: 8501 kg 'Khichdi' being cooked in a 12500 litre cauldron to mark completion of 7 years of Sri Sai Baba Handi wale temple at the locality at Awadhpuri , BHEL Area, on October 15, 2014 in Bhopal, India. Khichdi is derived from Sanskrit word Khicca which refers to a dish prepared from rice and pulses. (Photo by Praveen Bajpai/Hindustan Times via Getty Images)

ADVERTISEMENT

It might be your favourite comfort food when you're sick, but it's not going to become India's national dish.

Following multiple reports that announced the Indian government's intention to designate khichdi as the country's national dish, the union food minister Harsimrat Kaur Badal said it was all "fictitious".

Enough Khichdi cooked up on a fictitious 'National Dish'. It has only been put for a record entry in #WorldFoodIndia. ‚Äî Harsimrat Kaur Badal (@HarsimratBadal_) November 1, 2017

She had earlier been quoted as saying, "Khichdi is considered nutritious, healthiest food in India and it is is eaten by poor and rich alike, irrespective of their class. It symbolises India's great culture of unity in diversity. So it has been selected as the brand of Indian food."

Badal had been speaking at an event before the World Food India conference, where celebrity chef Sanjeev Kapoor is expected to cook 800 kilograms of khichdi in an attempt to set a world record. However, news reports soon appeared suggesting that this was part of a decision to make khichdi a national dish.

Instead, it will be reportedly promoted as a "Brand India Food" globally.

Also On HuffPost:
TITLE: No, Khichdi Is Not Being Made The National Dish of India

SUMMARY:
Sull'arresto di De Luca parla anche il candidato dei 5 Stelle in Sicilia, Giancarlo Cancelleri.
"Cateno De Luca dell'Udc √® il primo impresentabile arrestato di Nello Musumeci.
Critico anche il deputato del M5S, Danilo Toninelli che a Radio Cusano Campus afferma: "Mi fa schifo questa cosa.
Mi fa schifo Musumeci che ha detto che non sa chi abbia messo gli impresentabili nelle sue liste.
Mi fa schifo il fatto che non sia stato possibile far sapere attraverso la commissione antimafia il nome degli impresentabili.
TEXT:
Cateno De Luca, il neo deputato regionale eletto in Sicilia nelle fila dell'Udc e arrestato per evasione fiscale a meno di 48 ore dal voto, "era un nome segnalatoci dal candidato Cancelleri, ma anche dalla prefettura e dalla procura competente". A riferirlo √® la presidente della commissione Antimafia, Rosy Bindi, che parla di "fatto gravissimo", aggiungendo: "√à l'ennesima dimostrazione che gli strumenti di cui disponiamo per tutelare l'elettorato attivo e passivo nel nostro Paese sono insufficienti. Non solo per i tempi lasciati a disposizione delle commissioni elettorali per valutare la regolarit√† della situazione giuridica dei candidati, in base alle leggi, e in particolare alla legge Severino. Ma forse esiste anche una contraddizione all'interno della stessa legge per la distinzione tra incandidabilit√† ed ineleggibilit√†".

Per Bindi "√® evidente che chi √® candidabile ma non eleggibile comunque droga il risultato delle elezioni, perch√© il consenso raccolto, anche nel caso in cui la persona di fatto ineleggibile non venisse eletta, interviene ad alterare il risultato". "Questo - ha aggiunto - sono tutti aspetti sui quali la nostra Commissione interviene da tempo e ha gi√† da tempo segnalato. Il legislatore deve intervenire".

Beppe Grillo interviene nella vicenda con un post su Facebook dove scrive: "Non sono passate manco 48 ore e... Taaac: primo arrestato negli eletti di Musumeci!".

Sull'arresto di De Luca parla anche il candidato dei 5 Stelle in Sicilia, Giancarlo Cancelleri. "Cateno De Luca dell'Udc √® il primo impresentabile arrestato di Nello Musumeci. Lo hanno eletto all'assemblea siciliana neppure 48 ore fa: un record storico", scrive su Facebook.

Luigi Di Maio, su Twitter, √® perentorio: "Ora chiedete scusa ai siciliani". Critico anche il deputato del M5S, Danilo Toninelli che a Radio Cusano Campus afferma: "Mi fa schifo questa cosa. Mi fa schifo Musumeci che ha detto che non sa chi abbia messo gli impresentabili nelle sue liste. Una cosa inaccettabile. Mi fa schifo il fatto che non sia stato possibile far sapere attraverso la commissione antimafia il nome degli impresentabili. Mi fa schifo il fatto che la stampa nazionale non abbia mai parlato di impresentabili nonostante noi avessimo fatto un elenco all'interno del quale c'era anche questa persona. Questa Italietta qui non va da nessuna parte. Musumeci si dovrebbe vergognare quando si guarda allo specchio. Lo sapeva perfettamente che ha preso i voti degli impresentabili".

L'Udc, in una nota, parla di "massima diligenza nella formazione delle liste elettorali a tutela del partito e dei cittadini-elettori". "Abbiamo chiesto a tutti i candidati dell'Udc e dei movimenti a esso associati, tra cui anche Sicilia Vera, il certificato del casellario giudiziario e quello dei carichi pendenti a tutela dei cittadini e della onorabilit√† del partito", si legge ancora nella nota.
TITLE: Rosy Bindi: "Cateno De Luca era segnalato, cos√¨ si droga il risultato elettorale"

SUMMARY:
Sur les terrains comme en dehors.
Mais ce mercredi 8 novembre, ceux qui s'int√©ressent √† ce personnage hors norme auront acc√®s √† un nouveau pan de ses pens√©es.
Dans un fac-simil√©, on d√©couvre 90 dessins in√©dits et les petits mots de l'ancien footballeur.

CULTURE - Que se passe-t-il dans la t√™te d'√âric Cantona? "The King" est un myst√®re. Sur les terrains comme en dehors. Mais ce mercredi 8 novembre, ceux qui s'int√©ressent √† ce personnage hors norme auront acc√®s √† un nouveau pan de ses pens√©es.

√âric Cantona publie "Mon carnet". Passionn√© par la peinture et la photographie depuis son plus jeune √¢ge, celui qui est √©galement acteur et producteur s'est r√©cemment mis √† √©crire. Cantona dessine et annote ses id√©es dans de petits carnets en moleskine. Les √©ditions Flammarion les ont √©dit√©s.

Dans un fac-simil√©, on d√©couvre 90 dessins in√©dits et les petits mots de l'ancien footballeur. Le trait est faussement na√Øf, l'√©criture malhabile. Mais derri√®re les bonhommes enfantins, Cantona "observe le monde", ce qu'il voit, ce qu'il entend et ce qui l'amuse, explique-t-il dans sa pr√©face. Pour passer le temps.

Son moleskine contient quelques bons mots, mais il parle aussi d'amour, de mort, de l'absurdit√© de notre soci√©t√©. Et si jamais vous trouvez √ßa trop s√©rieux par moment, quelques dessins de "bites" viendront vous rappeler que... c'est du Canto.

SUMMARY:
On craignait la venue de manifestants et on tenait √† garantir la s√©curit√© des invit√©s en cette soir√©e importante.
√Ä l'ext√©rieur, la pr√©sence d'une trentaine de repr√©sentants de l'escouade anti-√©meute en a √©bahi plus d'un ; √©tait-ce vraiment pour Guy Nantel que toutes ces forces de l'ordre avaient √©t√© mises √† contribution?

Aucune anecdote r√©pr√©hensible n'a √©t√© observ√©e, aucune pancarte et aucun groupe extr√©miste ne sont pass√©s pour troubler la qui√©tude d'avant-repr√©sentation.
D√©j√†, toute l'attention accord√©e √† la blague sur Alice Paquet biaisait notre √©coute et d√©valorisait d'embl√©e le reste du mat√©riel de Nantel.
TEXT:
Les tapis rouges sont souvent courus, mais rarement aura-t-on vu une entr√©e d'artistes aussi attendue que celle qui pr√©c√©dait la premi√®re du nouveau spectacle de Guy Nantel, Nos droits et libert√©s, mardi, au Th√©√¢tre Maisonneuve de la Place des Arts.

Pas qu'on pr√©voyait y rencontrer beaucoup d'artistes ; en fait, Nantel √©corche tellement de coll√®gues humoriste dans son nouveau one man show ‚Äì Guillaume Wagner, Sugar Sammy, Louis-Jos√© Houde et Mike Ward y go√ªtent tous, et pas avec tendresse ‚Äì que ce n'√©tait pas le glamour qui attirait les cam√©ras au rendez-vous mondain. D'ailleurs, la colonie artistique ne s'√©tait pas d√©plac√©e en si grand nombre pour applaudir son confr√®re. Manque d'int√©r√™t, de solidarit√© ou pur hasard? Passons.

Non, c'est plut√¥t la cohue anticip√©e qui g√©n√©rait la curiosit√©. Le Journal de Qu√©bec l'√©crivait mardi matin, Nantel aurait re√ßu des menaces de mort extr√™mement s√©rieuses apr√®s sa premi√®re dans la Vieille Capitale, la semaine derni√®re.

Son allusion √† Alice Paquet dans un de ses num√©ros lui a valu un d√©ferlement de critiques n√©gatives et d'insultes, majoritairement de la part de gens qui n'ont pas encore vu Nos droits et libert√©s. Un homme a √©t√© arr√™t√© par le Service de police de la Ville de Qu√©bec apr√®s avoir prof√©r√© des menaces √† l'endroit de Nantel ; on aurait m√™me retrouv√© des armes dans la r√©sidence de l'individu en question.

Mardi matin, √âric Young, pr√©sident de Groupe Entourage, qui produit Nos droits et libert√©s, annon√ßait dans les pages du Journal de Montr√©al que la s√©curit√© serait accrue √† la Place des Arts pour encadrer la rentr√©e montr√©alaise de son poulain. On craignait la venue de manifestants et on tenait √† garantir la s√©curit√© des invit√©s en cette soir√©e importante. Un communiqu√© a √©galement √©t√© envoy√© aux m√©dias pour indiquer la volont√© de Guy Nantel de se tenir debout devant le tumulte et de n'occulter aucune ligne de son spectacle.

Nos droits et libert√©s, de Guy Nantel Nos droits et libert√©s, de Guy Nantel

1 of 15 Partager cette image:



Anti-√©meute

Tout un d√©ploiement policier s'√©talait effectivement dans le grand hall du Th√©√¢tre Maisonneuve, quelques pas devant la Place DesChamps. Plusieurs agents de s√©curit√©, en veste noire ou jaune, ont patrouill√© au fur et √† mesure que les gens entraient dans la salle. De grandes affiches avertissant d'un contr√¥le de s√©curit√© et d'une possibilit√© de fouille se dressaient non loin de la billetterie.

√Ä l'ext√©rieur, la pr√©sence d'une trentaine de repr√©sentants de l'escouade anti-√©meute en a √©bahi plus d'un ; √©tait-ce vraiment pour Guy Nantel que toutes ces forces de l'ordre avaient √©t√© mises √† contribution? Le journaliste Rapha√´l Gendron-Martin, du Journal de Montr√©al, qui rendait compte de la situation en temps r√©el sur Twitter a finalement r√©v√©l√© que l'anti-√©meute √©tait sur place pour une autre manifestation, qui se tenait √† quelques m√®tres de l√†, et non pour l'√©v√©nement Nantel. Une co√Øncidence √©tonnante, quand m√™me.

Or, tout ce tapage aura au final donn√© lieu √† un tapis rouge un peu plus d√©sordonn√© que d'habitude, mais √† aucun d√©bordement. Aucune anecdote r√©pr√©hensible n'a √©t√© observ√©e, aucune pancarte et aucun groupe extr√©miste ne sont pass√©s pour troubler la qui√©tude d'avant-repr√©sentation. Le producteur, √âric Young, se trouvait apparemment √† l'int√©rieur du Th√©√¢tre Maisonneuve plusieurs minutes avant la lev√©e du rideau et n'a pu r√©pondre aux questions des journalistes, alors que se jouait un segment majeur de son grand rassemblement, un escalier plus bas.

Aujourd'hui, on est en droit de se poser la question : on ne doute pas de la v√©racit√© des propos graves adress√©s √† Guy Nantel, mais sa garde rapproch√©e a-t-elle profit√© de la r√©cente d√©rape publique pour orchestrer une op√©ration marketing? A-t-on exag√©r√© une mise en sc√®ne de s√©curit√© pour mousser le bruit autour de la premi√®re montr√©alaise de Nos droits et libert√©s?

D√©j√†, toute l'attention accord√©e √† la blague sur Alice Paquet biaisait notre √©coute et d√©valorisait d'embl√©e le reste du mat√©riel de Nantel. Mardi, une fois le spectacle commenc√©, les journalistes avaient davantage la t√™te √† √©plucher les r√©seaux sociaux pour effectuer le suivi des mesures de s√©curit√© qu'√† √©couter le contenu du comique sur sc√®ne. Mais, parlez-en en bien, parlez-en en mal... N'est-ce pas?
TITLE: Un tapis rouge sous haute surveillance pour Guy Nantel

La protesta dei lavoratori dell'Ilva, che da tre giorni stanno occupando lo stabilimento di Genova, manda su tutte le furie il presidente di Confindustria, Vincenzo Boccia.
Il presidente di Confindustria invita i sindacati ad avere "il senso del limite, un limite oltre il quale c'√® solo la capacit√† di farsi del male".
Alle parole di Boccia replica la Fiom di Genova: "Boccia si deve vergognare".
Si tratta di un fatto gravissimo del quale dovr√† essere chiesto conto al Presidente che, con questa frase, alza moltissimo il livello della tensione".

TEXT:
La protesta dei lavoratori dell'Ilva, che da tre giorni stanno occupando lo stabilimento di Genova, manda su tutte le furie il presidente di Confindustria, Vincenzo Boccia. Con l'occupazione "si crea solo ansiet√†, il pi√π grande male dell'economia", incalza Boccia, che aggiunge: "Questi sono i peggiori contenuti per chi non ha capacit√† di confronto e crea conflitto e manda a quel paese l'altro per avere un titolo sul giornale. Scusate questa chiarezza ma sono un po' incazzato". Il presidente di Confindustria invita i sindacati ad avere "il senso del limite, un limite oltre il quale c'√® solo la capacit√† di farsi del male".

Alle parole di Boccia replica la Fiom di Genova: "Boccia si deve vergognare". "Il presidente Boccia - sottolinea il sindacato - ha rilasciato alla stampa dichiarazioni circa fantomatici corpi intermedi dello Stato che dovrebbero intervenire nella vicenda Ilva Genova, nei fatti incitando un intervento della polizia. Si tratta di un fatto gravissimo del quale dovr√† essere chiesto conto al Presidente che, con questa frase, alza moltissimo il livello della tensione". "Forse - prosegue la Fiom - il presidente dal caldo dei suoi salotti non si rende conto di cosa vuol dire per degli operai lottare per il proprio futuro e per quello dei propri figli. Inoltre il presidente, ignora o fa finta di non sapere, che l'Accordo di Programma del 2005, unico strumento a garanzia del futuro di Cornigliano, √® stato firmato anche da Confindustria. Le sue scellerate affermazioni screditano la stessa firma di Confindustria sull'Accordo, al quale a questo punto, non si sa che peso dare".

A Genova, intanto, prosegue la protesta degli operai. I lavoratori hanno deciso di marciare fin sotto la sede della Regione Liguria dove incontreranno il presidente Giovanni Toti, che questo pomeriggio insieme al sindaco di Genova Marco Bucci e al presidente dell'autorita portuale Paolo Signorini incontreranno a Roma il ministro dello Sviluppo Economico Carlo Calenda.

Anche Calenda √® contrario all'occupazione dello stabilimento dell'Ilva di Genova. "In quale altro Paese al mondo un investitore che vuole investire in tutto 5 miliardi e 300 milioni di euro sull'acciaio viene accolto in questo modo?", afferma il ministro a un convegno promosso da Confindustria. Calenda punta il dito contro l'occupazione, il ricorso presentato dal sindaco di Taranto e dal presidente della Puglia "contro il piano ambientale che risolve i problemi dell'ambiente di Taranto", simbolo di "un populismo istituzionale e talvolta sindacale". Poi, domanda: questo accade perch√® in Italia "permane una forte cultura antindustriale, su cui penso vada aperto un confronto serio?".
TITLE: "Sono un po' inc..., sull'Ilva i sindacati dovrebbero avere il senso del limite". La Fiom: "Si deve vergognare"

JUSTICE - Une "mauvaise journ√©e" de plus pour Jul. Le rappeur marseillais a √©t√© condamn√© mardi 7 novembre √† 5000 euros d'amende par le tribunal correctionnel de Marseille, pour une vir√©e √† plus de 160 km/h sous l'emprise du cannabis, sur une autoroute pr√®s de la cit√© phoc√©enne.

Le rappeur le plus √©cout√© de l'ann√©e 2016, qui a accept√© de compara√Ætre dans le cadre d'une proc√©dure de plaider-coupable, a reconnu sa culpabilit√©. Le tribunal a ensuite homologu√©, en audience publique, la peine de 5000 euros d'amende et six mois de suspension du permis de conduire.

L'artiste de 27 ans, Julien Marie de son vrai nom, "versera sans difficult√©" le montant de l'amende, a soulign√© son avocat Damien Benedetti, en tendant au pr√©sident l'avis d'imposition de Jul, ce "contribuable fort g√©n√©reux avec la ville de Marseille", a-t-il soulign√©. Quant √† la peine de suspension du permis de conduire, "elle ne posera pas de difficult√©", son label ayant mis un chauffeur √† sa disposition.

8 points de permis en moins

Barbe de plusieurs jours, en noir des baskets √† la doudoune, Jul a assur√© au tribunal qu'il ne r√©cidiverait pas apr√®s ce d√©lit routier. Son casier judiciaire portait jusqu'ici trace d'une condamnation √† 4 mois de prison avec sursis en 2011 pour un vol aggrav√©.

Outre la sanction p√©nale, sa vir√©e sur l'autoroute A50 a d√©j√† valu √† Jul la perte de 8 points de permis sur 12, le mettant √† la merci d'une annulation s'il grille un feu rouge, par exemple, l'a sermonn√© le pr√©sident.

Fin octobre, la "mauvaise journ√©e" de Jul, titre d'une chanson de son nouvel album d√©voil√©e juste apr√®s les faits, s'√©tait achev√©e par son interpellation alors qu'il roulait √† "plus de 160 kilom√®tres heure", faisant des appels de phare aux voitures roulant devant lui, parmi lesquelles une voiture de policiers de la Bac, qui l'ont intercept√©.

Un mot d'excuse sur Facebook

Apr√®s sa sortie de garde √† vue, il s'√©tait dit "d√©sol√©" sur Facebook, dans un texte truff√© de fautes d'orthographe.

Son passager avait √©t√© interpell√© avec une arme de poing de 9 mm de calibre, et une petite quantit√© de r√©sine de cannabis.

En mai, Jul avait √©t√© auditionn√© dans le cadre d'une enqu√™te pr√©liminaire pour propos injurieux et atteinte √† la vie priv√©e, apr√®s avoir cit√© nomm√©ment un fonctionnaire de police dans une de ses chansons.

Labour MP Dawn Butler has retracted her demand that an independent investigation be launched into how Welsh Labour handled allegations against Carl Sargeant.
Sargeant was found dead on Tuesday after he was sacked from his post as Welsh communities secretary following what he called ‚Äúshocking and distressing‚Äù allegations about his conduct.

TEXT:
Labour MP Dawn Butler has retracted her demand that an independent investigation be launched into how Welsh Labour handled allegations against Carl Sargeant.

Sargeant was found dead on Tuesday after he was sacked from his post as Welsh communities secretary following what he called ‚Äúshocking and distressing‚Äù allegations about his conduct. It is understood he took his own life.

Butler, the shadow minister for women and equalities, told BBC Radio 5 Live on Wednesday that how the accusations against Sargeant were handled needed ‚Äúto be fully investigated‚Äù.

She said: ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt sound as though everything that should have happened, happened‚Äù.

However following the broadcast she issued a clarification and withdrew her comment.

‚ÄúAfter giving an interview this morning, I have looked further into the process followed in this case,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI am satisfied that the appropriate process was followed, including preserving the anonymity of alleged victims at this stage of the process, and therefore do not feel an investigation is required.‚Äù

Sargeant‚Äôs family have released correspondence indicating that he was facing allegations of ‚Äúunwanted attention, inappropriate touching or groping‚Äù - which he denied.
TITLE: Dawn Butler Retracts Demand For Investigation Into How Labour Handled Carl Sargeant Allegations

TEXT:
Hamed Abdel-Samad bei einer Veranstaltung in Leipzig. (Photo by Marco Prosch/Getty Images) | Marco Prosch via Getty Images

Der Politikwissenschaftler Hamed Abdel-Samad warnt eindringlich vor dem politischen Islam

Dieser w√ºrde die Integration von muslimischen Migranten in Deutschland massiv behindern

Auch die katholische und evangelische Kirche tr√ºgen daran eine Mitschuld

Der √§gyptisch-deutsche Politikwissenschaftler Hamed Abdel-Samad hat vor dem politischen Islam in Deutschland gewarnt. Insbesondere kritisierte er den gr√∂√üten Moscheeverein in Deutschland, die von der T√ºrkei dominierte Ditib.

Auf einer Veranstaltung der ‚ÄúPassauer Neuen Presse‚Äù sagte er am Montagabend, Ditib stehe f√ºr einen Islam, mit dem muslimische Migranten in Deutschland nicht erfolgreich mit einbezogen werden k√∂nnten. Das Ziel dieses politischen Islam sei ‚Äúniemals die Integration der Muslime‚Äú.

Auch wenn sich islamische Organisationen in Deutschland oft als offizielle Repr√§sentanten der hierzulande lebenden Muslime darstellen w√ºrden, habe das nichts mit der Realit√§t zu tun.

Abdel-Samad begr√ºndet das damit, dass nur ein kleiner Teil der f√ºnf Millionen Muslime in Deutschland Mitglieder solcher Verb√§nde sind. F√ºr eine gelungene Integration sei es viel wichtiger auf die einzelnen Individuen einzugehen, als auf politische Gruppierungen.

Oft ge√§u√üerte Kritik

Wenn Abdel-Samad so etwas sagt, erzeugt das immer Aufmerksamkeit in Deutschland. Der Politologe ist f√ºr seine harte Haltung ebenso bekannt wie umstritten.

Neues hat sein Beitrag am Montagabend in der Diskussion denn auch nicht gebracht. Dass die t√ºrkische Regierung √ºber Ditib Einfluss in Deutschland zu nehmen versucht, ist bekannt. Der Glaubensverband steht hierzulande schon l√§nger in der Kritik. Unter anderem werden Imamen von Ditib Spionage f√ºr die t√ºrkische Regierung vorgeworfen.

Gleichwohl h√§lt Abdel-Samad damit eine Diskussion am Laufen, die tats√§chlich gef√ºhrt werden muss. Zuletzt hatte etwa der CDU-Politiker Jens Spahn in harschen Worten angemahnt, die Zusammenarbeit mit den Islamverb√§nden zu √ºberpr√ºfen.

Dabei geht es darum, wie der Islam in Deutschland in der Gesellschaft vertreten werden soll, wer f√ºr Muslime sprechen kann und darf.

Denn klar ist: Muslime sind traditionell weniger hierarchisch organisiert als etwa die Christen.

"Die Kirche macht sich mitschuldig"

Abdel-Samad nahm am Montag auch die Kirchen in die Pflicht. Auch sie setzen seiner Ansicht nach zu stark auf Verb√§nde wie die Ditib.

Er warf Heinrich Bedford-Strohm, dem Landesbischof der evangelischen Kirche in Bayern, Fehler im Umgang mit der Ditib vor.

So habe seine Kirche zur Gedenkfeier nach dem Terroranschlag auf dem Breitscheidplatz in Berlin 2016 einen Imam eingeladen, der zu diesem Zeitpunkt vom Verfassungsschutz beobachtet wurde.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: "Der Islam ist kein Problem, das man l√∂sen muss"

‚ÄúIndem man solche Leute hoff√§hig macht, macht man sich als Kirche mitschuldig‚Äù, so Abdel-Samad. Die Kirche w√ºrde keinerlei Konsequenzen im Umgang mit Ditib folgen lassen, und das obwohl man um ihre problematische Rolle wisse.

Bedford-Strohm argumentierte, man wisse um die Kritik - aber deswegen werde man den Dialog nicht abrei√üen lassen. Denn er sei unabdingbar.

Doch Abdel-Samad wehrt sich gegen solche Kompromisse. Nur mehr Ehrlichkeit mit dem Islam und mit seinen Vertretern in Deutschland k√∂nne zu einer besseren Integration f√ºhren.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: Ist der Islam mit dem Grundgesetz vereinbar? Warum diese Frage Unsinn ist



(mf)
TITLE: Politikwissenschaftler Hamed Abdel-Samad warnt vor politischem Islam in Deutschland

SUMMARY:
After living in Europe for 18 months I was ready to come back to the big old sunburnt country I call home.
Here are 11 things you'll do when you've lived away from Australia for too long:1.
You hesitate before pulling out onto the road because you can't remember if the right side is right or left.
You'll find yourself triple checking which way the traffic goes and scaring the wits out of your passengers.
No matter how long you've been away, nothing feels as good as the sand between your toes on an Australian beach.
TEXT:
"That big hole in the ozone layer has the ability to roast you tomato red within minutes."

After living in Europe for 18 months I was ready to come back to the big old sunburnt country I call home. As a patriotic Aussie, I would proudly tell people my heritage, only to be bombarded with proclamations about how lucky I was and funny things they love about Australians.

What I hadn't counted on was losing my Aussieness as I adopted the characteristics of the people around me, and it wasn't until I landed back on Australian soil that I realised how much I'd changed.

Here are 11 things you'll do when you've lived away from Australia for too long:

1. You hesitate before pulling out onto the road because you can't remember if the right side is right or left.

After mastering driving on the wrong (or I guess I should say right) side of the road and entering roundabouts completely backwards, getting back to the left on Australian roads can be a shock to the system. You'll find yourself triple checking which way the traffic goes and scaring the wits out of your passengers.

2. You nearly choke at the price of food in caf√©sand restaurants.

After buying coffee for as little as ‚Ç¨2 every day, coming home to Oz and paying up to $4.50 hurts your over-caffeinated soul. Paying $15 for brunch absolutely crushes you when you used to be able to get your smashed-avo fix for ‚Ç¨8.

3. Likewise with alcohol.

Gone are the days of the ‚Ç¨12 bottles of J√§germeister. Thanks to the Aussie alcohol tax, your drinking habits are about to become a whole lot more expensive.

4. You're super cautious walking in the bush.

Despite growing up in the country where snakes and lizards were a part of life, after being away for months in a place where the worst thing you could find is a spider, it can be a little daunting to get back to the great outdoors. After talking up how dangerous Aussie wildlife is to your new European pals, you start to believe the bulls**t you have been feeding them and are overly cautious of what's out there.

In Europe this is a stick.

5. You find the buzzing noise of flies literally the most annoying sound you've ever heard.

Imagine a summer without needing a fly swat on hand at all times. European countries lack the droning soundtrack of flies and mosquitoes that our wonderful country Down Under has during the warmer months. The serenity of a fly-free country such as the Netherlands seems like a distant, and quiet, memory.

6. You start picking up local catchphrases.

Even if you turn on the ocker Aussie accent when needed, you will find yourself parroting what your European friends say. "Yeah" becomes "Ja" and a "bogan" can also be known as a "f***in' knacker". This does work in reverse and you will find yourself becoming a professor of the Australian language to your European pals. I've never been more proud than when my workmates started answering questions with "yeah nah yeah".

7. You're appalled at the severely limited free WiFi in cafes.

What is this? You want me to talk to my dining companion? And this NBN rubbish, it moves at a glacial pace compared to the super-fast Internet in the Northern Hemisphere.

8. You go out in the sun for more than 10 minutes and wonder how you got so damn sunburnt.

If there is one thing you don't miss about Australia, it's that big hole in the ozone layer that has the ability to roast you tomato red within minutes. In saying that, you're grateful for the huge range of quality fake tan that is available in Aussie shops -- the European version still leaves you looking like a tandoori chicken.

9. You wince walking outside barefoot.

After being cushioned in winter boots for so long, protected from the frigid Euro winter, your baby-bum-soft feet can't deal with the blistering-hot sand or asphalt. Even wearing shoes inside doesn't feel like total sacrilege anymore.

10. You're offended when the security guard asks for your ID at the pub.

You haven't even looked at your ID for months, beer is like water for Europeans and if you look a smidge over 16 you'll be grand for a pint.

11. You're gobsmacked by the sunset.

While the polluted haze of the Northern Hemisphere made for mysterious and gloomy sunsets, the colourful, clear skies of Australia turn on a show nothing short of spectacular. While European countries have beautiful, old architecture, there is nothing better than Australian nature -- it truly is the most picturesque country in the world.

No matter how long you've been away, nothing feels as good as the sand between your toes on an Australian beach. It may take a while to accustom yourself back to your Aussie self, but once you do you realise that the words of Peter Allen are immortal and why you still call Australia home.
TITLE: Signs You‚Äôve Lived Away From Australia Too Long

SUMMARY:
Papua New Guinea's Supreme Court has rejected a bid by 600 starving refugees and asylum seekers living in Australia's mothballed detention centre on Manus Island to have water and electricity restored to the facility.
Public and international condemnation has mounted since the centre was closed last week, months after it was declared unconstitutional by PNG's Supreme Court.
Lacking medication, sickness and medical emergencies have spread inside the centre.
#Manus pic.twitter.com/eiUdlCxsbx ‚Äî justice Manus (@JusticeManus) November 3, 2017The men inside have dug wells for water and sleep under the stars to keep at bay the muggy and oppressive Manus heat.
The United Nations High Commission for Refugees reports one of the new facilities is unfinished, lacking water or power connections as of Monday.
TEXT:
Papua New Guinea's Supreme Court has rejected a bid by 600 starving refugees and asylum seekers living in Australia's mothballed detention centre on Manus Island to have water and electricity restored to the facility.

The men -- refugees and asylum seekers -- have been barricaded inside the centre for a week and say they are safer inside the shut-down centre than in new, but unsecured, accomodation closer to the Manus capital of Lorengau.

Lawyers for the refugees are expected to appeal the decision as early as Wednesday.

Public and international condemnation has mounted since the centre was closed last week, months after it was declared unconstitutional by PNG's Supreme Court.

Lacking medication, sickness and medical emergencies have spread inside the centre.

"We are heading for many deaths in the coming days and weeks unless urgent action is taken by Australia, Medical advocacy group Doctors 4 Refugees wrote in a letter to Australian MPs on Monday night.

"Action to alleviate these men's situation needs to be taken today to prevent deaths. As a start, they need food and water today."

Some of the men have made appeals to world leaders, with more than 280 refugees reportedly signing a letter pleading to U.S. President Donald Trump, New Zealand Prime Minister Jacind Ardern and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for their help.

BREAKING: #PNG Supreme Court rejects application to restore basic services to the #Manus detention centre ‚Äî ABC News (@abcnews) November 7, 2017

Manus refugees have written to Jacinda Ardern, Trump and Trudeau begging for help and resettlement pic.twitter.com/gRloC2N4zl ‚Äî Josh Butler (@JoshButler) November 6, 2017

Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is adamant the men won't come to Australia and said activists were encouraging the men not to move. New Zealand offered to take 150 of the men but Turnbull rejected the offer on the grounds it would encourage people smugglers.

He blamed "activists" for encouraging the men not to move from the centre.

"I think... is that there are some activists in Australia, including the Greens senator Nick McKim, who are basically encouraging these people not to move," he told the ABC on Tuesday.

PM Turnbull says the NZ option for the men in limbo on #Manus would be marketed by people smugglers as a "backdoor to Australia"@RNBreakfast ‚Äî Karen Barlow (@KJBar) November 6, 2017

On the humanitarian emergency Dutton and Turnbull have created on Manus Island.https://t.co/pNoz4BwmQa ‚Äî Nick McKim (@NickMcKim) November 4, 2017

PNG Immigration Minister Petrus Thomas has urged the men to leave, and has said it isn't just a case of reconnecting the water or electricity.

"The Government takes its obligations towards the treatment and care of all persons transferred to PNG very seriously," he told the Port Moresby based Post Courier.

"It is not incumbent on PNG to deliver services and this remains the responsibility of the service providers but at the new locations where the residents have to move to."

Amnesty international has warned that over the past 10 days refugees reported three medical emergencies.

"In one case, a refugee who has epilepsy, had a fit and was unconscious for several hours," Amnesty said.

"Refugees called to guards to provide medical assistance but there was no response. In another incident, a refugee self-harmed and, while physically stable, he remained in a fragile mental state, supported only by his friends."

Human Rights Watch's Elaine Pearson said the Australian government was acting irresponsibly.

"Moving hundreds of men to a town where refugees have been beaten, stabbed and robbed is incredibly irresponsible," she said in a statement.

Dehydration, Starvation, No Medicine, Disease And Heat

We desperately need water so guys are digging another well right now. #Manus pic.twitter.com/eiUdlCxsbx ‚Äî justice Manus (@JusticeManus) November 3, 2017

The men inside have dug wells for water and sleep under the stars to keep at bay the muggy and oppressive Manus heat.

The water they draw from the well -- using a small plastic bucket and thin rope -- is dirty.

The United Nations High Commission for Refugees reports one of the new facilities is unfinished, lacking water or power connections as of Monday.

I'm on the phone with the men on #Manus what they are describing is absolutely terrifying. ‚Äî Kon Karapanagiotidis (@Kon__K) November 7, 2017

Two women have climbed a crane at Flemington ahead of the Melbourne Cup, protesting refugee policy and Manus



(Via @akaWACA) pic.twitter.com/bzmvPcGMUP ‚Äî Josh Butler (@JoshButler) November 7, 2017

Two other facilities do not have security fences.

One man who accepted the offer to relocate to a new facility returned to Lombrum on Thursday, having walked three hours back on foot, saying he "could not stay in that place".
TITLE: PNG Court Rejects Bid To Restore Water And Power To Detention Centre

TEXT:
In San Francisco steht ein Haus, das auf den ersten Blick wie ein gew√∂hnliches Reihenhaus aussieht

Wer es jedoch betritt, dem wird klar, weshalb es fast 10 Millionen Euro kostet

Wie es von innen aussieht, seht ihr im Video oben

In der Chenery Street in San Francisco steht ein Haus, das auf den ersten Blick wie ein gew√∂hnliches Reihenhaus aussieht. Doch dieser Eindruck t√§uscht - hinter der Fassade des Hauses versteckt sich mehr. Das Haupthaus erstreckt sich auf drei Geb√§udeeinheiten, die an die Stra√üe angrenzen.

Wenn man es betritt, k√∂nnte man meinen, in einer Villa aus einem James Bond-Film zu sein.

Das Haupthaus sieht n√§mlich aus wie ein eindrucksvoller Palast ‚Äì mit Glasdach und einem Swimmingpool im Speisesaal. Im Hauptgeb√§ude sind Buntglasfenster der ehemaligen Kirche Little Sisters of the Poor verbaut.

Das Haus wurde im Jahr 1987 erbaut

Das Glasdach der Villa l√§sst sich zudem zur Seite fahren, damit die Sonnenstrahlen auch ungefiltert in das Innere des Hauses fallen k√∂nnen. Im Hauptgeb√§ude befinden sich f√ºnf Schlafzimmer und genauso viele B√§der. Im Obergeschoss der Villa hat man einen atemberaubenden Blick auf die Skyline von San Francisco.

Die Villa wurde im Jahr 1987 f√ºr den Werbefachmann Robert Pritikin gebaut. Derzeit steht das Anwesen zum Verkauf. Wer es haben m√∂chte, muss aber tief in die Tasche greifen: Das Anwesen kostet elf Millionen Dollar, also umgerechnet knapp zehn Millionen Euro.

TITLE: Es sieht aus wie ein ganz gew√∂hnliches Haus - doch es kostet nicht ohne Grund 10 Millionen Euro

SUMMARY:
To find out everything about calcium, including why we need it and where we can find it, HuffPost Australia spoke to two health experts.
If not enough calcium is absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract, calcium will be taken from the bones.
"Good sources of calcium include dairy foods like milk, yoghurt and cheese, calcium-fortified foods such as soy products, and to a lesser degree some leafy green vegetables, nuts, seeds and fish," Spendlove said.
One cup of calcium-fortified breakfast cereal (40g) contains up to 200mg of calcium -- ¬Ω cup of calcium-fortified orange juice (100ml) contains up to 80mg of calcium; two slices of bread (30g) provides 200mg of calcium.

TEXT:
When we think of calcium, what springs to mind are teeth, bones and cows milk. While calcium is certainly related to these things, the mineral is required for many more processes in our bodies and is found in an array of healthy foods.

To find out everything about calcium, including why we need it and where we can find it, HuffPost Australia spoke to two health experts.

What is calcium and why do we need it?

"Calcium is a mineral and facilitates a number of functions in the body, including bone and tooth formation, muscle contraction and nerve transmission," nutritionist Zoe Bingley-Pullin told HuffPost Australia. "It also regulates heart rhythm and plays a role in electrolyte balance."

Calcium plays a role in:

strengthening bones and teeth

regulating muscle functioning (such as contraction and relaxation)

regulating heart functioning and blood clotting

regulating the transmission of nervous system messages and enzyme functions.

Interestingly, calcium is the most abundant mineral in the human body and is stored in our teeth and bones.

How much calcium do we need per day?

"The amount of calcium we require does change as we age," accredited practising dietitian and performance dietitian Jessica Spendlove told HuffPost Australia.

"Calcium requirements are at their highest for men and women during adolescence when we are developing peak bone mass, and then also later in life when bone mass is naturally declining.

"For women, this is at the onset of menopause (typically in their 50s) and for men this is once they hit their 70s."

What happens when we're calcium deficient?

"Calcium deficiency may cause or be associated with a number of health conditions such as heart palpitations, tooth decay, poor bone mineral density and osteoporosis, muscular cramps, depression and stunted growth," Bingley-Pullin said.

Osteoporosis is quite common in western cultures and often results in bone fractures, Spendlove explained.

"When the body notices there is not enough calcium circulating in the blood, it will use hormones to reduce the amount excreted out by the kidneys in the urine. If not enough calcium is absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract, calcium will be taken from the bones.

"If your dietary intake of calcium is constantly low, your body will eventually remove so much calcium from the skeleton that your bones will become weak and brittle."

Osteoporosis is one of the major causes of morbidity amongst older Australians and New Zealanders, particularly postmenopausal women.

"Calcium intake throughout life is a major factor affecting the incidence of osteoporosis -- however, other factors, notably adequate vitamin D status and exercise, also play a role," Spendlove said.

What foods are high in calcium?

Calcium is found in many foods, including animal and plant-based products.

"Good sources of calcium include dairy foods like milk, yoghurt and cheese, calcium-fortified foods such as soy products, and to a lesser degree some leafy green vegetables, nuts, seeds and fish," Spendlove said.

Good dietary sources of calcium and recommended doses:

Dairy products including milk, yoghurt, cheese and buttermilk -- 300mg equates to roughly 250ml of milk, 200g tub of yoghurt, 250ml of calcium-fortified soy or plant milk, or 40g of cheddar cheese

-- 300mg equates to roughly 250ml of milk, 200g tub of yoghurt, 250ml of calcium-fortified soy or plant milk, or 40g of cheddar cheese Leafy green vegetables including broccoli, collards (cabbage family), bok choy, Chinese cabbage and spinach -- 100mg equates to roughly one cup of cooked spinach, although not all of this may be absorbed (due to the high concentration of oxalate, a compound in spinach that reduces calcium absorption); 45mg equates to roughly one cup of cooked broccoli, but the absorption from broccoli is much higher at around 50‚Äì60 per cent.

Kale, broccoli and cabbage can provide good doses of calcium.

Other notable sources of calcium include:

Soy and tofu

Fish -- sardines and salmon (with bones); half a cup of canned salmon contains 402mg of calcium

Nuts and seeds -- brazil nuts, almonds and sesame seed paste (tahini). Fifteen almonds contain about 40mg of calcium.

Calcium-fortified foods -- including breakfast cereals, fruit juices and bread. One cup of calcium-fortified breakfast cereal (40g) contains up to 200mg of calcium -- ¬Ω cup of calcium-fortified orange juice (100ml) contains up to 80mg of calcium; two slices of bread (30g) provides 200mg of calcium.

Are calcium supplements beneficial?

Before considering a calcium supplement, it's important to check in with a GP to assess your calcium and vitamin D levels by way of bone mineral density scans, blood tests, food diary and/or symptoms.

"It's important to assess vitamin D status as well because vitamin D helps to regulate the absorption of calcium," Bingley-Pullin said.

"It is much better to get calcium from foods (which also provide other nutrients) than from calcium supplements," Spendlove said.

"If you have difficulty eating enough foods rich in calcium, you might need to consider a calcium supplement, especially if you are at risk of developing osteoporosis. It's a good idea to discuss this with your doctor or other registered healthcare professional.

"If you do take calcium supplements, make sure you don't take more than the amount recommended on the bottle. Too much calcium may cause gastrointestinal upsets, such as bloating and constipation."
TITLE: These Are The Best Sources Of Calcium

TEXT:
‚ÄòÍ∞úÏù∏Ï†Å ÌñâÎèô‚ÄôÏùÑ Ïù¥Ïú†Î°ú ÎÖ∏ÎèôÎãπÏóêÏÑú Ìï¥ÏûÑÎêú ÏòÅÍµ≠Ïùò Ïõ®ÏùºÏä§ ÏûêÏπòÏ†ïÎ∂ÄÏùò Ïπº ÏÇ¨Ï†ÑÌä∏(49) ÏßÄÏó≠ÏÇ¨Ìöå¬∑ÏïÑÎèôÎ∂Ä Ïû•Í¥ÄÏù¥ Ïà®ÏßÑ Ï±Ñ Î∞úÍ≤¨ÎêòÏóàÎã§Í≥† Í∞ÄÏ°±Ïù¥ Î∞ùÌòîÎã§.

Ïπº ÏÇ¨Ï†ÑÌä∏Îäî ÏßÄÎÇú Ï£ºÏóê (Í∑∏Ïùò ÌëúÌòÑÏùÑ ÎπåÎ©¥) ‚ÄòÏ∂©Í≤©Ï†ÅÏù¥Î©∞ Í≥†ÌÜµÏä§Îü¨Ïö¥‚Äô ÌòêÏùòÍ∞Ä ÏùºÏñ¥ Ïû•Í¥ÄÏßÅÏóêÏÑú ÏÇ¨ÏûÑÌñàÎã§.

Ï†úÎ†àÎØ∏ ÏΩîÎπà ÎÖ∏ÎèôÎãπ ÎãπÏàòÎäî Í∑∏Ïùò Ï£ΩÏùåÏù¥ ‚ÄúÎÅîÏ∞çÌïòÎ©∞ ÏïÑÏ£º Ï∂©Í≤©Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÜåÏãù‚ÄùÏù¥ÎùºÍ≥† ÎßêÌñàÎã§. Ïπ¥Ïúà Ï°¥Ïä§ Ïõ®ÏùºÏä§ Ï¥ùÎ¶¨Îäî Í∑∏Ïùò Ï£ΩÏùåÏùÄ ÎãπÍ≥º Íµ≠Í∞ÄÏóê ‚ÄúÌÅ∞ ÏÜêÏã§‚ÄùÏù¥Îùº ÎßêÌñàÎã§.

ÏÇ¨Ï†ÑÌä∏Îäî ÏßÄÎÇú Ï£ºÏóê ÎãπÏóêÏÑú Ìï¥ÏûÑÎêòÏóàÏúºÎ©∞, Í∑∏Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú ÌòêÏùòÍ∞Ä ÏàòÏÇ¨ÎêòÎäî Í∞ÄÏö¥Îç∞ Ïõ®ÏùºÏä§ ÏùòÌöåÏóêÏÑúÎèÑ Ï∂îÎ∞©ÎêòÏóàÎã§.

ÏÇ¨Ï†ÑÌä∏Ïóê ÎåÄÌïú ÌòêÏùòÍ∞Ä Ï†úÍ∏∞ÎêòÏûê ÎÖ∏ÎèôÎãπÏùÄ 11Ïõî 3ÏùºÏóê Ìï¥ÏûÑ Ï°∞ÏπòÎ•º ÎÇ¥Î†∏Îã§.

ÏÇ¨Ï†ÑÌä∏Ïùò Í∞ÄÏ°±ÏùÄ 11Ïõî 7ÏùºÏóê ÏÑ±Î™ÖÏùÑ Î∞úÌëúÌïòÏó¨ ‚ÄúÏπºÏùÄ ÏïÑÏ£º ÏÇ¨ÎûëÎ∞õÎäî ÎÇ®Ìé∏, ÏïÑÎ≤ÑÏßÄ, ÏπúÍµ¨ÏòÄÎã§. Í∑∏Îäî Ïö∞Î¶¨ Í∞ÄÏ°±Ïùò ÏùºÎ∂ÄÏùº Îøê ÏïÑÎãàÎùº, Ïö∞Î¶¨Î•º ÌïòÎÇòÎ°ú Î¨∂Ïñ¥Ï£ºÎäî Ï°¥Ïû¨ÏòÄÎã§. Í∑∏Îäî Ïö∞Î¶¨ Í∞ÄÏ°±Ïùò Ï§ëÏã¨Ïù¥ÏóàÎã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Í∑∏Î•º Î¨¥Ï≤ô ÏÇ¨ÎûëÌñàÎã§.‚ÄùÍ≥† Î∞ùÌòîÎã§.

‚ÄúÍ∑∏Îäî ÍµâÏû•Ìûà ÏπúÏ†àÌïòÍ≥† Ïö∞Î¶¨Î•º ÏïÑÎÅºÎäî ÎÇ®Ìé∏, ÏïÑÎ≤ÑÏßÄ, ÏïÑÎì§, ÏπúÍµ¨ÏòÄÎã§. Ïö∞Î¶¨Îäî Ìï† ÎßêÏùÑ ÏûÉÏùÑ Ï†ïÎèÑÎ°ú ÌÅ∞ Ï∂©Í≤©ÏùÑ Î∞õÏïòÏúºÎ©∞, Í∑∏Î•º ÏïåÍ≥† ÏÇ¨ÎûëÌñàÎçò Î™®Îì† ÏÇ¨ÎûåÎì§Ïù¥ Ïö∞Î¶¨ÏôÄ Ìï®Íªò ÎπÑÌÜµÌï¥ Ìï®ÏùÑ ÏïåÍ≥† ÏûàÎã§.‚Äù

ÏÇ¨Ï†ÑÌä∏Îäî 2003ÎÖÑÏóê Ïõ®ÏùºÏä§ ÏùòÌöåÏóê Îì§Ïñ¥ÏôîÎã§. 2009ÎÖÑÎ∂ÄÌÑ∞ Ïû•Í¥Ä Î∞è Ï∞®Í¥ÄÏßÅÏùÑ Í±∞Ï≥§Í≥†, 2016ÎÖÑ 5ÏõîÏóê ÏßÄÏó≠ÏÇ¨Ìöå¬∑ÏïÑÎèôÎ∂Ä Ïû•Í¥ÄÏù¥ ÎêòÏóàÎã§.

ÏßÄÎÇú Ï£ºÏóê Ìï¥ÏûÑÎêú Îí§ ÏÇ¨Ï†ÑÌä∏Îäî Í∞úÏù∏Ï†Å Ï†àÏ∞®Î•º Í±∞Ï≥ê Î™ÖÏòàÎ•º ÌöåÎ≥µÌïòÍ≥† Ïã∂Îã§Í≥† ÎßêÌñàÎã§.

Í∑∏Îäî ‚ÄúÏò§Îäò Ï¥ùÎ¶¨Î•º ÎßåÎÇòÏÑú ÎÇ¥ Í∞úÏù∏ ÌñâÎèôÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÌòêÏùò Ïù¥ÏïºÍ∏∞Î•º Îì§ÏóàÎã§. ÎÇ¥Í≤ê ÎÅîÏ∞çÌïòÎ©∞ Ï∂©Í≤©Ï†ÅÏù∏ ÏÜåÏãùÏù¥ÏóàÎã§. ÎÇòÎäî ÌòêÏùòÏóê ÎåÄÌïú ÏûêÏÑ∏Ìïú ÎÇ¥Ïö©ÏùÄ ÏïÑÏßÅ Îì£ÏßÄ Î™ªÌñàÎã§.‚ÄùÍ≥† ÌïòÎ©∞, ‚ÄúÌòêÏùòÏùò ÏÑ±Í≤©ÏÉÅ‚Äù ÏûêÏã†Ïù¥ ÎÇ¥Í∞ÅÏóêÏÑú ‚ÄúÎ¨ºÎü¨ÎÇòÎäî Í≤É‚ÄùÏù¥ Ï†ÅÏ†àÌïòÍ≤†Îã§Í≥† Ï¥ùÎ¶¨ÏôÄ Ìï©ÏùòÌñàÎã§Í≥† ÎßêÌñàÎã§.

ÎòêÌïú ‚ÄúÎÇòÎäî Î™ÖÏòàÎ•º ÌöåÎ≥µÌïú Îí§ Ï†ïÎ∂ÄÎ°ú ÎèåÏïÑÏò¨ ÎÇ†ÏùÑ Í≥†ÎåÄÌïúÎã§.‚ÄùÍ≥† ÌñàÎã§.

"Mir ist klar, dass wir alleine nicht das Enddatum 2030 f√ºr die Zulassung von fossilen Verbrennungsmotoren durchsetzen werden k√∂nnen", sagte Parteichef Cem √ñzdemir der "Stuttgarter Zeitung".

TEXT:
Die Gr√ºnen haben am Montag bei den Sondierungsgespr√§chen in mehreren Fragen Kompromissbereitschaft signalisiert

Gr√ºnen-Chef √ñzdemir gab eine vormals ausgerufene Koalitionsbedingung auf

Die Gr√ºnen bestehen nicht mehr auf dem Ende des Verbrennungsmotors bis 2030

Es war ein kleiner Kreis, den Kanzlerin Angela Merkel am Montagabend zu sich ins Kanzleramt geladen hatte. Der CSU-Vorsitzende Horst Seehofer, das Gr√ºnen-Spitzenduo Katrin G√∂ring-Eckardt und Cem √ñzdemir sowie FDP-Chef Christian Lindner und FDP-Vize Wolfgang Kubicki kamen zusammen, um die Schwerpunkte der weiteren Sondierunsgespr√§che festzulegen.

"Am Donnerstag, dem 16. November, wollen wir fertig sein mit allem. Und da steht noch viel Arbeit an", erkl√§rte Merkel bei Facebook am Tag des Chef-Treffens.

‚ñ∫ Bei einem zentralen Thema k√∂nnte ein Gro√üteil der Arbeit derweil bereits getan sein. Denn in der Frage um die Zukunft der Automobilindustrie gibt es Ann√§herungen.

"Mir ist klar, dass wir das nicht durchsetzen k√∂nnen"

Die Gr√ºnen kommen den Jamaika-Unterh√§ndlern von Union und FDP im Tauziehen um die Klimapolitik in einen wichtigen Punkt entgegen. Sie beharren nicht l√§nger darauf, bei einer Koalitionsvereinbarung das Ende des Verbrennungsmotors im Jahr 2030 festzuschreiben.

"Mir ist klar, dass wir alleine nicht das Enddatum 2030 f√ºr die Zulassung von fossilen Verbrennungsmotoren durchsetzen werden k√∂nnen", sagte Parteichef Cem √ñzdemir der "Stuttgarter Zeitung". Statt des konkreten Datums f√ºr den Ausstieg verlangt die Umweltpartei nur noch "ein klares Bekenntnis, dass wir alles daf√ºr tun, um die Fahrzeuge der Zukunft - vernetzt, automatisiert und emissionsfrei - zu bekommen".

Noch im August hatte √ñzdemir das Aus des Verbrenners zur Koalitionsbedingung ausgerufen.

‚ñ∫ Probleme sieht √ñzdemir indes weiter beim Thema Asyl: "F√ºr eine bessere Integration m√ºssen wir die Familienzusammenf√ºhrung wieder erm√∂glichen", sagte der Gr√ºnen-Chef in der "Stuttgarter Zeitung".

Hofreiter wei√ü, dass Kompromisse n√∂tig sind

Der schleswig-holsteinische Ministerpr√§sident Daniel G√ºnther (CDU) deutete beim Thema Familiennachzug zuletzt Kompromissbereitschaft an. Dagegen machte CSU-Vize Christian Schmidt in der "Passauer Neuen Presse" klar, dass seine Partei in dieser Frage nicht gespr√§chsbereit sei.

‚ñ∫ √ñzdemirs Parteikollege Anton Hofreiter hatte am Montag nach einer Fraktionssitzung ebenfalls angedeutet, zu Zugest√§ndnissen auf mehreren Gebieten bereit zu sein.

Den Gr√ºnen sei bewusst, dass die FDP ein Ergebnis beim Thema Steuererleichterungen brauche. Die Union brauche etwas "in Richtung Planbarkeit, Steuerbarkeit und Ordnung der Fl√ºchtlingsfrage".

Die Gr√ºnen erwarteten nun auch Kompromisse in Richtung Humanit√§t, legale Fluchtwege, bei der sozialen Gerechtigkeit ‚Äì und beim Klima.

Dass es ausgerechnet beim gr√ºnen Herz-Thema nicht die Brechstange sein muss, wie √ñzdemir jetzt andeutete, macht Hoffnung, dass es mit der Koalition tats√§chlich klappt. Vielleicht sogar noch in diesem Jahr.

Mit Material der dpa.

Anzeige: Zum 30. November k√∂nnt ihr eure Kfz-Versicherung k√ºndigen und eine neue w√§hlen. Die Allianz bietet zu dieser Gelegenheit Neukunden einen einmaligen Willkommens-Rabatt in H√∂he von 50 Euro an. ‚Üí Was eure Kfz-Versicherung kostet, k√∂nnt ihr bei der Allianz innerhalb weniger Minuten berechnen ‚Üí Jetzt kostenlos und unverbindlich direkt bei der Allianz beraten lassen: 0800 7243951 (kostenlos)

SUMMARY:
Odessa, Texas, was the 23rd stop on our Listen to America road trip.
It‚Äôs something different.‚Äù‚Äï Leslie Robles, 18, shift manager‚ÄúOdessa is a great place really.
It was really different from my hometown, but adjusting to it wasn‚Äôt really a problem for me.‚Äù‚Äï Lauren Marenco, 18, student‚ÄúI really like it here.
I think what makes Odessa special is the people here ...
I fell in love with Odessa when I was a kid because I‚Äôve always felt comfortable.‚Äù‚Äï Jacyree Webbs, 19, sales/student
TEXT:
Odessa, Texas, was the 23rd stop on our Listen to America road trip. We spoke to residents about why they‚Äôre there. Here‚Äôs what they had to say:

‚ÄúI decided to come here so I wouldn‚Äôt be that far away from home ... There‚Äôs a big difference from El Paso to Odessa, but I really like it. It‚Äôs something different.‚Äù

‚Äï Leslie Robles, 18, shift manager

‚ÄúOdessa is a great place really. Everyone has their opinions about it. It has its own beauty. It has its own culture. It has its own attraction.‚Äù

‚Äï Scott Windham, 37, sales

‚ÄúPeople are so divided on things and so polarized and that‚Äôs what I try to teach is civil discourse. To get along, listen to the other side, and realize that everybody doesn‚Äôt believe in the same thing that you do. Whether it‚Äôs guns on campus, gun control, religion, politics ...‚Äù

‚Äï Myra Salcedo, 67, university senior lecturer

‚ÄúI like it. It was really different from my hometown, but adjusting to it wasn‚Äôt really a problem for me.‚Äù

‚Äï Lauren Marenco, 18, student

‚ÄúI really like it here. I think what makes Odessa special is the people here ... I would say Odessa is a lot more than what people might think it is.‚Äù

‚Äï Vincent Pierce, 31, music teacher

‚ÄúWhen I first moved here, it was not my ideal place to live, but after being here, you fall in love with the people. They‚Äôre salt of the earth.‚Äù

‚Äï Debi Hays, 60, self-employed

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a first-generation college student ... I actually love it. It reminds of the small community I grew up in. It feels like home for me, even though I‚Äôm six hours away from my family.‚Äù

‚Äï Jefember Villela, 23, student/media coordinator

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs home ... I fell in love with Odessa when I was a kid because I‚Äôve always felt comfortable.‚Äù

‚Äï Jacyree Webbs, 19, sales/student
TITLE: 'It‚Äôs Something Different': Meet The People Of Odessa, Texas

SUMMARY:
A lesbian couple has launched an LGBTQ bridal magazine to offer an alternative to the heteronormative wedding publications.
The launch of the magazine is incredibly timely, with the country holding a same-sex marriage referendum.
Currently same-sex couples can register their relationship as a civil union but this does not carry the same legal status as a marriage.
Nothing over the top, simple and romantic is what we will be going for on the day.‚ÄùSarah Kennedy One of the real-life weddings featured in the magazine.
Some countries have had legal marriages between same-sex couples for nearly 15 years.
TEXT:
A lesbian couple has launched an LGBTQ bridal magazine to offer an alternative to the heteronormative wedding publications. Dancing With Her is the first of its kind, offering real-life stories of couples from around the world and advice to fianc√©es about their upcoming nuptials. Co-founders Tara Baker, 29, and Arlia Hassel, 30, were spurred to launch the print magazine after getting engaged in August this year. The couple, who are from Australia, started looking at wedding magazines, but were left ‚Äúuninspired‚Äù by the lack of diversity and representation in the existing publications. ‚ÄúI guess what most people would call ‚Äòtraditional‚Äô, I would call ‚Äòheteronormative‚Äô,‚Äù Tara told HuffPost UK. SUBSCRIBE AND FOLLOW LIFESTYLE Get top stories and blog posts emailed to me each day. Newsletters may offer personalized content or advertisements.
